DeepSeek’s achievement is to have developed an LLM that AI experts say achieves a performance similar to US rivals OpenAI and Meta but at considerably lower costs.

site_title: India’s economy likely to grow 6.3%-6.8% in 2025/26: government report
summary: India's economy is projected to grow 6.3%-6.8% in the next fiscal year, the slowest in four years, according to a finance ministry report. The current financial year's growth is expected to be 6.4%, the lowest in four years. The report attributes this to rural demand, agricultural production, and a stable macro-economic environment, but also mentions geopolitical and trade uncertainties as headwinds. Economists expect policy changes to boost growth, with a focus on strengthening consumption and local manufacturing.

images.alt_text: National Cadet Corps cadets light candles to pay their respects to India's late former prime minister Manmohan Singh at Hindu College, Singh's alma mater, in Amritsar.
US President Donald Trump discussed plans for a visit to the White House by Narendra Modi, the Hindu nationalist leader with whom he had close ties in his first term as president.
Devendra Fadnavis, chief minister of Maharashtra, says: “My pitch to investors is that there is very good investment climate. We have got huge investments from diverse sectors.”

site_title: Businesses must stay resilient amid challenges in 2025: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong urges businesses in Singapore to remain agile and resilient amid challenges in 2025, citing the uncertainty created by the US administration's trade policies. Despite expected moderate growth in GDP (1-3%) and core inflation (1-2%), Gan emphasizes the need for businesses to seize opportunities in the region, particularly in South-east Asia, where the economy is expected to expand to 60% of the world's GDP by 2030. The government is also working to alleviate regulatory burden and encourage digitalization and workforce transformation.

images.alt_text: Business reorganisation or restructuring continued to be the primary reason for lay-offs in 2024.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects Singapore’s growth momentum to slow over this year, after “outperforming” in the second half of last year.

site_title: Tesla commits to cheaper cars in first half, but results miss targets
summary: Tesla reported a dip in quarterly profit and revenue, missing Wall Street expectations, due to discounts and financing offers. The company aims to roll out cheaper electric vehicle models in the first half of 2025, cutting costs to under $35,000. Tesla also signaled progress on its autonomous driving software and plans for commercial-scale production of a self-driving Cybercab. The company's annual deliveries dropped for the first time last year, and rivals have launched cheaper models to capture market share.

images.alt_text: Tesla will begin deliveries of the new car in March.
The latest Model Y sports a new light bar that stretches across the front end, similar to Tesla’s Cybertruck, while the taillight is also a full-width light bar.
Tesla’s compensation could even exceed 1 billion euros if it monetises its entire long CO2 position.

site_title: SoftBank in talks to invest up to US$25 billion in OpenAI
summary: SoftBank is in talks to invest up to $25 billion in OpenAI, potentially making it the AI startup's largest backer. This would be in addition to the $15 billion SoftBank has committed to Project Stargate, a joint venture with OpenAI to build AI infrastructure. SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son has been in contact with OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman for years, and together they plan to invest $100 billion over four years. The talks come amid questions about the details of Project Stargate and its financing, with some industry players expressing doubt about companies' financial commitments.

site_title: Goldman venture buys US$300 million of warehouses from Blackstone
summary: Goldman Sachs' alternative investment arm has purchased a $300 million portfolio of 21 warehouses from Blackstone, partnering with Dallas-based Dalfen Industrial. The properties total 2.1 million square feet and are 92% leased to tenants, including Amazon and Red Bull. The deal highlights the growing importance of "last-mile" warehouses near population centers, which have become increasingly essential for online shopping. Despite a challenging commercial-property market, logistics facilities have remained resilient, and the value of the assets is expected to increase over time.

images.alt_text: Blackstone has structured its fund so that investors can withdraw as much as 3 per cent of the fund’s net asset value each quarter.
The fund, called G-INFRA, will invest in mid-sized infrastructure deals, secondaries – or buying stakes in infra assets from investors who sell out early – and liquid assets.
Sales of offices remain in the doldrums in Europe, with few larger deals and those put on the market struggling to find buyers.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank keeps base rate unchanged as Fed holds steady
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), left its base rate unchanged at 4.75% on January 30, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady. The HKMA's move is in line with market expectations, but the pace of future rate cuts remains uncertain. The US Federal Reserve chair, Jerome Powell, stated that interest rates will not be cut again until inflation and jobs data indicate it's appropriate. The decision aims to maintain financial market stability and manage interest rate risk in the property market.

images.alt_text: The city’s commercial real estate sector is going through one of its worst slumps in history, with no end in sight.

Home prices in Hong Kong, one of the world’s most unaffordable cities, have tumbled nearly 30 per cent from a 2021 peak, hurt initially by higher mortgage rates, easing demand as many professionals left the territory and a weak market outlook.

site_title: Australians are among the most frustrated in the world over housing: survey
summary: Australians are among the most frustrated in the world with housing, with 75% dissatisfied with affordable housing options in 2024, ranking second only to Turkey in the OECD. Despite satisfaction with healthcare, schools, and public transport, underinvestment in housing and high immigration levels have created a highly expensive market, with housing prices nine times the average income and rent more than doubling over the past two decades.

images.alt_text: the incentives are part of a A$626 million package aimed at hitting the government’s target of building 1.2 million homes in the next five years.
Rents are a key input for quarterly inflation data which is due later this month.
Higher interest rates, a shortage of homes and booming population growth have triggered a housing crisis in parts of Australia.

site_title: Toyota sells 10.8 million vehicles in 2024 to remain world’s top-selling automaker
summary: Toyota sold 10.8 million vehicles in 2024, maintaining its position as the world's top-selling automaker for a fifth consecutive year. Global group unit sales dropped 3.7% due to a decline in Japan sales, largely attributed to governance issues affecting Daihatsu. Despite this, Toyota's parent-only vehicles, including those of Lexus, saw a 1.4% drop in sales. The company's hybrid vehicles drove sales growth in the US, while unit sales in China declined 6.9% due to price competition.

images.alt_text: BYD's display at the Singapore Motorshow 2025. Can also be used as generic photo.
For Toyota, the deal with Interstellar deal is one small step for many companies looking to take advantage of booming demand for spacecrafts able to carry satellites to orbit.
The initial residents of Woven City will be composed mostly of the carmaker’s own employees and their families.

site_title: Import surge seen curbing US economic growth in fourth quarter
summary: The US economy likely slowed in the fourth quarter due to a surge in imports and a strike at Boeing, but strong domestic demand will likely keep the Federal Reserve on a shallow interest rate cut path. Consumer spending maintained a robust pace of growth, driven by solid wage gains in the resilient labor market. The full-year growth is estimated at 2.8%, with the Fed forecasting only two rate cuts this year, down from four previously projected.

images.alt_text: A view of the New York Stock Exchange building. Investors will scrutinise the Fed’s statement and Powell’s press conference for the slightest deviation from previous assessments of policy and the US economy.

The non-partisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates that extending Donald Trump’s tax cuts from the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act would cost more than US$4 trillion over 10 years, while Trump campaign pledges to eliminate taxes on tips, overtime and Social Security benefits could cost another US$1.8 trillion.
US businesses continued to express optimism about future demand, which matched the highest level since May 2022

site_title: Bitcoin consolidates gain after US Fed meeting, Powell commentary
summary: Bitcoin surged 3.5% to a record high of $104,300 after US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on crypto regulation, which suggested banks can serve crypto customers and a greater regulatory apparatus would be "very constructive". Powell's remarks followed a pause in monetary easing, leading traders to react positively. The rally comes despite some speculating that the gains may be due for a breather, with the token up over 50% since President Trump's election victory in November.

images.alt_text: MIAMI, FLORIDA - DECEMBER 16: The robo-crypto bull statue is seen on the campus of the Miami Dade College Wolfson campus on December 16, 2024 in Miami, Florida. Bitcoin surged to a new all-time high, reaching $107,000 in anticipation of an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve later this week.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: IEA comes under pressure from former oil market chief to cut energy transition focus
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) is facing criticism from the Trump administration and the oil industry for shifting its focus towards clean energy policy. The IEA's former oil industry chief, Neil Atkinson, has released a report criticizing the agency's assumptions on global oil output and electric vehicle adoption. The report claims the IEA underestimates growth in emerging economies and overestimates electric vehicle adoption. The IEA has defended its work, saying it welcomes ideas for improvement and that the report's claims are "fundamental misrepresentations".

images.alt_text: The IEA increased its 2025 global oil demand growth forecast to 1.1 million barrels per day (bpd) from 990,000 bpd last month, “largely in Asian countries due to the impact of China’s recent stimulus measures”.

site_title: IBM beats profit estimates as AI shift boosts software performance, shares surge
summary: IBM surpassed fourth-quarter profit estimates, driven by robust demand in its software unit, with revenue growth of at least 5% predicted for fiscal 2025. The company's software segment recorded its biggest revenue jump in five years, fueled by a rush to adopt generative artificial intelligence (AI) technology. IBM's AI Book of Business stood at over $5 billion, and the company made its "Granite" AI models open-source, a move seen as a challenge to rivals such as Microsoft.

images.alt_text: IBM has worked to transform itself from a conventional computer company into one focused on high-growth software and services.
“Granite 3.0” models will be made open-source, similar to other versions in IBM’s Granite family of AI models.
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz delivers a speech during the inauguration of the first IBM Quantum Data Center in Europe, in Ehningen, Germany.

site_title: ECB to cut interest rates, keep door open to further easing
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to cut interest rates on January 30, with a 25 basis point cut to the deposit rate to 2.75%, its lowest since early 2023. The decision is driven by concerns over lacklustre economic growth, despite persistent inflation, which rose to 2.4% in December. The ECB is likely to keep the door open to further policy easing, with some policymakers arguing that the direction of policy remains clear, and that the risk of a trade war with the US could sap weak growth even more.

images.alt_text: Any new duties on EU exports to the world’s biggest economy could hit the already stumbling eurozone hard.
ECB president Christine Lagarde says: "“The direction is very clear. The pace we shall see depends on data, but gradual move is certainly something that comes to mind at the moment.”

site_title: SIA ranked top airline, clinches 28th overall spot in Fortune’s list of world’s most admired firms
summary: Singapore Airlines ranked 28th overall in Fortune magazine's list of the world's most admired firms, topping the airline category. The airline is the only Singapore-based company in the top 50 and ranks second among Asian companies behind Toyota. SIA's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, attributed the recognition to the company's commitment to delivering a world-class travel experience and the dedication of its employees. This is the 23rd time SIA has made the annual list.

images.alt_text: A Singapore Airlines' plane flies over Chaotian Palace in Xiamen, southeastern China’s Fujian province on November 20, 2024. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

site_title: Eurozone government bond yields edge down before central bank policy meeting
summary: Eurozone government bond yields fell 1.5 basis points to 2.56% ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, which is expected to cut rates by 25 basis points and signal further policy easing. US 10-year Treasury yields dropped 3.5 basis points to 4.52%. German 10-year bond yield, the euro area's benchmark, fell to 2.56%. The ECB is likely to keep the door open to further policy easing due to the risk of a trade war with the US.

images.alt_text: A Louis Vuitton luxury store, a unit of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE, on Avenue des Champs Elysees in Paris, France, on Tuesday, Jan. 28, 2025 . Analysts expect LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE sales fell 1.04% in the fourth quarter amid poor demand in China in particular. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

site_title: Deutsche Bank posts weaker-than-expected profit and ditches 2025 cost target
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a weaker-than-expected profit of 106 million euros in the fourth quarter, missing analyst expectations of around 380 million euros. The bank also ditched its 2025 cost target, aiming for a cost-to-income ratio of below 65% instead of less than 62.5%. Despite the disappointing results, executives noted the bank's operational strength, marking its fifth consecutive year in the black. Deutsche plans to buy back 750 million euros in shares and has a series of ambitious profit and cost targets for 2025, which some analysts have questioned.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker walks past Deutsche Bank offices in London, Britain, March 16, 2023. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: China’s big EV push into Europe fizzles out on tariffs, slowdown
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers, including BYD and Xpeng, saw a 3.5% drop in European EV sales in 2024, marking their first annual decline. The drop was attributed to EU tariffs, which increased the cost of importing Chinese EVs by up to 45%. Despite this, BYD continued to expand its presence in Europe, with plans to build a factory in Hungary and a US$1 billion plant in Turkey. Chinese EVs remain an "existential threat" to European carmakers, but the price advantage in emerging markets, such as China, may limit their impact.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of the MINI, BMW, BYD, Denza booths at the Singapore Motorshow 2025 on Jan 9, 2025.

The EU imposed tariffs on China-made EVs at the end of October after an anti-subsidy investigation, including 17 per cent for BYD, 18.8 per cent for Geely and 35.3 per cent for SAIC, on top of the EU’s standard car import duty of 10 per cent.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands misses profit estimates on weakness in Macau business
summary: Las Vegas Sands missed analysts' estimates for fourth-quarter profit due to weak Macau business, with revenue from Macau operations falling 5% to $1.86 billion. The company's adjusted profit was 54 US cents per share, below the expected 58 US cents. Despite this, total revenue was marginally above estimates at $2.9 billion. CEO Robert Goldstein attributed the slowdown to ongoing recovery in Macau, with spend per visitor remaining below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Visitors react in front of the Eiffel Tower attraction, a half-size replica of the Eiffel Tower in Paris, at the Parisian Macao casino resort, operated by Sands China, a unit of Las Vegas Sands, ahead of Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to mark the 25th anniversary of Macau’s handover, in Macau, China, December 18, 2024. site_title: Sensitive DeepSeek data exposed to web, cyber firm says
summary: A New York-based cybersecurity firm, Wiz, discovered over 1 million lines of sensitive data from Chinese AI startup DeepSeek, which was left unsecured on the internet. The data included digital software keys and chat logs, revealing prompts sent to DeepSeek's free AI assistant. The company secured the data within an hour after being alerted, but experts warn that others may have found it. DeepSeek's rapid success has sparked anxiety in the US, as it appears to match OpenAI's capabilities at a lower cost, posing questions about the sustainability of US AI giants' business models.

images.alt_text: DeepSeek’s quick progress has stirred doubts about the lead America has in AI with models that it claims can match or even outperform Western rivals at a fraction of the cost.

DeepSeek’s achievement is to have developed an LLM that AI experts say achieves a performance similar to US rivals OpenAI and Meta but at considerably lower costs.

site_title: Europe: Tech stocks lift Stoxx 600 to record high; US Fed in focus
summary: European stocks reached a record high, with the Stoxx 600 index up 0.5% in its largest one-day jump in over a week, driven by a 2.5% gain in technology stocks. ASML's 5.6% jump after reporting strong fourth-quarter bookings fueled the rally. Investors shifted focus to the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision, with markets awaiting its verdict. The technology sector's strong performance outweighed losses in mining and healthcare stocks.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 dropped as much as 0.8 per cent earlier in the day, tracking a global market sell-off on concerns about AI investment and tech sector valuations, after DeepSeek rolled out a free assistant that it says uses lower-cost chips and less data.

site_title: Alibaba touts new AI model superior to DeepSeek and Meta
summary: Alibaba has released a new AI model, Qwen 2.5 Max, which outperforms Meta's Llama and DeepSeek's V3 model in various tests, according to benchmark scores shared on WeChat. The upgrade is part of Alibaba's efforts to recruit China's AI developers and compete with other cloud service providers like Tencent and Baidu. This move comes as the company slashes pricing to win over users, contributing to a price war with other AI startups in China. Alibaba's AI model also beats OpenAI and Anthropic's models in certain benchmarks.

site_title: LVMH’s subdued sales temper hopes for a rapid luxury rebound
summary: LVMH reported subdued sales in the fourth quarter, tempering hopes for a rapid luxury rebound. The company's sales of fashion and leather goods declined 1% on an organic basis, while overall revenue increased only 1%. The disappointing results were partly due to cautious holiday shoppers, and the situation globally still needs to be confirmed. Despite this, LVMH's Louis Vuitton brand posted double-digit growth so far in 2025, and CEO Bernard Arnault expressed optimism about the year ahead, citing a "gradual recovery" in China and a "booming" US market.

images.alt_text: Bvlgari CEO Jean-Christophe Babin calls 2024's performance "a miracle".
The luxury goods companies, including LVMH and Kering, are hoping US shoppers will come to the rescue after relying on brisk business from Chinese buyers for decades.
LVMH is already facing pressure due to slowing sales.

site_title: Gold little changed after US Fed holds rates steady
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,671.79 per ounce after the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, offering little clarity on the US monetary policy path this year. The decision, made by Chair Jerome Powell, aims to wait for signs of further progress on inflation or labor market weakness before cutting interest rates further. Higher interest rates are expected to dampen gold's appeal as an inflation hedge, and traders are also watching US President Donald Trump's latest tariff threats.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was up 0.2 per cent, making gold expensive for foreign buyers.

site_title: HSBC plans biggest investment banking retrenchment in decades
summary: HSBC is planning its largest investment banking retrenchment in decades, scaling back its M&A and equities businesses in Europe and the Americas to focus on Asia. The bank aims to move to a more competitive, financing-led model, retaining focused M&A and equity capital markets capabilities in Asia and the Middle East. The move follows years of scaling back its worldwide footprint, and analysts praise the decision as a necessary step to boost returns and tighten its focus on higher-growth markets.

images.alt_text: Builders work on a construction site near the headquarters of HSBC Holdings Plc, left, and Barclays Plc, in the Canary Wharf business, financial and shopping district of London, U.K., on Tuesday, April 8, 2014. Barclays settled the first U.K. lawsuit filed over allegations the bank manipulated Libor, weeks before the trial was scheduled to start. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Logan Group says creditors holding 66% debt have agreed to overhaul plan
summary: Logan Group, a Chinese developer, has reached a key milestone in its restructuring plan. Creditors holding 66% of the company's $6.2 billion offshore debt have agreed to support the plan. While other creditors holding 12% of debt have indicated support, their internal approval processes are delayed due to the Chinese New Year holiday. If approved, the plan would surpass the 75% minimum threshold required for execution, bringing the company one step closer to resolving its debt issues. The plan's debt payout cap has been reduced to $787 million.

site_title: Wolfspeed beats Q2 revenue as business transition takes hold
summary: Wolfspeed, a chipmaker, reported a net loss of 95 US cents per share in its second quarter, beating estimates, as it transitions to a more profitable business model. The company closed underperforming facilities and shifted its device business to a silicon carbide fab, capitalizing on growing demand for high-power chips. Revenue rose to US$180.5 million, exceeding estimates. Wolfspeed expects third-quarter revenue to be between US$170 million and US$200 million, with a potential restructuring-related cost of US$72 million.

images.alt_text: Private markets are emerging as a major player in energy-transition investing.

site_title: American Airlines regional jet collides with helicopter near Washington’s Reagan Airport
summary: A mid-air collision occurred on Wednesday night near Reagan Washington National Airport between an American Airlines regional jet and a US Army Black Hawk helicopter. The PSA Airlines regional jet, operated by American Airlines, collided with the helicopter while on approach to the airport. Senator Ted Cruz confirmed fatalities, but the exact number is unknown. The National Transportation Safety Board is gathering information on the incident. This is the first fatal US passenger airplane accident since February 2009.

images.alt_text: Emergency service vehicles stand near the site of the crash after American Eagle flight 5342 collided with a helicopter while approaching Reagan Washington National Airport and crashed in the Potomac River, outside Washington, U.S., January 29, 2025. REUTERS/Carlos Barria

site_title: DeepSeek defies America’s AI supremacy
summary: A Chinese AI startup, DeepSeek, has developed a large language model (LLM) that achieves performance similar to US rivals OpenAI and Meta, but at a significantly lower cost. This breakthrough challenges the US tech valuations, which have been based on an assumption of unassailable AI supremacy. DeepSeek's open-source approach and lower computing power requirements make it a formidable competitor, and its success highlights China's ability to innovate despite export controls and stimulate the development of more efficient AI models.

images.alt_text: The deepseek logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration taken January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Philippine economic growth disappoints in 2024 as risks abound
summary: The Philippine economy grew 5.2% in the fourth quarter, below the government's 5.5% target, resulting in a full-year growth of 5.6%. The slower growth was attributed to natural calamities, including a devastating typhoon season, which damaged crops and disrupted commerce. Despite this, the central bank took advantage of cooling inflation to deliver interest rate cuts. However, rising tariff risks and evolving US policies are making policymakers cautious, with Finance Secretary Ralph Recto warning of fewer rate cuts this year. The central bank will review key rates on February 13.

images.alt_text: Borrowing costs in the Philippines have remained elevated even after a total of 75 basis points in rate cuts from August to December last year.
Price increases averaged 6 per cent in 2023 and 5.8 per cent in 2022 – breaching the target band, driven mainly by supply disruptions.

site_title: Japan’s government interest costs to swell more than 50% in next few years
summary: Japan's government interest costs are expected to surge more than 50% in the next few years, with annual interest payments on government debt reaching 16.1 trillion yen in fiscal 2028, up from 10.5 trillion yen in 2026. The central bank's decision to raise interest rates to 2.5% in 2028 will contribute to the increase in debt-servicing costs. Japan's public debt stands at over twice the size of its economy, the worst in the industrial world, and the government's budget deficit is forecast to increase to 4.5 trillion yen in 2025.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration taken on December 5, 2024 shows new Japanese 10,000 yen notes (currently worth approximately 66 USD), which were released in July 2024, on display in Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
The au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index sank to 48.8 in January from 49.6 in December.
Governor Kazuo Ueda has signalled readiness to raise rates further if broadening wage hikes underpin consumption.

site_title: Just started investing? Here are 4 truths to live by
summary: A beginner investor should accept volatility, build resilience, learn from mistakes, and be patient. Volatility is a natural part of the market, and it can be an opportunity to buy quality businesses at a discount. Investors should complement their knowledge with hands-on experience by investing real money, rather than just reading books. Mistakes are a normal part of the investment process, and it's essential to learn from them. Developing patience and taking a measured approach will help investors build wealth over time, as seen in the example of Warren Buffett's slow and steady approach to investing.

images.alt_text: Every US Fed decision has been closely tracked by news outlets, with investors hanging on every word the central bank utters
The semiconductor industry is cyclical and experienced a tough 2023, with sales dropping by 8.2 per cent to US$526.8 billion. That marked the seventh downturn since 1990.

site_title: Singapore needs to seek out partners, launch initiatives to reel in tech IPOs
summary: Singapore's stock market may see revitalization efforts in Budget 2025, according to market observers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's Review Group is looking into ways to boost the market, and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expected to team up with ecosystem players and set up initiatives to attract tech companies and startups. Regional peers like the Indonesia Stock Exchange have successfully wooed local tech startups, and SGX may follow similar moves to increase its attractiveness as a listing destination. This could lead to more tech IPOs in the country.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

ST20240711_202476060069/pixgeneric/Brian Teo/Generic of SGX Centre 1 on July 11, 2024. Can be used for stories on singapore exchange, finance, singapore stocks, shares, trading, securities, derivatives. ST PHOTO: BRIAN TEO.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as Fed holds steady on interest rates
summary: US stocks retreated on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% at 44,713.52, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declined 0.5% each. The Federal Reserve held steady on interest rates, resisting President Trump's pressure to cut rates. Earnings from tech companies, including Meta and Tesla, will be released later this week, and investors are cautious about the impact of tariffs. Despite this, individual companies such as Starbucks and Trump Media & Technology Group saw gains.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Recently launched Amazon artificial intelligence processors that aim to tackle Nvidia and the chips made by the other hyperscalers such as Microsoft and Google are shown at an Amazon lab in Austin, Texas, U.S., July 19, 2024. REUTERS/Sergio Flores/File Photo

site_title: Meta warns first-quarter revenue will miss Wall Street expectations
summary: Meta Platforms reported fourth-quarter revenue that beat Wall Street expectations, but warned of a possible revenue shortfall in the first quarter, raising concerns about its capital spending on AI initiatives. The company expects total expenses to rise to $114-119 billion in 2025, while CEO Mark Zuckerberg aims to invest up to $65 billion in AI infrastructure. Meta's AI-powered tools are expected to gain scale, but the company's reliance on ad revenue to cover AI costs remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg expects Meta’s AI assistant – available across its services, including Facebook and Instagram – to serve more than one billion people in 2025.
India’s National Company Law Appellate Tribunal on Thursday (Jan 23) ordered a suspension of the data sharing ban while it continues to hear Meta’s challenge to the antitrust ruling.

site_title: Microsoft shares slide as cloud forecast, AI spending disappoint
summary: Microsoft's shares dropped over 5% after the company forecast disappointing growth in its cloud computing business, citing concerns about big spending on artificial intelligence (AI) and growing competition from cheaper AI models from China. Despite beating quarterly sales estimates, investors are seeking clearer results from the hundreds of billions of dollars being spent on AI. Microsoft's Azure unit reported revenue growth of 31% in the quarter, but below expectations, and the company's capital expenditures hit $22.6 billion, above analysts' consensus estimate.

images.alt_text: Microsoft Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The Stargate joint venture and rejiggered partnership with OpenAI also lets Microsoft offload some AI spending onto rivals.

Microsoft said that it still retains the exclusive right to offer OpenAI’s API – technology shorthand for application programming interface, which is the main way that software developers and business customers buy OpenAI’s services.

site_title: European office sales slumped to lowest since 2009 last year, data shows
summary: European office sales dropped to their lowest level since 2009 last year, with 42.4 billion euros worth of office properties sold, a 10% decline from the previous year. The commercial real estate market globally has struggled since the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by higher borrowing costs and changing working patterns. Despite this, the broader commercial property market in Europe showed signs of recovery, with deal volumes for other sectors, such as industrial buildings and hotels, turning positive in 2024. Real estate investors in Europe prioritize residential, industrial, and student accommodation investments this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of 70 St Mary Axe, nicknamed the 'Can of Ham', in London, Britain, October 18, 2024. REUTERS/Hollie Adams/File Photo

site_title: Steadier prices this festive season
summary: Singapore's inflation has cooled, and Chinese New Year prices are reflecting this trend. Producers and retailers are keeping prices stable or slightly raising them to absorb cost increases, rather than passing them on to consumers. This indicates a decrease in inflation pressure.

site_title: Glencore-Indonesia JV eyeing US$1b sustainability-linked loan: sources
summary: Glencore, a commodity trader, is partnering with Indonesia's Chandra Asri Pacific to secure a US$1 billion sustainability-linked loan, according to sources. The loan, arranged by DBS and OCBC, will be used for general corporate purposes and has an average life of 6.3 years. This marks a growing trend in the Asia-Pacific region, where companies are increasingly incorporating environmental, social, and governance-linked elements into their financing to boost decarbonization efforts.

site_title: Asian stocks advance on tech rebound ahead of Fed
summary: Asian stocks advanced on a tech-led rebound ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate decision, with Japanese, Australian, and Indian shares rising. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 rose, driven by Nvidia's 8.9% gain, while investors expect the Fed to hold borrowing costs steady. Earnings from Big Tech companies are also expected to be key, with some analysts predicting a "nothing-burger" from the Fed decision.

images.alt_text: US investor and hedge fund manager Scott Bessent won Senate approval to become the US Treasury Secretary on Jan 27, 2025.

site_title: Thai economy seen growing 3% in 2025, finance ministry says
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3% in 2025, driven by increased tourism, exports, and private consumption. Exports are forecast to rise 4.4% this year, stronger than initially predicted, while private investment and private consumption are expected to grow 2.7% and 3.3% respectively. Tourism is projected to reach 38.5 million foreign visitors, with China accounting for nearly a fifth of arrivals. The government has expressed concerns about Chinese tourists following recent safety questions, but predicts headline inflation at 0.9% this year.

images.alt_text: Japanese tourists (in the center) visit Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn on the eve of Lunar New Year, as the high-profile alleged kidnapping of a Chinese actor and similar crimes stoked worries over tourism and security in Bangkok, Thailand January 28, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

site_title: URA should whet the appetite of developers with a prime CBD office site in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Core Central Business District (CBD) Grade A office market faces a potential shortage due to the completion of IOI Central Boulevard Towers in 2024 and the lack of new significant supply until 2027. This may benefit prime CBD office landlords, but could negatively impact the city-state's competitiveness. Vacancy rates for Category 1 offices are trending down, while Category 2 offices remain elevated. The URA may consider releasing a prime CBD office site on the reserve list to ensure Singapore's competitiveness and provide more choices for future occupiers, potentially mitigating the shortage and supporting office demand.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
URA released the latest data on the Singapore office market on Friday (Jan  24).
ST20231031_202363269627 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of tourists taking pictures along the Merlion Park with the backdrop of Singapore's central business district (CBD) on Oct 31, 2023.

krlease18 - 

Copyright: GOOGLE MAPS

site_title: The Year of the Snake set to be transformative, but guard against surprises
summary: The Year of the Snake, which begins in 2025, is expected to be transformative, with investors needing to be nimble and potentially repositioning portfolios. Global monetary policy is likely to ease as inflation moderates, while the US may require more stimulus. The second Trump presidency is expected to bring significant challenges to the status quo, with investors advised to approach the year with prudence and portfolio diversification. Key themes include resilient economic growth led by the US and potential recovery in China, with gold expected to outperform amid geopolitical uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Chinese startup DeepSeek has rolled out a free assistant it says uses cheaper chips and less data, raising questions about investor expectations that AI will drive demand along a supply chain from chipmakers to data centres.
Non-yielding gold, often seen as a hedge against inflation and political uncertainty, benefits from lower interest rates.

site_title: World’s richest people lose US$108 billion after DeepSeek sell-off
summary: The world's 500 richest people, led by Nvidia co-founder Jensen Huang, lost a combined $108 billion on Monday as a tech-led sell-off tied to Chinese AI developer DeepSeek sent major indices plummeting. Tech billionaires with AI ties, including Huang, Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, and Dell's Michael Dell, were the biggest losers, with their fortunes dropping by $20.1 billion, $22.6 billion, and $13 billion respectively. The sell-off, triggered by DeepSeek's free AI chatbot app, has raised questions about the logic behind Silicon Valley's capital spending on AI development.

images.alt_text: Available as an app or on desktop, DeepSeek can do many of the things that its Western competitors can do - write song lyrics, help work on a personal development plan or even write a recipe for dinner based on what’s in the fridge.
The deepseek logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration.

site_title: Singapore’s reinsurance market gears for growth in bid to be Asian hub
summary: Singapore's reinsurance market is expected to experience substantial growth in 2025, driven by favorable conditions such as a supportive regulatory environment, geographical location, and stability. The country aims to strengthen its standing as a leading reinsurance hub in Asia, with the government seeking to develop a marketplace of insurers and reinsurers. Key factors contributing to the growth include Singapore's stable political environment, well-established financial ecosystem, and focus on green financing and climate risk management. The country is also expected to benefit from increased demand for reinsurance due to climate transition, with 91% of economic losses in the Asia-Pacific region in 2023 being uninsured.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
The Monetary Authority of Singapore is seeking details of insurers' contracts and reinsurers, saying these deals could be audited.

A drone view shows a flooded area following the impact of Typhoon Yagi, in Chiang Rai in the northern province of Thailand, September 13, 2024. REUTERS/Anupong Intawong TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY SEARCH "REUTERS FLOODS 2024" FOR THIS STORY. SEARCH "REUTERS YEAR-END" FOR ALL 2024 YEAR END GALLERIES.

site_title: US Federal Reserve pauses rate cuts, will ‘wait and see’ on Trump policies
summary: The US Federal Reserve has paused its rate cuts, keeping its benchmark lending rate between 4.25% and 4.5%, as policymakers adopt a patient "wait and see" approach to Donald Trump's economic policies. This decision follows three consecutive rate reductions that lowered the key rate by a full percentage point. Chair Jerome Powell stated that the economy remains strong and the policy stance is not in a hurry to adjust.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A woman and a child look at shops in a mall on Black Friday in Arlington, Virginia on November 29, 2024. US consumer inflation ticked up for a second consecutive month in November 2024, driven by food prices and other sectors, according to government data published Wednesday, complicating the Federal Reserve's rate cut deliberations. (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP)

A view of the New York Stock Exchange building. Investors will scrutinise the Fed’s statement and Powell’s press conference for the slightest deviation from previous assessments of policy and the US economy.
Trump has frequently criticised the Fed, which has a dual mandate from Congress to act independently to tackle inflation and unemployment.

The challenge for Fed Chair Jerome Powell and his colleagues will be in determining how much to allow uncertainty over what’s ahead to influence decisions on monetary policy now, and how much guidance to give about the Fed’s outlook.

site_title: Rare China support shows Vanke may be too big to fail
summary: China's state authorities have thrown a lifeline to struggling developer Vanke, providing a rare show of support that may make the company too big to fail. Vanke, which warned of a record 45 billion yuan loss for 2024, has seen its top executives step down and a new chairman take over. The move comes as China's housing slump enters its fourth year, with the government announcing additional stimulus measures to stabilize the market. The support from the local government and its largest state shareholder, Shenzhen Metro Group, aims to protect the rights of homebuyers, creditors, and investors, and is seen as a significant step to halt the housing slump.

images.alt_text: Worries over Vanke’s liquidity have intensified this month as it faces several looming debt maturity deadlines.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 28)
summary: Nvidia suffered a significant market value wipeout of nearly US$600 billion, marking a substantial decline in the company's stock price. The loss is attributed to concerns over the company's ability to compete with emerging technologies such as DeepSeek, a potentially cheaper and more power-efficient alternative. Meanwhile, Singapore's data centre REITs experienced a decline due to the DeepSeek threat, with analysts warning of potential fallout. In other news, corporate venturing in Malaysia gained traction, and a prime CBD office site in Singapore may attract developers, potentially alleviating a potential shortage in the local office market.

images.alt_text: Business reorganisation or restructuring continued to be the primary reason for layoffs in 2024.

site_title: Singapore’s data centre Reits fall on DeepSeek threat; analysts warn of fallout
summary: Singapore's data centre Reits, including Keppel DC Reit, Digicore Reit, and Mapletree Industrial Trust, fell on Monday after Chinese AI firm DeepSeek's rise, threatening the AI ecosystem. Analysts warn of a potential fallout, citing concerns that affordable and accessible hardware solutions could dampen demand for high-quality data centres. DeepSeek's technology, which can be built more cheaply and take up less power, has caused a US$600 billion wipeout in Nvidia's market value, with AI-related beneficiaries vulnerable to profit-taking and short-term corrections.

images.alt_text: Available as an app or on desktop, DeepSeek can do many of the things that its Western competitors can do - write song lyrics, help work on a personal development plan or even write a recipe for dinner based on what’s in the fridge.
The deepseek logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration.

site_title: TikTok bidders to offer ‘significantly’ more than US$20 billion
summary: A group of American investors, including tech entrepreneurs Jesse Tinsley and Roblox co-founder David Baszucki, have secured over $20 billion for their bid to buy TikTok. The offer is "significantly higher" than a rival bid estimated at $25 billion. Tinsley's group, backed by YouTuber MrBeast, claims to have an all-US-backed team and servers, but it's unclear if they will be serious contenders in negotiations with TikTok's Chinese parent company ByteDance. The bid comes as the US government has floated various buyers and proposals to keep TikTok running in the US, amid a broader US-China trade war.

images.alt_text: TikTok Inc. offices in Culver City, California. Photographer: Bing Guan/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil prices settle down as US stockpile grows, tariffs still in focus
summary: Oil prices fell 1.2% to $76.58 a barrel after US crude stockpiles rose by 3.46 million barrels, exceeding expectations. The US benchmark is now at its lowest year-to-date settlement price. Tariff threats, sanctions on Russian energy, and economic growth concerns continue to drive volatility in the oil market. The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, and the Opec+ ministerial meeting on February 3 is expected to focus on increasing supply from April.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield rises to 3.04%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced the latest six-month Treasury bill auction, with a cut-off yield of 3.04% and a total of S$15.3 billion in applications for the S$7.2 billion on offer. Demand fell compared to the previous auction, and the average yield increased to 2.69%. Analysts expect the US Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged, citing market expectations of 44 basis points of cuts. Singapore will issue up to S$450 billion in government securities, with a new limit of S$1.515 trillion set to last until 2029.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

A view of the New York Stock Exchange building. Investors will scrutinise the Fed’s statement and Powell’s press conference for the slightest deviation from previous assessments of policy and the US economy.
Demand falls for latest Singapore Savings Bond with 10-year average return of 2.82%

site_title: Trump officials discuss tighter curbs on Nvidia China sales
summary: US Trump administration officials are exploring stricter controls on Nvidia's sales to China, potentially expanding existing curbs on the company's H20 chips. This comes amid heightened tensions between the US and China over AI technology, following the release of a new AI model by Chinese startup DeepSeek. A decision on any restrictions is expected to be a long way off, given the Trump administration's recent staffing. Tighter controls would further limit Nvidia's revenue in China, where the company has been under restrictions since 2022.

images.alt_text: Nvidia issued a statement on Monday after its shares tumbled 17 per cent on investor concerns that China’s DeepSeek had matched rivals such as OpenAI using far fewer Nvidia chips than US firms.
Nvidia is facing a barrage of new rules and regulations in the final days of the Biden administration.

site_title: Norway US$1.8 trillion fund returns 13% on gains in US tech stocks
summary: Norway's US$1.8 trillion sovereign wealth fund returned 13% last year, driven by a strong US technology sector. The fund's investments in equities gained 18%, missing its benchmark by 45 basis points. CEO Nicolai Tangen attributed the performance to the "very well" performance of American technology stocks. Norway aims to ban the sale of private cars with emissions above zero by 2025, showcasing its commitment to reducing carbon emissions.

site_title: Who is Liang Wenfeng, the geek behind DeepSeek?
summary: Chinese AI startup DeepSeek's app has reached the top of Apple Store's download charts, causing a significant market fluctuation in US tech stocks. Nvidia suffered a nearly $600 billion wipeout in market value, the largest on Wall Street. DeepSeek's alternative AI model is said to be comparable to or outperforming Open AI and Meta's models, and is more cost-effective and power-efficient.

images.alt_text: Nvidia and Deepseek logos are seen in this illustration taken, January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustrationo
Nvidia issued a statement on Monday after its shares tumbled 17 per cent on investor concerns that China’s DeepSeek had matched rivals such as OpenAI using far fewer Nvidia chips than US firms.

DeepSeek has claimed it took just two months and cost under US$6 million to build an AI model using Nvidia’s less-advanced H800 chips. An app powered by the V3 model became the top iPhone download in the US on Monday.

site_title: DeepSeek shows China playbook for even bigger US Shock on chips
summary: China's tech company DeepSeek has developed an innovative AI model without spending as much as US rivals, showcasing the country's key advantages in IT talent, vast domestic market, and government support. Despite US export curbs, China continues to push forward in developing its own cutting-edge chips, with companies like Huawei and ChangXin Memory Technologies making progress. The success of DeepSeek's R1 model highlights China's ability to innovate and challenge world-leading products from US companies like OpenAI and Google. However, the US needs to catch up in producing talented engineers to stay ahead in the tech race, with experts warning of the need for a stronger defense against China's technological advancements.

images.alt_text: ByteDance’s release comes after Chinese AI startup DeepSeek rolled out an open-source reasoning model called DeepSeek-R1 on Monday that it said rivalled OpenAI’s o1 on several performance benchmarks.

site_title: Construction companies need to collaborate and plan better as demand climbs
summary: Construction companies in Singapore face a growing demand for manpower and resources, with the total value of construction contracts expected to reach S$53 billion in 2025, a 20% increase from 2024. To cope with this strain, stakeholders are encouraged to adopt collaborative contracting and better allocate risks and rewards. This includes planning ahead, managing resources effectively, and forging long-term partnerships. Companies risk facing poaching, project delays, and price pressure if they fail to adapt to the changing market, with the BCA urging contractors to differentiate themselves by identifying unique competencies and managing their risk.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The value of construction contracts is expected to range between S$47 billion and S$53 billion in nominal terms in 2025, according to BCA.
A significant rollout of residential projects led to higher than expected demand in 2024.

site_title: China AI firm DeepSeek shocks US tech; Nvidia dives US$589b, biggest one-day loss in US history
summary: China's AI firm DeepSeek has surpassed Western competitors in the US market, shocking industry insiders and analysts. The chatbot's success has led to a significant loss for Nvidia, with a one-day market value drop of nearly $589 billion, the largest in US history. This move has sent shockwaves through the tech industry, highlighting the growing competition between US and Chinese tech firms.

images.alt_text: Nvidia issued a statement on Monday after its shares tumbled 17 per cent on investor concerns that China’s DeepSeek had matched rivals such as OpenAI using far fewer Nvidia chips than US firms.

DeepSeek has claimed it took just two months and cost under US$6 million to build an AI model using Nvidia’s less-advanced H800 chips. An app powered by the V3 model became the top iPhone download in the US on Monday.
Brent futures fell US$1.42, or 1.8 per cent, to settle at US$77.08 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude ended US$1.49, or 2.0 per cent, lower at US$73.17 on Monday.

Chinese startup DeepSeek has rolled out a free assistant it says uses cheaper chips and less data, raising questions about investor expectations that AI will drive demand along a supply chain from chipmakers to data centres.
Lauded by investor Marc Andreessen as “one of the most amazing and impressive breakthroughs”, DeepSeek’s assistant shows its work and reasoning as it addresses a user’s written query or prompt.

site_title: Why AI resources must be distributed
summary: The world is shifting towards a new industrial revolution driven by advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), which will require a robust and sustainable compute power supply. Like Singapore's diversified approach to water management, AI compute must be distributed across various locations and devices to ensure efficiency, security, and sustainability. Key reasons for this include economics, distance, and regulatory requirements. As a result, AI-related compute is expected to move to the "edge" of networks, including edge devices, PCs, and IoT applications, enabling real-time processing and reducing network congestion.

images.alt_text: Companies will have to navigate the intricacies of the semiconductor supply chain, beginning with where components are being sourced.
Microsoft in May announced the new AI-powered personal computers, or “AI PCs”, which will use the company’s software under the Copilot Plus brand.

site_title: US markets: Stock buyers step in to boost tech after AI jolt
summary: US technology stocks rebounded after a selloff sparked by a Chinese AI startup, DeepSeek, raising concerns about America's technological dominance. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 rose 1% and 1.8% respectively, with Nvidia rallying 7.8% and Microsoft's shares up 2% after President Trump mentioned a potential acquisition of TikTok. The market's recovery reduced the search for haven assets, with bonds seeing small losses, ahead of the Federal Reserve rate decision and earnings season.

images.alt_text: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang's fortune fell US$20.1 billion, a 20 per cent drop. Tech-sector titans as a group saw US$94 billion of wealth evaporate.

site_title: Skip the hype, here’s how AI ‘agents’ can really help
summary: AI "agents" are being touted as the next big thing in artificial intelligence, but experts say they won't replace human workers just yet. Instead, agents will specialize in repetitive tasks, such as processing orders and handling routine documents, where the risk of mistakes is low. Companies like Rekki and Humanloop are already using agents to automate tasks, resulting in cost savings for businesses. The key to success lies in keeping tasks narrow and focused, rather than trying to create blank-slate geniuses that can handle multiple tasks.

images.alt_text: The tool, called Operator, is powered by a model that allows it to interact with on-screen buttons, menus and text fields.
The writer expects more companies to announce returns to the office, even as the majority quietly shrink their office footprints or continue to embrace hybrid arrangements.
For much of this year already, AI researchers have been looking at new paths for improving their models that don’t just involve throwing more data and computing power at them.
In an ideal world, Big Tech companies would be more explicit about their endgame. They have a fiduciary duty to their investors after all.

site_title: Indonesia’s full Brics membership unlikely to spur similar move by Asean peers
summary: Indonesia's entry into the Brics bloc has sparked discussions on its potential impact on other Asean nations, but observers believe it is unlikely to trigger a domino effect. The country's move is seen as a strategic choice driven by its own geopolitical identity and ambitions, rather than a collective march towards Brics. Indonesia's largest economy and fourth most populous country has maintained strategic ambiguity towards Brics, with Singapore focusing on Asean as its primary regional strategy. The bloc's diverse membership and differing economic trajectories make it unlikely that other Asean states will follow Indonesia's lead in joining Brics.

Indonesia’s move to join Brics signals  Prabowo’s global ambitions – but risks loom

Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto (left) and his Brazilian counterpart Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Brazil, this year's Brics chair, announced Indonesia's entry as a full member into Brics.

site_title: What is China’s DeepSeek and how is it altering the AI race?
summary: China's DeepSeek, a 1-year-old AI startup, has sparked global interest with its breakthrough AI models that offer comparable performance to top chatbots at a fraction of the cost. The company's mobile app, which articulates its reasoning, has surged to the top of iPhone download charts in the US and globally. DeepSeek's R1 model rivals OpenAI's and Meta AI's best products, with a more efficient design that puts into question the need for vast expenditures on AI hardware. The company's emergence may counter the widespread belief that AI requires increasing power and energy to develop, raising concerns about the impact on US export curbs and the global AI market.

images.alt_text: DeepSeek has claimed it took just two months and cost under US$6 million to build an AI model using Nvidia’s less-advanced H800 chips. An app powered by the V3 model became the top iPhone download in the US on Monday.
Nvidia issued a statement on Monday after its shares tumbled 17 per cent on investor concerns that China’s DeepSeek had matched rivals such as OpenAI using far fewer Nvidia chips than US firms.

Available as an app or on desktop, DeepSeek can do many of the things that its Western competitors can do - write song lyrics, help work on a personal development plan or even write a recipe for dinner based on what’s in the fridge.

site_title: Currency market whiplashed on tariff, DeepSeek concerns
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.08% to 107.89, following a significant drop to its lowest level since mid-December, due to new US tariff threats and concerns over US dominance in artificial intelligence technology. The euro fell 0.54% to $1.0435, while the yen slid back within its recent trading range. Investors are closely watching the Federal Reserve's two-day meeting, which is expected to keep interest rates steady, and the European Central Bank's meeting, which is likely to cut interest rates.

site_title: Australia says be 'very careful' over DeepSeek and privacy
summary: Australia's science minister raised concerns over China's DeepSeek AI chatbot, urging users to be cautious before downloading it due to privacy concerns. Developed by a China-based startup, DeepSeek has surpassed Western competitors, including ChatGPT, and is now leading app download charts. Minister Husic emphasized the need to address quality, consumer preferences, data, and privacy management, indicating that users should think carefully before downloading the chatbot.

images.alt_text: The deepseek logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration taken January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: US stocks, Nvidia shares steady after Chinese AI shock
summary: US stocks and Nvidia shares steadied on Tuesday after a 17% drop on Monday, triggered by China's DeepSeek unveiling its R1 chatbot, which can match US AI products at lower costs. The tech-heavy Nasdaq and Dow steadied, while the S&P index fell. Nvidia's drop wiped over half a trillion dollars from its market capitalization, but analysts say the sell-off "may have gone too far" and that the company may recover. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank are set to make interest-rate decisions this week, which will influence the market.

images.alt_text: Nvidia and Deepseek logos are seen in this illustration taken, January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustrationo

site_title: Trump is launching a trade offensive: Or is he?
summary: US President Donald Trump has launched a trade offensive, requesting that central bankers cut interest rates and foreign companies increase investment in the US. He also asked the European Union to buy more American oil to avoid US tariffs, while threatening to double tax rates on foreign nationals and companies if discriminatory taxes are imposed on American companies. This mercantilist agenda aims to strengthen the US dollar and reduce global demand for American exports.

site_title: A modern kampung home
summary: A homeowner, inspired by his childhood memories of a kampung, designed a semi-detached house that incorporates natural ventilation and connected spaces. Kelvin Lim, design director of Hier Architects, created the Quadrant House by sectioning the interior into four parts and linking them through double-volume voids and interior openings. The design allows for interaction between family members across different parts of the house, while also providing a breezy interior reminiscent of traditional kampung dwellings. The facade features screens for privacy and shade.

images.alt_text: A layered entryway behind the main facade on the first story.

site_title: Nvidia says DeepSeek advances prove need for more of its chips
summary: Nvidia stated that Chinese AI firm DeepSeek's advancements demonstrate the usefulness of its chips for the Chinese market, necessitating more of its chips to meet demand. Despite concerns that DeepSeek used fewer Nvidia chips than rivals, Nvidia claims its chips are export control compliant and suitable for inference, a process requiring significant numbers of GPUs and high-performance networking. Nvidia is currently selling a new chip, H20, designed to meet recent export control regulations, and experts predict it will remain in demand due to its capabilities.

images.alt_text: Lauded by investor Marc Andreessen as “one of the most amazing and impressive breakthroughs”, DeepSeek’s assistant shows its work and reasoning as it addresses a user’s written query or prompt.

site_title: Corporate venturing gains traction in Malaysia – a boost to local tech startups
summary: Malaysia's venture capital ecosystem is expected to double in size by 2030, reaching RM1.1 billion, driven by rising investments and strategic reforms to unlock the sector's full capabilities. The country's sovereign fund, Khazanah Nasional, has launched two strategic investments totaling RM1 billion under its Dana Impak Initiative, lending hope to the corporate venturing space. Despite ranking among the top three in South-east Asia for funding, Malaysia lags behind regional peers in activity, highlighting the need for further reforms to boost the sector.

South-east Asia’s potential cannot be ignored. While its AI industry is sputtering, its digital economy as a whole is growing in the double digits both by revenue and profit, according to a study.
Singapore has a strong developer ecosystem – 9,700 out of its 1.3 million coders contribute to AI projects on platforms such as GitHub, and the country is ranked ninth globally for AI contributions.
Fintech funding in the six largest Asean economies has fallen by less than 1 per cent for the first three quarters of 2024, a significant improvement from the year-ago period.

site_title: Singapore shares rise before Chinese New Year break; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on the eve of the Chinese New Year break, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,801.07 points. Trading volume was thin, with 622.7 million securities worth S$904.1 million changing hands. Top gainers included CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, up 2%, while Sembcorp Industries was the biggest decliner, falling 2.2%. Market sentiment was influenced by the launch of China's AI chatbot DeepSeek, with some analysts warning of uncertainties and caution ahead.

site_title: Former Workers’ Party MP Leon Perera moves to New York, unlikely to contest in GE2025
summary: Former Singapore Workers' Party MP Leon Perera, 54, has announced he will be based in New York City for work, signaling he is unlikely to contest in the upcoming general election. Perera, who previously served as an elected MP, left the Workers' Party in July 2023 after a scandal. He now works as the executive director for Yamada Consulting Group USA, and has expressed his desire for "fresh perspectives" and a "better future" while in the US. A PSP spokesman confirmed Perera remains a volunteer with the party, solidifying his decision not to run in the election.

images.alt_text: Singapore election 2025: With the formation of the committee, the next General Election (GE) – due by November 2025 – could just be months away.

site_title: VCs who bet US$300 billion on AI say DeepSeek will fuel industry
summary: US venture capitalists have sunk over $300 billion on AI startups in the past five years, with Chinese AI company DeepSeek's release sparking concerns about the industry's growth. Despite DeepSeek's release causing a 3% drop in the Nasdaq, major VCs remain unfazed, seeing it as an opportunity for US startups to catch up. DeepSeek's success is expected to put pressure on US startups, but its release is also being viewed as a galvanizing force for the industry, driving innovation and growth.

site_title: Billionaire financier Bessent confirmed as Trump’s Treasury chief
summary: US billionaire financier Scott Bessent won Senate approval on January 27, 2025, to become Treasury Secretary under President Donald Trump. Bessent, a 62-year-old Wall Street veteran, has defended Trump's tax cutting and tariff proposals while urging efforts to secure supply chains and the dollar's global status. He cleared a confirmation vote with a 68-29 margin and will oversee the administration's tax policies and budget, confronting the debt limit and potential tariffs. Bessent's appointment has raised concerns about the potential impact on the global economy.

site_title: Google Maps to rename ‘Gulf of Mexico’ to ‘Gulf of America’ for US users
summary: Google Maps will rename "Gulf of Mexico" to "Gulf of America" for US users, while the name will remain "Gulf of Mexico" in Mexico. This change follows President Donald Trump's executive order to alter the name of the Gulf of Mexico and Mount McKinley to the Gulf of America and Mount McKinley, respectively. The updates will be visible in Google Maps and the US Geographic Names System, but not in other countries.

site_title: Few clear winners on the road to EVs – only losers
summary: The road to an electric vehicle (EV) future is becoming increasingly challenging, with few legacy brands emerging as winners. Chinese EVs, offering more space, high-tech features, performance, and refinement at lower prices, are dominating the market. However, premium brands like BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Porsche, and luxury marques like Bentley, Ferrari, and Rolls-Royce are still on higher ground due to their strong brand recognition and prestige. As the market shifts, dealerships with no EVs are struggling, feeling like "hospices" rather than showrooms.

images.alt_text: Nine new Chinese car brands made their debut at the Singapore Motorshow 2025.
Governments in E

“China’s export of electric vehicles, lithium batteries and solar products have enriched supplies to the global market and eased inflationary pressure, as well as made a great contribution for global efforts to tackle climate change and green transition,” President Xi told Chancellor Olaf Scholz.

site_title: Trump says Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok, following a brief offline period for the app due to a national security law requiring its Chinese owner ByteDance to sell it. Trump had previously expressed interest in buying TikTok and had signed an executive order to delay the law's enforcement. This marks the second time Microsoft has been in talks to acquire the app, which has about 170 million American users. A bidding war is expected, with Trump expressing his preference for a competitive process.

images.alt_text: Under the new law, TikTok can remain in the US if ByteDance executes a “qualified divestiture”.

site_title: The day I dined with a tennis Grand Slam champion
summary: Emma Raducanu, the 2021 US Open winner, was eliminated in the first round of the Singapore Tennis Open by Spain's Cristina Bucsa on January 27. Despite the loss, Raducanu was seen dining at a hotel with over 100 guests, including other tennis personalities, on the evening of January 26. The event took place at the Hilton hotel's 35th-floor ballroom, offering a view of Orchard Road. Raducanu's current ranking is 56th in the world, and she will need to rediscover her form and confidence to regain her winning feeling.

site_title: Putting GST back on the agenda
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) is implementing GST InvoiceNow, an electronic invoicing initiative, from 2025 onwards to enhance efficiency and tax compliance. GST InvoiceNow enables direct transmission of invoices electronically, streamlining the invoicing process and reducing manual steps. The initiative aims to onboard GST-registered businesses onto the InvoiceNow network, which already has over 60,000 businesses on board. The implementation will require businesses to upgrade their accounting systems and review their GST treatment for accuracy, with the Iras gaining greater visibility into transaction data.

site_title: Fintech venture 129Knots secures US$10 million in funding
summary: Fintech startup 129Knots has secured US$10 million in funding from Sing Fuels, an oil trading company. The startup has developed origination-to-distribution technology for trade credit and audit trails, aiming to revolutionize deep-tier trade industries. Backed by a US$500 million deal pipeline, 129Knots seeks to become the world's most trusted originator and distributor of real-world assets. The investment validates the market opportunity for the company, which was incubated under Singapore's Corporate Venture Launchpad program.

site_title: KuCoin pleads guilty, agrees to pay nearly US$300 million in US crypto case
summary: KuCoin, one of the world's largest cryptocurrency exchanges, has pleaded guilty to operating an unlicensed money transmitting business and agreed to pay nearly US$300 million in fines and forfeiture. The US Department of Justice said KuCoin was used to facilitate billions of dollars in suspicious transactions, including those from darknet markets and malware. KuCoin's founders agreed to forfeit US$2.7 million and exit the US market for at least two years. The company will also strengthen its global compliance practices and explore opportunities to reenter the market with necessary licenses.

site_title: Fuji TV president to step down over pop star sex scandal
summary: Fuji Television President Koichi Minato and Chairman Shuji Kano are stepping down following a sex scandal involving popular host Masahiro Nakai, who was accused of sexual harassment. Minato will resign as president effective Monday, with Kenji Shimizu taking over on Tuesday, while Kano steps down today. The management shake-up comes after an investigation into the scandal.

summary: Keppel Reit reported a 3.4% decline in second-half 2024 distributable income (DPU) to S$0.028 per unit, despite a 13.6% increase in net property income to S$105.1 million. Higher borrowing costs and lower rental support contributed to the decline. However, the manager remains confident in strong demand for Singapore office space, citing healthy rental reversions and new demand from companies mandating working from the office.

site_title: Three reasons to focus on energy-transition infrastructure
summary: The global energy transition represents a significant investment opportunity, with the International Energy Agency (IEA) estimating $4.5 trillion in annual investments needed by the early 2030s. Energy-transition assets are highly differentiated, offering robust diversification benefits due to unique risk premia, including inflation risk, positive power price risk, and technology risk. As the energy sector continues to grow, new capital is required to build out a sustainable global energy system, with renewable energy being the largest energy sub-sector within infrastructure. Investing in energy transition also provides environmental and sustainability benefits, including potential outperformance during energy-transition shocks.

images.alt_text: sustainability, hand, keep
Overly simplistic approaches to ESG investing should be replaced with more sophisticated approaches that aim to reconcile views on system changes in the global economy, says the writer.

site_title: Deep-tech VC firm Elev8.vc announces close of latest US$30 million fund
summary: Deep-tech VC firm Elev8.vc has closed a US$30 million fund to back 20-30 startups in AI, medtech, robotics, and advanced manufacturing. Capital has already been deployed into startups like Aevice and Gush. Elev8.vc aims to support founders transforming scientific discoveries into commercially viable solutions, with institutional investors, family offices, and founders like Steve Chen backing the fund.

summary: Chinese startup DeepSeek claims to have built a highly advanced AI model in just two months for under $6 million, using less-advanced chips, and its app powered by the V3 model became the top iPhone download in the US. This challenges the notion that scaling AI requires vast computing power and investment, sparking investor scrutiny of big tech giants' billion-dollar spending on AI. Analysts expect executives to offer clarity on their strategy as the market watches for results from industry bellwethers, with some doubting the long-term viability of DeepSeek's breakthroughs due to concerns over data privacy and security.

site_title: Europe: Tech shares tumble as China’s AI push spooks investors
summary: European tech shares plummeted as much as 0.8% due to concerns over China's AI push, specifically DeepSeek's low-cost artificial intelligence model. The Stoxx 600 dropped 3.4% and chip equipment maker ASML fell 7%, with Siemens Energy and Schneider Electric also experiencing significant declines. Analysts warn that the success of DeepSeek's model may lead investors to reassess spending on AI development and chip costs.

site_title: GuocoLand to launch its fourth Lentor project in Q1
summary: GuocoLand will launch its fourth Lentor project, Lentor Central Residences, in the first quarter of 2025. The 477-unit development follows three other successful projects in the Lentor Hills estate, where six plots of land have been sold under the Government Land Sales programme. Lentor Central Residences will be the developer's fourth project in the area, with pricing details yet to be announced.

Net property income rose 1.9% to S$99.6 million. The distribution will be paid on March 26, after the record date on February 10. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 94.5% as of end-December.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz expects higher margin on car division in fourth quarter, analysts say
summary: Mercedes-Benz expects its car division to achieve a margin above 6-7% in the fourth quarter, exceeding analysts' forecasts. The company is confident it will meet its full-year margin target of 7.5-8.5%. Executives attribute this to strong performance in China, despite caution over the longer-term outlook due to excess capacity driving prices down. The automaker reported core car sales fell 3% in 2024, but rose 1% in the fourth quarter, boosted by sales of top-end vehicles.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 fall; China’s DeepSeek AI model hits tech shares
summary: US stocks declined sharply on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq falling 1.44% and 3.04% respectively, due to concerns over the impact of a low-cost Chinese AI model, DeepSeek's AI Assistant. Nvidia's shares dropped, and other tech-related companies, including Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet, also fell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose, but tech shares and data center operators tanked. The market is awaiting earnings reports from tech companies and the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision on Wednesday.

site_title: DBS raises stake in Shenzhen Rural Commercial Bank
summary: DBS Bank has acquired an additional 2.7% stake in Shenzhen Rural Commercial Bank (SRCB), increasing its stake from 16.7% to 19.4%, expanding its exposure to China's greater bay area. The investment, valued at 1.6 billion yuan, is expected to be immediately accretive to earnings and return on equity, with a minimal impact on consolidated capital ratios.

In 2024, the number of single family offices in Singapore rose 43 per cent on year to exceed 2,000.

site_title: World Bank president cautions against hasty reaction to Trump policies
summary: World Bank President Ajay Banga advises policymakers to wait before reacting to US President Donald Trump's policies, cautioning against hasty judgments. Banga recommends that policymakers prepare to argue their case and wait to see what policies are actually executed. He also notes that the World Bank could be affected by any travel restrictions on Colombian officials, which could impact its operations. Banga has experience working with Trump and believes that a practical approach is necessary for effective communication.

site_title: Oil hits two-week low as China’s DeepSeek AI spurs demand fears
summary: Oil prices fell 2% to a two-week low as Brent futures dropped US$1.42 to US$77.08 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell US$1.49 to US$73.17 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns over surging interest in Chinese startup DeepSeek's low-cost AI model, which may boost energy demand for data centers. This news followed weak economic data from China and worries about US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs, which could further pressure economic growth and energy demand.

site_title: Saudi Arabia opens foreign property investments in holy cities
summary: Saudi Arabia has begun allowing foreigners to invest in publicly-traded companies owning real estate in holy cities of Makkah and Madinah. Foreign investors can purchase shares and convertible debt instruments in firms listed on the Saudi stock exchange with real estate in these cities. The move is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to boost its appeal as an investment destination under the Vision 2030 diversification agenda. Shares of real estate firms rose following the announcement, with some climbing as much as 10% at the open.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's Minister of Economy and Planning Faisal Alibrahim says: "This number represents investments, procurement, public and private sector, and it’s just a mirror reflection of the strong relationship.”

site_title: Economic-centred German election may also pivot on migration
summary: Germany's economic-centred election campaign may pivot on migration amid recent attacks, including a Christmas market attack in Magdeburg and stabbings in Aschaffenburg. Christian Democratic Union (CDU) leader Friedrich Merz has pivoted to the right on law and order, including tougher immigration policies, which could benefit the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD). Merz's "Agenda 2030" aims to boost economic growth through tax cuts and infrastructure investments, but his plans may face challenges in coalition negotiations, potentially leading to a grand coalition with the Social Democrats (SPD).
