site_title: Ex-PropertyGuru execs bet big on rent-to-own in Indonesia
summary: Two former PropertyGuru executives, Winston Lee and Marine Novita, have launched a new proptech company called MilikiRumah, which aims to address Indonesia's housing shortage through a rent-to-own model. The company has closed its seed round at S$2 million and plans to onboard at least 500 families by the end of 2025. MilikiRumah's model is inspired by Singapore's Housing and Development Board and Central Provident Fund, and targets consumers with non-fixed incomes, high debt-to-income ratios, or poor credit histories. The company aims to become profitable in its first year of operation.

site_title: China misses fiscal spending target on effects of housing slump
summary: China's government failed to meet its fiscal spending target for 2024, with total augmented spending at 38.6 trillion yuan, 5% less than the budgeted amount. The housing market slump, which has led to decreased land sale revenue and tighter borrowing rules, hindered local authorities' ability to meet funding commitments. As a result, fiscal policy failed to provide an adequate boost to the economy, with actual spending being less than 1% higher than the previous year, missing the targeted increase. This has resulted in a deficit of 10.4 trillion yuan, equivalent to 7.7% of gross domestic product.

images.alt_text: The holiday snapshots reflect a home-bias shift among Chinese tourists, who for years were the globe’s biggest spenders.
Intense competition between factories has pushed export prices lower and squeezed companies’ profit margins.

site_title: China boosts index investments in latest bid to revive market
summary: China has announced new measures to boost index investments in the equity market, aiming to increase the scale and proportion of index investment through a period of time. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) set a goal to strengthen the asset allocation function of index funds and provide more convenient channels for medium and long-term funds to enter the market, as Chinese shares have been under pressure amid fears of a prolonged economic slowdown and higher US tariffs.

images.alt_text: New housing construction has been dropping for years and slashing demand for land.

site_title: Wall Street enters darker age with most stock trading now hidden
summary: Wall Street has entered a new era with most stock trading now occurring off-exchange, with 51.8% of trading volume expected to be off-exchange in January, a record. This shift is driven by growing alternative trading systems and dark pools, which allow institutional investors to trade anonymously. The trend is expected to continue, potentially changing how the market functions, and could lead to worse pricing on and off-exchange.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan’s chief executive officer Jamie Dimon said there are signs that the US stock market is overheated.
The shrinking stock pool – in the US, the number of listed companies has fallen by half from a 1996 peak – also means fewer equity analysts are needed.
Wall Street’s year-end rewards are notoriously volatile as the industry cycles through booms and busts.

Banks, which have spent years modernising their IT systems to speed up processes and shave costs in the wake of the financial crisis, have been flocking into the new generation of AI tools that could further improve productivity.

site_title: JPMorgan’s investment banking chair to step down, memo shows
summary: JPMorgan Chase's global chair of investment banking and capital markets, Kevin Willsey, will retire at the end of March, according to an internal memo. Willsey, who joined JPMorgan in 1989, has served as global chair since 2013 and co-head of North America investment. His retirement marks the end of an era for the bank's investment banking division, with Willsey being a long-serving and influential figure in the industry.

site_title: Starbucks CEO made US$96 million in first four months on the job
summary: Starbucks CEO Brian Niccol received a compensation package of approximately $96 million for four months of work, with 94% of the pay coming from stock awards tied to performance. The package also included a $5 million sign-on bonus after his one-month anniversary with the company, as agreed upon by Starbucks.

site_title: Authentic leadership – key to thriving in uncertain times
summary: Authentic leadership, characterized by a leader's inner compass, is crucial in uncertain times. It rejects traditional stereotypes and empowers leaders to lead in alignment with their values, fostering inclusivity and equity. Authentic leaders create cultures of trust, collaboration, and innovation, and champion Diversity, Equity and Inclusion initiatives. By embracing their humanity and vulnerability, leaders can inspire trust and respect, promoting inclusivity and advancing gender equity in the workplace. Authentic leadership is a deeply personal and continuous process, requiring growth and adaptation, but its impact is universal, driving meaningful change and setting a course for a more equitable future.

site_title: UK chancellor to fast-track housing approvals near rail stations
summary: UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves plans to fast-track planning approvals for housebuilding near commuter rail stations to deliver 1.5 million new homes over five years. Developers who submit acceptable projects in high potential areas will receive a default "yes" under proposals designed to boost economic growth and simplify the planning process. The government aims to cut "red tape" in the planning process by simplifying consultation requirements and replacing environmental impact assessments. Reeves will also champion a regeneration project in Manchester's Old Trafford district, committing to making 150 decisions on major economic infrastructure applications.

site_title: Many Thais disapprove casino, online gambling plans: poll
summary: About 59% of Thai respondents disapprove of investments in casinos and entertainment complexes, according to a January 20-21 survey by the National Institute of Development Administration. The survey found 69% disagree with the government's plan to legalize online gambling to support casinos. Despite the opposition, Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra believes the initiatives will bring economic benefits and create jobs. The government has approved a Bill to legalize casinos in principle, which could lead to Thailand emerging as a major player in the global gaming industry in about six years.

images.alt_text: Tourists ride a cruise in the Chao Praya river, in Bangkok on December 19, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
The holiday snapshots reflect a home-bias shift among Chinese tourists, who for years were the globe’s biggest spenders.

site_title: US business activity moderates as growth in services cools
summary: US business activity is expanding at the slowest pace in nine months, with the S&P Global flash January composite index for services and manufacturers decreasing to 52.4. Despite the moderation, businesses remain optimistic about future demand, matching the highest level since May 2022. The manufacturing sector moved into expansion territory, while services activity retreated four points. Inflationary pressures also rose, with prices paid for materials and output prices at manufacturers reaching four-month highs. The economy's growth slowdown may be short-lived, according to S&P Global's chief business economist.

images.alt_text: The challenge for Fed Chair Jerome Powell and his colleagues will be in determining how much to allow uncertainty over what’s ahead to influence decisions on monetary policy now, and how much guidance to give about the Fed’s outlook.

site_title: More job cuts loom after UK firms run down Covid coffers
summary: UK businesses have depleted their pandemic-era cash reserves, leaving them vulnerable to job cuts as Labour's tax hikes take effect in April. Firms added £150 billion in savings during the pandemic but have since tapped into them to keep up with inflation-busting pay rises and high borrowing costs. The ratio of savings to payroll bills is now back to its pre-pandemic level, making it harder for businesses to retain staff. Job cuts have already accelerated, with over 150,000 employees lost since Labour took office, and more layoffs are expected as businesses prepare for increased national insurance contributions and minimum wage hikes.

images.alt_text: The British median pay award fell to 3.3 per cent in the three months to December, the lowest since December 2021, and down sharply from 4 per cent in the three months to November, according to Brightmine data.

site_title: Time for OCBC to offload Great Eastern
summary: OCBC, the parent company of Great Eastern, has been granted another extension of time by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to comply with the minimum free float rule. The latest extension, which expires on May 25, provides breathing room for Great Eastern and OCBC to address the issue ahead of their upcoming annual general meetings (AGMs). OCBC had previously made two announcements about SGX granting it extensions of time to restore Great Eastern's public float, citing uncertainty about OCBC's final shareholding. The extension could result in shareholders not getting substantive answers to questions about OCBC's ownership of Great Eastern.

site_title: South Korea court rejects request to extend Yoon's detention
summary: South Korea's Seoul Central District Court rejected a prosecutors' office request to extend the detention of impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol, who is being investigated for his attempt to impose martial law. Yoon's detention was due to end on January 28, but the court's decision allows prosecutors to ask for an extension for another 10 days before filing charges. This decision comes as investigators probe Yoon's attempt to impose martial law, which was overturned by parliament.

site_title: Some self-storage operators may have to move out of current locations after JTC review on land use
summary: Singapore's JTC may force some self-storage operators to move out of their current locations after a review aimed at accommodating increasing demand from operators like Lock+Store and StorHub. The review, which began in 2021, identified areas around Singapore for potential conversion to self-storage use, but will prioritize industrial land for manufacturing activities. Existing operators will be allowed to continue operating until the end of their leases or sublet terms, with JTC to discuss future use with operators. The review aims to balance demand from self-storage operators with limited industrial land available for manufacturing.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
JTC Corporation's review comes amid rising demand for self-storage services, and a corresponding surge in demand for industrial space by industry players.
The changing face of self-storage in Asia

site_title: Learning financial literacy through a supermarket trip
summary: Standard Chartered Bank and Prudential Singapore launched a year-long programme to teach underprivileged children basic money management concepts through a supermarket shopping trip. The programme, which kicked off on January 22, aims to educate 500 children from the Ministry of Social and Family Development's ComLink+ programme. The children, aged 7-12, were guided by volunteers and taught the concepts of earning, saving, spending, and donating through the Cha-Ching curriculum. The event marked 25 years of partnership between StanChart and Prudential.

site_title: Emerging market currencies get relief rally from softening Trump threats
summary: Emerging market currencies, including the Malaysian ringgit, experienced a relief rally as US President Donald Trump's comments hinted at a softer rollout of US tariffs on China. The benchmark index for developing-nation currencies rose 1.2% last week, the best weekly showing since July 2023. Analysts attribute the rally to relief that the worst-case scenario regarding US tariffs appears to be falling by the wayside, with Trump's comments suggesting he would rather not impose levies on China.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar rose to a five-week high of US$0.6312, breaking the former January top of US$0.6302 and leaving it 1.9 per cent higher on the week.

site_title: Frankfurt’s skyline darkens as old office buildings sit vacant
summary: Frankfurt's office vacancy rates have grown to nearly 10% due to the Covid pandemic's aftermath, with many older buildings being left behind as tenants prioritize newer, ESG-compliant spaces. Rising construction costs, urban planning requirements, and delayed renovations are exacerbating the issue. Owners are struggling to invest in renovations, and vacant buildings can negatively impact the surrounding area. Major tenants, such as the European Central Bank, are moving out of aging buildings, and lenders are facing balance sheet risks. Experts warn that the crisis is yet to come, and banks should step up to invest in properties to prevent further decline.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is also relaxing restrictions that may lead to a flood of housing units being put up for sale.

site_title: Hong Kong races to find its property market bottom
summary: Hong Kong is removing its property cooling measures, including extra stamp duty for foreigners and multiple-home owners, in an attempt to boost demand in the stagnant market. The move aims to restore normalcy to the city's real estate sector, which relies heavily on land sales. The relaxation of restrictions is also accompanied by eased mortgage rules and lowered loan-to-value ratios, further expected to stimulate the market. The government hopes this will increase fiscal income from land sales, which has evaporated due to the cooling measures.

images.alt_text: Home prices in Hong Kong, one of the world’s most unaffordable cities, have tumbled nearly 30 per cent from a 2021 peak, hurt initially by higher mortgage rates, easing demand as many professionals left the territory and a weak market outlook.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat, cutting into weekly gains
summary: US stocks retreated on Friday, cutting into weekly gains, after a flattish open and a trend of profit taking. The S&P 500 fell 0.3% to 6,101.24, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.3% to 44,424.25. Despite recent gains due to benign US inflation data and strong bank earnings, the market is poised for a pause ahead of a Federal Reserve monetary policy decision and earnings from tech giants.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent higher at 44,565.07 on Thursday.

site_title: India’s Maharashtra gets US$200 billion investment vows at Davos
summary: Maharashtra, India's financial capital, signed investment pledges worth $200 billion at the Davos summit, with a majority coming from foreign investors. Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis announced deals with Blackstone, Reliance Industries, Jindal Steel Works, and Brookfield. The state aims to capitalize on its good investment climate, with companies like Amazon and Microsoft interested in building data centers. Maharashtra's economic productivity contributes 10% to India's GDP, but the state faces fiscal pressure, maintaining a 3% fiscal deficit despite increased spending.

images.alt_text: The RBI has kept interest rates unchanged for nearly two years now.

site_title: Huationg Global’s Patrick Ng enhances stake amid robust business prospects
summary: Top Glove's net institutional inflow reached the 8th highest in the Singapore stock market for the month, with the group's stock hitting S$2.4 million in average daily trading turnover. The company reported a 80% increase in sales revenue and a 104% surge in sales volume for Q1 FY2025. Huationg Global's CEO Patrick Ng acquired 650,800 shares, increasing his direct interest in the company to 8.26%. Thirteen primary-listed companies conducted buybacks with a total consideration of S$25 million, led by OCBC. Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, leading to a net institutional outflow of S$393 million over the five sessions.

site_title: Japan Foods warns of loss for 9-month period amid lower revenue, higher expenses
summary: Japan Foods expects to report a loss for its nine months ended Dec 31, 2024, due to lower revenue and higher selling and distribution expenses. Weak sales in November and December 2024, despite a higher number of operating outlets, contributed to the decline. The company will disclose further details of its financial performance in its upcoming business and financial update.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open flat ahead of economic data; Boeing declines
summary: US stocks opened flat ahead of economic data, with the Dow Jones falling 31.3 points to 44,533.75. The S&P 500 rose 2.7 points to 6,121.43, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 33.4 points to 20,087.105. Boeing declined after issuing a quarterly profit warning. Investors remained cautious due to upcoming economic data, despite the benchmark indices reaching fresh records earlier in the week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 9, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Fed to hold rates steady at an unsteady moment
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers are expected to keep interest rates steady at 4.25%-4.50% as they navigate uncertainty surrounding President Donald Trump's economic policies, including potential tariffs and immigration restrictions. Trump has urged the Fed to lower interest rates, but policymakers must balance providing guidance on their outlook without appearing to make policy decisions based on politics. The Fed aims to keep inflation within 2% and has expressed confidence that inflation will continue to slow, but the impact of Trump's policies on the economy is uncertain and may influence future rate decisions.

images.alt_text: Investors are now betting the central bank is likely to lower its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point this year after cutting it by a full percentage point in the final months of 2024.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 slips from record highs amid rising yield pressure
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed flat on Friday, slipping from record highs due to declining telecom and energy sectors. Rising bond yields, particularly in Germany, added downward pressure. The index rose 1.3% for the week, its fifth consecutive gain, despite a 2.8% decline in Ericsson and a 1% drop in the energy sector. The personal and household goods sector rose 0.6%, led by Burberry, while mining rose 1.2% due to a jump in metal prices.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 climbed 0.44 per cent to close at 530.34 points on Thursday, marking its seventh consecutive day of gains - its longest winning streak in over a month.

site_title: Hackers target Singapore baby brand’s Amazon Account, threatening US$78 million business
summary: KeaBabies, a Singapore-based baby brand, reported a significant security breach on its Amazon seller account, starting January 16. Hackers gained unauthorized access, making repeated changes to admin e-mail and bank account, resulting in a $50,000 withdrawal. The breach led to the suspension of KeaBabies' Amazon account and halted daily sales of $230,000, generating $78 million in 2024. The company's co-founder and CEO, Ivan Ong, expressed concerns about Amazon's security protocols and the lack of a crisis management response, citing a high risk of bankruptcy and business shutdown.

images.alt_text: Retail seemed taken by surprise as fans snapped up not only Taylor Swift merchandise but also personalised Taylor Swift sneakers and even a cake with a picture to burn.

site_title: This Hong Kong newspaper seller is preparing for a yuan crash
summary: A Hong Kong newspaper seller, Wong, is preparing for a yuan crash, betting that the Chinese yuan will weaken to parity against the Hong Kong dollar. The yuan has lost over 12% of its value against its neighboring currency over the past three years, with some analysts predicting a further weakening to 7.75 US dollars by the third quarter. The currency shift has exacerbated pressure on Hong Kong, with rising costs for tourists and residents, while some investors are benefiting from the yuan's decline. The future of Hong Kong's 41-year-old currency peg against the greenback remains uncertain, with speculation intensifying.

images.alt_text: The holiday snapshots reflect a home-bias shift among Chinese tourists, who for years were the globe’s biggest spenders.

site_title: Meta to spend up to US$65 billion this year to power AI goals, Zuckerberg says
summary: Meta Platforms plans to spend between US$60 billion and US$65 billion this year to build out AI infrastructure, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg expecting the technology to serve over 1 billion people by 2025. The company will build a massive data centre covering a significant part of Manhattan and end the year with over 1.3 million graphics processors. This investment follows a wave of Big Tech firms unveiling hefty investments to capitalise on AI, with Meta's planned spending marking a significant jump from last year's estimated US$38 billion to US$40 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg makes a keynote speech at the Meta Connect annual event at the company's headquarters in Menlo Park, California, U.S., September 25, 2024. REUTERS/Manuel Orbegozo/File Photo

site_title: Far East Orchard unit acquires additional stake in Woodlands Square for S$25 million
summary: Far East Orchard's unit, Tannery, has acquired an additional 6.7% stake in Woodlands Square for S$25 million, increasing its ownership to 40% and its wholly-owned subsidiary, Far East Civil Engineering, to 60%. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to generate higher returns for shareholders, with the office and retail units at Woods Square nearly fully leased. The deal is expected to contribute to FEO's income stream and maintain the pro forma net tangible asset and earnings per share per share.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Artist's impression of Woods Square, an office units in Woodlands.

site_title: Oil prices settle pennies higher, down for week as Trump touts energy policy
summary: US President Donald Trump's plan to boost domestic oil production and lower energy costs faces a challenge from the threat of harsh US sanctions on Russia and Iran, key oil producers. Oil prices settled slightly higher on Friday, but posted a weekly decline, as Brent crude futures rose 0.27% to $78.50 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.05% to $74.66. Trump's demands for OPEC to cut oil prices to hurt Russia's finances and help end the war in Ukraine may be undermined by the sanctions threat, analysts say.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 71 cents, or 0.9 per cent, lower at US$78.29 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) settled down 82 cents, or 1.09 per cent, to US$74.62 on Thursday.

site_title: 2025 Kia Carnival and Sorento review: Seven seats in two different styles
summary: The 2025 Kia Carnival and Sorento offer seven-seat configurations in two different styles, catering to families and practicality. The Sorento takes a more common approach with a medium SUV body, while the Carnival accommodates seven passengers as a giant box on wheels. The Carnival features plush middle-row armchairs and a spacious boot, but lacks thrilling handling. In contrast, the Sorento has a more refined driving experience and generous features, including a huge glass roof. Both models excel at stretching fuel budgets with hybrid powertrains, making them appealing options for those seeking value.

site_title: Can you breathe stress away?
summary: Scientists are studying the link between breathing and the mind, with some studies showing that controlled breathing can reduce stress. A meta-analysis of 12 studies found that slow-breathing exercises, such as "breathwork," resulted in significant stress reduction, comparable to online cognitive behavior therapy. However, some studies have methodological flaws, and more research is needed to fully understand the effects. Researchers believe that controlled breathing may help by focusing attention away from negative thoughts and increasing heart-rate variability, a measure often low in people with psychiatric disorders.

site_title: Investing in synthetic biology: Rewriting life’s code
summary: Synthetic biology, a field that manipulates the genetic code of organisms, is gaining significant investment and attention for its potential to revolutionize industries, economies, and social norms. However, it also poses profound ethical, regulatory, and risk concerns. Investors must carefully consider these complexities as the global synthetic biology market is projected to reach $38.7 billion by 2027, with applications in food and materials science. Companies are pioneering genetic modifications to produce lab-grown meats, sustainable materials, and bio-based alternatives, but regulatory bodies struggle to define and regulate these novel products, and consumer acceptance remains unpredictable. A cautious and strategic investment approach is essential to balance the potential benefits with the inherent risks.

site_title: Saudi US$600 billion package with US includes investments, procurement: minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's Minister of Economy and Planning Faisal Alibrahim announced a US$600 billion expanded package with the US, including investments and procurement from the public and private sectors, in a strong reflection of the bilateral relationship. This figure was first mentioned by US President Donald Trump, who suggested it could be increased to US$1 trillion. The package aims to broaden investments and trade between the two countries over the next four years, with a focus on long-term oil market stability and US exports to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Santosa, Kolonas families offer to privatise Japfa at S$0.62 per share
summary: The Santosa and Kolonas families, siblings and cousins of Japfa's founder, are offering to privatize the agri-food company at S$0.62 per share, representing a 34.8% premium to its last traded price on Jan 15. The offer, through special purpose vehicles TAC 1 and TAC 2, aims to acquire around 18.3% of Japfa's total issued shares. Japfa plans to use the funds to save on listing expenses and focus on business operations.

site_title: ST Engineering Urban Solutions, SP Mobility win tender to deploy public EV charging points
summary: ST Engineering Urban Solutions and SP Mobility have won contracts to deploy public electric vehicle (EV) charging points in Singapore, with a minimum of 46 charging points to be installed across 20 locations. The charging points will primarily be located in industrial areas to support the electrification of commercial fleets and provide drivers with more charging options. The deployment will be rolled out in two phases, with the first charging point site expected to be operational by end-2025.

site_title: Rolls-Royce wins US$11 billion UK nuclear submarine contract
summary: Britain has awarded Rolls-Royce a US$11 billion eight-year contract to design, make, and provide support services for nuclear reactors powering its submarines. The deal will strengthen the Royal Navy's continuous at-sea deterrent and boost the AUKUS defence pact with the US and Australia, saving the UK £400 million. The contract is expected to create 1,000 jobs and safeguard 4,000 others, with Defence Minister John Healey calling it a "boost to British jobs and business".

images.alt_text: Rolls-Royce sold 6,032 vehicles last year, with the US and greater China its top markets.

site_title: BMW joins Chinese EV makers in filing EU court challenge to tariffs
summary: BMW has joined Chinese electric vehicle makers BYD, Geely, and SAIC in filing a challenge against EU tariffs on China-made EVs at the Court of Justice of the European Union. The tariffs, imposed in October, include 17%, 18.8%, and 35.3% rates for the respective companies. BMW's rate is 20.7%. The challenge is part of a larger EU investigation into anti-subsidy practices in the Chinese automotive industry. Proceedings at the General Court typically take 18 months and can be appealed.

Beijing’s commerce ministry said that authorities have “decided to implement temporary anti-dumping measures in the form of a cash deposit or letter of guarantee” against European brandy products.

site_title: Putin says he and Trump should meet to discuss Ukraine and energy prices
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed interest in meeting US President Donald Trump to discuss Ukraine and energy prices. Putin stated that Trump is "smart and pragmatic" and suggested that they should meet to talk calmly about areas of mutual interest. However, Putin emphasized that Ukraine's ban on negotiating with Russia must be lifted before any serious peace talks can occur. The two leaders also discussed energy and arms control, with Putin noting that high or low oil prices are bad for both countries.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump and his administration reportedly believe there are ways of toughening measures to press Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: Alfa Romeo and Jeep dealership in Singapore to close by June
summary: Alfa Romeo and Jeep dealership in Singapore, operated by Capella Auto, will close by June 2025. The company has sold fewer than 25 units of each brand per year for the last three years. Existing customers will continue to receive maintenance, repair, and warranty claims until the middle of 2025. The remaining stock of cars will be sold over the next few months.

site_title: Entering the age of buyouts in healthcare investing
summary: Healthcare investing in Asia is becoming increasingly attractive as the industry continues to benefit from government support, aging demographics, and growing innovation. Buyout strategies, where investors acquire controlling ownerships in undervalued or mismanaged companies, are gaining traction as the market transitions from excessive exuberance to guarded optimism. Successful buyouts require a hands-on approach to manage investments effectively, with investors needing to take on greater responsibility to drive value creation. Companies will increasingly turn to consolidation to be more efficient, and investors with strong value creation capabilities will be in high demand.

site_title: Great Eastern granted further extension to May 25 to explore options to return free float
summary: Great Eastern, a Singaporean insurer, has received approval from the Singapore Exchange to extend its deadline to May 25 to explore options to comply with free float requirements. The company is currently preparing its financial statements for FY2024, which will be published in March 2025, and needs the additional time to examine its options. The insurer had initially requested an extension, citing the importance of information from its annual report. The extension is seen as a positive move for the company, allowing it to address its compliance issues without rushing into a decision.

site_title: Economists mixed on whether MAS will ease monetary policy again in 2025, after January move
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has loosened monetary policy settings for the first time since October 2022, citing a slowing growth momentum for the country this year. Economists are mixed on whether MAS will ease policy again in 2025, with some citing global trade impacts from US President Trump's tariffs as a reason. The MAS will "slightly" reduce the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate policy band, and a common base scenario is for the central bank to maintain a steady policy for the rest of 2025.

summary: Singapore-listed companies' boards are more diverse than six years ago, according to the 2025 edition of the Singapore Board Diversity Index. The improvement is attributed to the increasing representation of women and ethnic minorities on corporate boards. Meanwhile, Singapore banks are investing in carbon capabilities, with several institutions launching initiatives to reduce their carbon footprint. These developments reflect the growing emphasis on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in the country's corporate governance landscape.

site_title: WHO freezes hiring and cuts costs after Trump signals US exit
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has frozen hiring, suspended investments, and cut non-essential travel in response to the US withdrawal from the global body. The move is attributed to the US withdrawal, which has made the WHO's financial situation "more acute," according to Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus. Plans include cost redundancies and efficiencies to address the financial strain.

site_title: Malaysia Airports sale to Gateway Development Alliance moves a step closer
summary: Malaysia Airports' sale to the Gateway Development Alliance, led by Khazanah Nasional, has reached an acceptance level of 92.82%. The consortium, also including BlackRock's Global Infrastructure Partners and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, offered RM11 apiece for all remaining shares, valuing the airports operator at RM18.4 billion. The deal, initially delayed due to protests, remains open until February 4.

site_title: Lian Beng’s Ong family offers to privatise SLB Development at S$0.23 per share
summary: Lian Beng Group's controlling Ong family proposes a scheme of arrangement to acquire and privatize property developer SLB Development at S$0.23 per share. This comes after Lian Beng's privatization in 2023 and delisting in August that year. The offer represents a premium of 36.1% over SLB's last trading price and provides shareholders with a unique cash exit opportunity without incurring brokerage fees. The acquisition will allow SLB to save on expenses and costs related to its listing status.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Lian Beng has one more week to gather enough acceptances to cross the 90 per cent threshold and compulsorily acquire the remaining shares in the company and take it private.

site_title: Analysts upgrade Frasers Centrepoint Trust to ‘buy’, citing its high retail portfolio occupancy
summary: Analysts have upgraded Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) to a "buy" rating due to its high retail portfolio occupancy and ongoing asset enhancement initiatives. The trust reported a 99.5% committed occupancy rate for its retail portfolio in Q1, with analysts citing stable operational performance and higher-than-expected tenant sales as positive signs. They also believe the trust's recent price weakness provides an attractive entry point for investors, and that its strong balance sheet and asset enhancement projects will drive rental reversions and earnings growth.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The progress for Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Hougang Mall AEI is on track, with its main contract awarded within its budget.

site_title: Trump says he would ‘rather not’ have to impose tariffs on China
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he prefers not to impose 10% tariffs on China, citing its significant influence over the Asian nation. Trump made the comments during an interview with Fox News host Sean Hannity, highlighting the power of tariffs over China. Despite previous threats, Trump softened his stance, instead emphasizing his desire to maintain a relationship with China. The yuan and Chinese stocks gained following Trump's comments, with the benchmark CSI 300 Index rising 1% and the offshore yuan increasing 0.3%.

site_title: Reeling from shock Paris defeat, fragile Manchester City face Chelsea in must-win EPL battle
summary: Manchester City, struggling after a 4-2 loss to Paris Saint Germain in the Champions League, faces a must-win match against Chelsea in the English Premier League. A win would secure City's spot in the Champions League next season, but a loss would put them in danger of elimination. Meanwhile, Nottingham Forest, third in the EPL table, meets in-form Bournemouth, who are also vying for a Champions League spot.

site_title: OCBC CEO Helen Wong meets Lee family members and other key Great Eastern shareholders holding out on offer
summary: OCBC CEO Helen Wong met with Lee family members and other key Great Eastern shareholders to persuade them to support the bank's attempt to buy up all shares it doesn't own in the Singapore insurer. The bank has been trying to take full control of Great Eastern for over two decades, with a previous bid of S$1.4 billion in 2023. Wong's efforts come as Great Eastern shares have been suspended for six months due to low public ownership, and some shareholders have questioned the S$25.60 cash offer price.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant Group unit Anext Bank appoints CEO-designate
summary: Anext Bank, a wholly owned subsidiary of Jack Ma-backed Ant Group's overseas unit Ant International, has appointed Kai Qiu as its new CEO-designate, replacing Toh Su Mei who left the bank after nearly four years. Qiu, the current deputy CEO and chief technology officer, will continue the bank's focus on embedded finance, a key strategy for the bank. site_title: Japanese pay hikes must exceed last year's, Rengo union head says
summary: The head of the Rengo trade union group, Tomoko Yoshino, stated that Japanese annual pay hikes this year must exceed last year's 5.1% due to falling real wages, which have decreased for the fourth straight month. Real wages account for inflation and have been impacted by rising food costs. Yoshino believes that even after last year's wage hikes, few people feel their real living conditions have improved, making it necessary to secure a result that outstrips last year's increase.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 24)
summary: Singapore's central bank eased monetary policy settings, lowering its 2025 core inflation forecast to 1-2%. Private home rents fell 1.9% in 2024, the first full-year decline since 2020. Factory output rose 10.6% in December, beating expectations. HDB resale prices accelerated 9.7% in 2024, double the previous year's increase. MAS also lowered its forecast for the 2025 core inflation rate, citing the easing of monetary policy settings.

site_title: Indonesia central bank has room to cut rates further, governor says
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the country has room to cut interest rates further, driven by inflation and economic growth forecasts. However, the bank will monitor global dynamics and the rupiah exchange rate before making any future easing moves. Warjiyo believes the rupiah will stabilize with a strengthening bias, supported by the government's new policy to make exporters retain foreign currency earnings for longer onshore. This policy is expected to increase domestic US dollar supply and boost foreign exchange reserves by $90 billion annually.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China. Higher tariffs are expected to hit the plus-three economies harder, particularly China, noted the macroeconomics surveillance organisation in its quarterly report.
The rupiah slid as much as 0.4 per cent to 16,318 per dollar on Wednesday, a level not seen since late July last year.
Indonesia's central bank, led by Governor Perry Warjiyo, has targeted inflation in 2024 and 2025 to be within a range of 1.5 per cent to 3.5 per cent.
Bank Indonesia initially boosted purchases of government debt during the Covid years in an extraordinary measure to help fund the state budget.
The raid was on Thursday, days after the agency conducted similar search at the central bank’s headquarters, Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) said.
The rupiah had weakened by as much as 1.03 per cent to 16,250 per a dollar as of 0240 GMT, its lowest level since Aug 2.

site_title: Grab contributed as much as 0.8% of Singapore GDP in 2023: report
summary: Grab contributed 0.8% to Singapore's GDP in 2023, adding S$5.2 billion to the economy. The contribution came from Grab's operations, merchant-partners, and driver-partners, with sectors such as finance, insurance, and real estate benefiting the most. The company's on-demand services created an estimated 117,000 earning opportunities and S$2.5 billion in household income, with a multiplier effect of S$6 in economic activity for every S$10 of GDP generated.

images.alt_text: The profit is due to improvements in group-adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation.

site_title: Fu Yu board rejects substantial shareholder’s directorship bid due to non-conformance with SGX’s ‘integrity requirements’
summary: Fu Yu Corporation's board of directors rejected a bid by substantial shareholder Victor Lim to become a director due to potential non-conformance with the Singapore Exchange's 'directors' integrity requirements'. Lim has proposed a turnaround strategy and has been a director of strategy for the past four years. The board's nominating committee remains willing to assess other board candidates proposed by Lim, indicating the company is open to exploring other options.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Fu Yu’s IDs Christopher Huang and Royston Tan had previously expressed surprise that Lim, who holds a 29.45 per cent stake in the company, had requisitioned for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Jan 9 to have them removed.
Fu Yu's independent directors noted that Victor Lim's request for a board seat had been rejected.
Fu Yu's largest shareholder Victor Lim says substantial shareholder value has been erased since the appointment of directors Christopher Huang Junli and Roystan Tan Tong Loong.

site_title: China’s new rules to add one trillion yuan into market: analysts
summary: China's new market rules aim to inject at least 1 trillion yuan (S$186 billion) into its stock market in 2025, according to analysts. Major state-owned insurers must invest 30% of new premiums in onshore stocks, while mutual funds must raise holdings by at least 10% annually for three years. Estimates from banks like JPMorgan, Citigroup, and UBS Group vary, but most predict an influx of funds, with some predicting as much as 13 trillion yuan over three years. The measures aim to stabilize China's stock markets amid economic slowdown fears and US President Donald Trump's tariff threats.

site_title: Thomson Medical warns of H1 loss on poorer Malaysia performance
summary: Thomson Medical expects to report a loss after tax for the six months ended Dec 31, 2024, due to a poorer performance of its Malaysia market, mainly resulting from the termination and discounts of certain insurance contracts. Increased interest expenses from the acquisition of Far East Medical Vietnam and the cessation of projects in Singapore also contributed to the expected loss. The hospital operator will disclose further details of its financial performance on or before Feb 14.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
FV Hospital in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, is owned by Thomson Medical Group.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid easing monetary policy settings and Trump tariff remarks; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Friday, January 24, amid easing monetary policy settings by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and US President Donald Trump's comments on lower interest rates and tariffs. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,804.26. Notable movers included Singtel, which rose 2.9%, while Sats fell 2.3%. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC declined 0.7%, 0.3%, and 0.1%, respectively.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Keppel signage is pictured in their office in Singapore July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: China firms boost shareholder returns via dividends and buybacks
summary: China firms are boosting shareholder returns through increased dividends and buybacks, driven by Beijing's push for corporate governance reforms and directives to pension and mutual funds to invest in domestic stocks. The dividend yield of Chinese companies reached 2.8% at the end of 2024, the highest in eight years, as corporations distribute dividends and deliver stable returns to institutional investors. This aligns with the government's objectives in a bleak and uncertain economic environment.

images.alt_text: Chinese equities have been under pressure in recent months amid fears over a prolonged economic slowdown.
Big state-owned insurance companies will be directed to raise both the size and proportion of their investments in Chinese stocks listed on the mainland and equity funds.
The cost of protecting against swings in the Hang Seng Tech Index is hovering around a four-month low relative to the broader Hang Seng Index.
One of the two structural monetary policy tools the CSRC referred to is a liquidity support facility that allows institutional investors to tap the PBOC for funding for stock purchases.
Goldman recommends investors buy government consumption proxies, emerging market exporters.
Chinese stocks have started 2025 on a weak note as investors brace for higher tariffs that may prolong China’s economic slowdown.

The demand for MRF funds’ surge sheds a light on onshore investors scouring for assets abroad as a recent domestic stock rally deflates and sovereign bond yields fall to historic lows on a dimming economic outlook.

The guidance came as Chinese stocks kicked off 2025 with deep losses on worries that incoming US President Donald Trump would impose hefty tariffs on Chinese goods, heaping more pressure on an already sluggish economy.

site_title: Keppel gets US approval to build SG-US subsea cable amid region’s digital infrastructure push
summary: Keppel has received US approval to build the 20,000 km Bifrost Cable System, the world's first subsea cable connecting Singapore to the US via Indonesia. The project, jointly developed with Edge Cable Holdings USA and Telekomunikasi Indonesia International, is expected to be ready for commercial service in the second half of 2025. CEO Loh Chin Hua said the project will enhance Singapore's strategic position as Asia's leading digital hub and support the region's growing digital economy, generating attractive returns for Keppel and its investors.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
Tailwinds from energy transition, digitisation and AI as well as real estate demand is expected to keep pushing the Keppel forward said CEO Loh Chin Hua

site_title: Singapore’s factory output rises 10.6% in December, beats expectations
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 10.6% year-over-year in December, beating economists' forecasts of 6.2% growth. The key electronics sector saw a 14.3% increase, with some segments expanding, while others contracted. Broad-based growth across all clusters was attributed to frontloading of shipments ahead of potential trade barriers. Manufacturing output fell 0.7% on a seasonally adjusted month-on-month basis, and OCBC chief economist Selena Ling notes uncertainty over sustained frontloading activities.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: Japan Q1 aluminium premium hits 10-year high on stronger overseas prices
summary: Japan's aluminium premium for January to March has reached a 10-year high of US$228 per metric ton, driven by supply fears amid stronger overseas premiums. This marks a fourth consecutive quarterly increase and the highest since 2015. The premium is higher than the previous quarter's US$175 per ton, but below initial offers of US$230-260 per ton from global producers. Supply concerns, including a potential tariff increase on aluminium imports from Canada and Mexico, have pushed premiums higher in Asia, with buyers seeking to secure the metal.

images.alt_text: China’s exports of semi-finished aluminium rose to 5.2 million tonnes - about 7 per cent of the global market - in 2023, according to state researcher Beijing Antaike Information Development

site_title: Hong Kong home prices slip in December, fall 7.1% in 2024
summary: Hong Kong's home prices dropped 7.1% in 2024, with a 0.7% decline in December, marking the fifth consecutive month of price declines. The decline is attributed to higher mortgage rates, easing demand, and a weak market outlook. Authorities introduced measures to support the sector, but housing demand remains soft. Realtors forecast a 5% price rise or fall in 2025, depending on interest rate cuts and trade tensions.

images.alt_text: China Life is one of the country’s biggest state-owned insurers and owns 29.59 per cent of Sino-Ocean, according to its latest annual report.
Eversholt’s portfolio includes 19 passenger fleets as well as freight locomotives.

Country Garden has now been granted an adjournment until May 26 in a court hearing held to gauge the extent to which its debt restructuring is proceeding ahead of a decision on a liquidation petition.

site_title: Oracle, Apple, Google diverge on whether to keep serving TikTok
summary: US tech giants Oracle, Apple, and Google diverge on whether to keep serving TikTok amid a national security law that could impose billions of dollars in fines. Oracle, which provides cloud services for TikTok, has kept the app operational despite a ban, citing a Trump executive order that halted enforcement. Apple and Google have removed the app from their stores, but may relist it if ByteDance executes a "qualified divestiture" by early April. The move highlights the confusion around Trump's order and the uncertainty about TikTok's future.

images.alt_text: Any purchase would have to satisfy the government’s national security concerns over its owner, ByteDance, and its ties to China.
Bidders have already begun circling the social media platform and Trump has endorsed the idea of a deal involving billionaire technology moguls and the US.

site_title: Major Chinese port hit by congestion ahead of holiday, Trump tariff threat
summary: China's Yantian Port, one of the world's largest container ports, is experiencing congestion ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday and potential US tariffs on Chinese goods. The port increased daily container quotas by 15% to 15,000 units, but congestion worsened, causing trucking fees to rise and exporters to lose money. US President Donald Trump's threat of a 10% punitive duty on Chinese imports has driven factories to ship goods ahead of the holiday, exacerbating the congestion. The Chinese commerce ministry has vowed to work with the US to promote stable trade ties.

images.alt_text: Gantry cranes at the Yantian International Container Terminals in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Tesla launches new Model Y in US, Canada, Europe weeks after China
summary: Tesla has launched a new, higher-priced Model Y in the US, Canada, and Europe, weeks after its China release. The long-range, all-wheel-drive variant costs $59,990, 25% higher than its predecessor, and features supervised full self-driving software. Deliveries will begin in March, with the new car offering redesigned exteriors, upgraded features, and a 515km range. This marks the fourth version of the Model Y available in the US market, with the new variant being the most expensive.

images.alt_text: The latest Model Y sports a new light bar that stretches across the front end, similar to Tesla’s Cybertruck, while the taillight is also a full-width light bar.
Tesla’s compensation could even exceed 1 billion euros if it monetises its entire long CO2 position.
Panasonic Energy, which supplies batteries to Tesla as well as other automakers, is a unit of Japanese electronics giant Panasonic.

site_title: HDB resale prices climb 9.7% in 2024; rise is double that of 2023
summary: HDB resale prices rose 9.7% in 2024, driven by strong demand and supply constraints. This is double the 4.9% increase in 2023 and less than the 10.4% gain in 2022. The number of resale transactions increased 8.4% to 28,986, while prices rose 2.6% in the fourth quarter. Analysts expect prices to continue climbing, albeit at a slower pace, amid economic uncertainties and geopolitical tension. The supply of newly MOP flats is expected to remain low, with HDB increasing its BTO supply in 2025.

site_title: Hong Kong’s CKI is said to weigh sale of UK’s £4 billion Eversholt Rail
summary: Hong Kong-listed CK Infrastructure (CKI) is evaluating the sale of UK's Eversholt Rail, a major rolling stock leasing company, potentially valuing it at £4 billion (S$6.7 billion). CKI is working with Rothschild & Co on the review, which could attract infrastructure investors and sovereign wealth funds. A sale would reduce CKI's exposure to the UK, its largest market, and is seen as a strategic move. Deliberations are at an early stage, and a decision may be made against a deal.

images.alt_text: CK Hutchison counts most of its revenue from overseas regions including Europe, the Americas and the Middle East.

site_title: Bank of Japan raises interest rates to highest in 17 years, yen jumps
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) raised interest rates to 0.5% for the first time in 17 years, exceeding market expectations, as it aims to control inflation. The decision was made in an 8-1 vote, with the central bank projecting core inflation to hit 2% for three consecutive years. BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda emphasized the need for gradual rate hikes to avoid overheating the economy. The yen surged 0.8% following the decision, while markets expect further rate hikes in the coming months, with some analysts predicting a 25-basis-point hike by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan (BoJ) governor Kazuo Ueda speaks during a press conference after a two-day monetary policy meeting at the BOJ headquarters in Tokyo on January 24, 2025. The Bank of Japan increased interest rates on January 24 to their highest in 17 years and signalled more hikes to come, sending the yen higher against the dollar. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Retail space rents in central region of Singapore edge up 0.6% in Q4, rise 0.5% for 2024
summary: Retail space rents in Singapore's central region rose 0.6% in Q4 2024, the second straight year of growth. Islandwide, the retail vacancy rate fell to 6.2% in Q4, marking the lowest levels in 10 years. Despite a challenging operating environment, occupier demand remained resilient, driven by new-to-market brands and existing brands expanding their presence. However, retail asset prices fell 1.3% in Q4, reversing from a 1.7% increase in the previous quarter, as investors turned cautious amid a potentially higher-for-longer interest rate environment.

site_title: Tentsuru serves up exclusive tempura omakase for readers of The Business Times
summary: Master chef Daiki Kawaguchi has curated a special tempura omakase menu for BT Club, featuring nine pieces of tempura and a welcome glass of sake. The exclusive menu, called "The Art of Tempura," will be held at Tentsuru, a high-end tempura restaurant in Singapore, on February 22. All ingredients are flown directly from Japan, showcasing Kawaguchi's innovative approach to tempura artistry. The event promises to start the new year on a delectable note, with limited seats available.

site_title: US Supreme Court removes hurdle to anti-money laundering law
summary: The US Supreme Court has put on hold a nationwide injunction blocking the enforcement of the Corporate Transparency Act, an anti-money laundering law that requires businesses to disclose their beneficial owners. The law, passed in 2021, was challenged by small businesses, who argued that Congress overstepped its powers. The court's decision allows the law's enforcement to continue, but its fate remains uncertain, pending a review by President Donald Trump's administration.

site_title: Climate Impact X’s ex-CEO Mikkel Larsen dies at 50
summary: Climate Impact X's former CEO, Mikkel Larsen, died at 50. He was a sustainability pioneer and key figure in the carbon exchange, which launched standardised carbon contracts supporting forest conservation and cookstove projects. Under his leadership, CIX reached a million tonnes in traded and cleared credits. Larsen stepped down as CEO in March 2024 to focus on family, leaving behind a legacy as a visionary leader and champion of nature conservation.

site_title: How to fix democracy? Ancient philosopher Plato may have an answer
summary: Ancient Greek philosopher Plato's work, "The Republic," argues that democracy is flawed because ruling is a skilled trade that not everyone possesses. In a democracy, the majority rules, which can lead to unskilled leaders making bad decisions. However, a more targeted argument is needed to critique democracy. Plato's solution is to nurture the political skills of everyone, making the best use of their talents and experiences, while ensuring fairness in decision-making. This approach could preserve democracy by leveraging the skills of the majority, rather than relying solely on skilled rulers.

images.alt_text: Migrants on a boat arriving at the Canary island of El Hierro. Tens of millions of people are likely to flee Africa and Latin America in the coming years, driven by political and economic challenges and climate change.

site_title: BYD plans to sell plug-in hybrids in Japan
summary: Chinese automaker BYD plans to sell its first plug-in hybrid vehicle in Japan this year, with the goal of expanding its lineup to seven or eight models by 2027. The company, which has a strong presence in China's powertrain technology, will also start selling its fourth electric vehicle in Japan from April. BYD's sales in Japan increased by over 50% last year, with the company aiming to further expand its dealer network in the country. The exact date of the plug-in hybrid's release depends on certification.

images.alt_text: BYD's display at the Singapore Motorshow 2025. Can also be used as generic photo.
The opening of the 2,000 square foot BYD showroom comes after Inchcape was appointed as a distributor of the brand in 2023.
BYD's plant, which is being built at an industrial complex in Subang, West Java, will have a production capacity of 150,000 EV units annually.
BYD manages its supply chain financing through a system called Dilink, which launched in 2021 and, by May 2023, had issued some 400 billion yuan of promissory notes.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit five-week highs as Trump softens tone on China
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached five-week highs after US President Donald Trump expressed a willingness to negotiate with China, potentially easing trade tensions and boosting the currencies. The Australian dollar rose 0.4% to US$0.6312, while the New Zealand dollar added 0.4% to US$0.5703. The news also lifted bond markets, with yields on 10-year bonds easing to 4.673% in New Zealand. Analysts expect a potential interest rate cut in Australia and New Zealand in February, pending a benign inflation reading.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul and Singapore stocks rose while Shanghai and Manila stocks slipped on Friday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent higher at 44,565.07 on Thursday.

site_title: Tiktok’s possible buyers, from Elon Musk to MrBeast
summary: US President Donald Trump has given ByteDance, the Chinese parent company of TikTok, a 75-day extension to find a buyer for the app's US business, allowing it to avoid a nationwide ban. The deadline was initially set for January 19. Potential buyers include billionaire Frank McCourt, tech entrepreneur Jesse Tinsley, and Elon Musk, who has expressed interest in acquiring the app. Trump has also suggested that a US government stake in TikTok could be part of a deal. Other companies, such as Meta, Google, Amazon, and Microsoft, are unlikely to make a bid due to antitrust concerns.

images.alt_text: Entrepreneur Frank McCourt’s Project Liberty advocacy group submitted a bid to buy the US assets of TikTok in early January.
Bidders have already begun circling the social media platform and Trump has endorsed the idea of a deal involving billionaire technology moguls and the US.
The search to find a buyer for TikTok continues after it went dark and was revived later after US President Donald Trump signed an executive order delaying the enforcement of a ban on it by 75 days.

ByteDance plans to spend 40 billion yuan (S$7.45 billion) to acquire AI chips in China in 2025, the Financial Times report said, adding that the company will invest about US$6.8 billion overseas to ramp up its foundation model training capabilities using advanced Nvidia chips.

site_title: LNG firm Venture Global gets US$1.75 billion in year’s biggest IPO
summary: Venture Global, a liquefied natural gas (LNG) firm, raised $1.75 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), pricing its shares at $25 each. The company's market value is now estimated at $60.5 billion, below its original target of $110 billion. Venture Global aims to build a more integrated supply chain and has secured capacity for LNG re-gasification in the UK and Greece. The IPO is the largest energy-sector IPO in the US since 2021, and the company's founders, Mike Sabel and Bob Pender, will retain control with Class B shares.

images.alt_text: The company will add 50 to 100 people to manage the newly acquired fleet of South Korean-built ships and sell the cargoes, Mike Sabel says.

site_title: Sino-Ocean’s Hong Kong wind-up case delayed as UK ruling looms
summary: A Hong Kong court delayed a hearing on Sino-Ocean Group Holding's restructuring agreement with lenders due to a pending UK decision on a debt plan for all creditors. The company's UK case, involving a cross-class cramdown, will determine restructuring terms on a dissenting class of creditors. Sino-Ocean's parent China Life Insurance, a state-owned insurer, owns 29.59% of the company, and the UK judge is set to hand down a decision on January 29.

images.alt_text: Sino-Ocean’s problems are part of the debt crisis that has beset China’s beleaguered property sector.

site_title: Q4 rebound underscores resilient housing demand, but market challenges remain: analysts
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to rise 3-6% in 2025, driven by strong household balance sheets, lower interest rates, and potential benchmark pricing at new launches. Despite a rebound in Q4, full-year price growth moderated to 3.9% in 2024. Buyers may become more discerning due to global uncertainties and ample fresh supply. Rental prices are expected to recover in 2025, with a 2-4% increase, driven by demand outstripping supply in suburban and city fringe areas.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, Keppel DC Reit, Suntec Reit, ESR-Reit
summary: Keppel DC Reit posted a 13.2% increase in distribution per unit for the second-half ended Dec 31, reaching S$0.04902. This is up from S$0.04332 in the previous period. The trust's DPU for FY2024 reached S$0.09451, driven by contributions from a Japan data centre, higher variable rents, and finance income.

site_title: Bifurcation of Singapore office market widens on the back of flight to quality by tenants
summary: The Singapore office market has seen a widening bifurcation between better-quality office buildings and the rest of the market, driven by tenants' flight to quality. Category 1 offices, with median rents of S$12.52 per square foot, outpaced Category 2 offices, with a 4.5% median rent growth in 2024 compared to 1.8% for Category 2. Vacancy rates for Category 1 offices fell to 9.1% in Q4 2024, while Category 2 vacancies remained elevated. Experts predict continued prioritization of high-quality office spaces in 2025, with steady demand recovery expected.

site_title: Gold set for fourth week of gains amid Trump policy jitters
summary: Gold prices rose for a fourth consecutive week amid uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's trade plans, boosting demand for the safe-haven asset. Spot gold edged up 0.2% to $2,760.40 per ounce, while the US dollar weakened after Trump's comments on interest rates. Investors await policy announcements from global central banks, with a 99.5% chance of the Fed keeping rates unchanged. Trump's potential inflationary policies may diminish gold's appeal as an inflation hedge, but the metal remains a safe-haven asset amid market volatility.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held its ground at US$2,755.68 per ounce.

site_title: Thousands flock to see rare, smelly corpse flower bloom in Sydney
summary: A rare corpse flower, nicknamed Putricia, bloomed in Sydney's Royal Botanic Garden on January 24, 2025, for the first time in over a decade. The plant, known as Amorphophallus Titanum, emits a strong odor likened to rotting flesh and attracts thousands of visitors. The bloom lasts only about a day and typically occurs only once every few years. The garden stayed open late to accommodate the crowd, with many people queuing to catch a whiff of the plant's unique scent.

site_title: No major impact from Johor data centres, US export ban: Keppel DC Reit manager
summary: Keppel DC Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported a 13.2% increase in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.04902. The manager attributed this growth to a strong performance despite the potential impact of new data centres in Johor, Malaysia, and the US chip export ban, which are unlikely to affect the company significantly due to differences in workload and market segments.

site_title: Rivian says other automakers ‘knocking on door’ about tech from Volkswagen joint venture
summary: Rivian's joint venture with Volkswagen is in talks with other automakers about supplying software and electrical architecture. Rivian's architecture reduces vehicle weight and simplifies manufacturing, making it attractive to traditional automakers. Rivian Chief Software Officer Wassym Bensaid said "many other OEMs" are interested, but declined to provide names. The joint venture aims to integrate advanced electrical infrastructure and Rivian's software technology for future electric vehicles, with a priority until 2027 to roll out Rivian's smaller SUV and integrate technology in Volkswagen brands.

site_title: UK consumer confidence sinks to lowest for over a year: GfK
summary: UK household confidence has sunk to its lowest point in over a year, according to GfK, with a key sentiment gauge of minus 22 in January. This marks the weakest confidence since before Labour returned to power in 2023. Consumer spending accounts for around two-thirds of GDP, and the decline in confidence is concerning for the economy. A survey found nearly half of Britons expect the economy to worsen in the next three months, with households becoming more pessimistic about their financial prospects and increasing savings.

images.alt_text: Some of the UK’s biggest retailers have warned of a tough period ahead, citing the country’s sluggish growth and a sharp rise in taxes that comes into effect in April.
Net debt stood at £2.83 trillion, 97.2 per cent of GDP in December, levels last seen in the early 1960s.
A survey on Wednesday showed two-thirds of British retailers plan to raise prices this year in response to higher employer social security costs, adding to households’ high living costs.

site_title: JPMorgan boosts Jamie Dimon’s pay to US$39 million after record profit
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon's pay was boosted to $39 million for 2024, an 8.3% increase from last year. The bank's record annual profit of $58.5 billion, a 41% rise in stock value, contributed to the increase. Dimon, 68, has run JPMorgan for nearly two decades and has yet to confirm his retirement plans, with the firm recently shuffling its top ranks. Dimon's pay is now comparable to that of Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon, who also received a $39 million pay boost.

site_title: EV maker Nikola explores sale, partnerships with cash dwindling
summary: Nikola, the electric vehicle maker, is exploring options to address a dwindling cash fund, including potential sales of parts or all of the company. The company has considered bringing on partners or raising new funds. Nikola's shares have lost 95% of their value over the last 12 months and are trading down 22% as of January 23. CEO Steve Girsky is leading the effort to raise money or find strategic alternatives.

images.alt_text: Hindenburg has wiped billions of dollars off companies’ market values, including Indian conglomerate Adani Group after the research firm accused it of “brazen” corporate fraud.

site_title: Australian PM pledges cash for construction apprentices ahead of election
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced a cash incentive of A$10,000 for construction apprentices to attract workers to the industry ahead of the general election. The A$626 million package aims to build 1.2 million homes in the next five years, tackling Australia's unaffordable housing market. This is part of a larger A$15 billion pledge made by the government, including upgrades to a highway, broadband network, and support for the aluminium industry. The incentives are seen as a key election promise to address the cost of living crisis.

images.alt_text: A sign advertising a residential development by Meriton Pty stands outside a construction site adjacent to apartment blocks in the suburb of Eastwood in Sydney, Australia, on Saturday, Jan. 11, 2014. Purchases by locally resident Chinese and those from mainland China are inflating housing bubbles in and around Sydney, where prices in some suburbs have surged as much as 27 percent in the past year. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

site_title: Ice in the sky: Thailand’s fight against air pollution
summary: Thailand's Royal Rainmaking department is attempting to combat severe air pollution in Bangkok by spraying icy water or dry ice into the air to cool it down and disperse pollutants. The technique, known as "ice seeding," has been used twice a day since January 15, but its effectiveness is disputed, with critics arguing it has little evidence to support its claims. The method aims to reduce particulate matter (PM2.5) levels, which have reached eight times the World Health Organization's recommended daily maximum average.

images.alt_text: Buildings shrouded in smog in Bangkok. By Thursday morning, the Thai capital was the sixth most polluted major city in the world, according to IQAi.
Thai exports increased 5.4 per cent in 2024 to a record US$301 billion, the ministry said in a statement.
China has remained at the top of Thailand’s tourist numbers list in the first two weeks of January, comprising almost a sixth of the 1.3 million arrivals.

site_title: OpenAI unveils tool to automate web tasks as AI agents take centre-stage
summary: OpenAI has unveiled a tool called Operator, powered by a model that allows it to interact with on-screen buttons, menus, and text fields. Operator enables users to perform tasks such as creating to-do lists and planning vacations. The tool represents a significant step in AI development, allowing models to use the same tools humans rely on daily, and opens the door to new applications. This move is part of OpenAI's efforts to enhance its chatbot amid intensifying competition.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has made it clear that US leadership in AI is a priority for his administration.

(From left) US President Donald Trump delivers remarks on AI infrastructure next to Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman at the White House, Washington, D.C., Jan 21, 2025.
With o3, OpenAI has demonstrated its technical edge, but its business model remains untested.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on Trump rally, yen steady ahead of BoJ
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday following a record day on Wall Street in response to US President Donald Trump's tax-cut pledge, while the yen weakened ahead of a Bank of Japan interest rate hike. Trump's speech at the Davos World Forum called for lower interest rates and tariffs on key trading partners, sparking concerns about inflation. Despite these concerns, Asian markets followed suit, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney stocks up, while Shanghai and Manila slipped. The Bank of Japan is expected to hike interest rates to 0.5% for the first time since 2008, which could impact the yen's value.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 climbed 0.44 per cent to close at 530.34 points on Thursday, marking its seventh consecutive day of gains - its longest winning streak in over a month.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent higher at 44,565.07 on Thursday.
Across the broader market gainers outnumbered losers 61 to 25.

site_title: Japan factory activity sinks to lowest level in 10 months: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity sank to its lowest level in 10 months, with the au Jibun Bank flash manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 48.8 in January from 49.6 in December. The manufacturing sector has been under pressure due to subdued demand, but the service sector strengthened further in January. The Bank of Japan is expected to raise interest rates to 0.50% on Friday, citing strong domestic wage momentum and price pressures.

images.alt_text: Governor Kazuo Ueda has signalled readiness to raise rates further if broadening wage hikes underpin consumption.
The report came after Nissan and Honda last year said they would begin formal talks on the merger that could potentially create the world’s third-largest auto group.

site_title: Between laughs and ‘disaster’, Trump divides Davos
summary: US President Donald Trump addressed the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, receiving applause and attention from executives, diplomats, and officials. He spoke about his administration's actions and warned about tariffs on allies, repeating his claims of unfair treatment by Europe. While some attendees praised his forceful speech, others criticized him for spreading misinformation. The event was seen as a "special" day, with a long queue forming to watch Trump's address, and reactions ranged from support to outrage, with some calling it a "disaster."

site_title: The market is wrong about US rates under Donald Trump in 2025
summary: The US economy and President Trump's policies are expected to push inflationary expectations higher, leading to a tightening of Federal Reserve policy in 2025. Despite a "hawkish" outlook from the Fed in December, the market is pricing in only 0.4 percentage points of rate cuts, contradicting expectations of four cuts. The resilient US economy, with low unemployment and stable job growth, and Trump's potentially inflationary policies will force the Fed to increase rates from September, potentially leading to a more hawkish stance and a shift in the Fed's inflation target to 3% by 2030.

site_title: Japan’s core inflation accelerates, hits 16-month high in December
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 3.0% in December, the fastest annual pace in 16 months, exceeding market expectations. The Bank of Japan is expected to raise short-term interest rates to 0.5% from 0.25% in its policy meeting. The increase in core CPI was driven by the phase-out of government subsidies and stubbornly high food prices. Governor Kazuo Ueda has signaled readiness to raise rates further if wage hikes underpin consumption, suggesting the central bank may keep raising interest rates to combat inflation.

Japan‘s labour-intensive service sector had long managed to avoid making big or sustained pay raises, by tapping a vast pool of part-time, lower-paid retirees and housewives.
Orders from manufacturers rose 6.0 per cent, while those from “core” non-manufacturers excluding the ship and electricity sectors rose 1.2 per cent.

summary: WTO director-general Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala warns that tit-for-tat trade wars sparked by US President Trump's tariff threats would have catastrophic consequences, predicting double-digit global GDP losses if retaliation reaches 25-60% tariffs, similar to pre-1930s levels.

site_title: China’s frugal tourists avoid far-flung trips over Chinese New Year holiday
summary: Chinese tourists are shifting their travel habits due to economic constraints, opting for domestic trips or nearby destinations in Asia, such as Japan and South Korea, with weakened currencies extending the buying power of the yuan. According to digital marketing firm China Trading Desk, 2.2-2.6 million Chinese tourists are expected to travel globally during the Chinese New Year holiday, a 30% increase from last year but still below pre-pandemic levels. This home-bias shift reflects a desire for value and experiences over luxury spending.

images.alt_text: China's Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang said economic globalisation was not a zero-sum game but a process of mutual benefit and shared progress.
Intense competition between factories has pushed export prices lower and squeezed companies’ profit margins.
China’s record trade surplus of nearly US$1 trillion last year was equivalent to more than 5 per cent of its gross domestic product, the highest level since 2015.

site_title: Microsoft to train one million South Africans on AI skills
summary: Microsoft plans to train 1 million South Africans in AI and cybersecurity skills by 2026, as part of its national skilling initiative. The program aims to benefit all sectors, including companies, government, and youth. This initiative follows Microsoft's training of 4 million Africans in the last 5 years, with a goal to train 30 million Africans in the next 5 years. The company's Africa President, Lillian Barnard, emphasized the importance of providing industry-recognized certifications to equip the youth with global competitiveness.

site_title: Federal judge blocks Trump bid to restrict birthright citizenship
summary: A US Federal judge blocked President Donald Trump's attempt to restrict birthright citizenship, imposing a 14-day halt on the enforcement of the order. The ruling was hailed by states and civil rights groups, who argued that the 14th Amendment to the US Constitution guarantees citizenship to anyone born on US soil, regardless of immigration status. Judge John Coughenour deemed the order "blatantly unconstitutional" and "un-American," citing a 1898 Supreme Court ruling that established birthright citizenship as settled law.

site_title: Crypto’s richest man CZ turns venture capital firm into giant family office
summary: Zhao Changpeng, the billionaire founder of Binance, is turning the venture capital arm of his company into a family office called YZi Labs, with an estimated $10 billion in crypto-related assets. The rebranded firm will prioritize "impact" over returns and invest in AI, biotech, and other areas, with Zhao involved in investment decisions. This move comes after Zhao's release from prison and a fine for failing to prevent cybercriminals and terrorists from trading on Binance. YZi Labs will manage the wealth of Binance co-founder Yi He and Zhao's three children.

images.alt_text: The Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC) alleged that Binance Australia Derivatives offered crypto derivative products to 505 retail investors, about 83 per cent of its local clientele, who were misclassified as wholesale clients between July 2022 and April 2023.
