site_title: Claims against e-wallet players hit nearly half a million dollars in just over a month: financial dispute agency
summary: In just over a month, 16 claims totaling S$441,625.12 were filed against e-wallet providers in Singapore, with a median claim amount of S$1,093.50 and an average claim amount of S$27,601.57. The claims include disputes over fraud, scams, customer service delays, and unauthorized transactions. Thirty-four e-wallet providers have subscribed to the Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre (Fidrec) since December 16, enhancing consumer protection in the digital payments ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng

Scam-related claims rose 62.9 per cent, taking up 38 per cent of all claims handled by the Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre for its latest financial period from Jul 1, 2023 to Jun 30, 2024.

site_title: Country Garden shares surge 11% in resumed trade after nine-month halt
summary: Country Garden's shares surged 11% in resumed trade after a nine-month halt due to delayed financial statements. The company expects to reach debt restructuring terms with creditors by next month, addressing a US$16.4 billion offshore debt crisis. A court granted an adjournment until May 26 to gauge debt restructuring progress ahead of a potential liquidation petition. This move comes after the company defaulted on US$11 billion of offshore bonds in late 2023, deepening China's property sector debt crisis.

site_title: Trump holds off on immediate China tariffs, calls for study
summary: US President Donald Trump has delayed unveiling China-specific tariffs, instead ordering his administration to investigate unfair trade practices globally and assess compliance with a 2017 trade deal. The decision aims to "reversing the destructive impact of globalist, America last trade policy" and may set the stage for future trade duties. Analysts say Trump's tariffs could have a significant impact on the US economy, but some economists are skeptical of their effectiveness in closing the trade deficit or boosting manufacturing.

images.alt_text: China’s record trade surplus of nearly US$1 trillion last year was equivalent to more than 5 per cent of its gross domestic product, the highest level since 2015.
During Trump’s first presidency, his administration imposed new tariffs on Chinese imports that were worth about US$380 billion in 2018 and 2019.
“President Xi and I will do everything possible to make the World more peaceful and safe!” US President-elect Donald Trump wrote in social media.

site_title: From the sublime to the ridiculous, Trump casts himself as a man of destiny in fiery inaugural speech
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a fiery inaugural speech, showcasing both effective rhetoric and divisive rhetoric. He vowed to make America "great again" and claimed divine intervention saved him from an assassin's bullet, casting himself as a man of destiny. Trump signed dozens of executive orders, including plans to collect tariffs from foreign countries, despite previous tariff plans being put on hold. He also promised to deport migrants, change the name of Mount Denali, and seal the Mexican border under a health emergency. Trump's speech was marked by contradictions, including a promise to plant the US flag on Mars and a vow to reclaim the Panama Canal, which he inaccurately alleged China operates.

site_title: Here’s what is known about Trump’s executive orders after swearing-in
summary: US President Donald Trump has issued a flurry of executive orders and directives on his first day in office, aiming to put his stamp on the administration. The orders cover pardons for Capitol rioters, immigration, and criminal pardons, as well as revoking 78 executive actions of the previous administration. Trump also signed orders on energy, climate change, free speech, and regulatory freezes, including a national energy emergency, withdrawal from the Paris climate treaty, and revoking an electric vehicle mandate. Additionally, the president vowed to impose tariffs, slash diversity and inclusion programs, and end transgender rights in the US military and schools.

site_title: Tech billionaires take centre stage at Trump inauguration
summary: US tech billionaires, including Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, and Jeff Bezos, attended Donald Trump's inauguration, with Musk and Bezos sitting at the president's right and left side, respectively. The tech tycoons, who combined have a fortune of over $1 trillion, have been courting Trump since the election, shifting from a hostile response to his first term. Their prominent positions on the inauguration stage is seen as a demonstration of their power and influence, with Zuckerberg having previously been threatened with life imprisonment by Trump.

site_title: Trump’s new memecoin and new crypto token soar on his first day in office
summary: US President Donald Trump's new memecoin, $TRUMP, and his wife Melania's coin, $MELANIA, have surged in market value after his inauguration, reaching over $10 billion and $1 billion respectively. The coins were launched on the Solana blockchain and have raised concerns over ethics and regulatory questions. Analysts predict a 90% probability of a civil lawsuit opposing the coins, and experts warn of the blurring of lines between governance, profit, and influence. The boom in Trump-related crypto ventures comes as he promises to loosen regulations and promote ownership of digital assets.

site_title: TSMC says all its sites operating following Taiwan quake
summary: TSMC, a major chipmaker, reported that all its sites in Taiwan are operating following a 6.4 magnitude earthquake that hit central and southern Taiwan. The company evacuated workers at some sites as a precaution and conducted post-earthquake inspections, confirming the structures are safe. Operations are gradually resuming, with water supply, power, and workplace safety systems functioning normally. TSMC's construction sites were unaffected and continued regular operations following environmental safety checks.

site_title: Unilever’s empire falters in Indonesia amid fierce competition, boycotts
summary: Unilever Indonesia, the London-based consumer goods giant, is battling to reclaim its dominant position in the country's fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) sector. The company's market share slipped to 34% in the third quarter of 2024, down from 38% a year earlier, due to shifting consumer habits, fierce competition, and boycotts linked to the Israel-Palestine conflict. Unilever Indonesia has sold its ice cream business to Magnum Indonesia and aims to streamline operations, boost efficiency, and drive innovation in its beauty and wellness segments. The company faces steep hurdles in regaining its market share and financial standing.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon flags belief in free democracy at trial
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol appeared at an impeachment trial on January 21, marking his first public comments since imposing martial law on December 3. Yoon expressed his belief in free democracy, stating he has lived with this belief since childhood, and hopes the Constitutional Court justices will protect the Constitution. The trial is investigating Yoon's brief and shocking imposition of martial law, which led to Capitol Hill-like rioting in Seoul.

site_title: Trump hold-off on tariffs only a temporary reprieve for markets, analysts say
summary: US President Donald Trump's pause on imposing tariffs on China is seen as a temporary reprieve for markets, but analysts warn that tariffs will still be imposed and the scale of the tariffs is uncertain. Markets reacted negatively to the news, with the US dollar index falling and gold prices rising. Asia markets were mixed, with Chinese stocks ending mostly higher, while Japan's Nikkei 225 and Australia's ASX 200 gained. Analysts expect trade tensions to continue affecting Asia, particularly China, but some countries like Asean and Singapore may benefit from shifting supply chains.

site_title: EU launches new WTO case against China high-tech patent rules
summary: The European Union launched a WTO case against China's rules on royalty rates for high-tech patents, accusing Beijing of pressuring EU companies to lower fees. China's courts set binding worldwide royalty rates, forcing EU firms to give Chinese companies cheaper access to technologies. The EU seeks a level playing field and protection of its high-tech industries. This adds to the escalating trade tensions between Beijing and Brussels, which have seen both sides accuse each other of unfair practices and take tit-for-tat measures.

site_title: China’s worst deflation was in industry as supply glut persisted
summary: China's economy experienced its worst deflation in industry for a second consecutive year, with a 2.3% drop in prices in 2024, the steepest decline among sectors. Entrenched deflation reflects weak domestic demand and robust production, with the gross domestic product deflator expected to decline for the third straight year. Intense competition between factories has pushed export prices lower, boosting overseas shipments and leading to a record $1 trillion trade surplus. The real estate sector also contributed to deflation, but stabilized after Beijing's stimulus measures.

The region's overall GDP forecast was cut to 4.2% from 4.4%, with China's forecast reduced to 4% from 4.3%. The company is seeking a three-year facility to refinance $10.1 billion in unsecured loans maturing in 2025 and 2026, potentially leaving fewer assets for unsecured bondholders. site_title: Trump signs TikTok order delaying ban of app
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order to delay the enforcement of a ban on popular short-video app TikTok by 75 days, allowing his administration to determine the "appropriate course of action" with respect to the app. The order directs the Justice Department to issue letters to companies working with TikTok stating there has been no violation of the statute and no liability for any conduct. Trump stated the order gives him the "right to sell it or close it," implying he needs to make a decision on the app's future.

Trump's swearing-in marks the second time in US history that a president has lost office and returned to power, cementing his place in the Republican Party as a transformational figure.

Many workers, like Nguyen Thi Hiep, who spent 16 years in the factories, are now re-entering rural society, bringing with them valuable skills and experience.

Premium Automobiles, featuring Deepal, Xpeng, and Zeekr, showcased the strategic merits of introducing multiple brands to cater to diverse market segments. summary: HSBC is exploring options for its consumer banking business in Australia, including a potential sale, as part of its CEO Georges Elhedery's plan to simplify its operations. The UK lender is likely to retain its commercial banking operations to serve global corporate clients. If sold, the consumer banking business could attract other major banks in Australia, which has seen consolidation in recent years. Deliberations are at an early stage, and a decision could come later.

site_title: Panama opens audit of Chinese port operator while Trump threatens to take canal back
summary: Panama launched an audit of the China-linked Panama Ports Company, which controls two ports near the Panama Canal. The audit aims to verify compliance with a 25-year concession granted to the company in 1998. President Donald Trump has threatened to take control of the canal, claiming China is medling in the waterway, but Panama's government has denied any Chinese presence. The audit will also examine revenue sharing and ensure efficient use of public resources. The move comes as Trump reiterated his claim of Chinese control in his inaugural address.

The EU is concerned about losing to China and the US in new technologies and wants to boost its competitiveness, develop capital markets, and reduce energy prices. Officials emphasize the need for unity and cooperation among EU governments to strengthen the European economy, protect industry, and develop new technologies such as artificial intelligence.

site_title: Bank of Korea cuts growth view on political instability, Trump impact
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) has cut its growth forecast for South Korea's economy to 0.2% or lower in the last quarter, down from 0.5%, due to political instability triggered by President Yoon Suk-yeol's martial law declaration and concerns over US trade policies under Donald Trump. The central bank now projects 1.6-1.7% growth for 2025, below previous forecasts of 1.8-1.9%. The decision comes ahead of scheduled interest rate reviews and follows the BOK's previous rate cuts at the end of last year.

images.alt_text: The political turmoil and Jeju Air plane crash “led to contractions in domestic consumption and construction investment, likely causing the fourth-quarter growth rate to fall well below the November projection”, Bank of Korea said.

site_title: Top Ikea retailer says in Davos that tariffs could drive prices higher
summary: Ikea's CEO, Jesper Brodin, stated that fewer trade tariffs would benefit the company, as it would allow for more harmonized costs and pass on savings to customers. Despite a 5% drop in sales last year, Brodin expressed optimism about the outlook, citing a shift in consumer behavior towards bigger investments. He emphasized the need for international cooperation to combat climate change, stating that adapting to mitigate its effects can be economically beneficial.

site_title: Oil dips as market awaits Trump’s executive orders on energy
summary: US oil prices dipped 0.8% on Monday after President Donald Trump declared a national energy emergency, promising to fill up strategic reserves and export American energy globally. Trump vowed to rapidly approve new oil, gas, and electricity projects, and sign an executive order focused on Alaska. The move is expected to have a significant impact on the energy market, with analysts predicting potential price gains or losses. Trump also promised to impose tariffs and overhaul the trade system, adding to market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures dropped 16 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$80.63 a barrel by 0453 GMT on Monday after closing down 0.62 per cent in the previous session.

site_title: Chinese solar panel makers close plants, scale back production in Malaysia as US tariffs bite
summary: Chinese solar panel makers, including Jinko Solar, Risen Energy, and JA Solar Technology, have shut down or scaled back operations in Malaysia due to US tariff hikes, squeezing margins and eroding competitiveness. The move is expected to impact 5,000 workers and lower tax revenue from the sector. Economists predict China will diversify to supply other rapidly growing markets, such as the South-east Asian region and Africa, in the long run, as the US becomes less of a major market. Malaysia's government agencies are exploring alternative uses for idle manufacturing facilities to spur the country's transition to renewable energy.

summary: China may increase its coal imports from Mongolia as demand flattens and Russia's share shrinks. In 2024, Mongolia's coal exports to China rose 19% while Australian shipments surged 60% due to improved diplomatic relations. China's coal imports from Australia and Mongolia drove record purchases last year, while Russian cargoes fell. Mongolia aims to cement its position as a thermal coal supplier to China with improved rail connections, potentially doubling coal cargoes.

site_title: Energy trade – missing link to sustainable development in South-east Asia?
summary: South-east Asia, a vulnerable region to climate change, faces a critical juncture as energy demands are projected to triple by 2050. Despite having 40-50 times its current renewable energy potential, the region lags behind others in transitioning to renewables due to infrastructure gaps, inconsistent policy support, and limited financing. Regional energy trade and investment can break down systemic barriers and unlock sustainable development, with projects like the Lao PDR-Thailand-Malaysia-Singapore Power Integration Project offering a blueprint for cross-border collaboration. Strong government action, robust policy frameworks, and regional cooperation are vital to overcoming inertia and ensuring a "just transition" that protects vulnerable communities.

site_title: South Korea seeks tougher delisting rules to remove zombie firms
summary: South Korea is tightening its delisting rules for poor-performing companies, aiming to improve the quality of its stock market. The government plans to increase the market capitalization requirement for stocks to remain on the Kospi exchange from 5 billion won to 20 billion won in 2026 and 50 billion won in 2028. Firms with a market cap below 100 billion won will face higher minimum revenue requirements, set to increase to 30 billion won by 2029. The goal is to remove low-performance companies effectively and boost market valuations, addressing structural problems that have hindered the market's growth.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit two-week highs on Trump tariff delay
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached two-week highs on Tuesday after US President Donald Trump delayed imposing new tariffs. The Aussie dollar rose 0.1% to US$0.6282, while the kiwi dollar gained 1.6% to US$0.5683. Local bonds also gained, with Australia's three-year government bond futures rising 3 ticks to 96.11. The US dollar fell 1.1% to 7.2611 yuan, providing relief to the yuan. Market analysts expect the delay to be temporary, but some see it as a positive sign for the markets.

site_title: How Trump’s policy agenda impacts emerging markets
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's policy agenda is expected to impact emerging markets through tariffs, trade, interest rates, and capital flows, potentially leading to an initial increase in inflation and a strong US dollar. Emerging markets, including Asia, Latin America, and Europe, will be affected differently due to their diversified economies and varying exposures to trading partners. While there are potential tail risks, cautious optimism exists for emerging markets fixed income, particularly in countries with sound fundamentals and a willingness to cooperate with US immigration policy, such as Mexico.

site_title: Bitcoin falls from record in volatile inauguration day trading
summary: Bitcoin fell from a record high of $109,241 on inauguration day, closing at $103,700 amid heightened volatility in the crypto market. US President Donald Trump's pledge to make the US the world's crypto capital and his backing of a strategic Bitcoin stockpile have boosted investor confidence. Memecoins, including the Trump token, also surged, with some industry executives viewing the move as a positive step for the industry. However, others expressed concerns about the tokens' questionable intrinsic value and high volatility.

site_title: Chinese investors pile into Bridgewater-style funds, eyeing Trump return
summary: Chinese investors are rushing to launch Bridgewater-style funds, seeking to mitigate volatility during Donald Trump's second US presidency. Bridgewater's "All Weather" strategy, which helped shield Chinese clients from the Sino-US trade war, has seen a 37% return last year and has prompted a dozen rival hedge funds to launch similar products. Local players such as SHQX Asset Management and Shanghai Luoshu Investment are also launching similar strategies, with global hedge fund Man Group preparing to offer a similar product to mainland investors.

site_title: Banks play matchmakers in private credit shift toward high grade
summary: Private credit firms are partnering with banks to offer tailored, high-grade debt deals to top-tier clients, bypassing regulatory constraints that limit banks' ability to take on risk. The potential scope for private high-grade asset-backed loans is estimated to surpass $30 trillion. This shift is helping banks find partners with billions in funds, and private credit is seen as a tool for traditional lenders to enhance their return on equity, with some analysts warning that it could eventually chip away at banks' position as the primary go-between.

images.alt_text: Asia’s private credit market is also much less mature and more nuanced with each country presenting a different risk profile.

site_title: South Korea's Yoon shuns questioning, as supporters face charges over court rampage
summary: South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol refused to be questioned by investigators on Monday, amid a probe into whether he committed insurrection. Yoon's supporters faced charges over a violent rampage on a court building, with 66 people detained and more to be identified. The unrest comes amid South Korea's worst political crisis in decades, which has rattled the country's economy. Security was increased at the Seoul Detention Centre and Constitutional Court, where Yoon is being held as a pre-trial inmate.

images.alt_text: A blue van believed to be transporting impeached South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol leaves the Seoul Western District Court after a hearing in Seoul on Jan 18, 2025, as the court weighs whether to extend Yoon's detention.

site_title: UBS sets new record in Singapore Book of Records with 60-metre long tapestry
summary: UBS Singapore has set a new record in the Singapore Book of Records with a 60-meter-long tapestry commemorating the country's 60 years of independence. The tapestry was made from over 400 kg of textiles collected from a donation drive and excess fabric was donated and recycled. The record-breaking achievement marks the bank's third consecutive year as the founding and lead partner of ART SG, an event that promotes art and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Khairulddin Wahab's installation at Art SG.

Young Jin Yee, co-head of UBS Global Wealth Management Asia Pacific and Country Head UBS Singapore, with Care Corner students and UBS staff volunteers embarking on the
60-metre long tapestry as part of the “Art for All” programme.
Hilmi Johandi’s history-based paintings at Ota Fine Arts, one of the 116 galleries participating in Art SG.

site_title: Trump’s second act in the White House: Expect the unexpected on inauguration day
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump will be inaugurated as the 47th President on January 21, with Vice President-elect JD Vance. The ceremony will take place in the Capitol Rotunda, a change from the traditional West Front location, due to extreme weather forecast. Approximately 1,000 attendees will be present, while millions more will watch via TV or digital platforms. Despite the venue change, the event will still feature familiar traditions, marking a significant departure from outdoor celebrations. Trump's inauguration comes after his surprise victory in the November 5 election, where he defeated Kamala Harris.

site_title: Middle East ceasefire is a humanitarian and economic boon
summary: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas has been implemented, marking a humanitarian success after tens of thousands of innocent people were killed or injured in the war. The deal has the potential to boost the regional and global economy, alleviating energy market volatility and reducing the risk of inflation. The agreement may also lead to the reconstruction of Gaza, requiring an estimated $40 billion to $50 billion over 10 years, and could pave the way for the India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor. However, the ceasefire's collapse remains a significant risk, with tensions in the region remaining high and trust low.

images.alt_text: Gold is used as an inflation hedge but higher interest rates dampen its appeal.
What will come next in Gaza remains unclear in the absence of a comprehensive agreement on the post-war future of the enclave, which will require billions of dollars and years of work to rebuild.

site_title: Houthis say US and UK ships can safely take Red Sea passage
summary: Houthis announce they will stop attacking US and UK vessels in the Red Sea area in response to the Israel-Hamas ceasefire agreement. As of January 19, ships belonging to US and UK individuals or entities are no longer subject to sanctions, allowing for a gradual return to the Red Sea trade route. However, ships wholly owned by Israeli individuals or entities remain banned. The Houthis warn that any aggression against Yemen by the US, UK, or Israel would lead to restrictions being reinstated, and a gradual restoration of shipping operations may take several months to stabilize.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk on the beach as a container ship crosses the Gulf of Suez towards the Red Sea before entering the Suez Canal, in El Ain El Sokhna in Suez, east of Cairo, Egypt April 24, 2017. REUTERS/Amr Abdallah Dalsh/File Photo

site_title: No day-one tariffs but Trump plans trade overhaul, official says
summary: US President Donald Trump did not impose tariffs on Monday, despite weeks of speculation about his first-day actions. Instead, he plans to issue a broad trade memo that directs federal agencies to evaluate US trade relationships with China, Canada, and Mexico. The memo will assess Beijing's compliance with its 2020 trade deal with the US and the status of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, but will not announce new tariffs. This approach has driven a relief rally in global stocks and currencies, with relief expressed by industry groups and trade lawyers in Washington.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's swearing-in marks just the second time in US history that a president lost the office and managed to return to power - a comeback cementing his place within the Republican Party as an enduring, transformational figure rather than a one-term aberration.
Brent crude futures closed lower by 64 cents, or 0.8 per cent, at US$80.15 in early settlement on Monday due to a US public holiday.
The wider crypto market beyond Bitcoin was mixed, including gains for the likes of Ether and XRP.
US president-elect Donald Trump at a rally on Jan 19, the day before his inauguration.
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam and PM Lawrence Wong have congratulated United States President Donald Trump on his inauguration.
“Now we see people returning to bigger investments like wardrobes, kitchens, and so on,” said Jesper Brodin, CEO of Ingka Group.

site_title: Who’s who in Donald Trump’s Cabinet line-up
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet lineup is shaping his agenda for his second term. Key figures include his administration's priorities, such as trade policies, economic growth, and international relations. Notable mentions include Citigroup's forecast of a 1,150 target for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026 and the potential seizure of assets by the Malaysian government. Additionally, Thailand's court is expected to clear its prime minister's daughter in an ethics case, while the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row. These developments indicate a complex and dynamic global landscape.

site_title: What to do with your CPF funds after the Special Account closure
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Special Account (SA) for Singaporeans above 55 has been closed, transferring funds to the Ordinary Account (OA). Members can now choose from three original intentions: keeping SA funds for immediate drawdown, transferring to Retirement Account (RA) for higher payouts, or treating SA as a reserve fund. Investing OA funds is not recommended unless necessary, as the interest rates are lower than previously available. Members should consider their financial goals and risk tolerance before making a decision, as their hard-earned CPF money is at stake.

images.alt_text: The Central Provident Fund Board says it is a key pillar of Singapore’s social security system.

site_title: Singapore to play ‘pivotal role’ as financial flows shift to South-east Asia amid trade tensions: Citi
summary: Singapore is poised to play a "pivotal role" in South-east Asia as foreign direct investment shifts amid uncertainty from trade tensions, particularly under the Trump 2.0 trade policy. The city-state will serve as a hub for foreign investment, with Chinese companies relocating their treasury centres to Singapore. Trade flows from emerging markets, such as India, Chile, and Brazil, to the region are expected to increase, creating new opportunities.

images.alt_text: US trade tariffs on imports from China could hit Malaysia's burgeoning electronic chips market, says Malaysia's Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Zafrul Aziz.
Singapore’s open economy may be affected by the uncertainty that comes from the imposition of additional tariffs and the pace at which they are implemented
During Trump’s first presidency, his administration imposed new tariffs on Chinese imports that were worth about US$380 billion in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 20)
summary: Singapore Polytechnic graduates can now receive subsidized training to become Chartered Accountants under a S$6 million initiative. Marine stocks have been booming, with analysts predicting continued growth for the sector. City Developments Ltd's Kiwi unit has made an offer to delist Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand. Despite improvements in board diversity, Singapore-listed companies still lack cultural background and global experience diversity. Singapore shares ended lower ahead of Donald Trump's presidential inauguration, with the STI down 0.1%.

site_title: Julius Baer sees end to S&P 500’s bull run; positive on US banks
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer predicts the end of the S&P 500's bull run, forecasting zero interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve in 2025 due to inflation concerns. However, the bank is positive on US banks, citing a robust economy and potential easing of regulatory hurdles under a Trump presidency. Julius Baer also sees value in Chinese and Indian equities, with stabilizing home sales in China and a growing working-age population in India making them attractive investments.

site_title: Nomura to rebuild FX options business stung by wave of exits
summary: Nomura Holdings is rebuilding its FX options business after a wave of staff exits, with at least eight traders leaving the division in the past year. The remaining staff, led by David Leigh, will focus on enhancing the firm's client franchise and trading capabilities globally. Despite the departures, Nomura sees the business as profitable and will continue to invest, according to a spokesperson. The move aims to bounce back from a setback in the FX options market.

images.alt_text: Japan’s biggest brokerage had completed most of those steps by March, including structural changes at its wealth management business at home.
Shares of Nomura opened lower in Tokyo trading on Friday, falling as much as 2.7 per cent.
Nomura has said that it will announce if there is any possibility of a material impact on its financial results from the fallout of this incident.

site_title: President Tharman, PM Wong congratulate Trump on his inauguration
summary: Singapore President Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Prime Minister Lawrence Wong have congratulated US President Donald Trump on his inauguration, highlighting the strong ties between the two countries. They noted the robust cooperation in fields like economy, innovation, and security, and expressed their commitment to deepening the partnership in the years to come. The US is recognized as a crucial pillar of global stability, security, and innovation, and Singapore looks forward to working closely with the incoming administration to strengthen their bonds and explore new opportunities for closer cooperation.

site_title: China’s BYD to complete US$1 billion Indonesia plant by year-end: executive
summary: China's electric vehicle maker BYD aims to complete its US$1 billion plant in Indonesia by the end of 2025, with a production capacity of 150,000 EV units annually. The plant, built at an industrial complex in Subang, West Java, will support BYD's ambition to dominate the Indonesian market, where Japanese automakers are popular. BYD has sold 15,429 units in Indonesia in 2024, with 36% market share in battery-based EV sales, and plans to introduce more models this year to book rapid growth in sales.

images.alt_text: BYD manages its supply chain financing through a system called Dilink, which launched in 2021 and, by May 2023, had issued some 400 billion yuan of promissory notes.
BYD has already launched in Japan and is set to be joined by Geely Automobile Holdings in South Korea as early as next year.
Grab on Wednesday announced its partnership with BYD to expand its electric vehicle fleet in South-east Asia.
The rise of BYD as a best-selling car brand stands in contrast to the turmoil facing a growing number of legacy auto giants.
The factory has become a symbol of China’s growing influence in the South American nation and an example of a closer relationship between both countries.

site_title: Singapore Reits need to stay relevant by scaling up and owning more good domestic assets
summary: Singapore's Reits need to scale up and own more high-quality domestic assets to remain a leader in the Reit space. The government could consider a stamp-duty waiver for the transfer of properties into existing listed trusts or trusts eyeing a public listing. Scaling up is crucial for listed entities to attract institutional investors, and existing trusts can benefit from increasing their portfolio size and trading liquidity. Tax transparency treatment and incentives, such as a stamp-duty waiver, could also encourage property owners to inject their assets into listed trusts, propelling the growth of the Singapore Reit market.

Last month, Keppel DC Reit launched an EFR exercise, seeking to raise around S$1 billion, including S$600 million from a private placement and S$300 million from a preferential offering.

site_title: Poly grads can now receive subsidised training to become chartered accountants under S$6 million programme
summary: Singapore Polytechnic graduates from any discipline can now access subsidised training to become Chartered Accountants (Singapore) under the S$6 million Polytechnic Pathway Programme. The programme covers SCAQ-related fees and provides learning support for up to two years after graduation. Upon completion of the foundation programme, candidates can advance to the professional programme and qualify as a Chartered Accountant (Singapore). The initiative aims to expand the pipeline of candidates pursuing the professional accountancy qualification, with over 110 polytechnic graduates currently enrolled.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Generic photos for stories related to manpower, the future of work after COVID-19 and the complex impact of COVID-19 on work-life balance.
The Accountancy Workforce Review Committee’s report lays out strategies to make the industry more appealing to graduates and mid-career professionals.

Annual new enrolments have exceeded 1,000 for the first time, says Isca president Teo Ser Luck.

site_title: Xi calls for proactive macro policies to keep China momentum
summary: President Xi Jinping urged China to implement proactive macroeconomic policies to maintain growth momentum amidst potential new US tariffs. China's economy grew 5.4% in the last quarter, exceeding forecasts, and Xi reiterated the need for high-level scientific and technological self-reliance. The country is set to announce its 2025 growth goal in March, with a target likely to be similar to last year's. Xi's call comes as the US economy is set to return to a post-Trump era, potentially affecting global trade and China's growth.

site_title: Trump’s trade challenge
summary: US President Joe Biden's parting gift to Donald Trump is a new trade verdict that argues for US government support for the maritime, logistics, and shipbuilding sectors in the face of Chinese competition. The investigation, issued by the US Trade Representative, alleges that China has used non-market practices to dominate the global maritime industry. The report highlights China's hukou system, which distorts the labor market and favors state-owned enterprises. The Biden administration hopes to test Trump's focus on industrial policy and US workers, while also addressing national security concerns.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady as Trump inauguration centre stage
summary: European stocks closed flat on Monday at 523.87 points, after adding over 2% in the past week. The flat close was due to investors' uncertainty about US President-elect Donald Trump's stance on tariffs, despite expectations that he may refrain from increasing them. The automobile sector, sensitive to tariff news, rose 1.1%. The Stoxx 600 reached a three-month high earlier in the week due to anticipation of Trump's potential tariff policy.

images.alt_text: “Buckle up for the upcoming shock and awe,” warns Phillip Securities’ head of research, Paul Chew, noting widespread expectations of major tariff announcements.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 67 to 48.

site_title: Your cup of morning Joe is about to shock you
summary: A growing deficit between demand and supply due to bad weather in Brazil and Vietnam, the world's two largest coffee producers, is expected to lead to double-digit inflation for coffee drinkers in early 2025. Wholesale green coffee beans have reached their highest level since 1977, with the arabica variety nearly touching $3.50 a pound in December. Retail coffee prices are expected to rise by 20-25% in the next few months, with the potential for even higher prices if the supply chain reaches a breaking point.

images.alt_text: A worker picks coffee berries at a plantation in Anolaima, Colombia December 4, 2024. REUTERS/Luisa Gonzalez

site_title: Xiaohongshu shows Americans a whole new social media world
summary: Xiaohongshu, a Chinese social media platform, has seen a significant surge in US users, with over 700,000 new registrations in a week, becoming the most downloaded social network in the US on Apple's App Store. This "protest migration" is a response to the impending TikTok ban in the US, creating an unprecedented cultural exchange between Chinese and American internet users. The move marks a shift in how Americans interact with Chinese social media platforms, and its impact on the global social media landscape is expected to be significant.

site_title: South Korea unveils huge export finance support, citing Trump risks
summary: South Korea has unveiled a US$250 billion support package for its exporters, citing the risk of possible tariffs by incoming US President Donald Trump. The package includes allowing the Export-Import Bank of Korea to provide 50 trillion won over the next five years to industries such as semiconductors and batteries. The move comes amid protracted political uncertainty in the country, including the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol, which has led to a decline in the won's value and a spike in unemployment.

images.alt_text: Trump and the trade hawks he’s enlisted are broadening their scope in what threatens to be a more prolonged and unpredictable trade war than during his first presidency.

site_title: Singapore SME bloodletting will continue as China investors pump US$73 billion into Singapore
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face a "red ocean" of foreign competition with deep pockets and integrated supply chains, warns ASME president Ang Yuit. Despite rising business costs and labor shortages, rents and wages are unlikely to fall. Chinese investors have pumped US$73 billion into Singapore, with many setting up operations in the country, giving a quick economic boost but ultimately weakening local SMEs. ASME aims to help SMEs expand globally through collaborative projects and partnerships, and is calling for increased funding for innovation, grants, and streamlined grant application processes.

site_title: LME approves warehousing in Hong Kong, a gateway for metals to China
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) has approved Hong Kong as a warehouse delivery point, aiming to boost access to mainland China, the world's largest metals consumer. The move could lead to increased LME trading volumes, but industry sources note that high storage costs in Hong Kong may deter international warehouse firms from listing warehouses in the territory. Despite concerns, LME CEO Matthew Chamberlain believes the proximity to China will make it economically attractive for investors, and no financial incentives have been agreed with the Hong Kong authorities.

images.alt_text: Vitol is ramping up its presence in global metals markets after a previous foray into base metals ended in 2014.

Unlike other metals such as nickel, cobalt and lithium – which have their fortunes mainly tied to electric vehicle batteries – copper has a wider role in the green transition, said Marex' Edward Meir.
Visible inventories of metals such as copper and aluminium have risen significantly this year.
The LME has been working to identify sites that could rival those that have long benefited from proximity to China including Singapore, Malaysia and Taiwan.

site_title: Hong Kong chief justice admits difficulty hiring overseas amid tensions
summary: Hong Kong's top judge, Andrew Cheung, admitted difficulty hiring overseas judges due to geopolitical tensions, which have led to a spate of foreign judges departing the Court of Final Appeal. About half of the court's 15 overseas justices have stepped down since 2019, mainly due to Beijing's national security law. Despite this, Cheung emphasized the court's independence and quality, with six overseas judges remaining. The exits have raised concerns among foreign companies about the future of Hong Kong's rule of law, a key factor in its status as a global financial hub.

images.alt_text: The government first introduced the idea to take back part of the site in 2019 to help solve the city’s housing crisis as the property market was overheated.

site_title: YZJ, Seatrium stocks ride wave of upcycle orders; smooth sailing ahead seen for marine sector
summary: Singapore marine stocks, including Yangzijiang, Seatrium, and Marco Polo Marine, have seen significant growth over the past year, with analysts attributing factors such as an industry upcycle, supply crunch, and rebound in global demand for shipbuilding and offshore support vessels. Analysts predict continued growth for the sector, driven by increased demand for greener vessels and LNG carriers, as well as exploration and production activity in the oil and gas industry. Shipbuilders in Singapore, Korea, and China are expected to benefit from the trend, with many having their capacity fully booked until 2027.

images.alt_text: Industrial stocks listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw substantial gains in 2024 while performance across other sectors such as banking and real estate varied.

site_title: Malaysia and EU resume free trade negotiations
summary: Malaysia and the European Union have resumed free trade negotiations 12 years after talks were halted due to disagreements over the palm oil industry. The resumption of talks is expected to unlock benefits across multiple sectors of Malaysia's economy, strengthening the global supply chain and bolstering exports to the EU market. Key sectors to benefit include manufacturing, green energy, and palm oil exports. The EU aims to build a partnership on robust commitments on labor rights and climate and environmental protection. The agreement is seen as a significant step for Malaysia's economy, particularly ahead of its leadership role in ASEAN in 2025.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim presenting the 2025 national budget document at Parliament.

site_title: From potential to impact: Harnessing AI in 2025
summary: Mid-market organisations in Asia-Pacific are poised to lead the AI revolution in 2025, but their success depends on their ability to measure AI's value holistically, balance short-term gains with long-term vision, and prioritize trust. Key trends include redefining AI's return on investment, adopting a cohesive AI roadmap, and building trust through data governance and employee upskilling. To succeed, leaders must address these challenges head-on, rethink success metrics, and foster an environment that encourages calculated risks and open communication, ultimately shaping the future of Asia-Pacific's rapidly evolving digital economy.

site_title: Young Chinese turn to AI pets for emotional relief
summary: In China, a growing number of young people are turning to AI-powered "smart pets" to combat social isolation, with sales expected to reach $42.5 billion by 2033. These AI companions, such as BooBoo, a fluffy robot that uses AI to interact with humans, are designed to provide emotional relief and alleviate feelings of loneliness. Many users, including 19-year-old Zhang Yachun, report feeling a sense of companionship and comfort with their AI pets, with some even using them as a substitute for human friends.

images.alt_text: Robots that can move heavy objects, automate repetitive or dangerous tasks or replace humans in service jobs are drawing investors.

site_title: Singapore listcos improve board age and gender diversity, but not cultural background mix: study
summary: Singapore-listed companies have improved in board diversity over the past five years, with advancements in age, gender, industry experience, and board independence. However, progress in cultural background and global experience remains stagnant. The 2025 Singapore Board Diversity Index found that only 14% of companies met the criteria for cultural diversity and 12% had international experience. Despite these challenges, companies have taken steps to improve diversity, such as capping independent directors' tenure at nine years, and 43 companies met the diversity standards across four or more categories.

site_title: What opportunities lie ahead for Asean following the upgraded FTA with China?
summary: Asean and China have completed the upgraded Asean-China Free Trade Area (ACFTA) 3.0 negotiations, marking a significant milestone in their economic collaboration. The trade between the two blocs is projected to achieve a compound annual growth rate of 6.6%, surpassing the global average. Asean is well-placed to capture strategic opportunities to ascend the global value chain and accentuate its position as a key supply chain hub. The full implementation of ACFTA 3.0 will lower barriers, facilitate interoperability, and reduce operational costs, ultimately establishing a more robust supply chain.

images.alt_text: Chinese EV manufacturer BYD has already made significant ventures into Thailand. The EV sector is expected to be of interest to Chinese investors.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, January 20, 2025
summary: Asian markets tracked Wall Street and Europe's rally after US President Trump's talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping, while Indonesia opened its domestic carbon market to global investors. Thailand is searching for a central bank chief with 'modern ideas'. YZJ and Seatrium stocks rose due to upcycle orders, with the marine sector expected to have smooth sailing ahead.

site_title: Asia markets wary as investors brace for barrage of executive orders from Trump 2.0
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has vowed to issue executive orders within hours of his swearing-in, focusing on immigration, energy, and government reform. This has sparked uncertainty in Asia, with investors adopting a cautious stance ahead of the inauguration. Markets in China, Hong Kong, and Japan rose, while Singapore's Straits Times Index ended lower. Economists warn of potential tariffs and trade war risks, which could impact Asian currencies and equities. The timing and magnitude of Trump's tariffs remain uncertain, with some predicting a 60% tariff on China and 10-20% on the rest of the world.

US President-elect Donald Trump addresses supporters at a rally at Capital One Arena in Washington, DC, Jan 19, 2025.

Crypto market struggled over the weekend, including a dip in the largest token, Bitcoin, and a shaper retreat for second-ranked Ether.

site_title: Malaysia's December exports rise 16.9% above forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports rose 16.9% in December, exceeding forecasts, with a trade surplus of 19.2 billion ringgit. For the full year 2024, exports increased 5.7% to 1.5 trillion ringgit, while imports rose 13.2% to 1.37 trillion ringgit. Exports to the US and Taiwan reached all-time highs, with Taiwan becoming Malaysia's fourth-largest trading partner.

site_title: Bitcoin hits record above US$109,000 awaiting Trump
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$109,241 on January 20, ahead of US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration, as he prepares to deregulate the cryptocurrency sector. This surge follows Trump's nomination of cryptocurrency backer Paul Atkins to head the US securities regulator. Trump previously launched his own cryptocurrency, $TRUMP, which saw its market capitalization soar to several billion dollars. Bitcoin has surged since Trump won the presidential election in November, surpassing US$100,000 for the first time in early December.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump is planning to release an executive order elevating crypto as a policy priority.

site_title: Malaysia Airports buyout offer extended to Feb 4
summary: A takeover offer for Malaysia Airports Holdings by a consortium of Khazanah and BlackRock's Global Infrastructure Partners has been extended to February 4, with the consortium now holding 86.51% stake. The offer price of RM11 per share remains unchanged, valuing the airport operator at RM18.4 billion. The consortium expects to declare the offer unconditional and remove Malaysia Airports from Bursa Malaysia indexes once the acceptance condition is met, which is expected to be above 90%.

images.alt_text: A consortium led by Malaysia’s sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd and state pension fund the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) announced on May 15 an offer to take Malaysia Airports Holdings private, in a deal that would value the airport operator at US$3.9 billion.

site_title: Japan’s Seven Bank enters Malaysia, sharpens 7-Eleven’s edge amid stiff competition
summary: Seven Bank, the banking arm of the 7-Eleven Group, has launched its ATM service in Malaysia, marking the group's fourth overseas venture. The move aims to expand Seven Bank's presence in South-east Asia and complement 7-Eleven's operations amid fierce competition. The initial rollout will feature 100 ATMs in key cities, with plans to install more in 7-Eleven's convenience stores and high-traffic areas. The partnership is expected to boost foot traffic and enhance sales for 7-Eleven Malaysia, which operates 2,611 convenience stores across the country.

Berjaya Corp founder Vincent Tan highlighted the company’s dedication to a world-class high-speed rail, enhancing connectivity, driving Malaysia’s economy, and promoting green mobility.
The court ruled in April that Truong My Lan must compensate Saigon Commercial Bank a total of 674 trillion dong – an amount Lan appealed against but still committed to repay “at all costs”.

site_title: Last 2 BTO projects delayed by Covid-19 completed
summary: The National Development Minister Desmond Lee announced that all 92 Build-To-Order (BTO) projects delayed by the Covid-19 pandemic have been completed, with over 75,800 flats delivered over the last five years. The last two projects, phase two of Punggol Point Cove and Kempas Residences, were completed in January 2025. Despite some delays, the Housing and Development Board (HDB) has implemented measures to prevent such occurrences, including tighter coordination, digitalization, and standardization.

site_title: China leaves benchmark lending rates unchanged
summary: China left benchmark lending rates unchanged for a third consecutive month, keeping the one-year loan prime rate at 3.1% and the five-year rate at 3.6%. The decision was expected due to a weakening yuan, which has limited Beijing's efforts to ease monetary policy. The decision follows a review of the yuan, which has been facing renewed depreciation pressure, and a narrowing interest rate margin that limits the scope for monetary easing.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street and Europe rally after Trump-Xi talks
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday following a Wall Street rally and record-breaking European day, boosted by positive talks between Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Hong Kong led gains, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Sydney also rising. Despite concerns about Trump's trade policies and potential tariffs, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq ended at fresh records. Trump and Xi vowed to improve ties, with the Chinese leader hoping for a "good start" to relations. The news provided some relief to markets, which are now bracing for significant policy shifts under Trump's presidency.

site_title: China steps up Vanke intervention as developer woes deepen
summary: Chinese officials are taking steps to stabilize operations at China Vanke, a major property developer, amid liquidity stress and questions surrounding its top executive. The Shenzhen government, where Vanke is based, held a closed-door meeting to discuss the company's stability and plans to bring in new auditors and financial advisors to assess its balance sheet. The move comes as Vanke faces a wall of debt repayments and widening losses due to the slowdown in the real estate market, with its largest shareholder being a state-controlled firm.

site_title: Airbus puts Seletar Aerospace Park facility up for sale at S$20 million upon Kelley Aerospace’s exit
summary: Airbus has listed its Seletar Aerospace Park facility in Singapore for sale at S$20 million after Kelley Aerospace vacated the building due to a rent dispute. The three-storey property, located on a 189,338 sq ft plot, features a hangar, simulator halls, ancillary office, and 75 car park lots. The sale comes with a 30-year tenure lease that can be renewed for an additional 20 years, making it suitable for an aviation business or aircraft maintenance, repair, and operation (MRO) activities.

Seletar Aerospace Park, which will be home to Collins Aerospace's new site, is home to more than 70 industry players.

site_title: Great Eastern cuts coverage for A and B1 policyholders who upgrade to a higher-class ward
summary: Great Eastern Life (GE) has reduced coverage for its integrated shield plans (IPs) for policyholders who opt for higher-class treatment. Previously, 70% of bills were covered, but now 35% will be covered for those who choose private hospitals over public ones. The change affects all policyholders who recontracted with GE from October 2024, while those who receive treatment in their original class of treatment remain unaffected. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has approved the changes, citing the need to balance costs and benefits in the insurance system.

site_title: ComChest launches SGShare campaign to encourage regular donations to those in need
summary: ComChest launches SGShare, a national giving campaign to encourage regular donations to communities in need. Participants can pledge a small donation every month, with one-time contributions also accepted. The campaign aims to enable Singaporeans to express solidarity in a more accessible and sustainable manner, with ComChest working with government agencies, businesses, and community groups to create more platforms for contributions. The campaign expands on ComChest's existing Share programme, which has about 260,000 donors and more than 2,000 supporting employers, and aims to increase sustainable funding for social service programmes and initiatives.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, CDL, Frasers Property, Sabana Reit, ValueMax
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed non-binding memoranda of understanding with the Odisha state government, expected to have minimal impact on earnings per share. City Developments Limited plans to acquire Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand, aiming to delist and privatize the company. Frasers Property launched The Orie, selling 86% of units at an average price of S$2,704 per square foot. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust faces an extraordinary general meeting due to concerns over significant costs incurred by the Reit. ValueMax issued 233,436 warrants, bringing its ordinary shares to about 868.4 million.

site_title: China faces Trump’s return just as reliance on exports soars
summary: China is facing a repeat of the economic uncertainty from Donald Trump's presidency, with the country's reliance on exports soaring to a record $1 trillion in 2024. The US is expected to impose 10% tariffs on Chinese goods, potentially threatening China's growth driver. To counter this, China will likely boost government borrowing to support its ambitious economic growth target. Companies may redirect goods to other markets, but there's no guarantee other nations won't impose their own tariff barriers. China's efforts to diversify its trading relationships and boost domestic consumption may be the most effective tool to mitigate the impact of a new trade war.

images.alt_text: China's capital account is under pressure partly because of a decline in foreign direct investment flows into the country.

site_title: Oil slips as investors eye Trump move on Russian export curbs
summary: Oil prices dropped 0.2% to $80.63 a barrel on Monday, offsetting concerns about supply disruptions from harsher sanctions on Russia's energy sector. US President-elect Donald Trump is expected to relax curbs on Russia's energy sector in exchange for a deal to end the Ukraine war, potentially easing tensions and boosting oil prices. Analysts note that recent price gains could be short-lived, and investors are watching for the impact of a cold snap in Texas and New Mexico on US oil production.

site_title: Vietnam plans tax breaks, fee cuts to lure overseas investors
summary: Vietnam plans to introduce tax breaks and fee cuts to attract overseas investors, aiming to boost its stock market and ensure sufficient capital inflows. The country's main stock exchanges have been asked to expedite the introduction of a new trading system to speed up settlement. The reforms, including streamlining account-opening rules and requiring English disclosures, are part of efforts to make Vietnam more attractive to foreign funds. The country's benchmark VN Index has slipped 2.8% over the past three months due to concerns about US tariffs, but a potential emerging-market status could attract $5 billion to $6 billion of capital inflows.

site_title: Trump’s volatile new memecoin sucks flows, saps wider crypto market
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's new memecoin has disrupted the cryptocurrency market, attracting billions of US dollars in trading volume and stoking concerns about conflicts of interest. The token's market value surged to US$15 billion over the weekend, only to slide below US$10 billion on Sunday. The wider crypto market also struggled, with Bitcoin and Ether experiencing dips. Trump's forays into crypto have raised concerns about speculative demand and potential conflicts of interest, with the president-elect reportedly considering an executive order to designate cryptocurrency as a "national priority".

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has enjoyed strong support from the crypto industry, which has a powerful presence in Washington, backed by well-funded political action committees.

site_title: Singapore dollar set to weaken as MAS pivot comes into focus
summary: Singapore's currency, the Singapore dollar, is expected to weaken to as low as 1.40 against the US dollar over the next year due to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) anticipated pivot to easing monetary policies. The currency is already near a two-year low, and options data shows bearish trading, indicating market expectations of a shift in MAS's stance. Economists predict the pivot, which could be announced on January 24, will be followed by a weakening of the currency.

images.alt_text: Consistent strength in the US dollar may also be driven by a widening growth differential between the US and the rest of the world, especially under Donald Trump’s administration, analysts said.

site_title: Hedge funds kept US$1.8 trillion as fees, half their total gains
summary: Hedge funds have earned US$3.7 trillion in profits since 1969, but nearly half of that, US$1.8 trillion, was taken as fees, leaving clients with only 50% of the gains. This is the first time fees have been quantified, with the industry's expenses rising to 50.4% of gains from 30% in the early 2000s. Critics, including Warren Buffett and Bill Gross, have long described these fees as "unbelievable" and "a giant ripoff."

site_title: Country Garden given more time for debt talks by Hong Kong court
summary: A Hong Kong court granted Country Garden Holdings more time to negotiate with creditors, delaying a hearing on a winding-up petition until May 26. The company, which defaulted on US dollar debt in 2023, expects to reach a deal with offshore creditors in the first half of 2025. Country Garden continues to struggle amid Hong Kong's property crisis, reporting a record loss of 178.4 billion yuan in 2023. The company has not yet secured support from a key bondholder group, despite reaching an understanding with a bank creditor group.

site_title: Asia private credit funding hits eight-year low on China slump
summary: Asia's private credit market has hit an eight-year low due to China's economic slump, with fundraising falling 34% to $5.4 billion in 2024 and capital deployment dipping 67% to $4.6 billion. China's real estate crisis and crackdown on the financial services sector have led to an investor exodus, making the region a harder sell. Despite this, market participants remain optimistic about 2025, with opportunities emerging in countries like Australia, India, and Japan, driven by M&A activity and growing demand for private debt.

site_title: Asia looks to buy more US fossil fuels to make Trump happy
summary: Asian countries, including South Korea, Taiwan, Vietnam, and the European Union, plan to buy more US fossil fuels to appease incoming US President Donald Trump. The move is seen as a way to avoid tariffs and encourage domestic oil and gas development. Trump is expected to order changes to encourage domestic oil and gas development, including lifting a moratorium on fresh licenses for liquefied natural gas (LNG) export projects. This could lead to increased US LNG exports, potentially stabilizing prices for utilities and benefiting projects such as the long-delayed Alaska LNG project.

images.alt_text: The trajectory of electricity demand will be key to determining whether fossil fuel generation begins its decline in 2025.

site_title: Rakuten billionaire justifies mobile arm losses with big AI bet
summary: Rakuten, a Japanese e-commerce pioneer, has reported four years of losses in its mobile arm despite its potential to drive growth through artificial intelligence. Billionaire founder Hiroshi Mikitani believes the telecom arm's data is "extremely powerful" and will help train an AI that will expand the company's business. Rakuten is launching an AI assistant to drive traffic and engagement, and has recruited a former Google expert to develop its AI capabilities. The company aims to become one of the top-tier profitable companies in Japan and plans to deliver 100% smartphone coverage with satellite-based services starting in 2026.

images.alt_text: Rakuten has been tapping financial markets this year to raise fresh funds to pay down its obligations.

site_title: Chinese vice-president meets Musk just before Trump takes office
summary: Chinese Vice-President Han Zheng met with Elon Musk and other US business figures before Donald Trump's inauguration, aiming to set a positive tone for China-US ties. Han urged American companies, including Tesla, to invest in China and contribute to economic relations. The meeting comes amid concerns about China's trade surplus and potential tariffs. Han also met with vice-president-elect JD Vance to discuss cooperation on fentanyl and trade issues, highlighting the need for strengthened dialogue between the two sides.

site_title: Thailand hunts for central bank chief with ‘modern ideas’
summary: Thailand is searching for a new central bank governor with "modern ideas" to work closely with the state, as the current governor's term nears its end in September. The government has been exploring ways to exert greater influence over the Bank of Thailand, with potential candidates including Deputy Governor Roong Mallikamas and former IMF economist Suthapa Amornvivat. Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira emphasized the need for a forward-thinking leader with knowledge of economics and finance to tackle the country's economic challenges and address sparring between the administration and the bank over monetary policy and inflation targets.

site_title: China tech stock hedges cheapen before Trump becomes president
summary: China's tech stocks are bracing for potential changes in US trade policies under President Donald Trump. The cost of protecting against swings in the Hang Seng Tech Index is near a four-month low, while the number of total options outstanding has fallen to a record low. Investors are waiting to see if Trump will act on his threat to impose 60% tariffs on Chinese goods. The Hang Seng Tech Index has lost 17% from its two-year high, and companies in the gauge now trade at 15 times estimated earnings, below the three-year average.

site_title: Mugshot, khaki uniform and solitary cell for South Korea’s detained President Yoon
summary: South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol spent his first night in a solitary cell at the Seoul Detention Centre after a court issued a formal detention warrant to hold him for up to 20 days. The 48-hour detention period for questioning on insurrection charges has ended, and Yoon will face further questioning if grounds are found to believe he may tamper with evidence or witnesses. Yoon, the first incumbent president to be arrested, cooperated with the process, and his lawyers argue the arrest is illegal due to the warrant's jurisdiction and mandate issues.

site_title: Does Acra’s action against Miyoshi’s CEO signal a more proactive stance by the corporate regulator?
summary: Acra fined Miyoshi's CEO Andrew Sin S$22,400 for the company's failure to recognize a large impairment loss in its financial statements for FY2019. The impairment loss was discovered after a review under the Financial Reporting and Surveillance Programme (FRSP), which aims to guide companies towards meeting accounting standards and increase investor confidence. This case highlights Acra's growing proactive stance in regulating corporate actions, following similar actions against other companies such as Hyflux and Noble Group. The regulator's increased powers and penalties may help boost investor confidence in Singapore companies.

site_title: Chinese soda maker Dayao is said to consider US$500 million Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese soda maker Dayao is considering a Hong Kong IPO, potentially raising up to $500 million, as the city's emerging recovery in new listings is expected to continue. Founded in the 1980s, Dayao produces carbonated beverages, juices, and protein drinks with seven major production bases in China. The company's IPO plans come as Hong Kong listings, including those of China-listed firms, raised over $11 billion in 2024, nearly doubling from the previous year. The IPO is part of a growing trend of Chinese companies listing in Hong Kong.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower ahead of Trump inauguration; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares finished Monday slightly lower, closing at 3,807.97 after a 0.1% decline, ahead of US President Donald Trump's presidential inauguration. site_title: Trump says Apple CEO to make large investment in US
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump stated that Apple CEO Tim Cook plans to make a large investment in the US due to the country's big election win. Apple previously announced plans to commit $430 billion in US investments and add 20,000 new jobs over a five-year period in 2021. Trump's comments come ahead of his inauguration on Monday. Apple has not commented on the matter, but Trump's statement suggests a potential boost to the US economy.

site_title: CDL’s Kiwi unit makes NZ$2.25-a-share offer to delist M&C New Zealand
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) is offering NZ$2.25 per share to purchase all shares of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand (M&C), with a maximum aggregate cash consideration of NZ$57.3 million. The move aims to delist and privatize M&C, simplifying CDL's ownership structure. The offer is expected to provide liquidity for minority shareholders at a premium, with the consideration being a 25.1% premium over the market value. site_title: BYD’s supply chain financing masks ballooning debt: GMT
summary: BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle giant, has been masking its ballooning debt through a system called Dilink, which issues promissory notes to suppliers. According to GMT Research, BYD's true net debt is estimated to be around 323 billion yuan (S$60 billion), significantly higher than its reported 27.7 billion yuan. The company's reliance on supply chain financing has made it harder for investors to understand its financial situation, which is unclear due to the lack of details on "other payables". This has raised concerns about BYD's liquidity risk and the impact on its investors.

site_title: Indonesia opens domestic carbon market to global investors
summary: Indonesia has opened its domestic carbon market, IDXCarbon, to global investors, with nine overseas buyers participating in transactions on its first day. The move aims to attract investment and restore Indonesia's position as a major hub for offsets. The exchange has listed over 1.7 million domestic carbon credits for purchase, with plans to add forestry and land use-based credits in March. The government expects to generate billions of dollars in revenue from the carbon sector, with President Prabowo Subianto pledging to accelerate Indonesia's net-zero target by a decade.

site_title: UK home asking prices show biggest early-year rise since 2020: Rightmove
summary: The average price of newly listed homes in Britain rose by 1.7% between Dec 8 and Jan 11 to £366,189, its biggest start-of-the-year increase since 2020. This represents a 1.8% increase compared to the same period last year. Despite a positive start to the year, many buyers are struggling to afford homes due to high mortgage rates. The Bank of England is expected to cut its benchmark Bank Rate from 4.75% to 4.5% on Feb 6, which could help reduce mortgage rates and boost the market.

site_title: Gold dips as Middle East tensions ease, focus on Trump inauguration
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $2,690.81 per ounce as Middle East tensions eased, with investors awaiting Donald Trump's inauguration and uncertainty over the incoming administration's policies. The easing of tensions, following Hamas's release of three Israeli hostages and Israel's release of 90 Palestinian prisoners, reduced safe-haven demand for gold.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: Exploring Singapore’s Budget process
summary: Singapore's budget process is explored in a recent episode of "Lens on Singapore" through a conversation with experts from the OECD and the Singapore University of Social Sciences. The episode delves into the country's fiscal policy and budgeting frameworks, highlighting the importance of transparency and public engagement. The discussion also touches on the future of budgeting, with experts speculating on how the system needs to adapt to changing economic conditions and societal needs. site_title: Japan’s November machinery orders beat forecast on strong factory investment
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 3.4% in November, beating analysts' forecast and signaling a recovery in capital expenditure. Orders from manufacturers increased 6.0%, while those from "core" non-manufacturers rose 1.2%. This marks a second consecutive month of increase, driven by demand for capital investment in response to labor shortages and digitalization. The Bank of Japan is expected to raise interest rates at its policy meeting on January 23-24, but the impact on capital investment is expected to be minor.

site_title: Stock markets are less afraid of war than we imagine
summary: Financial markets are less concerned about regional conflicts than previously thought, according to a commentary piece. Historically, conflicts have not triggered global bear markets, with the exception of World War I and II. Regional conflicts, such as the Ukraine-Russia war and Israel-Gaza conflict, have caused volatility but not bear markets. Stocks are more sensitive to uncertainty from mounting tensions than the conflict itself, with markets often rallying after initial fears subside. The author cites examples of past conflicts, including the Korean War and the Iran-Iraq War, which did not trigger global bear markets.

site_title: ‘Mufasa’ claws its way back atop North American box office
summary: "Mufasa: The Lion King" has regained its spot atop the North American box office, earning an estimated $15.5 million over the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday weekend. site_title: Don’t blink: ‘Asean tigers’ to claw back above 6% economic growth in 2025
summary: Asean economies are expected to experience a boost in growth this year, with the region's fastest climbers, Vietnam and the Philippines, projected to achieve annual economic expansion of 6.25% and 5% respectively. Indonesia is also forecast to grow, albeit with headwinds, while Malaysia is set to become a high-income economy by 2028 with a forecast GDP growth of 5%. site_title: Indonesia’s dire shortage of specialist doctors opens window for investors
summary: Indonesia faces a severe shortage of specialist doctors, with the country needing 29,000 more to meet current healthcare needs. The government has launched a Hospital-based Specialist Doctor Education Programme to address this shortage. The programme allows general practitioners to train and become specialists in-hospital, rather than in classrooms. With the potential to increase the number of specialist clinics, Indonesia could build profitable clinic chains, offering advanced care to patients without the high costs of hospital care. This could also help combat chronic diseases and improve healthcare outcomes.

site_title: TikTok return draws scrutiny of Trump’s, Beijing’s stance
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has pledged to delay enforcement of a ban on TikTok, restoring the app's services after a weekend shutdown. Trump plans to sign an executive order granting another 90 days for TikTok to find a US backer, potentially leading to a joint venture under which American owners would purchase 50% of the company. However, the proposal faces challenges, including the requirement for ByteDance to sell the service's US business to a buyer approved by the American government, and skepticism from some Republicans about the app's national security threat.

site_title: Australia’s Star Entertainment reports second-quarter loss
summary: Star Entertainment reported a second-quarter loss of A$8 million (S$6.8 million) before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization, down from an EBITDA loss of A$18 million in the first quarter. The company cited a weaker consumer environment and ongoing remediation activities as factors contributing to the decline in operating performance. Revenue fell 15% to A$299 million, while operating expenses declined 18% to A$52 million. The company's available cash was A$78 million at the end of December.

site_title: Financing costs will come under scrutiny as S-Reits report results amid Trump’s inauguration, interest rate decisions
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are expected to report results amid US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration and interest rate decisions. Industry watchers believe most S-Reits are already facing near "peak" interest rates, with financing costs expected to decline from this year. Analysts will monitor key financial metrics, such as gearing ratios and interest coverage ratios, and watch for asset valuations, which are expected to remain stable despite interest rate volatility. Distribution growth is forecasted to rebound in 2025, with a 3.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) growth over the next two years.

site_title: South Korea’s central bank slashes forecasts over political crisis
summary: South Korea's central bank, Bank of Korea, has slashed its 2025 growth forecast due to the political crisis triggered by President Yoon Suk Yeol's declaration of martial law last month. The crisis, coupled with the Jeju Air plane crash, significantly dampened economic sentiment, leading to contractions in domestic consumption and construction investment. The bank revised its estimate for the fourth-quarter growth rate, projecting a range of 2.0-2.1% for 2024, down from 2.2%, and 1.6-1.7% for 2025, down from 1.9%.

images.alt_text: Several of those involved live-streamed the intrusion on YouTube, showing protesters trashing the court and chanting Yoon’s name. Some streamers were caught by police during their broadcasts.
Embattled leader Yoon Suk-yeol does not accept the legality of the probe by South Korea's Corruption Investigation Office.
Investigators this month said feathers were found on one of the engines recovered from the crash scene, adding that video footage showed there was a bird strike on an engine.

site_title: Former Trudeau ally Freeland enters race to be Canada PM
summary: Former Canadian Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland launched her campaign to replace Justin Trudeau as Liberal Party leader and prime minister, opposing US President Donald Trump's potential threats. Freeland, a former finance minister, accused Trudeau of prioritizing politics over preparing Canada for Trump's administration. Freeland promises "dollar for dollar retaliation" if Trump imposes tariffs, calling them "illegal and unjustified." She becomes a front-runner to replace Trudeau, who may not serve as prime minister for long due to the Liberals' trailing polls and opposition parties' pledge to bring down the government after parliament returns.

images.alt_text: Chrystia Freeland, Canada's former finance minister, during a campaign event in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Sunday, Jan. 19, 2025.
