site_title: Hong Kong weighs raising taxes on top earners for second year
summary: Hong Kong's government is considering raising taxes on top earners for a second year to address budget shortfalls. Officials are exploring options to increase the 16% tax rate on income above HK$5 million or lower the threshold to include more people in the highest tax bracket. The move comes as the city struggles to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic and talent drain, with a focus on targeting expenses and increasing revenue from high-income earners.

images.alt_text: This is the second time US President Joe Biden has extended the programme.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow Wall Street higher on welcome US inflation data
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday following below-forecast US inflation, with Hong Kong, Sydney, and other markets gaining over 1% and Shanghai, Singapore, and Wellington also seeing gains. The inflation data revived hopes for interest rate cuts this year, lifting sentiment and sending the S&P 500 and Dow above 1% higher. Despite caution ahead of Donald Trump's return to the White House, traders are eyeing a reduction in July and expect the Fed to respond with rate cuts, potentially triggering a growth rebound in 2027 and 2028.

images.alt_text: The day’s largest gains came in the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index, which surged by 2.5 per cent to end the day at 19,511.23.

site_title: US tightens controls on advanced chips to curb flow to China
summary: The US has tightened controls on advanced computing semiconductors to curb their export to China, part of a series of actions before President Joe Biden leaves office. The move aims to prevent diversion of tech to China and strengthen US national security. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said the rules will target the People's Republic of China and others who seek to circumvent US laws. This is the latest in a series of curbs on AI chip exports, following recent announcements.

images.alt_text: The software curbs take effect for model year 2027 while the hardware controls come into play for model year 2030.

The new regulations will cap the number of AI chips that can be exported to most countries and allow unlimited access to US AI technology for America’s closest allies, while also maintaining a block on exports to China, Russia, Iran and North Korea.

site_title: Biden extends protections for Hong Kongers in US
summary: US President Joe Biden has extended a two-year protection for Hong Kong residents living in the US, allowing them to stay beyond their visa expiry dates. This is the second time Biden has done so, following a similar extension in 2022. The move is likely to add to tensions between Beijing and Washington, particularly with the incoming Trump administration vowing to confront a "dangerous" China and deter any invasion of Taiwan.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang is touring China at a sensitive time for the company.

Dominated by China hawks and Trump loyalists, the incoming administration threatens to knock off-keel US-Asean relations, often likened to a three-legged stool held up by defence, economic and diplomatic relations.
The equivalent of 451,000 40-foot containers of goods from China landed at US seaports in December, a year-over-year increase of 14.5 per cent.

site_title: UK housing market at risk from bond turmoil, surveyors warn
summary: The UK housing market is facing a "significant headwind" due to elevated government bond yields, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics). Buyer interest fell to 5 in December, the weakest in five months, and property surveyors reduced expectations of home sales and supply. The market is feeling the effects of high mortgage rates and economic stagnation concerns following Chancellor Rachel Reeves' tax-raising budget, with affordability risks further stretched by the bond market sell-off.

images.alt_text: A survey on Wednesday showed two-thirds of British retailers plan to raise prices this year in response to higher employer social security costs, adding to households’ high living costs.

Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer will lay out fuller details of Britain’s approach to AI technology, which is raising complex questions for governments around the world, during a speech later on Monday.
Prices of non-food items fell by 2.4 per cent, a bigger drop than November’s 1.8 per cent decrease.
The five-year UK yield is up about 20 basis points since the budget, and the benchmark 10-year rate has risen around 30 basis points to trade at the highest since October 2023.

site_title: AI roles surface on list of fastest-growing jobs in Singapore: LinkedIn
summary: Singapore's top 15 fastest-growing jobs in LinkedIn's annual report include AI-related roles, such as AI researcher and AI engineer, which have seen significant growth. The list also features roles in the hospitality sector's recovery, including F&B assistant, and sustainability consulting. Despite rising job search challenges, over two-thirds of Singapore professionals are looking to switch roles, with younger generations leading the charge. Key motivators for job seekers include better salary, work-life balance, and growth opportunities, while companies struggle to find the right talent with only 3.4% of applications meeting required qualifications.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The 2025 job market will present both opportunities and challenges.
Pay increments may be preferred, but alternatives such as flexible work arrangements aren't bad options either.
Generic photo people at shenton way traffic crossing. For stories related to Labour, Employment, Wages and Productivity.

site_title: Luxury groups pin hopes on US as China weakness persists
summary: Luxury goods companies, including LVMH and Kering, are pinning hopes on US shoppers to counter China's weakening economy. Despite relying on brisk business from Chinese buyers for decades, US shoppers are expected to drive sales this year. US credit card spending on luxury brands improved in December, rising 1% year-on-year, driven by better sales of leather goods and clothing. The forecasted market weakness in China and potential US tariffs could support the dollar, increasing Americans' purchasing power for European luxury goods.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in San Francisco seek post-Christmas deals.

site_title: US mortgage rates pushing past 7% hint at tough road ahead
summary: US mortgage rates have surpassed 7%, a level that may hinder home purchases, particularly for first-time buyers. High costs and a shortage of affordable listings contribute to the challenging housing market. The US economic strength may limit policymakers' ability to provide substantial interest rate cuts, leaving buyers with increased borrowing costs. Experts, such as Ali Wolf, warn that home values are rising, insurance costs and property taxes are increasing, and affordability relief is unlikely in 2025. This may prolong the tough road ahead for the US housing market.

images.alt_text: Mortgage rates tend to track Treasury yields, which continued to climb in late December after Federal Reserve policymakers projected a slower pace of interest-rate cuts in 2025 amid sticky inflation.
The combination of mortgage rate declines, firm consumer income growth and a bullish stock market have increased homebuyer demand in recent weeks.

site_title: Australia’s jobless rate stays low as hiring gains persist
summary: Australia's unemployment rate remained low in December, rising to 4% as expected, with 56,300 new jobs added, mostly part-time. The economy showed resilience despite elevated interest rates, fueling expectations of a soft landing. The Reserve Bank of Australia may consider cutting rates in April, but the chance of easing in February is seen as low, at around two-thirds. The strong labor market supports the economy's growth, with full-time employment accounting for two-thirds of gains over the past year.

images.alt_text: The survey’s measure of the economic outlook for the next 12 months was flat in December, while the outlook for the next five years edged up by 0.7 per cent.
The RBA will have the December retail sales report, as well as updates on a surprisingly tight labour market before it decides its next move on Feb 18.
Rents are a key input for quarterly inflation data which is due later this month.

site_title: Hour Glass partners non-profit SCWO for Singapore Women’s Hall of Fame exhibition
summary: The Singapore Council of Women's Organisations (SCWO) has partnered with luxury watch retail group The Hour Glass to showcase the 192 women inducted into the Singapore Women's Hall of Fame through a roving exhibition. The event celebrates the 10th anniversary of the Hall of Fame, featuring women from various fields, including advocacy, business, politics, and education. The exhibition includes sections on the lives of women, "Hidden Heroes" highlighting community contributions, and is set to conclude at Tampines Regional Library in February.

images.alt_text: At the POSB Mini Mart, kids could also visit a series of interactive ATMs to learn about money management skills via gamified experiences.

site_title: Property tax should not be conflated with wealth tax
summary: A letter to the editor argues that targeting retired, asset-rich but cash-poor property owners with higher property taxes as a form of wealth tax is unjust and ineffective. The writer contends that such a tax would impose undue financial burdens, disrupt family stability, and fail to achieve meaningful wealth redistribution. Instead, alternative approaches such as progressive income taxes and targeted social programs should be explored to promote a more inclusive society.

site_title: New York City apartment values expected to jump 7.3%
summary: New York City apartment values are expected to rise 7.3% in the upcoming fiscal year, driven by a housing shortage and high interest rates. The market value of the city's over 1 million properties is projected to increase 5.7% to $1.6 trillion, with rental apartment values in Brooklyn expected to lead with a 9.4% jump. Single-family home values are also poised to rise 6%, with homes in Staten Island showing the biggest increase.

images.alt_text: Residential apartment buildings in the Ridgewood neighborhood in New York. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg
A "For Sale" sign is placed in front of a residential property in Washington, U.S., December 15, 2024. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier

site_title: Biden cites threat from ‘extreme wealth’ in farewell address
summary: President Joe Biden warned Americans of a "dangerous concentration of power" in the hands of the ultra-wealthy, citing the threat to democracy and basic rights. In his farewell address, he drew parallels to former President Dwight Eisenhower's warning of a "military industrial complex" and highlighted the need to preserve democratic ideals. Biden criticized successor Donald Trump and his allies, who are drawn from the country's business and financial elite, and expressed concerns about the impact of wealth on politics. He also emphasized the importance of protecting democracy and ensuring accountability.

images.alt_text: Zuckerberg might talk a good talk about how he is no longer going to be caving in to government demands, but he still is caving in — just to different ones.
Meta on Friday said it is ending its diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programmes, including those for hiring, training and picking suppliers, in a memo to its employees.
Under the guise of free speech, Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg doesn't have to worry about whether any of its content is factually correct.
US President-elect Donald Trump has been a harsh critic of Meta and Zuckerberg for years, accusing the company of bias against him and threatening to retaliate once back in office.
Players have long been hungry for news on a follow-up to Nintendo’s hybrid Switch console, which can be handheld or connected to a TV screen.
Robots that can move heavy objects, automate repetitive or dangerous tasks or replace humans in service jobs are drawing investors.

site_title: Going beyond aesthetics into specialised medical care
summary: Beyond Medical Group, a Singapore-based healthcare provider, has expanded from aesthetic services to specialist care, growing to 20 doctors by 2024. The company supports its doctors from a central headquarters, freeing them to focus on quality patient care while retaining autonomy. With a doctor-equity model, medical practitioners have ownership stakes in their practices. The group has achieved significant growth, with compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 21% from 2018 to 2023. Plans include expanding into Cambodia, Vietnam, and Indonesia, and operating its own hospital by 2026.

images.alt_text: VIPs including guest of honour Minister for Education Chan Chun Sing (seventh form left) and E50 Award winners gathering for a group photo at the end of the gala event.
"Winning the award is like a badge of endorsement – that the company has been scrutinised closely on various front", says Chen Huifen, editor of The Business Times.

site_title: Trump State pick Rubio praised in Senate, warns against China reliance
summary: Marco Rubio, President-elect Donald Trump's choice for secretary of state, warned that the US must change course to avoid becoming more reliant on China. In a Senate hearing, Rubio emphasized the need to confront China and promised a robust foreign policy focused on American interests. Rubio's nomination is expected to be confirmed by the full Senate on January 20, as Trump is inaugurated for a second term. Rubio's comments sent a stark message about changes in US policy, with a focus on addressing major international issues, including the war in Ukraine and the US-China relationship.

images.alt_text: The move - part of a series of actions before President Joe Biden leaves office - comes days after US officials announced fresh curbs on AI chip exports, seeking to make it harder for Beijing to access the advanced technology.
This is the second time US President Joe Biden has extended the programme.
One of the biggest drivers of US inflation in December was the energy index, which jumped by 2.6 per cent, accounting for “over” 40 per cent of the monthly increase.
US president-elect Donald Trump threatened to impose sweeping tariffs of between 10 and 20 per cent on all goods entering the United States.
Investors are now betting the central bank is likely to lower its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point this year after cutting it by a full percentage point in the final months of 2024.

Dominated by China hawks and Trump loyalists, the incoming administration threatens to knock off-keel US-Asean relations, often likened to a three-legged stool held up by defence, economic and diplomatic relations.

site_title: Gold hits over one-month peak on Fed rate-cut hopes
summary: Gold prices reached a one-month peak on Thursday, January 16, after data showed US core inflation rose less than expected, raising hopes for further interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. Spot gold was flat at $2,695.84 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 0.2%. Expectations for rate cuts increased, and odds for a 25-basis-point cut at the June Fed meeting rose. The Fed is expected to hold its benchmark rate steady in its next policy meeting on January 28-29.

site_title: Italy and Lufthansa seal ITA Airways deal
summary: Lufthansa has finalized its acquisition of a 41% minority stake in ITA Airways, a state-owned Italian carrier, through a €325 million capital increase. The deal marks the first step in a merger, with Lufthansa's operational control of ITA, and a planned increase to 100% ownership for €829 million. The agreement, approved by the European Commission, will strengthen Lufthansa's position on the American continent and in Africa and Asia.

images.alt_text: Generics of SIA and Scoot：SIA , Scoot, 新航，新加坡航空公司，酷航，Singapore Airlines，飞机，客机。
Recent rocket launches have changed their timing at short notice, which in turn has forced Qantas to postpone flights right before departure.
Twelve flights due to land at Changi Airport (above) and six flights bound for Seletar Airport were redirected.

The South Korean transport ministry, which has been inspecting safety conditions at airlines and airports since the Boeing 737-800 jet crashed at the southwestern Muan airport, announced the move to change the so-called “localiser” structures on Monday.
Delta reported operating revenue of US$15.6 billion, alongside US$843 million in net income in the fourth quarter of 2024.

site_title: Goldman Sachs beats profit estimates; Wells Fargo benefits from dealmaking rebound
summary: Goldman Sachs reported its highest profit since 2021, beating analyst estimates with $11.95 per share in the fourth quarter. The investment bank's shares rose 2.6% before the bell. Wells Fargo's profit also beat expectations, driven by a rebound in dealmaking activity, and its shares rose 3.5%. Banking executives expect stronger dealmaking activity this year, fueled by interest rate cuts and pro-business comments from President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: Best of Singapore Art Week
summary: Singapore Art Week kicks off this weekend with over 130 events across the city, featuring top artists, galleries, and exhibitions. The week includes a flagship fair Art SG, a showcase of excellent works from Richard Koh's personal collection, and a debut art exhibition by Bvlgari in Shanghai. The event also includes a range of food and cultural experiences, including a new location for Spanish restaurant Binomio. The week is expected to be a "mega feast for the eyes" for art lovers.

site_title: TSMC drives record investment into US, Japan in China decoupling
summary: Taiwanese companies, led by TSMC, invested a record US$48.6 billion in the US and Japan in 2024, with US$14.1 billion going to the US. This represents a surge in foreign direct investment due to supply-chain shifts resulting from tech rivalries and worsening cross-strait ties. In contrast, new investments into China rose only slightly to US$3.65 billion, accounting for 7.5% of total overseas spending, the lowest in data since 1991. The Biden administration's efforts to revitalize American chip manufacturing appear to be working.

images.alt_text: The strong showing from Taiwan’s largest company bolsters expectations that big tech companies from Alphabet Inc to Microsoft will continue to build and upgrade metacentres at a rapid clip to propel AI development.
TSMC is expected to report sales growth of 36 per cent for the December quarter, with a gross profit margin at 58.3 per cent, the highest since 2022.

site_title: Canada readies tariffs on US$105 billion of US products if Trump hits first
summary: Canada has drawn up a list of C$150 billion (S$143 billion) of US-manufactured items that could be hit with tariffs if US President-elect Donald Trump imposes tariffs on Canadian goods. The list is a draft and would only be implemented if the US moves first. Canada imported C$487 billion worth of US goods in the 12 months to November, and retaliatory tariffs would cover nearly a third of the value of these imports. Canadian leaders, including Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Premier Doug Ford, have agreed to work together to respond to possible US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Even as anxiety about tariffs grows, further interest rate reductions are expected to come in time for the crucial spring home-selling season.
If Greenland's population, which enjoys the right of self-determination, seeks political independence, it's unlikely that they would put the island up for sale.
Justin Trudeau will remain in the country’s highest political office until members of his party choose his successor on Mar 9.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation steady at 3.8% in December
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation remained steady at 3.8% in December, matching market forecasts. The corporate goods price index, which measures prices companies charge each other, rose 3.8% from a year earlier. The Bank of Japan will consider raising interest rates at its policy meeting, citing inflationary pressure from rising raw material costs, with Governor Kazuo Ueda signaling the intention to take borrowing costs higher.

site_title: China, Sri Lanka agree to more investment and economic cooperation
summary: China and Sri Lanka agreed on 15 cooperation documents, including economic and technological development, aligning China's 'Belt and Road Initiative' with Sri Lanka's 2030 digital economy blueprint. The agreements were signed during President Xi Jinping's meeting with Sri Lankan President Anura Kumara Dissanayake in Beijing. The move aims to boost investment and economic cooperation between the two countries, with specific deal details not disclosed.

images.alt_text: In this photograph taken on September 14, 2024, a couple sits at the Colombo Port City Marina Park in Colombo. Sri Lanka's economic collapse was partly blamed on struggling high-debt Chinese mega-projects, but candidates in September 21 presidential election are banking on at least one of them to buck the trend. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP) / To go with 'Sri Lanka-Vote-Economy-China', FOCUS

site_title: Shimao gets court approval to hold vote on restructuring plan
summary: Shimao Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, received a Hong Kong court's approval to hold a vote on its US$11.5 billion restructuring plan. The company plans to issue new US dollar notes and mandatory convertible bonds to restructure existing debt. Creditors holding 80.72% of debt principal have signalled their support for the proposal. A court hearing to sanction the debt plan is scheduled for March 13. The approval comes after a liquidation petition was filed by CPYM Link Investment, complicating the restructuring path for Shimao, which defaulted in 2022.

images.alt_text: Sunac China Holdings, one of the first major developers to restructure its offshore debt, said last week that it can’t rule out a second restructuring.

Shimao said on Friday CPYM Link Investment had filed a liquidation petition against the company in the Hong Kong high court regarding a 258 million yuan (S$48.3 million) cross-border loan guarantee provided by the property developer.
Shimao plans to seek a court order early next year to hold a creditor vote on the plan.

site_title: Malaysian glove makers poised for US growth but broader tariffs may upend optimism
summary: Malaysian glove makers are poised to enter the US market, benefiting from Chinese brands facing higher tariffs. However, a potential Donald Trump presidency could raise global tariffs, potentially hindering growth. Chinese brands are also shifting focus to European and Asian markets, adding competition for Malaysian manufacturers. Analysts predict a mixed outlook for the industry in 2025.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Top Glove is optimistic about the recovery of the glove industry and expects orders to continue flowing in.

site_title: Thailand eases visa rules for professionals, wealthy foreigners
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved changes to visa rules to attract skilled professionals, investors, and wealthy foreigners. The changes include scrapping the minimum annual income requirement for wealthy global citizens, reducing the minimum revenue requirement for companies sponsoring visa applicants, and expanding the list of target sectors for highly skilled professionals. Long-term resident visa holders can now bring in more dependants, including parents, and no longer face restrictions on the number of dependants. The changes aim to boost the economy and position Thailand as a global hub for investment and high-potential talent.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand move to block crypto betting site Polymarket
summary: Singapore and Thailand have blocked access to prediction markets platform Polymarket, citing unlawful gambling. Singapore's Gambling Regulatory Authority blocked the site in December, while Thailand's law enforcement is preparing a similar ban. Polymarket's use of cryptocurrency for trades and bets led to the restrictions. The move follows regulatory scrutiny, including restrictions in France and Taiwan, and an ongoing inquiry by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

images.alt_text: An illustration featuring U.S. President-elect Donald Trump holding Bitcoin is displayed outside a cryptocurrency exchange store after Bitcoin soars above $100,000, in Hong Kong, China, December 5, 2024. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Qatar, US announce Gaza truce, hostage release deal
summary: Qatar and the US have announced a ceasefire and hostage-release deal between Israel and Hamas, aiming to bring a permanent end to the war in Gaza. The deal, which includes the release of 33 hostages, including civilians, and the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Gaza's densely populated areas, is seen as a significant step towards peace. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed hope that the details would be finalized tonight, while US President Joe Biden hailed the agreement as a "toughest" negotiation of his career. The deal is expected to pave the way for a permanent ceasefire and humanitarian aid to Gaza.

images.alt_text: The package also includes small-diameter bombs and warheads, according to Axios.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaks during a press conference in Jerusalem, Israel, Dec 9, 2024.
Posters of hostages kidnapped during the Oct 7, 2023, attack by Hamas. Israel's response to the attack has weakened the ability of Iran to assert its position in the Middle East.

site_title: German chemical company sets up Singapore hub, partners PSA for its push into Apac
summary: Munzing Group, a German specialty chemical company, has set up a regional head office in Singapore as part of a 40-million-euro push into the Asia-Pacific region. The office will support production sites in Malaysia and Australia, and handle regional sales offices. Singapore's strategic location and port made it an attractive location for the company, which produces chemical additives for industrial applications, particularly in construction.

images.alt_text: Tan's appointment follows EDB's announcement in November 2024 that managing director Jacqueline Poh will be stepping down.
Saudi Global Ports was formed in 2012 and operates container terminals in King Abdulaziz Port on the country’s east coast.

site_title: Boost market with public money or implement ‘value-up’ programme? Maybe just do both
summary: Singapore's stock market is struggling with delistings outpacing new listings, despite the Straits Times Index's strong performance last year. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong has cautioned against relying solely on public sector money to shore up the market, instead suggesting a more holistic approach that includes commercial capital and streamlining regulations. A review group led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore is studying measures to strengthen the market, including the potential use of public funding and a "value-up" program, similar to South Korea's, to encourage companies to address undervaluation and unlock growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, January 15, 2025
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed performance on Wednesday, with traders closely monitoring US inflation data and earnings. The rupee's slump could delay a potential interest rate cut, while the yen rose on speculation of a BOJ rate hike. Grab partnered with BYD to expand its electric vehicle fleet across South-east Asia. Meanwhile, the Ministry of Health (MOH) renewed Cordlife's licence for one year, leading to a 10.3% increase in shares.

images.alt_text: Pixgeneric / SGX logo on June 25, 2024. Tags: SGX; finance; investment; money; finance; Singapore; ST PHOTO: AZMI ATHNI
Tokyo the biggest loser as traders returned from a long weekend to play catch-up with Monday’s sell-off.

Cordlife said: “The company is committed to meeting all applicable regulatory requirements and compliance measures, before considering the full resumption of operations in Singapore.”

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, ESR Reit, GuocoLand
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Scoot carried 3.6 million passengers in December 2024, a 7.1% increase from the previous year. Total passenger carriage for 2024 was 39 million, a 12.7% increase. ESR Real Estate Investment Trust (ESR Reit) agreed to sell a Tuas industrial building for S$9.9 million, representing a 1.5% premium to its current valuation. The sale is expected to be completed in Q1 2025 without impacting ESR Reit's net asset value or distribution per unit.

site_title: TikTok ban won’t be the end of the world, but what if its replacement is worse?
summary: The US is set to ban TikTok on January 19 unless it's sold to an American buyer by then. However, given TikTok's parent company ByteDance's reluctance to divest, a sale seems unlikely. The ban's impact may be mitigated if TikTok thrives outside the US or if its addictive algorithm's negative effects on mental health and attention span prompt a reevaluation of its role in society.

The entrance hall of the Xiaohongshu headquarters building in Shanghai. The platform leans heavily towards apolitical content such as lifestyle, travel, beauty and food topics.

site_title: US consumer inflation rises in December but underlying pressures ease
summary: US consumer inflation rose for a third straight month in December, driven by a 2.6% jump in the energy index, but underlying pressures eased with the core inflation measure coming in slightly below expectations at 3.2%. The Federal Reserve may pause rate cuts, with a 97% chance of holding interest rates between 4.25-4.50% at the next meeting. The news boosted stocks and led to lower yields on US Treasuries, benefiting consumers.

images.alt_text: Investors are now betting the central bank is likely to lower its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point this year after cutting it by a full percentage point in the final months of 2024.
The equivalent of 451,000 40-foot containers of goods from China landed at US seaports in December, a year-over-year increase of 14.5 per cent.
US president-elect Donald Trump threatened to impose sweeping tariffs of between 10 and 20 per cent on all goods entering the United States.

site_title: Singapore maritime breaks new records for arriving traffic, box throughput, fuel sales
summary: Singapore has achieved new records for vessel arrival tonnage, container throughput, fuel sales, and total tonnage of ships under its flag in 2024. The records were set amidst geopolitical conflicts and strained global supply chains, according to Minister of State for Law and Transport Murali Pillai. Total business spending by key maritime companies increased 8.3% to S$5.2 billion in 2024. Despite the challenges, Singapore remains the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Construction of Tuas Port

Singapore’s ports moved a record total of 27.43 million twenty-foot containers in the first eight months of the year, up 6.4 per cent on the same period in 2023, according to Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore data.
The commissioning of new berths in Tuas is one of the measures Singapore is taking to mitigate port congestion.
PSA starts to use the first of three new berths at Tuas on Monday.
Global port congestion has reached an 18-month high, with 60 per cent of ships waiting at anchor located in Asia, maritime data firm Linerlytica said this month.
Overall vessel arrival tonnage in Singapore – beyond container vessels, including bulk carriers and tankers – grew 4.5 per cent on year, to 1 billion GT in the first four months of 2024.

As at May 21, there were 50 ships at Singapore's port and 23 at anchorage, Linerlytica data showed.
Yemen’s Houthi rebels began their attacks on merchant vessels in the Red Sea in mid-November, forcing major liners to make detour via South Africa instead.

A cargo ship is seen past gantry cranes at the Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore on November 22, 2024. site_title: Canadian home sales slow as buyers await more rate cuts
summary: Canadian home sales slowed in December, dropping 5.8% from November, as buyers awaited further interest rate cuts from the Bank of Canada. Despite the decline, the fourth quarter was the strongest in 20 years, with total transactions up 10% from the third quarter. Economists expect the central bank to cut interest rates to 2.5% by mid-2025, which could boost sales in the spring. The benchmark home price rose 0.3% to C$723,600, while the national average home price is expected to increase 4.7% this year.

images.alt_text: Justin Trudeau will remain in the country’s highest political office until members of his party choose his successor on Mar 9.

site_title: Europe: Shares log best day in four months after US data
summary: European stocks rose 1.33% to 515.02 points, snapping a three-day losing streak, after the US released inflation data showing core inflation rose 3.2% and annual inflation rate was 2.9%. The rate-sensitive real-estate sector surged 3.3% and financial stocks gained 2%, boosting the Stoxx 600. Traders now expect close to 40 basis points in rate cuts from the Federal Reserve this year. European government bonds fell, providing a tailwind for equities.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. US stocks powered higher on the back of optimism over the technology giants, signaling that Wall Street is set to rebound from the four-day slump that marked the end of 2024. site_title: GuocoLand bags S$1.2 billion in green loans
summary: GuocoLand has secured S$1.2 billion in green loans from DBS and OCBC, under its green finance framework. The two facilities, worth S$1.1 billion and S$105 million, will be used to refinance GuocoLand's integrated mixed development, Guoco Midtown, and luxury residential development, Midtown Bay. This brings GuocoLand's total green financing to S$5 billion, making it one of the largest green lenders in the industry.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
The two state land sites at Dairy Farm Walk and Tengah Garden Avenue is expected to yield around 1,400 new private homes.
As problems in China's real estate sector persist, local property groups may do well to shift their overseas focus to Asean.
The perpetual securities were issued under GuocoLand's S$3 billion multicurrency medium term note programme.

site_title: Temasek among parties keen on Blackstone’s US$3 billion sale of Bob Dylan, Adele song rights: sources
summary: Blackstone, one of the world's biggest asset managers, is exploring the sale of its US$3 billion music rights portfolio, including songs by Bob Dylan, Adele, and Ariana Grande. Several firms, including Apollo Global Management, Warburg Pincus, and Temasek Holdings, have expressed interest in the assets. The sale is seen as a response to the growing demand for music rights, with global recorded music revenue more than doubling over the last decade to reach US$28.6 billion in 2023. Blackstone acquired the portfolio in 2017 for about US$1 billion.

site_title: US firms concerned about Trump tariff, immigration plans: Fed
summary: US businesses are concerned about the economic impact of President-elect Donald Trump's proposed tariffs and immigration plans, according to the Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" survey. Trump threatened to impose tariffs of 10-20% on all goods, and mass deportations of undocumented immigrants, which could negatively affect the economy. Despite concerns, businesses reported an overall increase in economic activity in late 2024, with modest price increases expected in 2025, potentially driven by higher tariffs.

images.alt_text: Dominated by China hawks and Trump loyalists, the incoming administration threatens to knock off-keel US-Asean relations, often likened to a three-legged stool held up by defence, economic and diplomatic relations.
A member of Trump's family on a private visit to Greenland.
The equivalent of 451,000 40-foot containers of goods from China landed at US seaports in December, a year-over-year increase of 14.5 per cent.

site_title: Oil rallies, settles at multi-month high on US crude draw, Russia sanctions
summary: Oil prices surged to a multi-month high on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures rising 2.64% to $82.03 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 3.28% to $80.04 a barrel. The increase was driven by a large draw in US crude stockpiles and potential supply disruptions caused by US sanctions on Russian oil. A ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas also limited gains. The US Energy Information Administration reported the lowest US crude oil inventories since 2022, while the International Energy Agency warned of potential Russian supply disruptions.

images.alt_text: Xie Chun’s four charges were abated following a pre-trial conference on Jan 9.
Oil tankers off Singapore.
Brent futures fell US$1.09, or 1.35 per cent, to settle at US$79.92 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Trump’s folly? Greenland for critical minerals is utter nonsense
summary: US president-elect Donald Trump wants to buy Greenland, citing its potential as a source of critical minerals. However, the article argues that the island is not a viable commodity superpower, citing a 50-year history of exaggerated claims about its mineral resources. The island's geology is an extension of the North American continent, and its deposits are not as extensive as claimed. The article concludes that the US has better places to flex its diplomatic muscle if it is serious about securing mineral supplies.

images.alt_text: If Greenland's population, which enjoys the right of self-determination, seeks political independence, it's unlikely that they would put the island up for sale.

The Old Colonial Harbour of Nuuk, Greenland is pictured on August 31, 2024. Greenland, an icy land whose rugged landscapes are bewitching, wants to attract more tourists, a paradox for a territory that is particularly vulnerable to global warming and whose geographical isolation means that many people have to take planes to get there. (Photo by James BROOKS / AFP) / TO GO WITH AFP STORY
An Arctic saga of profound absurdity in the age of Trumpism

site_title: US Federal Reserve trio express confidence inflation will continue to slow
summary: US Federal Reserve officials expressed confidence that inflation will continue to slow, citing fresh data showing a decrease in consumer prices in December. The officials, including New York President John Williams, Richmond Fed President Tom Barkin, and Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee, welcomed the data as evidence that inflation is trending towards the Fed's 2% target. They cautioned, however, that more time is needed to achieve this goal and that policymakers must remain restrictive to prevent inflation from rising again.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s favoured inflation gauge rose 2.4 per cent in the year to November, and 2.8 per cent minus food and energy, each above the central bank’s 2 per cent target.
The Fed will also face an array of new policies from the incoming Trump administration – on tariffs, immigration and taxes – that could blow their forecasts off course.

site_title: TikTok prepares for US shutdown from Sunday, sources say
summary: TikTok plans to shut its US app from Sunday, when a federal ban could take effect, unless the Supreme Court intervenes. Existing users can continue using the app, but new downloads will be blocked. Users will see a pop-up message directing them to a website with information about the ban. Additionally, users can download all their data before the ban. The shutdown is expected to impact one-third of the 170 million US users, with some potentially stopping access to the platform.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk's account on X. Since the billionaire acquired the social media platform, he tweaked its terms of service to allow users’ data to train his AI models and reportedly ordered major changes to X’s algorithm to increase his own influence.
Last week, the US Supreme Court seemed inclined to uphold the law, which was passed in April, despite calls from US President-elect Donald Trump and lawmakers to extend the Jan 19 deadline.

site_title: ESR Reit to sell Tuas industrial building for S$9.9 million
summary: ESR Reit has entered into a contract to sell an industrial building in Tuas, Singapore for S$9.9 million, a 1.5% premium above its valuation of S$9.7 million. The divestment, expected to be completed in Q1 2025, is not expected to impact the Reit's net asset value or distribution per unit. The sale proceeds will be used to repay borrowings, finance acquisitions, and fund working capital requirements. Upon completion, ESR Reit's portfolio will consist of 71 properties across Singapore, Japan, Australia, and property funds.

ESR Cosmosquare OS1 Data Centre in Osaka, Japan. The registered name of the manager will be ESR-Reit Management from Dec 4 onwards.
ESR Cosmosquare OS1 Data Centre in Osaka, Japan. The registered name of the manager will be ESR-Reit Management from Dec 4 onwards.
Since the offer, the shares of the company are up 14.4 per cent from the closing price on the last trading day before the first take-private announcement on May 14.

site_title: Brexit’s fifth anniversary fires up new negotiations
summary: The UK and EU are set to renegotiate their 2020 Trade and Cooperation Agreement (TCA), five years after its signing, amid growing interest in deepening economic ties. Despite the UK's unlikely rejoining the EU, both sides want to strengthen their post-Brexit relationship. The TCA, a "hard Brexit" deal, has created structural impediments to trade, and the EU is seeking to address these issues. Defence and security policy cooperation, previously excluded from the agreement, is now a priority. Talks may lead to a more comprehensive deal, potentially in the form of bilateral agreements, similar to Switzerland's relationships with the EU.

images.alt_text:

Demonstrators take part in a rally after the announcement of the results of the first round of French parliamentary elections, at Place de la Republique in Paris on June 30, 2024.. France's far right won the first round of pivotal legislative elections on June 30, 2024, with the centrist forces of France's President coming in only third behind the left after the highest turnout in over four decades, estimates said. (Photo by Dimitar DILKOFF / AFP) / AFP PICTURES OF THE YEAR 2024
The pact represents Britain’s first free trade deals with Malaysia and Brunei, but while it had agreements with the other countries.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after inflation data, strong bank earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, January 15, after inflation data showed core inflation rose less than expected in December. The Dow Jones rose 409.5 points, or 0.96%, to 42,927.76, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, rising 62.3 and 305.9 points, respectively. Strong quarterly earnings from major US banks contributed to the positive market sentiment.

site_title: Elon Musk won’t save TikTok
summary: Elon Musk's potential acquisition of TikTok may not save the app from being banned in the US due to Chinese cyber espionage concerns. Musk's track record of allowing right-wing misinformation and increasing his own influence on X, his social media platform, suggests he may not prioritize user data protection. The US government's threat to ban TikTok unless sold by its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, remains in place. A Musk takeover would likely show that money and power can buy social media influence, and Beijing's hacking attacks and lax US data protection laws pose a threat to user data.

images.alt_text: This photograph taken on January 13, 2025 in Toulouse shows screens displaying the logo of Grok, a generative artificial intelligence chatbot developed by xAI, the American company specializing in artificial intelligence created by South African Businessman Elon Musk and smartphone displaying his account on the social media platform X. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: JPMorgan posts record annual profit as dealmakers, traders ride market rebound
summary: JPMorgan Chase posted a record annual profit of US$58.5 billion for 2024, driven by a strong economy and interest rate cuts that boosted stock sales and bond offerings. The banking giant's dealmakers and traders benefited from the rebounding markets in the fourth quarter. This marks a significant increase from the US$49.6 billion profit in 2023. The strong performance is attributed to the bullish environment, which also prompted more mergers and acquisitions after years of low activity.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrencies have emerged as one of the key themes around Donald Trump’s election win in November.

site_title: UK activist investor Palliser takes protest against Great Eastern takeover to MAS, SGX
summary: UK activist investor Palliser Capital is appealing to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to block the takeover of insurer Great Eastern by majority shareholder OCBC, citing the deal as "gravely unfair" to shareholders. Palliser Capital accused OCBC of treating minority shareholders unfairly, with the UK-based firm stating that Great Eastern's board was "highly complacent" in recommending the offer. The appeal is the latest move in the protest against the OCBC takeover.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Dissident minority investor calls on OCBC to unlock value by distributing Great Eastern stake
Total weighted new sales fall 7 per cent on the year to S$390.8 million in Q3 FY2024.
Greg Hingston, new chief executive officer of Great Eastern

Helen Wong, group chief executive of OCBC, says that the lender continues to work on its "One Group" strategy to achieve greater synergies with GEH and minimise leakage of the economic value generated.

site_title: US: Stocks pop on inflation data, strong earnings
summary: US stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 2.5% to 19,511.23, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 1.7% to 43,221.55. Strong bank earnings and a slowdown in underlying inflation fueled the gains. The S&P 500 also rose 1.8% to 5,949.91. Investors reacted positively to the decline in core inflation and the drop in long-dated US Treasury yields. Notable gains were seen in tech stocks, including Tesla, which rose 8.0%.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 jumped 1.33 per cent to 515.02 points on Wednesday, snapping a three-day losing streak.

site_title: Hegseth’s hearing showed standards matter, just not for him
summary: Former Fox News host Pete Hegseth, nominated by President-elect Donald Trump for secretary of defence, was grilled by Democrats over allegations of financial mismanagement, sexual misconduct, and alcohol abuse during a confirmation hearing. Hegseth evaded questions, instead providing non-answers that were interpreted as responses. Despite allegations of unqualified leadership, Hegseth framed the current military as weak and suggested lowering standards for women in combat forces. His confirmation appears likely, despite lacking qualifications for the job.

images.alt_text: Pete Hegseth was stumped when grilled about Asean by Democrat Senator Tammy Duckworth

Donald Trump nominated Pete Hegseth (left) as part of his push to fill major administration posts quickly. Trump’s cabinet picks show that he prizes loyalty over experience and is fuelled by retribution.

site_title: Tourists to Japan hit record 37 million, crowding locales
summary: Japan welcomed a record 36.9 million foreign visitors in 2024, a 47% increase from the previous year, driven by visitors from South Korea, Taiwan, and China. This surpasses the previous record of 31.9 million set in 2019, just before the COVID-19 pandemic. The surge in tourism is attributed to the post-pandemic global travel boom and the decline of the yen, making Japan an attractive and affordable destination. The country is now ahead of schedule to reach its goal of 60 million foreign tourists by 2030.

images.alt_text: Average prices nationwide climbed 1 per cent in the year to July 1, accelerating from a 0.3 per cent increase a year earlier.

site_title: MOH to monitor Cordlife’s governance, practices over one-year period; shares climb 10.3%
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore will monitor Cordlife Group's governance and practices for a one-year period after renewing its cord-blood banking and human-tissue banking service licenses. The licenses were renewed with immediate effect, following MOH's audits that showed Cordlife had addressed critical shortcomings. Despite the renewal, the licenses are for a limited period, and Cordlife's operations will be restricted. The company's shares rose 10.3% following the announcement. Cordlife is currently unable to assess the impact on its fiscal performance for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2025.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

EMBATTLED cord-blood bank Cordlife’s cord blood banking service and human tissue banking service licences have been renewed by the Ministry of Health (MOH) for one year, with effect from Tuesday (Jan 14).

site_title: China is facing longest deflation streak since Mao era in 1960s
summary: China is experiencing its longest deflationary streak since the 1960s, with deflation persisting for the second straight year in 2024. Official data is set to show a gross domestic product deflator of minus 0.2% in 2025, according to economists. Analysts predict that stimulus, particularly on the fiscal side, is needed to combat deflation, which could worsen if a looming trade war with the US. China's economy is struggling with a housing crisis, weak demand, and a lack of determination to combat deflation, with some economists calling for a binding target for inflation at 2% to shape expectations.

images.alt_text: China’s economy has struggled for traction since a post-pandemic rebound quickly fizzled out, with a protracted property crisis, weak demand and high local government debt levels weighing heavily on activity, souring both business and consumer confidence.
One of the two structural monetary policy tools the CSRC referred to is a liquidity support facility that allows institutional investors to tap the PBOC for funding for stock purchases.
Export prices have been falling for more than a year as deflation inside China worsens and pushes down the cost of goods.

site_title: Yen firms on BOJ talk, sterling calmer on CPI
summary: The Japanese yen strengthened on Wednesday amid growing bets on a rate hike at the Bank of Japan's next meeting, while the British pound found relief from cooling inflation data. US consumer price index numbers for December are set to be released this week, which could further limit the scope for Federal Reserve rate cuts. The dollar was last down 0.6% on the yen at 156.99, with Japanese government bond yields hitting multi-month highs.

images.alt_text: The euro dropped to its lowest since November 2022 versus the greenback.

site_title: China State Grid plans record US$89 billion spend amid green surge
summary: China's State Grid plans to spend a record US$89 billion this year, with the majority going towards long-distance, ultra-high-voltage power lines and smaller networks linking rooftop solar panels. The increased spending aims to address strain on grids caused by the rapid addition of wind and solar farms. The move is part of China's efforts to meet climate pledges and reduce fuel imports. The investment is expected to boost demand for materials like copper and steel, further highlighting the country's growing focus on renewable energy.

site_title: What is Asean? Do not ask Pete Hegseth – Trump’s pick for defence secretary
summary: US President Donald Trump's nominee for Defense Secretary, Pete Hegseth, struggled to answer basic questions about Asean, a 10-nation South-east Asian grouping, during a Senate confirmation hearing. Hegseth couldn't name a single member nation of Asean, describe the US's agreement with the bloc, or say how many nations are in the grouping. Asean has significant economic and security importance, with a combined market of over 650 million people and a GDP of over $3 trillion, and the US seeks to tap its regional influence to counter Chinese influence.

images.alt_text: Dominated by China hawks and Trump loyalists, the incoming administration threatens to knock off-keel US-Asean relations, often likened to a three-legged stool held up by defence, economic and diplomatic relations.

Donald Trump nominated Pete Hegseth (left) as part of his push to fill major administration posts quickly. Trump’s cabinet picks show that he prizes loyalty over experience and is fuelled by retribution.

site_title: China’s regions set bullish 2025 growth goal in guide for nation
summary: China's five wealthiest provinces, including Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangdong, have set growth targets of 5% or above for 2025, signaling an ambitious national goal despite trade headwinds. The targets are a significant increase from 2024, when only six of the eight richest provinces met or exceeded the national growth pace. The provinces' performance last year, marked by a property downturn and sluggish consumption, has demonstrated the challenge of maintaining growth, but the recent stimulus efforts and strong exports have provided a boost.

images.alt_text: China’s economy has struggled for traction since a post-pandemic rebound quickly fizzled out, with a protracted property crisis, weak demand and high local government debt levels weighing heavily on activity, souring both business and consumer confidence.

site_title: Microsoft launches Copilot Chat for businesses to boost AI adoption
summary: Microsoft has launched Copilot Chat, a free service allowing businesses to use on-demand AI agents for routine tasks such as market research and writing strategy documents. The service uses OpenAI's GPT-4 and lets users create AI agents in natural languages like English and Mandarin. However, features like summarizing and transcribing Teams calls require a $30 monthly subscription. Microsoft aims to drive AI adoption with a pay-as-you-go model, following a strategy to monetize AI technology. The move comes amid pressure to show returns on the company's hefty AI investments.

site_title: Bank of Japan will raise rates if economy, price conditions continue to improve, Ueda says
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that the central bank will raise interest rates and adjust monetary support if the economy and price conditions continue to improve. This comes after Deputy Governor Ryozo Himino mentioned the possibility of interest rate hikes at the next policy meeting. Ueda's remark highlights the Bank of Japan's readiness to take action to maintain price stability, following recent economic improvements.

site_title: SIA, Scoot clock monthly record in passengers in December
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its low-cost arm Scoot carried a record 3.6 million passengers in December, a 7.1% increase from the previous year. The group's total passenger carriage for 2024 reached 39 million, a 12.7% increase from 2023. Cargo loads rose 13.6% year-over-year, outpacing the 11.3% growth in cargo capacity. This was driven by a boost in perishables traffic ahead of the Lunar New Year period.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Before becoming permanent secretary of the Ministry of Manpower, Ng is the permanent secretary of the Smart Nation and Digital Government Group in the Prime Ministers’ Office.
Both the national carrier SIA and the budget airline Scoot carried a total of 3.3 million passengers in November.
Miles cards seem to be where all the fun is at.

site_title: Sorry Asean, Trump’s return may sideline South-east Asia’s economic aspirations
summary: US president-elect Donald Trump's administration may sideline South-east Asia's economic aspirations due to its focus on China and bilateral, transactional tendencies. Pundits expect the US to struggle to improve its economic offerings in the region, dashing Asean's hopes of being recognized as a unified bloc with significant economic clout. The Trump administration's dominance by China hawks and US loyalists threatens to knock off-keel US-Asean relations, making it essential for Asean to manage its expectations.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
According to Boston Consulting Group, Asean’s digital economy is projected to triple by 2030, reaching almost US$1 trillion, up from the current US$300 billion.
Defa has the potential to boost Asean’s digital economy to US$2 trillion by 2030, doubling the current trajectory.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim at the 44th and 45th ASEAN Summits in Vientiane, Laos, in October. Malaysia will officially assume the Chair of Asean starting Jan 1, 2025.
Veteran diplomat Ted Osius believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken (right) greets Cambodia Prime Minister Hun Manet at a summit in Laos, as Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) looks on.
Most of Marco Rubio's (right) public remarks made on X regarding South-east Asia are disappointingly in relation to China.

site_title: Bank Indonesia surprises with rate cut, prioritising economic growth over currency stability
summary: Bank Indonesia unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 5.75% on January 15, prioritizing economic growth over currency stability. The move defies market expectations, sparking pressure on the rupiah, which weakened against the US dollar. The central bank cited low inflation and a slowdown in the economy as reasons for the rate cut, with governor Perry Warjiyo indicating the possibility of further rate cuts this year, depending on global dynamics. The decision is seen as a shift in focus towards revitalizing Indonesia's economy amid signs of a slowdown.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
The carbon units available for sale in the inaugural international carbon trade on Indonesia Carbon Exchange (IDX Carbon) are authorized units that can be traded with international businesses.

site_title: Citigroup swings to profit on trading strength, surging deals
summary: Citigroup reported a net income of US$2.9 billion, or US$1.34 per share, in the fourth quarter, driven by strength in trading and a recovery in dealmaking. Markets revenue jumped 36% to US$4.6 billion, as the S&P 500 reached record-high levels. The bank's capital markets businesses benefited from a revival in mergers, acquisitions, and initial public offerings. Industry executives expect continued momentum as the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates and President-elect Donald Trump takes office, promising pro-business policies.

site_title: South Korean investigators question arrested President Yoon in insurrection probe
summary: South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol was arrested and questioned by authorities on a criminal insurrection investigation, marking the first time an incumbent president has been arrested. Yoon, who has been holed up at his residence since a declaration of martial law on Dec 3, refused to talk to investigators and has not agreed to recorded interviews. The arrest is part of a probe into Yoon's actions, which lawmakers voted to stand him down after. The move has raised concerns about the country's democracy.

images.alt_text: South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol arrives at the Corruption Investigation Office for High-ranking Officials, Gwacheon, South Korea, Jan 15, 2025.

Police officers gather near the official residence of impeached South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, as authorities, including the Corruption Investigation Office for High-ranking Officials, seek to execute an arrest warrant, Seoul, South Korea, Jan 15, 2025.

site_title: US importers rush in goods from China as Trump tariff threat looms
summary: US importers rapidly increased Chinese goods shipments in December, with 451,000 40-foot containers landing at US seaports, a 14.5% year-on-year increase. This surge is attributed to companies stockpiling shipments ahead of potential 10-60% tariffs imposed by President-elect Donald Trump on goods from China. Experts predict these tariffs could lead to a trade war, prompting importers to "front-run" possible tariffs on consumer items.

images.alt_text: Trump and the trade hawks he’s enlisted are broadening their scope in what threatens to be a more prolonged and unpredictable trade war than during his first presidency.

site_title: JPMorgan says altcoin-ETF inflows may be as high as US$14 billion
summary: JPMorgan analysts predict that proposed alternative cryptocurrency exchange-traded funds (ETFs) could attract inflows of up to $14 billion, with Solana ETFs potentially gathering $3-6 billion and XRP funds gathering $4-8 billion within the next 6-12 months. This estimate is based on the adoption rate of existing spot-cryptocurrency ETFs, including Bitcoin and Ether funds. However, regulatory uncertainty and the change in administration may slow progress on other ETF applications.

images.alt_text: A screen displays an interactive bubble chart for cryptocurrencies inside a BitBase cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

site_title: Ho Bee Land sparks bidding war for Australian property developer AVJennings at A$0.70 a share
summary: Ho Bee Land has launched a non-binding indicative offer to acquire all outstanding shares of Australian property developer AVJennings for A$0.70 each, beating an existing offer of A$0.67 a share. The offer, which trumps a previous deal made by Proprium Capital Partners and Avid Property Group, is expected to have a minimal impact on Ho Bee Land's consolidated net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the fiscal year ending Dec 31, 2025.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Elementum, Ho Bee Land’s landmark biomedical life-science development. The group is selling a 49 per cent stake in this project to a sovereign wealth fund.
Elementum, Ho Bee Land’s landmark biomedical life-science development.

site_title: UK house prices rise by most since Feb 2023
summary: UK house prices rose by 3.3% in the 12 months to November, the fastest annual increase since February 2023, according to the Office for National Statistics. This follows a downwardly revised 3.0% increase in October. Private-sector rents also rose 9.0% in December, with the largest increase in London at 11.5%. The data suggests resilience in the property market despite high borrowing costs, leading investors to bet on potential Bank of England interest rate cuts in 2025.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in view of the Canary Wharf financial, business and shopping district skyline in London, UK, on Monday, May 27, 2024. The UK's chronic housing shortage has become a key battleground between the ruling Conservative Party and the opposition Labour Party ahead of the general election. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Grab partners BYD to expand electric vehicle fleet offering across South-east Asia
summary: Grab has partnered with Chinese carmaker BYD to provide up to 50,000 electric vehicles to its driver-partners across South-east Asia. The tie-up aims to improve the driver and passenger experience, reduce upfront costs, and increase the availability of green vehicles. Grab's fleet partners will have access to BYD vehicles at competitive rates, with extended warranties and financing options. The partnership also aims to integrate deep tech between BYD's vehicles and Grab's platform and services, enhancing navigation and routing capabilities.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The software curbs take effect for model year 2027 while the hardware controls come into play for model year 2030.
BMW walked back its outlook in September after a faulty braking system forced it to recall as many as 1.5 million vehicles, which took a particular toll on deliveries in China.

A screen displays stock figures at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Feb. 15, 2024. site_title: Los Angeles rental hits US$40,000 a month as fires roil housing market
summary: Los Angeles' housing market has worsened due to devastating wildfires, with rents skyrocketing to US$40,000 a month. The fires destroyed over 12,000 structures, including homes, and only 5% of apartments were vacant before the disaster. The median rent was US$2,299, and demand for furnished properties has soared. Homeowners are price-gouging, with some listings increasing prices by 50% or more. California law prohibits price hikes by more than 10% after an emergency, but enforcement remains a concern. The city's housing affordability crisis has intensified, with many Angelenos struggling to find affordable housing.

images.alt_text: Along a stretch near Saddle Peak in the Santa Monica Mountains, some homes were destroyed while others were undamaged by the Palisades Fire.

site_title: BlackRock CEO succession outlook shifts amid exits, buying spree
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink's succession outlook has shifted amid the departure of senior executive Mark Wiedman, who is leaving to pursue opportunities outside the company. Wiedman's exit follows that of BlackRock veteran Salim Ramji, who is now CEO of Vanguard Group. The management changes come after a year of significant investments, including a $30 billion commitment to three major deals. Fink has stated he plans to prepare the next generation of leaders, but his departure is seen as a potential indicator of his own transition.

images.alt_text: BlackRock is working with Evercore, while Centerview Partners and AlixPartners are advising Alacrity.

site_title: UK stagflation risk adds pressure on Reeves after market volatility
summary: UK finance minister Rachel Reeves faces growing pressure as stagflation risk adds to market volatility. A survey shows two-thirds of British retailers plan to raise prices this year due to higher employer social security costs, exacerbating households' high living costs. Economists expect the annual rate of consumer price inflation to remain at 2.6% in December, above the Bank of England's forecast of 2.5%. This adds to concerns about the UK economy's weak state and the impact on Reeves' ability to manage inflation.

images.alt_text: The UK’s housing market endured a challenging 2024, as higher mortgage rates reduced competition for homes and restricted sellers’ ability to hike asking prices.

Concerns over the state of the UK’s stretched public finances combined with persistent inflation fuelled a sharp market rout last week, and drew comparisons with a market meltdown two years ago that toppled Liz Truss’ administration.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves and Chinese Vice-President Han Zheng shake hands before their meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, Jan 11, 2025.

site_title: Red hot: key facts about Xiaohongshu, the Chinese app taking the US by storm
summary: The Chinese app Xiaohongshu has gained popularity among American users ahead of the US government's deadline to ban TikTok. With ByteDance's deadline to sell or shut down TikTok looming, Xiaohongshu has taken the top spot in the US Apple App Store free downloads chart. The app, a lifestyle-focused alternative to Instagram and Pinterest, has attracted users with its apolitical content on topics such as lifestyle, travel, beauty, and food. This shift in attention may indicate a growing preference for alternative social media platforms in the US.

images.alt_text: Last week, the US Supreme Court seemed inclined to uphold the law, which was passed in April, despite calls from US President-elect Donald Trump and lawmakers to extend the Jan 19 deadline.

site_title: Founder of collapsed oil trader Zenrock had cheating and other charges abated after his death
summary: The founder of collapsed oil trader Zenrock Commodities, Xie Chun, had all four charges against him abated following his death on January 3. The charges, including cheating and forgery, were applied for by the defense after Xie's passing, effectively ending his court proceedings. Xie, 47, was one of several high-profile traders to collapse in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on oil prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 15)
summary: Singapore's port recorded 3.1 billion annual gross tonnes in vessel arrival tonnage in 2024, a 0.6% increase over 2023. The country also set new records for container throughput, bunker sales, and total tonnage of ships under its flag. Meanwhile, Bank Indonesia cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 5.75%, prioritizing economic growth over currency stability. New home sales declined in December, but were 50% higher than the previous year. Grab partnered with BYD to expand its electric vehicle fleet across South-east Asia.

site_title: YTL-Sea consortium’s digital bank gets approval to operate in Malaysia
summary: Ryt Bank, a digital bank jointly owned by YTL Digital Capital and Singapore's Sea, has secured approval from Malaysia's Ministry of Finance to operate, starting December 20, 2024. The bank will be Malaysia's first AI-powered digital bank, offering features such as fast onboarding, seamless transactions, and personalized banking services powered by AI. Ryt Bank aims to empower Malaysians with a next-generation, AI-driven platform, and its capabilities include an AI-powered personal banking assistant for simplified banking services.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Analysts observed that the well-capitalised conventional banks are rapidly advancing in digitisation, creating an increasingly competitive market for newcomers.
Grab and Singtel have laid out plans for a further capital injection in the third quarter of this year.
The S$229.5 million capital injection is part of the shareholders' resolution filed earlier this year.
Malaysia’s favourable regulatory and business environment have bolstered the development of the country's Islamic fintech sector, say analysts.
(From left to right) GXS chairman Hsieh Fu Hua, Datuk Johan Merican, GXBank CEO Pei Si Lai and Datuk Zaiton Hassan, chairperson of GXBank, at the public launch of GXBank.
Malaysia’s Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (middle) at the Boost Bank launching event. Boost Bank is the first primarily Malaysian-owned digital bank in the country.

site_title: China is scouring the globe in search of new food suppliers
summary: China is expanding its food supply chain globally, diversifying away from traditional Western suppliers. The country has been exporting to countries like Vietnam, Bolivia, and Kenya, and has also increased trade with Brazil, Russia, and other Global South nations. This shift is a response to US president-elect Donald Trump's trade war, which exposed China's dependence on the US and its allies. China's goal is to ensure food security and reduce its reliance on Western markets.

images.alt_text: China’s economy has struggled for traction since a post-pandemic rebound quickly fizzled out, with a protracted property crisis, weak demand and high local government debt levels weighing heavily on activity, souring both business and consumer confidence.
One of the two structural monetary policy tools the CSRC referred to is a liquidity support facility that allows institutional investors to tap the PBOC for funding for stock purchases.
Export prices have been falling for more than a year as deflation inside China worsens and pushes down the cost of goods.
Cautious consumers are increasingly opting to rent items, such as cameras and handbags, instead of buying them.

site_title: Meta to cut roughly 5% of staff, targeting lowest performers
summary: Meta is cutting approximately 3,600 jobs, about 5% of its 72,000 employees, through performance-based terminations. The company plans to hire new people to fill the roles and aims to have a 10% reduction in headcount by the end of the current performance cycle. CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that the goal is to ensure the company has the "strongest talent" and will provide generous severance packages to affected workers. The terminations will be based on performance reviews, with US-based employees notified on February 10 and others at a later date.

images.alt_text: Even as Singapore's government tries to combat misinformation – not least through the use of the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act – it maintains a strong presence on platforms such as Facebook.

site_title: Indonesia’s rupiah hits over 5-month low ahead of rate decision
summary: Indonesia's rupiah plummeted to a 5-month low, reaching 16,318 per dollar, due to anticipation of a rate decision by Bank Indonesia. The currency has lost over 1% against the dollar this year and 8% from its September peak. Analysts expect Bank Indonesia to maintain its 6% interest rate, prioritizing rupiah stability over potential easing. The US dollar remains dominant, putting pressure on emerging currencies, with the Thai baht hovering around a 7-week low.

images.alt_text: General view of the capital city of Jakarta, Indonesia, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: TikTok seeks to reassure US employees ahead of Jan 19 ban deadline
summary: TikTok has assured its US employees that their employment, pay, and benefits will remain secure even if the Supreme Court does not overturn a law forcing the sale of the app or banning it by January 19. The company's leadership emphasized employee wellbeing in an internal memo, stating that offices will remain open despite the uncertainty. TikTok, owned by China-based ByteDance, has 7,000 US employees and plans to continue paying them regardless of the outcome.

images.alt_text: TikTok maintains that the control only applies to the China-based subsidiary Douyin Information Service, and has no bearing on ByteDance operations outside China.

site_title: Malaysia PM says Petronas retains national role after Sarawak gas deal
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has confirmed that state energy firm Petronas will retain its national authority over oil and gas despite Petroleum Sarawak (Petros) taking control of gas distribution in Sarawak state. The Petroleum Development Act (PDA) 1974 remains the governing framework, and Petronas will be involved in gas-related projects, particularly those requiring substantial financing. A deadlock in negotiations last year had raised industry concerns, but both parties have agreed to maintain existing agreements to avoid complicating relationships with major international companies.

site_title: Gold subdued as investors brace for US inflation print
summary: Gold prices were subdued on Wednesday as investors awaited US consumer price inflation data, potentially impacting the Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory. US gold futures rose 0.3% to $2,689.60, while spot gold eased 0.1% to $2,672.93 per ounce. A Reuters poll forecast a 2.9% annual rise in inflation, which could lead to a pause in Fed rate cuts. Investors remain cautious ahead of the CPI print, which could provide clarity on the Fed's policy path.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.3 per cent to US$2,671.13 per ounce.

site_title: Malaysian real estate getting a boost from chip and other high-growth sectors
summary: Malaysia's industrial sector is experiencing significant growth, driven by increasing demand for manufactured goods and the establishment of new industrial parks. This growth is expected to continue due to ongoing investments, technological advancements, and a focus on sustainability. Johor, in particular, is poised to attract global players with its ability to draw foreign direct investment (FDI) and establish a data centre ecosystem. The sector's growth is also seen as an opportunity for collaboration with global investors in green tech, given Malaysia's commitment to renewable energy.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Wednesday’s close; STI retreats 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.4% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,772.58 points, led by losses in Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and the three local banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC. However, Genting Singapore rose 2% and Cordlife Group surged 9.7% on news of renewed operation licences. Globally, indices were mixed, with the US awaiting key inflation data that will set interest rate expectations.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
The banking trio of DBS, OCBC and UOB offer investors good growth prospects and decent dividends.
Singapore Exchange data shows that SPDR Gold Shares, the only gold ETF on the local bourse, overtook the Lion-OCBC Securities Hang Seng Tech ETF and SPDR Straits Times Index ETF.

site_title: Distressed Chinese companies face flurry of court hearings
summary: At least eight major Chinese firms, including a unit of Evergrande Group, are set to defend themselves in court cases over their debt problems in the next two weeks. This marks one of the busiest stretches ever for such hearings. The cases include Tianji Holding, an Evergrande subsidiary, and HNA Group, as well as a three-day hearing in the UK to decide on Sino-Ocean Group Holding's offshore restructuring plan. The outcome will be closely watched as creditors and bondholders weigh their options. Multiple restructurings have already occurred in the sector.

Investors have grown increasingly anxious about Sunac's upcoming interest payments amid sluggish sales, which sent its shares and US dollar notes to their lowest levels in months last week.

site_title: New home sales shrink in December after November spike, but are 50% higher on year
summary: New home sales in Singapore dropped 92% in December 2024, with 203 units sold, compared to 2,560 units in November. Despite the decline, sales are 50% higher than the same period last year, driven by a surge in units launched in November. The total number of units sold in 2024 reached 6,560, a 2.2% increase from the previous year. Analysts forecast new home sales to hit between 7,000 and 9,000 units in 2025, driven by lower interest rates and a pipeline of new launches.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
2024 has been an unprecedented one for Singapore's private residential market, with contrasting performance in new home sales and non-awards for state land tenders.

site_title: Roxy Square owners move to cut 11% off asking price to S$1.12 billion for collective sale
summary: Roxy Square owners are relaunching the freehold site for collective sale with a reduced reserve price of S$1.12 billion, a 10.8% decrease from the previous S$1.25 billion. This follows a failed attempt last year and is aimed at attracting developers to create a mixed-use project. The site, comprising a shopping centre and hotel, has a GFA of 668,000 sq ft and is located in the Katong area, which has seen strong demand for quality residences. The reduced reserve price aims to enhance the site's appeal and meet modern urban needs.
