site_title: Davos drills down on cooperation challenges in 2020s
summary: The World Economic Forum's 55th annual meeting, set for Jan 20-24, will focus on 'Collaboration for the Intelligent Age', bringing together entrepreneurs, scientists, and leaders to discuss global cooperation in the face of emerging technologies like AI and quantum computing. The meeting aims to address both the benefits and risks of these technologies, with prominent figures like Nobel laureate Geoffrey Hinton warning of the technology's potential to pose greater global risks than climate change.

images.alt_text: The risks of AI have become a key global discussion  point.

site_title: Global electric vehicle sales up 25% at over 17 million in record 2024
summary: Global electric vehicle sales reached a record 17 million in 2024, up 25% from the previous year. In the US and Canada, EV sales rose 8.8% to 0.2 million in December, while Europe reported 0.3 million sales, a 0.7% increase from 2023. China's sales growth slowed, and new emissions targets will take effect in Europe in 2025. Electric car makers expect 2025 to be a transformative year due to these changes, with potential policy shifts in the US also on the horizon.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in estimated exports contrasts with a slight uptick forecast for vehicle sales in China this year, as extended policy incentives are expected to bolster sales in the world’s largest auto market.
The sales decline undermines Mercedes-Benz’s strategy to push further upmarket by selling more of its most luxurious vehicles to boost profit.
The latest Model Y sports a new light bar that stretches across the front end, similar to Tesla’s Cybertruck, while the taillight is also a full-width light bar.

site_title: Singapore shares in the red on Tuesday; STI falls 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,788.77 on Tuesday, led by a decline in DFI Retail Group and two banking stocks, DBS and OCBC. However, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rose 4.1% and Genting Singapore gained 0.7%. The broader market saw advancers beat decliners 278 to 226, with 938.1 million securities worth S$994.3 million traded. Regional markets were mixed, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 1.8% and Japan's Nikkei 225 falling 1.8%.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Therese Soh

Vincent Phang is one of the three SingPost senior executives fired in December for their alleged negligence in the handling of internal investigations over a whistle-blower's report and in subsequent probes.

site_title: Apple, Samsung smartphone shipments fall in fourth quarter as China competition bites: IDC
summary: Apple's global smartphone shipments fell 4.1% to 76.9 million units in the fourth quarter, while Samsung's shipments dropped 2.7% to 51.7 million units. Chinese companies, particularly Xiaomi, Oppo, and Honor, intensified competition, with Xiaomi showing the fastest growth with a 15.4% increase in shipments. Chinese mobile makers shipped 56% of the global smartphones, marking the highest combined volume ever in a quarter, as they expanded across Europe and Africa with low-end and mid-range devices.

images.alt_text: Apple has been playing catchup on AI, with its suite of AI enhancements rolling out in stages following the launch of the iPhone 16 in September.
Indonesia banned the sales of Apple’s iPhone 16 after it failed to meet a requirement that smartphones sold domestically must comprise at least 40 per cent locally-made parts.

site_title: Country Garden’s property services arm expects annual earnings to fall
summary: Country Garden Services, a property services arm of Chinese builder Country Garden, expects a drop of up to 1.1 billion yuan (S$205 million) in annual earnings due to an impairment charge for goodwill and tangible assets. The impairment is primarily caused by the delayed expansion of its sanitation business and unsatisfactory cash flows. The company has enough working capital and stable business operations, and expects to report its fiscal 2024 results in mid-to-late March 2025. This comes as Country Garden is facing a prolonged local debt crisis.

site_title: China’s coastal water temperatures hit record high in 2024
summary: China's coastal water temperatures reached a record high of 21.50 degrees Celsius in 2024, surpassing the previous year's record. This marks the world's hottest year on record since temperature records began. The increase in ocean temperatures contributes to one-third of global sea level rise, posing significant risks to coastal and low-lying areas. China, described as a climate-vulnerable country, is under pressure to adapt to changing weather patterns and rising sea levels. The country will closely monitor global sea temperatures in 2025.

images.alt_text: Sydney’s ocean beaches, famed for golden sand and clean water, draw tourists from around the globe.

site_title: Bitcoin falls to lowest since November in risk-asset sell-off
summary: Bitcoin dropped 5.3% to $89,329, its lowest since November 18, amid a risk-asset sell-off following stronger-than-expected US jobs data and rising bond yields. Other cryptocurrencies, such as Ether and Solana, fell 10% or more. Analysts attribute the downturn to investors curbing bets on a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut and a lack of certainty following President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration. A head and shoulders chart pattern may indicate a trend reversal from bullish to bearish territory, with potential lows at $88,000 or $74,000.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representation of the bitcoin cryptocurrency and a price chart are seen in this illustration taken October 24, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Tech supplier Arm plans to hike prices, has considered developing its own chips
summary: Arm Holdings, a technology supplier to chip firms, plans to increase prices by up to 300% and considers developing its own chips to compete with major customers like Apple and Qualcomm. The company aims to boost its annual smartphone revenue by $1 billion over 10 years. Arm currently licenses its intellectual property to customers, charging a small royalty, but will explore designing its own chips to increase revenue. The move could send a "chill" down the spine of Arm's customers, who are sophisticated enough to design their own chips using Arm's architecture.

images.alt_text: Arm is increasingly moving from being a licenser of fundamental standards and basic blueprints to more of a complete chipmaker.
Qualcomm is one of Arm’s biggest customers and a long-time partner, but the companies have grown increasingly at odds.
Arm licenses the fundamental set of instructions that software uses to communicate with chips.
Arm says that the move is a breach of Qualcomm’s license and is demanding that the company destroy Nuvia designs that were created before the Nuvia acquisition.

site_title: Oil prices climb 2% to four-month high with sanctions expected to disrupt Russian supplies
summary: Oil prices surged 2% to a four-month high, reaching $81.01 a barrel, due to US sanctions on Russian oil, which may disrupt supplies to India and China. Brent futures rose $1.25, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $2.25. The sanctions target vessels carrying 1.7 million barrels of oil per day, or 25% of Russia's exports, and could lead to a shift in trade from Europe to Asia. The price increase also comes as markets await the outcome of US presidential elections and potential interest rate changes.

images.alt_text: Crude is up more than 6 per cent this year, a robust start that has taken some market participants by surprise as many banks and agencies had forecast a significant supply glut that would weigh on prices.

site_title: China discusses sale of TikTok US to Elon Musk as one possible option: sources
summary: China is exploring a potential sale of TikTok's US operations to Elon Musk as a contingency plan if the company fails to fend off a US ban. The sale would involve Musk acquiring TikTok's US operations, with the Chinese government expected to have some say over the outcome. Beijing officials prefer to keep TikTok under parent company ByteDance's control, but are considering alternative options amid the uncertainty. Musk has ties to the Trump administration and could potentially benefit from a deal, with the Chinese government weighing the pros and cons of such a high-profile arrangement.

images.alt_text: TikTok logo is seen in this illustration taken January 8, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: US SEC fines Blackstone, KKR, Apollo, others in texting crackdown
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has fined 12 investment advisers and brokerages, including affiliates of Blackstone, KKR, and Apollo Global Management, a total of $63 million for failing to track employees' use of unauthorized communications platforms. The firms agreed to pay millions in penalties, with the largest fines going to Blackstone affiliates ($12 million) and a Schwab broker-dealer ($10 million). The SEC's crackdown aims to improve compliance and transparency in the markets, with the regulator warning that record-keeping lapses can have far-reaching consequences.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: The Offset returns to spotlight more greentech game-changers
summary: Tech in Asia and Taiwan Mobile have renewed their partnership to produce The Offset, a monthly newsletter featuring disruptors using tech to address sustainability issues. The newsletter aims to empower individuals and organizations to make a positive impact on the planet. With 12 monthly updates, The Offset will share the latest trends, breakthroughs, and best practices to keep readers informed and inspired for another year. The partnership will continue to facilitate the publication of The Offset, which was previously published.

site_title: US: Dow rises, Nasdaq falls ahead of earnings, inflation data
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.9% at 42,297.12. The S&P 500 climbed 0.2% to 5,836.22, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.4% to 19,088.10. Investors appear less sensitive to rising Treasury bond yields, with some analysts noting the market is less overbought. Individual companies saw mixed results, including a 1.7% gain for Johnson & Johnson and a 16.8% decline for Moderna due to projected 2025 revenue.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. US stocks powered higher on the back of optimism over the technology giants, signaling that Wall Street is set to rebound from the four-day slump that marked the end of 2024. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: China Evergrande's unit receives liquidation order from Hong Kong court
summary: China Evergrande's subsidiary CEG Holdings BVI has been ordered by a Hong Kong court to be wound up, with liquidators seeking to recover funds from the debt-laden property developer. The order follows a winding-up petition filed in September, as part of efforts to recover at least $6 billion in remuneration and dividends from the company's founder and other individuals. The move is part of a broader legal push by liquidators to recoup debts and recover losses from Evergrande's failed restructuring efforts. Trading in the company's shares remains suspended.

site_title: New Zealand Q4 business confidence improves but economy remains weak: think tank
summary: New Zealand's business confidence improved in the fourth quarter to its highest level since 2021, but the economy remains weak, according to a private think tank. A net 16% of firms surveyed expected general business conditions to improve, but the economy contracted further in the fourth quarter. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to cut interest rates again, with a 50-basis point cut anticipated at its February meeting. Despite improving sentiment, firms remain cautious about hiring and investment, and the demand environment remains weak.

images.alt_text: Prices rose modestly in early 2024 but buyer optimism was not sustained as the central bank kept borrowing costs high and economic growth stalled.
New Zealand typically runs an annual trade deficit as it needs to import oil, transport equipment and many raw materials that are not produced locally.
A bugbear for some foreigners wanting to invest in New Zealand is an inability to buy a house in the country, the consequence of a ban imposed in 2018 on outsiders.

site_title: 18 flights bound for Changi, Seletar airports diverted since Jan 10 due to bad weather
summary: Severe weather caused 18 flights to be diverted from Changi and Seletar airports in Singapore since January 10. 12 flights were redirected to regional airports, while 6 private jets were diverted to Changi Airport. The diversion was due to heavy rain, resulting in the highest total rainfall at Changi Airport since January 10 and 11. No further diversions were reported on January 13. Airlines, including Singapore Airlines, reported delays and cancellations, with some flights arriving hours after their scheduled times.

images.alt_text: Both the national carrier SIA and the budget airline Scoot carried a total of 3.3 million passengers in November.

site_title: Nvidia faces revenue threat from new US AI chip export curbs: analysts
summary: Nvidia faces a significant revenue threat due to the US export restrictions on artificial intelligence (AI) chips, limiting exports to most countries except close US allies. The regulations, aimed at preventing China from acquiring advanced chips, may complicate Nvidia's ability to deliver robust revenue growth, with analysts estimating that up to half of its chips may be affected. Major cloud providers, such as Microsoft and Google, are likely to increase their market share, while the new rules threaten to crimp earnings potential for US firms like Nvidia.

images.alt_text: The new regulations will cap the number of AI chips that can be exported to most countries and allow unlimited access to US AI technology for America’s closest allies, while also maintaining a block on exports to China, Russia, Iran and North Korea.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 13)
summary: Weak economic conditions and increasing competition may cause telco prospects to soften in 2025, particularly in South-east Asia. Analysts predict a 3% year-on-year rise in sector's mobile and fixed revenue, down from 4% in 2024. Non-core operations could be monetized to offset declining telco prospects.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore Exchange’s (SGX) total securities market turnover value climbed 5.4 per cent on the year to S$20 billion in December despite total market volume falling 14.6 per cent to 19.4 billion shares, said SGX on Thursday (Jan 9).

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, January 13, 2025
summary: Asian markets tracked US Wall Street losses after a blockbuster jobs report, with oil prices rising amid new Russian oil sanctions. Chinese trade surplus reached $1 trillion on pre-Trump exports, sparking concerns about trade tensions ahead of Trump's return.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.3%
Equities fell across Asia on Monday, with Hong Kong, Taipei and Manila off more than one per cent each, while Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul and Jakarta were also down.
Independent Chinese refiners, known as teapots, will likely suffer losses as oil prices climb and shipping costs become more expensive.
Export prices have been falling for more than a year as deflation inside China worsens and pushes down the cost of goods.

site_title: Over 35% increase in mutual assistance, extradition requests received by Singapore
summary: Singapore's Attorney-General's Chambers received 275 mutual legal assistance and extradition requests in 2024, a 35% increase from the previous year. The country has entered into new treaties with South Korea and Vietnam and continues to combat transnational crimes, seizing assets worth over S$3 billion in 2023. Attorney-General Lucien Wong emphasized Singapore's zero-tolerance policy against money laundering and its commitment to international cooperation on climate change and generative artificial intelligence.

site_title: US tightens its grip on AI chip flows across the globe
summary: The US has introduced new regulations to further restrict the export of artificial intelligence (AI) chips and technology, capping exports to most countries and allowing unlimited access to US AI technology for its closest allies. The regulations, unveiled in the final days of President Joe Biden's administration, maintain a block on exports to China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea. The new rules aim to maintain the US's dominant status in AI by controlling its global development and flow, and are set to take effect 120 days from publication.

images.alt_text: Davos is gearing up for the 55th annual meeting of the World Economic Forum. The meeting from Jan 20-24 will bring together entrepreneurs, scientists, corporate and political leaders under the theme  'Collaboration for the Intelligent Age'.

site_title: China exports more to Vietnam than Japan for first time as supply chains shift
summary: China's exports to Vietnam surpassed Japan for the first time, reaching $162 billion in 2024, a 18% increase. This shift is driven by electronics components being assembled in Vietnam before being exported to the US and elsewhere. The rerouting of trade risks has benefited Vietnam, attracting billions in investment from companies like Samsung Electronics and Luxshare Precision Industry. This trend is expected to continue, with Vietnam's trade surplus with the US reaching a record high.

images.alt_text: Vietnam proposes ‘unprecedented’ policies for financial centres in Ho Chi Minh City, Da Nang
Vietnam, which counts the US as its biggest market, is home to big export-focused industrial operations of US multinationals such as Apple, Google, Nike and Intel.
Vietnam is targeting a 31 per cent jump in foreign travellers this year from 2024.

site_title: Fu Yu IDs ‘surprised’ at EGM requisition by largest shareholder following his failed application to be a director
summary: Fu Yu Corporation's largest shareholder, Victor Lim, has requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove independent directors Royston Tan and Christopher Huang, citing the erasure of substantial shareholder value since their election. The independent directors, Tan and Huang, stated they are surprised by the move and clarified that they do not control the company's day-to-day operations. They also defended their performance, citing a 55.2% revenue increase and a narrowing net loss, and stated that the company's management team has done a "very good job" amid a difficult macroeconomic environment.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Fu Yu's largest shareholder Victor Lim says substantial shareholder value has been erased since the appointment of directors Christopher Huang Junli and Roystan Tan Tong Loong.
David Seow, chief executive of Fu Yu, says the company's customers typically give one, three and six-month forecasts for future orders.

site_title: BMW sales slide after brake fault recall, China demand slump
summary: BMW car sales dropped 4% to 2.45 million vehicles in 2024 due to a faulty braking system recall and weak demand in China. The recall, affecting up to 1.5 million vehicles, particularly impacted deliveries in China. BMW's electric vehicle sales, however, rose 14% in 2024, making up 17% of total car sales. The company faces challenges from local Chinese brands like BYD and weak demand for electric vehicles in Europe.

images.alt_text: The sales decline undermines Mercedes-Benz’s strategy to push further upmarket by selling more of its most luxurious vehicles to boost profit.
BMW's revenue fell 15.7 per cent to 32.4 billion euros from 38.46 billion euros a year earlier, below analyst expectations of 34.3 billion euros.
Models affected include locally-made 3 Series and 5 Series vehicles, as well as several imported X Series SUVs.
While German automakers still control nearly 15 per cent of the Chinese market, that’s down from a quarter before the pandemic and worse yet, their share of EVs is less than 10 per cent.

site_title: Bezos says space industry has room for ‘multiple winners’
summary: Jeff Bezos expressed optimism about the space industry, stating that it has room for "multiple winners," including Blue Origin and SpaceX. He acknowledged SpaceX's potential success, saying they will continue to be successful, while also predicting Blue Origin's success. Bezos also suggested that there will be new uses for space driving demand for large capacity launches, indicating a positive outlook for his company's first orbital rocket launch attempt.

images.alt_text: Blue Origin has struggled to bring its giant New Glenn rocket to market.
The roughly 0.74 hectare  next door to the properties Jeff Bezos bought in South Florida. is located at Indian Creek, a man-made barrier island that’s been dubbed “Billionaire Bunker”.

site_title: Macquarie investing arm hires Gabriel Ho for South-east Asia push
summary: Macquarie Asset Management has hired Gabriel Ho, a former partner at Dymon Asia Private Equity and Baring Private Equity Asia, to expand its coverage of South-east Asia. The move is part of Macquarie's push to deploy its billions raised as one of the world's top infrastructure investors in emerging parts of Asia outside of China. Ho will focus on investing in the region, which Macquarie aims to do through its South-east Asia-focused arm.

images.alt_text: Beyond Japan, Macquarie has been actively investing across Asia-Pacific with more than US$16 billion managed under its infrastructure fund series.
Asset managers have long favoured aviation-related leasing, which is part of the booming private credit market.
Beyond Japan, Macquarie has been actively investing across Asia-Pacific with more than US$16 billion managed under its infrastructure fund series.

site_title: Thailand expecting at least US$29 billion in investment applications this year
summary: Thailand expects to secure at least $28.8 billion in investment applications this year, a 10-year high, driven by foreign investment in data centers and cloud services. The country's Board of Investment (BOI) Secretary General Narit Therdsteerasukdi attributes the increase to investors seeking a safe and suitable place for long-term investment, particularly those relocating from China due to anticipated high tariffs. This marks a significant milestone in the government's five-year plan to exceed $5 trillion in investment pledges.

images.alt_text: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will potentially draw more investments not just between both countries, but also across the region, supporting businesses’ expansion plans.

site_title: SingPost’s fired CEO Vincent Phang resigns from board
summary: SingPost's former CEO Vincent Phang has resigned from the board following his termination along with two other top management staff. The firings were related to a whistle-blower's report on the company's international e-commerce parcels business, where three managers were found to have committed serious breaches of the company's code of conduct. Phang and the other two executives deny any negligence, stating they will "vigorously contest" their termination.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
SingPost's sudden dismissal of its three senior executives raised "critical questions in the minds of shareholders, investors and the market".
David Gerald, founder, president and chief executive of Sias, says that shareholders deserve better and so does the market.
SingPost has performed within the quality of service standard – which is independently audited – in the last four years.

The Securities Investors Association (Singapore), or Sias, noted that the company’s 2024 annual report – published in the last week of June this year – did not specifically mention any whistleblowing report.
Maybank maintains its buy rating on SingPost, with a price target of S$0.77.
Singtel has failed to maintain control of the narrative surrounding the whistleblower reports, and the disclosures it has made are now being second guessed

site_title: A sceptic’s guide to 2025: three risks to monitor
summary: A 2025 investment outlook is optimistic, with the US economy expected to avoid a sharp growth downturn and result in solid gains for global equities and high-yield bonds. However, three key risks to monitor include how US President Donald Trump implements his policy agenda, Chinese policymakers' response to US tariffs and domestic growth challenges, and the potential for a rebound in inflation. To mitigate these risks, investors can consider diversifying their portfolios through asset classes such as gold, domestic sectors, and onshore equities, and building in diversified assets to help mitigate the impact of risk scenarios.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held ground at US$2,690.49 per ounce.

Concerns over the state of the UK’s stretched public finances combined with persistent inflation fuelled a sharp market rout last week, and drew comparisons with a market meltdown two years ago that toppled Liz Truss’ administration.

The US market’s strong surge has renewed concerns over valuations. At least two fund management firms have adjusted downwards their long-run expectations of returns for large-cap US equities, with a 10 to 15-year view.

site_title: Johor-Singapore SEZ’s faces toughest test – slashing immigration clearance delays, says Malaysian minister
summary: Malaysia's Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli says the Johor-Singapore SEZ faces its toughest test due to immigration clearance delays, specifically reducing clearance time to 20 minutes. This is crucial to unlocking the zone's full potential as a model for bilateral cooperation, with harmonization of customs policies and technology being key to streamlining clearance times.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

The package is designed to attract high-value investments into Johor.
Berjaya Corp founder Vincent Tan highlighted the company’s dedication to a world-class high-speed rail, enhancing connectivity, driving Malaysia’s economy, and promoting green mobility.

The exchange of the SEZ document took place during the 11th Malaysia-Singapore Leaders’ Retreat on Jan 7 in Putrajaya, and was witnessed by Singapore’s Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.

site_title: Chinese holiday travellers shun Thailand after actor’s abduction
summary: Chinese travelers are shunning Thailand ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday due to safety concerns following the kidnapping of a Chinese actor, Wang Xing. Cancellations of flights from China to Thailand jumped 155% over the weekend, with some tourists canceling shows and bookings. The incident has dealt another blow to Chinese tourism in Thailand, which remains below pre-pandemic levels. Despite efforts to reassure visitors, concerns about scam operators and human trafficking in the region continue to affect tourist numbers.

images.alt_text: Casinos and most forms of gambling are illegal in Thailand but soccer betting and underground gaming activities and lotteries are rife, with vast sums of money changing hands.
Asia has seen a rather slow post-pandemic recovery compared to other parts of the world, held back by sluggish growth in its biggest economy, China.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as investors dial back bets on Fed rate cuts this year
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, January 13, as investors reduced bets on Federal Reserve rate cuts this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 13.8 points, or 0.03%, to 41,924.68. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 dropping 45.0 points, or 0.77%, and the Nasdaq Composite falling 258.0 points, or 1.35%. The decline was driven by rising interest rates following robust payroll numbers last week.

site_title: China’s battery giant CATL hires banks for first-half Hong Kong float: sources
summary: China's battery giant CATL has hired banks, including JPMorgan and Bank of America, to work on a potential Hong Kong listing, which could be one of the city's largest offerings in 2025. The company, with a market cap of $150 billion, is targeting the first half for the float, which will likely be in the billions of US dollars. This comes amid rising geopolitical tensions and increasing interest for Chinese A-share companies to tap into overseas liquidity.

images.alt_text: Tencent is one of the top players in China’s expansive technology sector, operating the WeChat “super-app” with other offerings across gaming, content streaming and cloud services.
CATL has been weathering the impact of an ongoing price war in China’s EV sector, with an increase in third-quarter profit growth.
CATL has a market value of 1.2 trillion yuan.
Stellantis and CATL have set up a 50-50 joint venture for the project and expect to start production by the end of 2026.

site_title: One Bernam developer slashes prices by up to 27%, sells 87 units in weekend promotion
summary: HY Realty and MCC Group sold 87 units of One Bernam, a 99-year leasehold condominium in Tanjong Pagar, at prices from S$1.3 million to S$3.5 million, with discounts ranging from 15 to 27% off the original prices. The project has cleared 99% of its 351 units since its launch in 2021. Market watchers speculate that the project may be nearing its Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) deadline, prompting the clearance of unsold stock.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Approval for sales timeline extension is on a case-by-case basis, said DPM Wong.

site_title: Disa signs non-binding term sheet to acquire medical company stake for S$5.5 million
summary: Disa, a Catalist-listed company, has signed a non-binding term sheet to acquire a 50% stake in a medical company for S$5.5 million. The stake purchase will be made up of S$3 million in cash and S$2.5 million in new shares. The deal is non-binding and has no obligation for Disa to purchase the shares until a binding sale and purchase agreement is signed. The target company's sole shareholder, a medical doctor, is not affiliated with Disa.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Industry observers believe Singapore still has what it takes to remain at the top – largely by taking on complicated treatment and surgeries.

site_title: European banks’ record takings fuel M&A talk as pressures on industry persist
summary: European banks are experiencing record profits, fueling speculation about mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals in the industry. Despite governments opposing some deals, executives and investors expect increased M&A activity, particularly in areas like alternative investments and FinTech. The US President-elect's plans to slash red tape for US lenders may also intensify competition, making it easier for US firms to acquire European rivals. However, regulatory challenges and political opposition remain hurdles to deal closure, with some experts warning that a full banking union is still needed for cross-border M&A.

images.alt_text: In almost two decades atop JPMorgan, Jamie Dimon has become increasingly outspoken about policy matters beyond those that directly affect the finance industry.

site_title: Regency Steel Asia chairman fined S$350,000 for false trading of Hiap Hoe, Hotel Grand Central shares
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) fined Gui Boon Sui, chairman of Regency Steel Asia, S$350,000 for conducting false and unauthorised trading of shares in Hiap Hoe and Hotel Grand Central between 2018 and 2022. Gui artificially inflated the closing prices of the two companies' shares for 554 days and 56 days, respectively. He admitted to contravening false trading rules and agreed to pay the penalty without court action, and also gave an undertaking not to be a company director for two years.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department usually jointly investigate market misconduct offences.

site_title: China developer that led the way on debt overhaul at risk again
summary: China's developer Sunac China Holdings, which successfully restructured its offshore debt in late 2023, is now at risk of defaulting again. The company's stock and bond prices have plummeted to their lowest levels in months amid concerns over meeting looming repayment deadlines. Sunac has stated it "can't rule out" a second offshore debt restructuring, and a court petition to wind up the company may lead to it being unable to pay some offshore debt. This puts its offshore agreement in jeopardy.

images.alt_text: Investors have grown increasingly anxious about Sunac's upcoming interest payments amid sluggish sales, which sent its shares and US dollar notes to their lowest levels in months last week.
China’s private-sector developers have yet to escape a years-long downturn in the country’s property market as sales of new homes remain weak.
Sunac has 15.4 billion yuan (S$2.9 billion) in outstanding onshore debt.

site_title: Gold beats STI, Hong Kong-listed tech to be top-traded ETF on SGX in 2024
summary: Gold ETFs experienced a surge in trading value in Singapore last year, with SPDR Gold Shares overtaking the Lion-OCBC Securities Hang Seng Tech ETF and SPDR Straits Times Index ETF in terms of average daily trading value. The rise is attributed to record-high gold prices in 2024, fueling investment appetite for physically backed gold ETFs. SPDR Gold Shares became the top-traded ETF on the local bourse, with an average daily trading value of S$3.1 million, and is now the largest bullion-backed ETF globally.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Generic photos of SGX
BT
Industrial stocks listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw substantial gains in 2024 while performance across other sectors such as banking and real estate varied.
Institutional investors were net sellers of S-Reits, with S$1.6 billion in net outflows in 2024.
The review group was set up in August last year to recommend measures to aid in the development of equities in Singapore.

site_title: Top Asian oil buyers in turmoil after sweeping US sanctions on Russia’s oil industry
summary: The US has imposed its most aggressive sanctions on Russia's oil industry, affecting top Asian oil buyers China and India. Independent Chinese refiners, known as "teapots," will likely suffer losses due to rising oil prices and increased shipping costs. The sanctions, targeting producers, insurers, and vessels, disrupt the trade of cut-price Russian crude, which China and India have relied on since the 2022 Ukraine invasion. As a result, Asian refiners, traders, and port executives are scrambling to manage the fallout, with potential losses expected for Chinese refiners.

images.alt_text: Crude is up more than 6 per cent this year, a robust start that has taken some market participants by surprise as many banks and agencies had forecast a significant supply glut that would weigh on prices.

site_title: iPhone loses global market share with Apple AI absent in China
summary: Apple lost global market share, slipping to 18% in 2024, as the company played catchup on artificial intelligence (AI) following the iPhone 16 launch in September. The absence of Apple AI in China, the world's largest smartphone market, contributed to the decline. Apple sold 5% fewer iPhones and marked a 2% sales decline for the full year, while the global market grew 4%. Chinese rivals, such as Xiaomi and Vivo, gained ground on Samsung and Apple.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid regional rout; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% on Monday, January 13, amid a regional rout, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,791.70. The decline was attributed to strengthened US employment numbers, which dimmed interest-rate-cut expectations. Analysts say the greenback's rise created an overhang for risk sentiment across Asia, with US 10-year treasury yields rising above 4.5%. Local banks, such as UOB and DBS, also fell.

The core CPI, a better snapshot of underlying inflation, is forecast to have risen 3.3 per cent from a year earlier – matching readings from the prior three months.

The Fed’s favoured inflation gauge rose 2.4 per cent in the year to November, and 2.8 per cent minus food and energy, each above the central bank’s 2 per cent target.

site_title: GIC’s investment chief to step down from Singapore wealth fund
summary: GIC's Chief Investment Officer Jeffrey Jaensubhakij is stepping down after nearly 30 years, marking the biggest leadership change at the Singaporean sovereign wealth fund since 2017. Deputy group CIO Bryan Yeo, 46, is expected to be promoted to the top investment role in April. Jaensubhakij's departure comes as GIC ramps up private market investments and deals in the US amid expectations of geopolitical instability and slowing returns. The change is seen as a strategic move to adapt to the changing global economy.

site_title: China vehicle export growth to slow in 2025, association data shows
summary: China's vehicle exports are expected to grow 5.8-6.2 million units in 2025, a slowdown from a 19.3% increase in 2024. This contrasts with a slight uptick forecast for vehicle sales in China, driven by extended policy incentives. Electric vehicle exports fell 10.4% last year, while plug-in hybrid exports rose 190%. Vehicle sales in China are forecast to rise 4.7% to 32.9 million units this year. A slowdown in new energy vehicle sales is expected in 2025, but auto trade-in subsidies are expected to boost growth.

Buyers who trade in an old car for a new EV or plug-in hybrid will receive a 20,000 yuan subsidy.

site_title: South Korea's impeached president gets a pay rise
summary: South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol will receive a 3% pay raise, increasing his salary to 262.6 million won (S$245,183), despite an ongoing impeachment trial and investigation into his martial law declaration. Yoon remains in the presidential residence, resisting arrest, and is awaiting a final Constitutional Court ruling that could finalize his removal from office. His successor, Prime Minister Han Duck-soo, will also receive a 3% pay raise.

site_title: Why global bond markets are convulsing
summary: Global bond markets are experiencing a surge, with yields on 10-year American Treasury bonds reaching almost 5% and German bunds rising to 2.6%. Rising inflation, coupled with uncertainty over economic growth and geopolitical tensions, are driving up yields. Investors expect central banks to keep interest rates high to contain inflation, but market pricing suggests a more hawkish approach may be needed. The increase in yields poses a challenge for governments, which must pay more to service debts, and is particularly painful for mortgage-holders.

images.alt_text: American consumers have not been more bullish on US stocks since surveys began tracking this sentiment. Momentum investing looks poised to crash in a way that could hit many investors hard.

site_title: PropertyGuru CEO Hari Krishnan steps down
summary: PropertyGuru's CEO Hari Krishnan is stepping down after a decade in the role, with Lewis Ng returning as CEO effective March 2025. Krishnan will transition to senior adviser to the board. Ng, who previously served as managing director of Singapore and chief business officer, has over two decades of experience across Asia and the technology industry. The company has been acquired by EQT Private Capital Asia for US$1.1 billion and has since been delisted from the NYSE.

Revenue for the second quarter was up 10.3 per cent amid higher contributions from its marketplaces segment.

site_title: Efforts to improve stock market should also scrutinise Catalist
summary: Singapore Exchange chairman Koh Boon Hwee emphasized the need for courage and a willingness to take risks to improve the local stock market, including Catalist, which was established in 2007. However, Catalist's model, which allows loss-making companies to list without a proven track record of profitability, has been criticized due to episodes like Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine Holdings' (SIAMH) financial woes. A 2020 study found that 56.5% of Catalist companies booked losses in 2019, and the market's view of these companies' prospects is often dim from the start.

site_title: China flags more policy measures to bolster renminbi
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has announced additional measures to bolster the renminbi, its currency, which has been declining amid economic uncertainty and US trade tensions. The PBOC plans to increase its foreign exchange reserves in Hong Kong and allow companies to borrow more overseas, aiming to improve capital flows and stabilize the currency. The renminbi has lost over 3% to the US dollar since the US election in November, and China's onshore currency traded near a 16-month low on Monday.

images.alt_text: The PBOC has purchased a net one trillion yuan of sovereign notes for five straight months to December.
While the yuan has weakened against the US dollar, it climbed to the highest since 2022 versus trading partners’ exchange rates as a result of Beijing’s control.
The statement by the central bank reiterates plans to cut interest rates and the reserve requirement ratio, which dictates how much banks must hold in their coffers, rather than lending or investing.

site_title: Malaysia government to seek gag order on Najib house arrest bid
summary: Malaysia's government plans to seek a gag order to prevent public discussion on former Prime Minister Najib Razak's bid for house arrest, following his recent court victory. The move aims to prohibit the Malaysian parliament and other public bodies from commenting on the issue. Najib, serving a prison sentence for 1MDB-related crimes, is seeking to have the rest of his sentence served at his own residence, citing a decree from the former king. The application is set to be filed by January 20.

site_title: Indonesia’s stock exchange eyes rebound with major IPOs and renewed investor confidence in 2025
summary: Indonesia's stock exchange is poised for a strong rebound in 2025, driven by major initial public offerings (IPOs) and renewed investor confidence. Seven companies have debuted on the exchange, with 19 more in the pipeline, including two worth over 3 trillion rupiah. IDX president director Iman Rachman attributes the turnaround to the new administration's policy clarity and economic stimulus measures. The exchange is also simplifying its listing process and introducing new initiatives to strengthen its regulatory framework and attract high-quality companies.

Malaysia emerges as this year’s IPO winner in terms of deal number and size, on the back of positive economic indicators and robust investor support.

site_title: GSK to buy US cancer biotech IDRx for up to US$1.15 billion
summary: GSK agreed to buy US biotech IDRx for up to $1.15 billion, with $1 billion upfront. IDRx's lead cancer medicine shows potential against gastrointestinal stromal tumours, a type of cancer that leaves patients with few treatment options. The deal aims to expand GSK's oncology capabilities, which have been a bright spot for the company. GSK's pipeline and recent vaccine sales have raised investor concerns, but the acquisition is seen as a move to address these issues.

images.alt_text: GSK expects to record a £1.8 billion charge in its third quarter results due to the settlements, with no impact on its investment plans.

site_title: ST Engineering to work with NTUC, SkillsFuture to upskill workers in precision engineering suppliers
summary: ST Engineering has partnered with NTUC and SkillsFuture Singapore to upskill at least 1,000 workers from its precision engineering suppliers. The two-year collaboration aims to improve the sector's technology and engineering capabilities, with up to 90% of training costs covered by SkillsFuture. The initiative is expected to benefit around 40 SMEs, with ST Engineering leading efforts to upskill workers across its land systems unit, which works with over 100 suppliers.

images.alt_text: From Jan 1, 2025, NTUC will raise the retirement age for its workers to 64 and the re-employment age to 69, it said in a statement on Monday (Dec 9).

site_title: Infinity Financial Advisory Unveils Enhanced Digital Capabilities to Transform Client Financial Planning Experience
summary: Infinity Financial Advisory has launched the i-NITIATE Client App 2.0, an upgraded platform designed to improve the wealth management experience for its clients. The app offers a unified platform for financial management, rewards engagement through activities, and includes partnerships for high-yield savings accounts and premium services. Key features include biometric authentication, the "Enquire Shortfall" tool, and the "Coin Frenzy" in-app game. The app aims to simplify and enhance financial strategy, making it easier for clients to track investments and access personalized advice.

site_title: China’s Shimao drops 15% after developer receives liquidation petition
summary: China's Shimao Group saw its shares drop 15% to HK$0.73 after receiving a liquidation petition from CPYM Link Investment regarding a 258 million yuan cross-border loan guarantee. The Hong Kong high court is set to hear the case. This move comes as Shimao faces financial challenges and is part of the broader Chinese property market downturn.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves draft casino Bill in boost for tourism
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved a draft Bill to legalize casinos, aiming to boost tourism and combat illegal gambling. The proposed legislation, set to be reviewed by the Council of State, would allow integrated resorts with hotels, convention centers, and amusement parks. Casinos could generate 12-40 billion baht in annual revenue, and the government expects tourism revenue to increase by 120-220 billion baht. The move is seen as a major step to capitalize on the country's 60% gambling rate, with potential investors including Galaxy Entertainment Group and MGM Resorts International.

site_title: Goldman strategists see tumbling China stocks rising 20% in 2025
summary: Goldman Sachs strategists predict China stocks will rise 20% by year-end despite a current rout. The strategists, led by Kinger Lau, remain overweight on onshore and offshore shares, citing improving sentiment and liquidity. They recommend buying government consumption proxies, emerging market exporters, and select tech and infrastructure names. The firm also maintains an overweight call on online retail, media, and healthcare stocks. This bullish stance contrasts with a similarly optimistic call in November, which was undermined by recent market moves.

images.alt_text: Export prices have been falling for more than a year as deflation inside China worsens and pushes down the cost of goods.

site_title: The cravenness of Mark Zuckerberg
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has announced changes to Meta's fact-checking regime, scrapping professional fact-checkers and replacing them with a crowdsourced "community notes" system, echoing Elon Musk's X approach. This move has been influenced by Donald Trump, with whom Zuckerberg has met and appointed a Trump ally to the board. Critics argue that this shift is a form of censorship, and Zuckerberg's actions are driven by opportunism and a desire to please Trump rather than a commitment to free expression. The changes have been met with skepticism, with Trump suggesting that Zuckerberg would "spend the rest of his life in prison" if he attempted to "plot against" him.

images.alt_text: Under the guise of free speech, Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg doesn't have to worry about whether any of its content is factually correct.

site_title: Smart glasses enter new era with sleeker designs, lower prices
summary: Smart glasses have entered a new era with sleeker designs and lower prices, making them more comparable to traditional eyewear. Major manufacturers such as Ray-Ban and Halliday are showcasing innovative features like augmented reality, GPS, and cameras. The industry's growth is driven by advancements in AI, AR, and miniaturization technologies. However, integrating technology into fashionable frames requires careful compromise, with some models starting at $300 and others at $200. Companies are prioritizing cool designs, with ultra-thin frames and minimalist approaches becoming increasingly popular.

site_title: Don’t spare asset-rich, cash-poor private homeowners from paying higher property taxes
summary: Asset-rich, cash-poor elderly private homeowners in Singapore may face higher property taxes if the government increases rates in future budgets. However, the government is providing relief to owner-occupiers, including a one-off rebate and a 24-month interest-free instalment plan for those aged 65 and over. The author argues that elderly homeowners who are asset-rich but cash-poor should consider selling their homes to fund retirement or use their homes as collateral for loans. This can help drive down housing prices and create economic value, ultimately benefiting the younger generation.

site_title: Chinese artist cashes in on Buddha-like Trump statues
summary: Chinese artist Hong Jinshi has gained popularity by creating Buddha-like statues of US President-elect Donald Trump, selling them for between $187 and $20,000. The sculptures, designed as a joke in 2021, have become hot property ahead of Trump's inauguration, with hundreds sold in the last few years. Hong estimates he has shifted hundreds of the ceramic creations, with some copies appearing on US shopping platforms. The artist pokes fun at authority figures, admiring Trump's entrepreneurial spirit and criticizing his divisive rhetoric, while maintaining a neutral stance on his policies towards China.

site_title: Dubai’s world-beating property rally shows signs of strain
summary: Dubai's prime home prices are expected to rise 5% this year, surpassing London's 2% and New York's 3%. Despite the record rally, which has lasted several years, some developers, including Emaar Properties, are warning of a slowdown. The emirate's property boom will continue with new tower and villa communities springing up, but the need for caution is growing as builders face the challenge of filling the homes being built.

The article highlights the potential for Centurion to be a major player in the market, and investors should keep a close eye on its developments.

site_title: Gold flat amid Trump policy uncertainty, strong US data
summary: Gold prices held steady at $2,690.49 per ounce, as investors weighed the uncertainty of the incoming Trump administration's policies against a strong US employment report. The non-farm payrolls increase of 256,000 jobs supported the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on future rate cuts, with market estimates pricing in a pause to the Fed's easing cycle and just one rate cut this year. Investors will closely watch the release of the monthly consumer price index and Fed officials' comments this week.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was unchanged at US$2,670.16 per ounce.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street losses after blockbuster US jobs report
summary: Asia's markets plummeted on Monday, with Hong Kong, Taipei, and Manila down over 1% each, while Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, and Jakarta also fell. The sell-off followed a strong US jobs report, which dealt a blow to hopes for interest rate cuts. The US economy created 256,000 jobs last month, surpassing forecasts. The rally in oil prices, sparked by new sanctions on Russia's energy sector, also contributed to the decline.

summary: Singapore police are collaborating with Philippine authorities in investigating former mayor Alice Guo, who is facing Senate investigations into her ties to an online casino in the Philippines allegedly linked to money laundering and other crimes. The investigation is part of a broader crackdown on offshore gaming operators banned by Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr in July 2024. Guo's associates in Singapore include Zhang Jie, former president of an online casino group.

summary: Japan Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba asked US President Joe Biden to address concerns over Nippon Steel's planned $14.9 billion acquisition of US Steel, which Biden blocked on national security grounds on January 3. The Biden administration has delayed the order for Nippon Steel to abandon the bid until June. Ishiba also discussed maritime and economic security cooperation with Biden and Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. in an online meeting.

summary: Johnson & Johnson is in talks to acquire US$10 billion biotech company Intra-Cellular Therapies, focused on treatments for central nervous system disorders. The deal could be finalized as early as this week, with shares of Intra-Cellular rising 40% over the past 12 months. The acquisition would mark a significant move by J&J into the biotech sector, with the deal potentially worth US$10 billion.

site_title: Jamie Dimon says tariffs can help resolve competition, security issues
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon stated that tariffs, if used properly, can help resolve issues such as unfair competition and national security. Dimon expressed concerns about the potential impact of tariffs on supply chains and economic growth. He noted that President-elect Donald Trump's use of tariffs can be effective, but also warned about the risks of misusing this tool. Dimon emphasized the need for diversified supply chains and resiliency in the face of potential trade disruptions.

site_title: Zelensky says he’s ready to exchange North Korean soldiers for Ukrainians held in Russia
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announced that his country is ready to exchange North Korean soldiers for Ukrainians held captive in Russia. Ukraine has taken two North Korean soldiers prisoner in Russia's Kursk region, the first time Ukraine has announced a capture alive since entering the war last autumn. Zelensky proposed an exchange if North Korean leader Kim Jong Un facilitates it, and has expressed hope for North Korean soldiers who wish to stay in Ukraine or spread the truth about the war.

site_title: Bain matches CC Capital’s A$2.9 billion offer for Insignia
summary: Bain Capital has matched CC Capital Partners' A$2.9 billion offer for Insignia Financial, a Boston-based private equity firm. The bid values Insignia at A$4.30 per share, matching an earlier offer from CC Capital. This is the second bid for Insignia, following a lower offer from Bain last month that was rejected. The acquisition of Insignia is seen as part of a trend of overseas players acquiring Australian money management firms due to their exposure to one of the world's fastest-growing pension pools.

site_title: Global air finance summit to take stock of jet shortages, trade risks
summary: Global air finance leaders gathered in Dublin to discuss jet shortages, trade risks, and the impact of the US presidential change. Despite strong lease rates and relatively stable oil prices, industry uncertainty persists due to supply chain issues and planned manufacturer production delays. The industry is also weighing the potential effects of tariffs imposed by the new US administration, which could affect supply chains and air cargo demand. Experts predict the jet shortage will last at least a decade, with some speculating it may return to excess capacity in three years.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,790.51 at 9:01 am on Monday, following losses in global markets last Friday. Local banking stocks were down, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB trading lower. The market saw 76 losers for every 33 gainers, with 36.9 million securities worth S$43.6 million changing hands. The decline is attributed to a strong US employment report fueling expectations of fewer interest rate cuts this year.

summary: Fintech funding in South-east Asia declined 23% to US$1.6 billion in 2024, bucking the overall trend. However, payments and cryptocurrency sectors saw growth, with payments raising US$366 million (53% increase) and cryptocurrency raising US$325 million (20% increase). Banking tech also saw a 63% increase in funding. This contrasts with other sectors, which experienced a decline. Despite rising interest rates, the innovative spirit of the fintech sector continued to shine, according to CEO Neha Singh.

site_title: UK home sellers made smallest profit in over a decade in 2024
summary: The UK's housing market experienced its smallest profit in over a decade in 2024, with average gross profit on a sale in England and Wales decreasing by 11% to £91,820. Higher mortgage rates and increased transaction costs restricted sellers' ability to hike asking prices, while a cost-of-living squeeze reduced demand. According to a report by Hamptons International, only 25% of home sellers in London made a profit within five years, marking the first time profits fell below £200,000 in the capital.

summary: Miyoshi's CEO, Andrew Sin, will continue in his role despite being fined S$22,400 by Singapore's State Court for failing to recognize an impairment loss in the company's financial statements. The board of directors recommended Sin's continuation, citing his instrumental role in the company's performance and lack of regulatory conditions. Sin's expertise, experience, and relationships with business partners are also seen as crucial to the company's operations. The fine and sentencing are not expected to impact the company's business and operations.

site_title: Asean telcos face softer 2025 outlook, but asset sales offer silver lining
summary: Southeast Asian telcos are expected to face a softer 2025 outlook due to weak economic conditions and increasing competition. Maybank analysts predict a 3% year-on-year rise in sector revenue, down from 4% in 2024, and slower margin growth. However, consolidation and monetization of non-core operations could offer opportunities for some telcos, with Indonesian telcos XL Axiata and Smartfren expected to benefit from a merger. Analysts also predict significant free cash flow generation potential for the Asia-Pacific telecom sector, with an average yield of 8-9% for 2025 and 2026.

site_title: A*Star, Grand Venture Technology to develop manufacturing platform as company’s semiconductor business gains pace
summary: Grand Venture Technology (GVT) and the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) have partnered to develop a customised manufacturing platform for advanced ceramics. The partnership aims to strengthen GVT's competitive edge and capture opportunities in high-growth industries. This follows GVT's recent growth in its semiconductor business, including a preferred supplier contract for advanced semiconductor packaging equipment and a 50.8% year-on-year increase in its revenue. The company expects to meet its target revenue guidance for the second half of 2024.

summary: Retail investors navigating online trading platforms in Asia Pacific face numerous challenges, including overwhelming information and the presence of bad actors. To succeed, investors should adopt a customized approach, focusing on trading tools, technology, and risk management. Education and understanding of psychology behind trading are also crucial, as biases and emotions can impact decision-making. site_title: Chinese trade surplus soars to US$1 trillion ahead of Trump return
summary: China's trade surplus surged to a record $992 billion in 2024, driven by strong exports and weak imports, amid a years-long housing crisis. The surplus, 21% higher than the previous year, is now threatened by the incoming Trump administration's tariff threats, which could lead to severe challenges for China's export growth. Exports to the US rose to nearly $49 billion in December, and shipments to South-east Asia, particularly Vietnam, surged as companies sought to avoid US tariffs. However, a high base in 2024 may limit year-on-year readings, and punitive levies could divert Chinese exports and widen trade tensions.

site_title: Tokyo museum offers visitors ‘flashback’ to defunct technology
summary: The Extinct Media Museum in Tokyo offers a unique experience by showcasing a collection of defunct technology, including old cameras, cassette tapes, and cell phones. The museum's curator, Barbara Asuka, believes that all media equipment will eventually "die out" and aims to preserve these items through a hands-on experience, allowing visitors to pick up and touch the gadgets to engage their senses. The museum accepts donations and has a general admission price of around 2,000 yen, with discounted rates for donors and students.

site_title: Rosy wage outlook, weak yen drawing BOJ attention to inflation risks
summary: The Bank of Japan is closely monitoring rising inflationary pressures due to sustained wage gains and a weak yen, which may lead to an upgrade in its inflation forecast this month. Despite potential interest rate hikes, temporary factors such as rising rice prices may prevent a hike if inflation remains at 2% target. The BOJ is set to debate interest rate changes at its policy meeting on January 23-24, as core consumer inflation accelerated to 2.7% in November, with wage momentum appearing strong.

images.alt_text: Despite rising inflation, the government has held off on declaring an end to “deflation”, holding the view that Japan’s economy still faces risks of another downturn.

site_title: Taking the measure of US stocks: the long view and valuations
summary: Two fund management firms have adjusted downwards their long-run expectations of returns for large-cap US equities, citing concerns over valuations. Michael Cembalest, JPMorgan Asset Management's chairman of markets and investment strategy, expects a 10-15% correction in US equities this year due to high valuations. Citi's strategy bulletin also raises concerns over valuations, but remains optimistic about returns, citing strong fundamentals and new technology.

The structures, which guide landings, were found to be flawed at seven domestic airports, including Muan. The move comes after an investigation into the crash, which resulted in the plane bursting into flames after hitting a localiser.

site_title: Malaysia imposes anti-dumping duties on iron, steel imports from four countries
summary: Malaysia has imposed provisional anti-dumping duties on imports of flat-rolled iron products and non-alloy steel from China, India, Japan, and South Korea, effective January 11. The duties range from 2.52% to 36.8% and will remain in place for up to 120 days. A final determination will be made by May 10, with feedback on the preliminary determination due by January 20. The decision follows an investigation that started in August, aimed at protecting Malaysian industries from unfair trade practices.

site_title: Widening pay gap for women on boards is ‘red flag’ for Europe
summary: Women on boards in the European financial services sector are facing a widening pay gap, with women earning 36% less than men on average in 2023, compared to 31% in 2019. The pay disparity is attributed to women being placed in less important roles and having less C-Suite experience. The European Union aims to achieve 40% female representation on boards by 2026, with 28% of firms falling short of the target. The pay gap is a "red flag" for the industry, highlighting the need for boards to closely monitor pay discrepancies and address the issue.

Young conservative men, including evangelical Christians and Trump supporters, are leading the pro-Yoon protests, while others, including Shin Ji Young, criticize the president's actions. The divide highlights the country's deepening political divisions among its youth.

Canada buys more US-made goods than any other country, with a $320 billion trade deficit in the first 11 months of last year. site_title: BlackRock faces new deadline from US regulator over bank stakes
summary: BlackRock is facing a new deadline from the US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) to resolve an issue regarding oversight of the firm's stakes in banks. The FDIC granted a fresh deadline of February 10, potentially leading to an investigation and more compulsory actions. BlackRock had initially failed to meet a January deadline and requested an extension until March 31, citing concerns about the plan's impact on its clients. The FDIC may demand more information and issue a subpoena if progress is not made, amid growing calls for greater oversight of large asset managers.

site_title: US job growth beats expectations in December; jobless rate falls to 4.1%
summary: US job growth unexpectedly accelerated in December with 256,000 new jobs added, beating economists' forecasts of 160,000. The unemployment rate fell to 4.1%, reinforcing the Federal Reserve's cautious approach to interest rate cuts this year. This solid labor market performance contrasts with expectations of slowing growth, indicating a resilient economy.

site_title: JPMorgan asks staff to return to office five days a week, prompting complaints

The bank, which has over 316,000 staff worldwide, already has more than half of its employees working in the office full-time. CEO Jamie Dimon and other executives cited benefits of in-office work, including better learning and innovation, but acknowledged some employees' concerns about commuting and mental health costs. Employees will receive at least 30 days' notice before returning to the office.

site_title: US inflation is set to back Fed pause after robust jobs data
summary: US inflation is expected to remain steady after robust jobs data, supporting the Federal Reserve's cautious approach to further rate cuts. The core CPI, a measure of underlying inflation, is forecast to rise 3.3% from a year earlier, matching the prior three months. The resilient job market and steady economy have stalled progress towards tamer inflation, with employers adding over a quarter million jobs in December and the unemployment rate unexpectedly falling. Economists have pared their forecasts for more rate reductions, citing elevated household net worth and wage growth outpacing inflation.

Global growth forecasts are unchanged at 3.2% in 2024 and slightly lower at 3.1% in 2025, with regional trends showing divergent growth rates, including a slowdown in the EU and India.

site_title: Expanding South-east Asia’s grid supply chains can mitigate critical transmission equipment shortages
summary: Asean governments are urged to focus on localizing and scaling supply chains for grid components to address the global shortage of transmission equipment and equipment backlogs. The grid infrastructure and essential transmission system equipment pose a significant threat to economic growth and sustainability. Investing in transmission system supply chains represents a significant long-term business opportunity for Asean member states, addressing national energy security risks more successfully than competing with China in the solar panel market. The global demand for grid system components is projected to grow to $700 billion by 2032, with opportunities for Asean countries to capitalize on this growth.

summary: Chinese property developer Sunac China Holdings cannot rule out a second offshore debt overhaul due to sluggish sales and financial stress. The region's growing middle class, young workforce, and strategic sectors like manufacturing and digital economy are driving growth. Three of the top five costliest disasters were in Asia, including the Noto earthquake in Japan, Typhoon Yagi in Asia-Pacific, and floods in China. The two most devastating natural disasters globally were Hurricane Helene and Hurricane Melton, with total losses of $56 billion and $38 billion, respectively. The report also highlighted rising extreme weather events, with temperatures surpassing 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels for the first time in 2024.

This move, combined with the stock market's recent decline, has raised concerns about Buffett's intentions and the state of the economy. Berkshire's cash hoard of $276.9 billion is now at record levels, sparking worries about the impact on consumption and the labor market. Authorities have rolled out limited support measures, but market pessimism remains, driven by concerns over a housing crisis and deflationary pressures.

site_title: Potential US tariffs to put pressure on currencies of export-oriented economies: analysts
summary: US tariffs on export-oriented economies may pressure their currencies in 2025, with currencies of South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, and Thailand likely to be affected. A strong US dollar and widening growth differential between the US and the rest of the world are also contributing factors. Analysts warn that US tariffs and potential retaliations could pose significant risks to these economies. In contrast, domestic-driven economies' currencies may perform well in 2025.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Asian currencies have been swept aside by the US dollar’s broad gains due to Federal Reserve officials’ cautious tone on its interest rate path.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim at the 44th and 45th ASEAN Summits in Vientiane, Laos, in October. Malaysia will officially assume the Chair of Asean starting Jan 1, 2025.
Authorities in developing economies are on the defensive as the greenback’s strength wreaks havoc across global markets.

site_title: Bullish outlook seen for WTI after breakout
summary: WTI oil prices are rising due to a combination of the Chinese government's stimulus measures and heightened demand for heating fuel caused by a severe US winter storm. The latest round of stimulus measures from Beijing aims to boost business investment and consumer spending, increasing oil demand in the world's second-largest economy. WTI prices broke out above a key resistance level at US$70 per barrel in mid-December and continued to rise, with the Moving Average Convergence Divergence technical indicator remaining above the zero line. The price is expected to climb further towards US$77 per barrel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Oil pump jacks are seen at the Vaca Muerta shale oil and gas deposit in the Patagonian province of Neuquen, Argentina, January 21, 2019.  REUTERS/Agustin Marcarian/File Photo

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for January 10, 2025, reveals a mixed week for the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market experienced softness initially but regained momentum by Thursday, with rates increasing to $12,010 per day. The Pacific market remained under pressure due to oversupply, while the South Brazil and West Africa markets gained strength due to tighter tonnage availability. The North Atlantic market saw a shift towards the end of the week, with rates increasing on the transatlantic and fronthaul routes. The Panamax market declined further, with rates falling below $9,000.

images.alt_text: lA roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Dec 20, 2024).

site_title: Toymaker becomes a billionaire after frenzied Hong Kong IPO
summary: Toymaker Bloks Group's Hong Kong IPO debut on January 10 drew overwhelming demand, catapulting founder and chairman Zhu Weisong into billionaire status with a net worth of US$1.7 billion. The company's shares surged 41% to HK$85 on its trading debut, following a similar trend seen in other recent Hong Kong IPOs. Bloks Group, which has been unprofitable since 2021, aims to expand its product line, including assembly character figurines developed from famous animation series. Zhu's wealth adds to a pipeline of IPOs in Hong Kong supercharging wealth among ultra-rich individuals.

images.alt_text: One closely-watched issue is whether the earnings-growth momentum will accelerate beyond the largest tech companies, which could provide a boost to some of the market’s laggards.

site_title: Greenback firms as strong jobs data support Fed easing pause
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen following a report that showed the US economy added 256,000 jobs in December, exceeding expectations. The data also showed a decrease in unemployment to 4.1% and a 0.3% increase in average hourly earnings. The euro fell to its lowest level since November 2022, while the dollar rose to its highest level since July against the yen. The Federal Reserve is expected to pause its rate-cutting cycle, with foreign exchange forecasters predicting the euro will reach parity with the dollar in 2025.

images.alt_text: Sterling was last down about 0.69 per cent at US$1.2282 while the euro also eased, albeit less than the pound, to US$1.0302.

site_title: Growing risks from payment-in-kind debt draw watchdog scrutiny
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) plans to examine the growing use of payment-in-kind (PIK) debt, which allows companies to defer interest payments, amid concerns it may be delaying inevitable insolvency and undermining financial stability. PIK debt has become increasingly popular among private equity firms and companies struggling to manage higher interest payments. The IMF will also investigate interconnections between banks and private credit, as well as the different layers of leverage in the financial ecosystem. This comes as watchdogs warn of potential systemic risk from the growth of private credit and the risk of bubbles in private markets.

images.alt_text: Workers use their phones as they make their way about the City of London on a cold and sunny day in London, Britain, January 9, 2025. REUTERS/Chris J. Ratcliffe
A pedestrian walks past The Gherkin building (2nd L), officially 30 St Mary Axe, in the City of London financial district, central London, on January 9, 2025. (Photo by HENRY NICHOLLS / AFP)

site_title: Photo book and exhibition explore life, loss and the resilience of human spirit
summary: A photo book and exhibition titled "Moving: Yeo Whee Jim's Photographs and Reflections" will launch on January 15, showcasing 28 images of the author and photographer's life with motor neurone disease. The book, accompanied by an exhibition, explores themes of love, loss, and resilience. All proceeds will benefit The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, which supports young artistic talent in Singapore. Yeo aims to create a legacy that inspires future generations and fosters an inclusive arts community.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
A distant view of Tottori Sand Dunes.
Through 10 immersive rooms, the show "Jean-Michel Basquiat: Behind The Canvas Series 1" tries to capture the vibe of 1980s New York, which inspired the artist's iconic works.
Anh Sung-jae, the chef-owner of the three Michelin-starred Mosu restaurant in Seoul, was catapulted to global fame in 2024 as one of the judges on the hit reality cooking show "Culinary Class Wars".

site_title: Why Singapore is bringing blockchain into mutual funds
summary: Singapore is exploring the use of blockchain in mutual funds to improve efficiency and speed up transactions. The country's financial regulator, MAS, is collaborating with other regulators to develop a platform for distributed ledgers in mutual funds. This initiative aims to reduce the time it takes to move pension savings into mutual funds, which currently takes a week or longer. If successful, Singapore can demonstrate the utility of blockchain in mutual funds and pitch the platform to the wider asset management industry, potentially increasing its competitiveness in the global financial center.

images.alt_text: Crypto advocate Paul Atkins has been nominated as the next chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission..

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as US jobs boom stokes inflation fears
summary: European shares dropped 0.84% to 511.50 points on Friday, their largest fall in three weeks, amid US job growth and inflation fears. The US unemployment rate fell to 4.1%, sparking concerns about the need for interest-rate cuts, with traders expecting a rate cut in June and holding rates steady for the rest of the year. This cautious stance by the Federal Reserve, coupled with uncertainty over US President-elect Donald Trump's potential economic emergency declaration, contributed to the market's decline.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 94.9 points, or 0.22 per cent, at the open to 42540.29.

site_title: To be Asia’s next tiger economy, Vietnam needs to achieve close to double-digit GDP growth
summary: Vietnam aims to achieve double-digit gross domestic product (GDP) growth in 2025, a goal that experts consider ambitious and potentially unrealistic, even for a country like Vietnam that has historically experienced rapid growth. Analysts caution that achieving more than 10% growth is rare, even among developed nations, and that sustained prosperity and long-term economic stability are key to Vietnam's success. The country's vision of becoming a high-income nation by 2045 relies on sustained growth, and experts suggest that a more achievable goal is around 8% growth for a decade to lift Vietnam to a position of permanently high income.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's bureaucratic reform is expected to be finalised by the end of the first quarter of 2025.
Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has urged officials to focus on disbursing public investment from the start of 2025 to create growth momentum.
Both Vietnam and the Philippines consider the US a key trading and geopolitical partner, and these policy changes are set to take place as the new Trump administration comes in.
Vietnam expects its stock market to be upgraded in 2025 by FTSE to emerging market, from the current frontier status.
An underground metro station at District 1. The line is funded primarily through Japan’s official development assistance.

site_title: Financial spring-cleaning in Year of the Snake
summary: Financial experts recommend embracing the characteristics of the Chinese zodiac's Year of the Snake, which include wisdom, flexibility, intelligence, and transformation, to enhance financial wellness. Four key strategies inspired by the snake include: 1) Practising patience and discipline through long-term investing, 2) Planning strategically with financial literacy, 3) Adapting to changes with flexibility, and 4) Focusing on growth and preservation through transformation. Additionally, contributing to the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) and optimizing CPF monies can help individuals achieve higher returns and financial security.
