Good money habits empower you to make informed decisions, better handle emergencies, and help you to work towards your financial goals and achieve sustainable financial wellness.

site_title: US, UK unveil widespread sanctions against Russia’s energy sector
summary: The US and UK have unveiled sanctions against Russia's energy sector, including oil giant Gazprom Neft and Surgutneftegas, with the sanctions set to take effect between January 10 and 13. The move aims to reduce Russian revenues from energy exports, with the US Treasury Department designating over 180 ships and the UK government announcing sanctions against the two companies. The sanctions are seen as a response to Russia's actions in Ukraine, with the UK stating its profits are "lining (Vladimir Putin's) war chest and facilitating the war."

Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic claimed that the United States and the United Kingdom were preparing to impose sanctions on the NIS oil group, Serbia's only gas supplier, of which more than 50% are owned by Russia's Gazprom Neft and Gazprom. Brent crude futures settled at US$79.76 a barrel, up US$2.84, or 3.7 per cent, on Friday after crossing US$80 a barrel for the first time since Oct 7.

site_title: US stock market faces reality check in high-bar earnings season
summary: US stocks face a reality check as companies release quarterly earnings, with the S&P 500 Index expected to show a 7.3% increase in earnings growth from the previous year, the second-highest pre-season forecast in three years. This sets a high bar for future growth, with analysts forecasting 13% earnings-per-share (EPS) growth in 2025, nearly double the current estimates. The earnings season, led by financial bellwethers, will test whether valuations have outrun the underlying reality, with investors watching for signs of acceleration beyond tech companies and insight into trade, tariffs, and taxes.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 1.6 per cent to 41,938.45, and the broad-based S&P 500 Index fell 1.5 per cent to 5,827.04 on Friday.

site_title: Industrial stocks lead the way in 2024; analysts upbeat on banking, tech sectors this year
summary: Singapore's benchmark STI index rose 16.9% in 2024, its best year since 2017, driven by strong performance from industrial stocks. Oiltek International and Pharmesis International led the charge, with Oiltek's share price surging 368.2% and Pharmesis' rising 486.7%. Energy stocks also performed well, with Salt Investments rising 300%. Analysts attribute the growth to global macroeconomic conditions and internal factors such as corporate restructuring. However, valuations in technology-related firms have risen significantly, and investors should be cautious. The banking sector also delivered strong performance, driven by high interest rates and fee income growth.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty

site_title: Chinese developers begin new year with deepening debt woes
summary: Chinese property developers begin 2025 with deepening debt woes, despite Beijing's efforts to stabilize the housing market. Sales from top 100 builders slumped 28.1% last year, compared to a 16.5% drop in 2023. Defaults and share price drops, including a 30% decline for Sunac China Holdings, have raised concerns about the nation's real estate crisis entering its fifth year with little sign of improvement.

images.alt_text: Evergrande’s court-approved liquidators are still navigating its complex structural maze and thorny legal questions about their reach in mainland jurisdictions where much of its assets are based.

site_title: ‘Den of Thieves 2’ snatches top spot in North American box office
summary: Gerard Butler's "Den of Thieves 2: Panthera" has taken the top spot in North America with an estimated $15.5 million in ticket sales. The film, which stars Butler as Los Angeles sheriff "Big Nick" O'Brien, follows his pursuit of a gang of thieves inspired by the 2003 Antwerp diamond heist. The movie's opening is considered a good start for the crime thriller series, according to analyst David A. Gross, who notes that these films are made for audiences rather than critics.

images.alt_text: Gerard Butler as 'Big Nick' O'Brien and O’Shea Jackson Jr. as Donnie Wilson in Den of Thieves 2: Panthera. Photo Credit: Rico Torres.
Global ticket sales fell at a double-digit clip last year due to a sharp drop in China, the world’s second-largest market, along with contractions in Japan, South Korea and Germany.
Few would now bet against Demi Moore to win an Oscar for her role in "The Substance".

site_title: 2024 was the first year above 1.5 degrees Celsius of global warming, scientists say
summary: The world experienced its first full year above 1.5 degrees Celsius of global warming in 2024, according to the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service. Every month in 2024 was the warmest or second-warmest for that month since records began, with the planet's average temperature 1.6 degrees Celsius higher than in the pre-industrial period. The milestone confirms climate change is pushing the planet's temperature to levels never before experienced by modern humans, despite governments' promises under the 2015 Paris Agreement to prevent average temperatures exceeding 1.5 degrees Celsius.

images.alt_text: Hurricanes Milton and Helene, which ripped through the US, ended up being the costliest natural disasters of 2024, according to industry data compiled by Munich Re.

site_title: Larger S-Reits rank among those with highest net retail inflows in 2024
summary: Institutional investors were net sellers of Singapore Reits in 2024, with S$1.6 billion in net outflows, while retail investors bought S$1.6 billion net across the sector, taking total net inflows to over S$6 billion. The Reit sector had the highest net retail inflows in 2024, followed by real estate excluding Reits.

images.alt_text: 2024 saw S-Reits become more active in their equity fundraising, raising over S$2.8 billion, and with two S-Reits launching EFR exercises that raised more than S$1 billion.

site_title: Oil rises as Russia sanctions bolster crude’s hot start to 2025
summary: Oil prices surged to a three-month high as the US imposed sweeping sanctions on Russia, boosting crude by over 6% this year. Brent futures rose 3.7% to $79 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate closed above $76 a barrel. The sanctions target key Russian oil exports and insurers, and traders are now expecting a tighter market, fueled by cold weather and dwindling US stockpiles. Despite concerns about the sanctions' impact, hedge funds have become increasingly bullish on crude, and market participants warn that the rally may be short-lived.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$79.76 a barrel, up US$2.84, or 3.7 per cent, on Friday after crossing US$80 a barrel for the first time since Oct 7.

site_title: China's women e-sports players defy sexism for love of the game
summary: Women e-sports players in China face numerous challenges, including sexism, online abuse, and limited opportunities. Despite generating over $3.7 billion in revenue in 2024 and attracting 490 million viewers, women players are underrepresented in professional clubs and tournaments. Many face discriminatory comments, accusations of using sex for promotions, and reluctance from elite clubs to train them. To overcome these hurdles, women players must also prove themselves in a male-dominated field. Increased investment from big gaming companies and supportive policies from authorities are seen as key to creating a more inclusive e-sports industry.

images.alt_text: The abrupt move comes just days after Disney appeared to have removed one legal obstacle to the deal, agreeing to merge smaller streamer FuboTV .

site_title: US: Stocks plunge on solid jobs report
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 1.6% to 41,938.45, and the S&P 500 Index falling 1.5% to 5,827.04, after a strong employment report showed the economy added 256,000 jobs in December, beating expectations. The tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index also retreated 1.6%. Investors took the better-than-expected labor market figures as a sign that the Federal Reserve would be slower in reducing interest rates, with a 97% chance of holding rates steady at its next policy meeting.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx  600 dropped 0.84 per cent to 511.50 points on Friday, its most significant fall since Dec 20, despite clinching its strongest weekly performance in a month.

site_title: How the Fed will help Singapore Reits outshine banks
summary: The article suggests that Singapore's Reits (Real Estate Investment Trusts) may soon outshine the country's banks, driven by lower interest rates and higher rental income. Unlike banks, Reits have struggled with high interest costs and low profit margins, but as interest rates ease, Reits are expected to benefit from lower expenses and increased rental income. Analysts predict that Reits will pay 2.9% more per unit next financial year, and some Reits have already shown signs of recovery, such as Parkway Life Reit's acquisition of a nursing home in Japan. As banks retreat, Reits are poised to step into the spotlight.

images.alt_text: 2024 saw S-Reits become more active in their equity fundraising, raising over S$2.8 billion, and with two S-Reits launching EFR exercises that raised more than S$1 billion.

site_title: Trump, Zuckerberg meet at Mar-a-Lago, Semafor reports
summary: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with US President-elect Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago, according to a source familiar with the matter. Meanwhile, Meta announced it is ending its diversity, equity, and inclusion programs, including those for hiring and training, in a memo to its employees. The social media company also scrapped its US fact-checking program and relaxed curbs on discussions around contentious topics, bowing to criticism from conservatives as Trump prepares to take office for a second term.

site_title: Indonesia’s coal production hits record as energy needs rise
summary: Indonesia's coal production reached a record 831 million tons in 2024, exceeding the government's target by 17%. The country is the world's largest coal exporter and relies heavily on the fuel for power. Despite President Prabowo Subianto's plan to retire all coal power plants by 2040, the nation's rising production poses a challenge to achieving this goal. Global coal consumption has doubled in the past three decades, but is expected to plateau through 2027, highlighting the need for cleaner energy sources.

site_title: UK finance minister begins China visit amid government bond crisis
summary: UK Finance Minister Rachel Reeves began a visit to China on Saturday, seeking to revive dialogue with the world's second-largest economy amid a government bond crisis. The trip comes as the UK's borrowing costs soared, making it more costly for the government to finance current operations and repay debt. Reeves acknowledged the global financial market fluctuations but stated that the fiscal rules set out in her October budget are non-negotiable. She aims to unlock benefits for British businesses and discuss avenues for cooperation, including financial services.

Royal Mail, whose iconic red post boxes with the Royal Crest dot United Kingdom, has struggled with labour strikes, competition and loss of market share.

site_title: Trump spared jail, fine or probation at hush money sentencing days before inauguration
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has been spared jail, fine, or probation after a judge ruled on his guilty verdict for falsifying business records related to a hush money payment. Justice Juan Merchan sentenced Trump to unconditional discharge, placing a judgment of guilt on his permanent record without any other legal penalty. Trump pleaded not guilty and has vowed to appeal the guilty verdict, which marks the first time a US president has been convicted of a crime. The sentencing occurs just days before Trump's inauguration on January 20.

images.alt_text: The decision is a setback for Trump, who now must pin his hopes of freezing the case on the US Supreme Court, where his lawyers have made a similar emergency bid to avoid the sentencing, set for Friday in a New York state court in Manhattan court.

site_title: Is it the hour of Europe again?
summary: European leaders should support Ukraine, politically and financially, if US President-elect Donald Trump abandons it. Despite Trump's claim that Europe is not self-reliant in security, Europe has overtaken the US as the leading source of aid to Ukraine, with about 125 billion euros allocated. Public support for Ukraine remains strong in Europe, with popular majorities favouring continued support. EU policymakers see a Russian victory as a threat to the Union's existence, and are taking steps to compel Russia to change course, including imposing sanctions.

images.alt_text: (From left) US president-elect Donald Trump, France's President Emmanuel Macron and Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky before a meeting at The Elysee Presidential Palace in Paris, France, Dec 7, 2024. site_title: Prada among suitors for Versace, newspaper reports
summary: Capri Holdings, the owner of luxury brands Versace and Jimmy Choo, has hired Barclays to explore strategic options, including the sale of its brands. Prada is among potential suitors. This follows the abandonment of a $8.5 billion deal to buy Capri in November by Coach-owner Tapestry. Capri executives had not ruled out the possibility of a sale after the deal fell through, citing a desire to maximize shareholder value. The move comes amid a shift in the luxury market landscape.

Global luxury brands are increasingly returning to Hong Kong’s core business districts, attracted by property prices that are much lower than pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: 2025 Toyota Camry Hybrid review: Fresh face, familiar feels
summary: The 2025 Toyota Camry Hybrid receives a fresh face with a new hammerhead grille, sharper lines, and slim lamps, but maintains familiar feels with its intuitive and tactile design. The 12.3-inch touchscreen is clear and easy to use, and physical buttons add a touch of functionality. Despite being a hybrid, the new Camry is largely a facelift, with Toyota emphasizing its all-new design. The review concludes that the Camry remains a reliable choice for those seeking quality, with its hybrid model offering a familiar yet improved driving experience.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after hot payrolls data stokes rate cut worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday after a strong jobs report raised concerns about a potential rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones fell 94.9 points, or 0.22%, to 42,540.29, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The better-than-expected jobs report fueled expectations of a measured approach to monetary policy easing, leading to a sell-off on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 24, 2022.   REUTERS/Caitlin Ochs/File Photo

site_title: EDB executive vice-president Tan Kong Hwee to be appointed CEO of Ipos
summary: Tan Kong Hwee, executive vice-president of the Singapore Economic Development Board, will become CEO of the Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (Ipos) on March 1, succeeding Rena Lee, who is moving to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Lee drove the implementation of the Singapore IP Strategy 2030 and pushed significant legislative and policy reforms to the IP regime during her term. Tan oversees the statutory board's global enterprises and marketing group and has been a member of EDB's executive committee.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Jermany Loy (right), Principal Private Secretary to Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong will succeed Jacqueline Poh (left) on Mar 1.

site_title: Outgoing Iras chief to take over as Auditor-General from February
summary: Ng Wai Choong, 59, will succeed Goh Soon Poh as Auditor-General on Feb 8, 2025. Choong, a two-time Public Administration Medal winner, has 35 years of experience in the public sector, including head of the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore. Goh, a 40-year public sector veteran, will step down on the same day after six years of leading the Auditor-General's Office. The Auditor-General's Office will continue to scrutinize government accounts and publish findings in annual reports.

site_title: Ex-New York mayor Giuliani in contempt of court - again
summary: Former US President Donald Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, has been found in contempt of court for defamatory remarks about two Georgia election workers, Ruby Freeman and Wandrea "Shaye" Moss. A federal jury awarded them $148 million in damages in December 2023 for false claims of election fraud. Giuliani, 80, has been ordered to surrender assets, including a $6 million apartment and a 1980 Mercedes Benz convertible, and faces potential fines for continuing to make defamatory remarks. This is Giuliani's second contempt of court finding this week.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Donald Trump pleaded not guilty and has vowed to appeal the guilty verdict. He appeared with his lawyer Todd Blanche on TV screens beamed to the courtroom with two American flags in the background.

Rudy Giuliani was a key figure in Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election he lost to Democrat Joe Biden. A former New York prosecutor, he has been disbarred over his false election claims.
Rudy Giuliani was photographed on Tuesday in the luxury car outside of a Palm Beach, Florida polling station.

site_title: Oil prices rally 3% as US hits Russian oil with tougher sanctions
summary: US oil prices rallied nearly 3% to their highest in three months on Friday, driven by supply disruptions from the broadest US sanctions package targeting Russian oil and gas revenue. Brent crude futures rose to $79.76 a barrel, a three-month high, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures surged to $76.57 per barrel. The sanctions, imposed by President Joe Biden's administration, are expected to severely disrupt Russian oil exports to India and China, making them more expensive and cutting export volumes.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 76 US cents, or 1 per cent, at US$76.92 a barrel.

site_title: Singapore Poly projects spotlight VR solutions for elderly, circular economy
summary: Students from Singapore Polytechnic have developed a virtual reality app, Steady Lah, to help elderly individuals with physical rehabilitation. The app uses VR games to test mobility and cognitive skills, and provides an engaging way for seniors to exercise in their own homes. The project aims to address the increasing number of elderly in Singapore and the lack of rehab centers. Other student initiatives showcased sustainability-focused projects, including an eco-brick made from upcycled plastic waste and a startup that recycles coffee grounds into chemical-free air fresheners.

images.alt_text: Vincenzo Vinzi, dean and president of Essec Business School (left) and Tony Soh, chief executive of NVPC, at the MOU signing.
Gan Kah Shuen (centre in black), a YFS participant in 2021 who is now a Singapore country director, with other country directors for Singapore and Malaysia and co-founder Lim Ee Ling (far right).

site_title: IMF turns less upbeat on Hong Kong growth, with 2025 forecast cut
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its forecast for Hong Kong's economic growth in 2025 to 2.7% from 3%, citing risks from the city's integration with China, a housing market downturn, and global geopolitical divides. The IMF warns that a sharper-than-expected slowdown in China or a fractured global market could lead to weaker demand for Hong Kong's goods and services, despite a resilient financial system. The fund also expects growth to slow modestly to 2.5% by 2029.

images.alt_text: The RBA has left its key rate at a 13-year high of 4.35 per cent since November 2023 and money market pricing implies a first cut will occur only in April or May.
Friday’s payout brings the total disbursed under the programme since it was signed in March 2023 to around US$9.8 billion.

site_title: Malaysia has no record of documents granting ex-PM Najib home detention
summary: Malaysia's law ministry has no record of documents granting former Prime Minister Najib Razak house arrest, despite his claims that the ex-king's palace granted him the privilege in an "addendum order" accompanying his pardon. Najib's 12-year sentence was halved last year, and he had sought to serve the remainder of his sentence at home. Najib's legal team says the document has been ignored by authorities, but the palace and Najib deny this, stating the ex-king's pardon was unconditional.

images.alt_text: The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.

site_title: In the land of churches and wine
summary: Travelers can explore the historic and culturally rich lands of Georgia and Armenia, home to stunning monasteries and a long history of winemaking. Notable sites include Noravank Monastery in Armenia, built in the 13th century, and Lentekhi in Georgia's Lower Svaneti province. The region's Christian heritage is evident in the presence of Georgian Orthodox and Armenian Apostolic churches, as well as medieval Armenian Khachkars, carved memorial steles marked by a cross. The countries' shared history and cultural elements make for a unique travel experience.

images.alt_text: Bunches of Pinot Noir grapes growing on the Williams Selyem Estate, at an elevation of 30-40m.  The vines are cane-pruned to help with the effects of winter frost in the Russian River Valley AVA, and trained in a six-wire vertical-shoot position (VSP).
A panorama of Siena’s historic centre – a UNESCO World Heritage Site characterised by its distinctive Gothic architectural style – viewed from the Basilica of San Domenico.
Throughout history, and even now in politically unstable regions, autocrats seek to control wine Ñ for many people, it is worth defending.
Christmas in the Caucasus

site_title: Japan’s NTT plans US$1 billion data centre Reit listing in Singapore; appoints BofA, UBS
summary: NTT, a Japanese telecommunication giant, plans to list a US$1 billion data centre real estate investment trust (REIT) in Singapore, with Bank of America and UBS appointed as advisors. The listing, expected in the second half of 2025, could boost IPO activity in Singapore, following a 37.7% increase in IPO proceeds last year. This would be the largest REIT listing in Singapore since 2021's Digital Core Reit IPO. The move comes as investor appetite for data centres grows in Asia, driven by demand for AI and cloud computing services.

images.alt_text: NTT’s global data centres platform is one of the largest in the world, spanning more than 20 countries globally.

site_title: An uphill battle for gender parity in financial leadership
summary: Financial institutions face an uphill battle to achieve gender parity in leadership, despite the business case for diversity and inclusion. Only 14% of senior staff roles in the 2024 Gender Balance Index had female leaders, and representation drops to 16% in top leadership positions. Efforts to build talent pipelines and implement initiatives such as mentorship programs and recruitment quotas have shown some progress, but the pace of change remains glacial. Political uncertainty and a tougher macroeconomic climate threaten to stall progress, with the US experiencing a DEI retreat in the lead-up to the presidential election.

site_title: Global box-office decline was even steeper than in US last year
summary: Global box-office revenue declined 10% to $30.5 billion in 2024, with China's market shrinking 25% due to changing audience tastes and deteriorating relations between the US and China. The international market, excluding the US and Canada, saw a 8.2% decline, with Japan, South Korea, and Germany also experiencing contractions. The decline is attributed to factors such as strikes, a strong US dollar, and the growing popularity of streaming. Despite this, industry experts predict a rebound in 2025 with delayed films and other titles, with a forecasted global ticket sales of $33 billion.

images.alt_text: Few would now bet against Demi Moore to win an Oscar for her role in "The Substance".

(From left) Mexican actress Adriana Paz, Venezuelan actor Edgar Ramirez, US singer and actress Selena Gomez, French director Jacques Audiard, Spanish actress Karla Sofia Gascon and US actress Zoe Saldana pose with the Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy award for "Emilia Perez" in Beverly Hills, California, Jan 5, 2025.
"Mufasa: The Lion King" has earned US$168.6 million domestically over three weekends, propelling it into the top 15 of 2024 releases, Variety reported.
Season 2 is set to compete for best TV series at the upcoming Golden Globes.
Disney’s animated drama 'Mufasa: The Lion King' prevailed in the five days from Christmas Day to Sunday with an estimated take of US$63.8 million.
The third and final season of Squid Game is due in 2025.
Christmas Eve sales are closely watched because this is the last sprint at the end of the year.

site_title: US extends deadline for Nippon Steel to end US Steel bid to June
summary: The US has extended the deadline for Nippon Steel to abandon its $14.1 billion takeover of US Steel Corp to June 18, from February 2, following President Joe Biden's order to halt the deal. Nippon Steel and US Steel had filed a petition with the federal appeals court arguing that the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) failed to consider the deal on national security grounds. The two companies had set June 18 as the completion date for the merger, which now appears to be on track despite the initial block.

site_title: The signals of workplace submissiveness
summary: Workplace submissiveness is a natural phenomenon, mirroring animal behaviors such as pant-grunts, hindquarter displays, and erections. In humans, deference is evident in seating arrangements, job titles, and organizational hierarchies. In meetings, individuals often avoid sitting at the head of the table or in the middle, instead opting for safer positions near the edges or towards the end. This behavior is a subtle yet pervasive expression of dominance and submissiveness in the workplace.

site_title: Big media pulls plug on Venu sports streaming service before launch
summary: Disney, Fox, and Warner Bros Discovery have abandoned plans to launch Venu Sports, a live sports streaming service, due to substantial legal opposition. The joint venture aimed to attract younger viewers with a bundle of sports rights, including the NFL, NBA, and FIFA World Cup. The decision comes just days after Disney agreed to merge with FuboTV, removing one major legal hurdle. Shares of Warner Bros Discovery and Fox fell, while FuboTV's shares rose nearly 8% following the surprise announcement.

images.alt_text: Apple has invested billions of US dollars in original programming over the last few years, earning industry awards and critical praise.
The Recording Academy will produce multiple Grammy-branded music specials and other new programming across Disney’s platforms.
Disney has been building expertise across the organisation to capitalise on the emerging technology.

site_title: The economic consequences of Trump 2.0
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's second administration is set to begin on January 20. Despite his populist agenda, reality is unlikely to match his rhetoric, particularly on tax cuts, tariffs, and immigration. Trump's proposed tax cuts will likely lead to higher interest rates and inflation, while his tariffs will be met with special pleading and exemptions from foreign leaders. Mass deportation of undocumented immigrants could harm the economy, and Trump may relax sanctions on Venezuela to benefit the Venezuelan economy. The reality will not be significantly different from his first term, with the rich getting richer and most Americans struggling with inflation and cuts to public services.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, Dec. 9, 2024. Stocks struggled to make headway, following a furious rally that put the market on pace for its best year since 2019, with traders awaiting key inflation data that will help shape the outlook for Federal Reserve rates. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
Trump's campaign is proposing a second, much bigger hike in tariffs; lavish tax cuts; a labour-supply shock in the form of mass deportations; and attacks on the independence of the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Wind lull offers hope in Los Angeles fires
summary: At least 10 people have died in the devastating wildfires in Los Angeles, with flames ripping through neighborhoods and razing thousands of homes. The blazes, which have burned over 14,000 hectares, have displaced hundreds of thousands and disrupted life for millions. A temporary wind lull has allowed firefighters to make progress, with the Pacific Palisades fire's perimeter now 8% contained. However, authorities warn the situation remains "still very dangerous" and the reprieve from intense gusts is short-lived, with winds expected to increase again in the coming days. The estimated damage and loss is between $135 billion and $150 billion, making it one of the costliest disasters in California's history.

images.alt_text: Kamala Harris has faced speculation about her next move with some allies seeing a run for governor of California in 2026 as a natural step.
Raging wildfires in Los Angeles killed at least two people, destroyed hundreds of buildings and stretched firefighting resources and water supplies since they began on Tuesday.

Destruction caused by a wildfire in Altadena, California, Jan 8, 2025. Rampaging wildfires around Los Angeles have killed at least two people, officials said January 8 as terrifying blazes leveled whole streets, torching cars and houses in minutes.

site_title: China Evergrande’s key unit ordered to liquidate by Hong Kong court
summary: A Hong Kong court has ordered the liquidation of China Evergrande Group's offshore unit CEG Holdings BVI, a move aimed at accessing assets to settle unpaid debt with creditors. This ruling follows a year ago when Evergrande Group itself was wound up in Hong Kong, marking the biggest casualty of China's property crisis. The liquidation will target assets within Evergrande's offshore units, with the goal of recovering funds from its complex structural maze.

images.alt_text: Evergrande is the world’s most heavily indebted property developer, with over US$300 billion in liabilities.
Evergrande's liquidators referred to a Shenzhen Stock Exchange document dated Sep 30, which publicly reprimanded Hengda and founder Hui Ka Yan.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value up 5% in December despite lower market volume
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 5% increase in total securities market turnover value to S$20 billion in December, driven by the Straits Times Index's 17-year peak. The STI rose 1.3% to 3,787.6 and closed the year up 16.9%, its best performance in over a decade. Despite lower market volume, SGX saw a 10% increase in derivatives trading volume to 23.2 million contracts, with key markets such as equities, foreign exchange, and commodities experiencing significant growth.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
SGX securities turnover value rises 51% in November; volume up 12%

site_title: Tycoon Vincent Tan seeks new partner in high-speed rail bid
summary: Berjaya Group founder Vincent Tan says his company is seeking a new partner after Malaysian Resources withdrew from a proposed high-speed rail line between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. The project, estimated to cost up to RM100 billion, aims to cut travel time between the cities to 90 minutes. Tan stated that his consortium has put in a proposal for the project, and a new partner may be brought in following Malaysian Resources' pullout.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) and his Malaysia counterpart Anwar Ibrahim meet at the two-day leaders' retreat between both South-east Asian neighbours in Putrajaya.
Berjaya Corp founder Vincent Tan highlighted the company’s dedication to a world-class high-speed rail, enhancing connectivity, driving Malaysia’s economy, and promoting green mobility.

site_title: Issue 131: Deadline year for sustainability-linked bond issuers; Singapore awards hydrogen-enabled gas plant
summary: Singapore-listed companies with sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs) face performance deadlines in 2025, with Optus, Sembcorp Industries, and CapitaLand Ascott Trust due to meet their sustainability targets. Optus must reduce Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions by 25% from 2015 levels by March 2025 to avoid paying higher interest. Sembcorp Industries and CapitaLand Ascott Trust have already reached their targets. Despite the success of these companies, the SLB market is experiencing a decline due to concerns over consistency in performance targets and the penalty for missing targets. The World Bank recommends using science-based targets and step-downs instead of step-ups to improve the market.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, January 10, 2025
summary: Asian markets experienced a decline on Friday, January 10, 2025, due to looming US jobs data. The Singapore Stock Exchange's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.7% with bank shares leading the decline. In contrast, ultramaker Bloks surged after its blockbuster Hong Kong IPO, and TSMC's sales beat estimates, providing a boost for AI's outlook in 2025.

images.alt_text: Singapore banks reverse midweek gains on Friday, dragging STI down 1.6%
Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Wellington and Manila fell, while Hong Kong barely moved and Jakarta cautiously edged up.

site_title: Miyoshi chief executive fined S$22,400 for accounting irregularity
summary: Miyoshi's chief executive, Andrew Sin, has been fined S$22,400 for failing to recognize a S$16 million impairment loss in the company's financial statements for FY2019. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) found that Miyoshi overstated its net asset value and provided an "inaccurate picture" of its financial health. The incident occurred after the group's audited financial statements were selected for review by Acra in 2021, and it highlights the importance of directors providing accurate and reliable financial information.

On Sep 5, 2022, ACRA issued a letter with its preliminary assessment that the group should have impaired its investment in Core Power as at Aug 31, 2019.

site_title: Gold prices on track for weekly gain; US data on tap
summary: Gold prices remain stable at US$2,670.16 per ounce, poised for a weekly gain, ahead of US jobs data that may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts this year. Investors await the release of the key government payrolls report, which is expected to show a 160,000 job increase in December. Gold strengthened to a four-week high last week due to safe-haven demand and concerns over inflation, particularly under President-elect Donald Trump's proposed tariffs and protectionist policies.

images.alt_text: Spot gold eased 0.1 per cent to US$2,659.27 per ounce.

site_title: Investors must diversify to navigate ‘world of uncertainty’ in 2025
summary: Investors are advised to diversify their portfolios in 2025 due to heightened market volatility and trade policy uncertainty. Strategists recommend focusing on defensive strategies, particularly in Asia and countries with minimal trade exposure, such as Indonesia and Malaysia. Key growth drivers in Asia include India, East Asian markets with AI exposure, and Japan equities. Despite potential risks, investors are expected to see solid returns in small and mid-cap US stocks and in China, where equities offer a decent dividend yield. A focus on long-term thinking and diversification can help navigate the uncertainties of 2025.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 10)
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 5% increase in securities turnover value for December despite lower market volume. Trading volume for derivatives rose 10% year-on-year to 23.2 million contracts. Meanwhile, Chinese F&B giants are expanding rapidly in South-east Asia, operating over 6,000 outlets. Analysts predict potential beneficiaries from the Johor-Singapore SEZ, while the impact of the Year of the Snake on gold prices is uncertain, with some market watchers predicting a potential decline.

images.alt_text: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone creates a "win-win" scenario, with Malaysia having the right resources—renewable energy, land, and emerging talent—while Singapore brings technology and expertise.

site_title: From mala to milk tea, China’s F&B giants take South-east Asia by storm
summary: China's food and beverage giants are rapidly expanding into South-east Asia, operating over 6,000 outlets across the region by the end of 2024. Brands such as Mixue, Chagee, and Luckin Coffee are capitalizing on the region's proximity, growing consumer demand, and less saturated market. This expansion began with 200 stores in 2021, surging to 5,000 in 2023 and 6,100 in 2024, with the biggest concentration in Singapore and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Chinese ice cream and bubble tea chain Mixue opened its 1,000th store in Vietnam this June via its fast-growing franchise model

The Vietnamese government is heightening scrutiny over local operators of foreign e-commerce platforms as well as eyeing additional taxes on duty-free imported goods enabled by the de minimis threshold.
Thanks to e-commerce giants, which have lowered entry barriers for South-east Asian sellers, small businesses in the region have been able to internationalise closer to home.

site_title: Property a big winner: Potential Malaysia beneficiaries from Johor-Singapore SEZ
summary: Malaysia is expected to benefit more from the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), with property developers, data centers, and power players set to gain. Analysts predict significant spillover effects driving long-term property sales growth in Johor and boosting Malaysian developers' earnings. Key beneficiaries include Eco World Development Group, Sime Darby Property, Mah Sing Group, and UEM Sunrise, with the JS-SEZ expected to boost construction, industrial property, data centers, and tech sectors.

images.alt_text: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone creates a "win-win" scenario, with Malaysia having the right resources—renewable energy, land, and emerging talent—while Singapore brings technology and expertise.

site_title: Hyundai launches 2.85 million yen EV in Japan to penetrate EV-wary market
summary: Hyundai Motor launched its cheapest compact electric car, the Inster, in Japan priced at 2.85 million yen (S$24,641), aiming to penetrate a market dominated by local auto giants with established hybrid technologies. This move follows a low-price strategy similar to China's BYD, targeting the ultra-compact "kei car" category. Despite a slow take-up of EVs in Japan, Hyundai's entry aims to challenge the market, with the Inster open for orders from Japanese customers starting this Friday.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor Group, including Hyundai Motor and Kia, ranks third in global vehicle sales behind Toyota Motor and Volkswagen.
South Korea’s Hyundai and BAIC subsidiary BAIC Investment will each inject about US$548 million into their equally owned venture Beijing Hyundai Motor.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz car sales drop as China, EV slump take toll
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported a 3% decline in car sales last year, reaching 1.98 million vehicles, due to weak demand for luxury models in China and electric vehicles in Europe. The company's sales in China dropped 7% to 683,600 cars, while EV sales plummeted nearly a quarter. Mercedes aims to revive EV sales with its entry-level CLA sedan, which will launch ahead of similar models from competitors. The decline undermines the company's strategy to push upmarket and boost profit.

site_title: Ultraman toymaker Bloks surges after blockbuster Hong Kong IPO
summary: Bloks Group, a Chinese toy maker, surged 82% in its Hong Kong trading debut after its $215 million initial public offering drew overwhelming demand from individual investors. The company's shares opened at HK$109.60 and closed 41% higher at HK$85. Demand was fueled by zero-interest loans and thousands of times the number of shares reserved for individual investors. Bloks' chairman and CEO, Zhu Weisong, became a billionaire, but the company remains unprofitable, with experts labeling it a short-term opportunity rather than a long-term value investment.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s stock exchange is seeking to change some requirements for IPOs through a market consultation, which touches on the clawback mechanism.

site_title: PBOC halts bond buying to defend yuan as economic gloom worsens
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has halted bond buying to defend the yuan, citing a shortage of sovereign debt and market demand. The move aims to temper investor bets on weak economic growth, which have undermined the currency and sapped confidence. The PBOC will reassess buying sovereign debt when market conditions improve, amid concerns over deflation and a prolonged property crisis. The decision reflects the central bank's discomfort with plummeting government bond yields and increasing yuan depreciation pressure.

images.alt_text: While the yuan has weakened against the US dollar, it climbed to the highest since 2022 versus trading partners’ exchange rates as a result of Beijing’s control.
The statement by the central bank reiterates plans to cut interest rates and the reserve requirement ratio, which dictates how much banks must hold in their coffers, rather than lending or investing.
China’s 10-year and 30-year treasury yields both hit record lows on Friday on expectations of fresh monetary easing.

site_title: S&P assigns ‘BBB-’ rating for Stoneweg European Reit on stable outlook
summary: S&P Global Ratings has assigned a 'BBB-' long-term issuer credit rating to Stoneweg European Real Estate Investment Trust (Stoneweg E-Reit) due to its stable operational performance and cash flow over the next two years. The agency expects the trust's logistics and industrial properties, accounting for 55% of its portfolio, to attract high-quality tenants, translating into a healthy occupancy rate. This rating is based on the sound quality of the trust's portfolio.

A logistics complex in Tilburg, the Netherlands, that is part of Stoneweg E-Reit's portfolio. The increase in the Reit's second-half portfolio value comes from its logistics and light industrial assets.

site_title: Gold dazzled last year, but may lose some lustre in 2025
summary: Gold prices are expected to retain some shine in 2025 despite a potential headwind from younger investors' preference for cryptocurrencies. Analysts do not anticipate a gold rush, but gold's purchasing power has remained steady over centuries as a solid portfolio diversifier. The yellow metal's spot price rose 26.5% in 2024, driven by uncertainty before the US presidential election. Despite a potential decline, gold's value remains tied to its status as a reliable asset.

site_title: The wayang of board evaluations
summary: Board evaluations have devolved into superficial exercises that fail to deliver meaningful outcomes, often prioritizing compliance over strategic planning. Evaluations can be performed as a choreographed performance, ignoring key aspects of board effectiveness such as decision-making quality and diversity of perspectives. To achieve genuine evaluations, companies must adopt a more thoughtful approach, focusing on qualitative metrics, involving external stakeholders, ensuring evaluator independence, linking evaluations to consequences, and making evaluations a continuous process. By doing so, boards can become catalysts for real change and drive long-term value creation for all stakeholders.

Good board leadership strikes a balance between having talent and experience and complementing that by learning, practising and refining those skills along the way.

site_title: Manulife US Reit to post FY2024 loss as its portfolio value falls 9.3%; divestment talks continue
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a potential FY2024 loss due to a 9.3% decline in its portfolio value to US$1.1 billion. The decline was driven by higher discount rates and terminal capitalisation rates for certain properties, alongside weak occupancy performance in US office submarkets. The Reit plans to deleverage its balance sheet by repaying US$200 million to lenders and is in divestment talks for multiple properties, aiming to reach its 2025 net proceeds target of US$328.7 million.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Manulife US Reit's gearing stands at 54.3 per cent after the divestment of its California asset.

site_title: Singapore banks reverse midweek gains on Friday, dragging STI down 1.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 1.6% on Friday, driven by losses in banks and other STI counters. The benchmark index fell 61.04 points to 3,801.56. Local banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, retreated from their highs earlier in the week. There were no gainers on the STI, with four counters ending flat.

site_title: Wall Street bonuses to jump by double digits at big banks
summary: Wall Street bonuses are expected to jump by double digits at major banks, with average increases ranging from 10% to 15% for traders and investment bankers. This follows two years of industrywide restraint during the pandemic, with revenue from trading rising less than 10% in the first nine months of last year. The increases aim to retain employees and reward those who have contributed to the upturn in business. Industry leaders, including Goldman Sachs, are also planning significant bonuses for top performers.

images.alt_text: The cash hoard has raised concern with regulators as the economy struggles to regain traction after the pandemic years and political upheaval.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift lower as US jobs data looms
summary: Asia's stocks declined on Friday, January 10, as traders awaited the US jobs data that could impact the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. Markets were cautious, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Sydney falling, while Hong Kong and Jakarta edged up. The Fed indicated it would cut interest rates just twice this year, citing sticky inflation, and several officials expressed concerns about the incoming US administration's potential impact on monetary policy.

images.alt_text: In early trade, Hong Kong edged up while Shanghai fell as investors assessed data showing Chinese inflation eased in December.

site_title: Millennium hedge fund spinoff Modular expands to Hong Kong
summary: Modular Asset Management, a Singapore-based hedge fund spinoff from Millennium Management, plans to expand to Hong Kong, its first move in the city. The firm will open an office in the second quarter, with former Barclays trader Alex Hu Xiuyi as its first hire for Hong Kong. The expansion aims to allow the firm to stay closer to the China market and attract investment staff in the city. Modular manages US$1.5 billion and focuses on macro bets. The move comes as Hong Kong faces geopolitical spats and China's economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Ken Griffin says he expects some consolidation among the smaller multi-managers, most of which have sprung up over the past 15 years.

site_title: South Korean leader's security chief warns against violent attempts to arrest Yoon
summary: South Korea's security chief, Park Chong-jun, resigned on January 10 amid an investigation into his role in preventing the detention of impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol. Park warned that any further efforts to detain Yoon must avoid bloodshed. The investigation has led to a standoff between investigators and Yoon's security, with hundreds of agents blocking the presidential compound. A new arrest warrant has been issued, but Yoon's lawyers claim it is invalid. The prolonged uncertainty has emboldened Yoon's supporters, with 64% of respondents backing his removal from office, according to a recent poll.

site_title: TSMC’s sales beat estimates in a boost for AI’s outlook in 2025
summary: TSMC, the world's largest chipmaker, reported a 39% rise in October-December revenue to NT$868.5 billion, beating estimates. The strong showing bolsters expectations for AI development and metacentre upgrades by big tech companies, including Alphabet Inc and Microsoft. TSMC's shares have more than doubled since the AI boom began in 2022, but some observers warn of potential over-building and bottlenecks to development. Despite this, the company is expected to project annual sales growth of low-20% and plans rapid international expansion.

images.alt_text: TSMC is expected to report sales growth of 36 per cent for the December quarter, with a gross profit margin at 58.3 per cent, the highest since 2022.

are predicting a

summary: Hong Kong's used home prices have declined almost 30% since 2021, reaching an eight-year low. Analysts predict a market bottom this year, driven by lower interest rates, an influx of mainland Chinese talent, and robust rents. Cheaper borrowing costs will help stabilize the market, but prices are unlikely to increase significantly due to a supply glut. Experts expect home prices to gradually rebound as lower mortgage rates unleash pent-up demand. The property market is expected to show improvement in 2025, measured by both value and volume of transactions.

site_title: Can Howard Marks spot a stock bubble twice?
summary: Legendary investor Howard Marks has expressed concern that the US stock market may be in a bubble, citing unusually high valuations and a "can't-lose" attitude among investors. Marks, in his latest memo, notes that the S&P 500 Index has delivered a compound annual growth rate of 17% since 2009, with only two calendar years of negative total returns. He warns that valuations are historically associated with poor returns and that investor behavior, fueled by the "reflexivity" theory of George Soros, could lead to a significant decline in the market.

site_title: Kamala Harris cancels overseas trip to focus on wildfire response
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris has cancelled a three-nation overseas trip to focus on the federal response to catastrophic wildfires in California, her home state. The trip, scheduled for Singapore, Bahrain, and Germany, was her final planned overseas travel as vice-president before President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration. Harris has been praying for the safety of Californians and first responders, amid at least five deaths and estimated damages of over $52 billion.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Kamala Harris hits the gavel after reading the vote totals as Speaker of the House Mike Johnson looks on during of a joint session of Congress to certify the results of the 2024 Presidential election, Washington, DC, Jan 6, 2025.

site_title: Emma Raducanu, Elise Mertens among the big stars set to grace inaugural Singapore Tennis Open
summary: The inaugural Singapore Tennis Open will take place from January 27 to February 2 at the new Kallang Tennis Hub, featuring top stars such as Emma Raducanu, Anna Kalinskaya, and Elise Mertens. The tournament, a WTA 250-level event, will be held for three years until 2027. Raducanu, the 2021 US Open champion, aims to stay healthy and compete at a higher level in 2025, while Kalinskaya, ranked 14th, seeks to build on her Grand Slam quarter-final appearance at the Australian Open. The event promises to be a significant milestone in Singapore's tennis scene.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
French swimming sensation Leon Marchand celebrates after winning the final of the men's 200m breaststroke during the Paris Olympic Games at the La Defense Arena.
Taylor Swift's six-night performance at the National Stadium helped boost Sports Hub's event attendance
Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong overlooking the 3D model of the future Toa Payoh Integrated Development during the groundbreaking ceremony.
A view of the National Stadium at the Sports Hub. The new WTA 250 Singapore Tennis Open will be played at the Kallang Tennis Hub in January.

site_title: Malaysia’s November industrial production up 3.6%, above forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production rose 3.6% in November, surpassing the forecasted 2.6% growth. This marked a higher increase than October's factory output, which was revised to 2% from 2.1%. The data suggests a stronger-than-expected performance in the country's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Tesla launches redesigned Model Y in China, seeking to fend off rivals
summary: Tesla launched a redesigned Model Y in China, priced at 263,500 yuan (S$49,217), 5.4% more expensive than the previous version. The new model features a light bar across the front end and a full-width taillight bar, similar to the Cybertruck. Deliveries in China are set to begin in March, subject to regulatory approval, aiming to regain market share from rivals such as Xiaomi.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s compensation could even exceed 1 billion euros if it monetises its entire long CO2 position.
Panasonic Energy, which supplies batteries to Tesla as well as other automakers, is a unit of Japanese electronics giant Panasonic.

ALHAMBRA, CALIFORNIA - JANUARY 02: The Tesla logo displayed at a Tesla dealership on January 2, 2025 in Alhambra, California. The electric vehicle (EV) company reported its first annual sales dip in 2024, down one percent from 2023.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Fu Yu’s largest shareholder requisitions EGM to oust directors amid poor performance
summary: Fu Yu's largest shareholder, Victor Lim, has requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to oust two directors amid the company's poor performance, including a 60% decline in its share price from S$0.33 in 2021 to S$0.13. Lim calls for a "strategic reset" and reorganisation of the board, and proposes appointing three new independent non-executive directors to replace the outgoing directors. The EGM will consider five resolutions, including the removal of the current directors and the appointment of the new directors.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Clients today want the ability to monitor their orders being produced, which the new smart factory will support, says Fu Yu Corporation group CEO David Seow.
David Seow, CEO, Fu Yu Corporation

site_title: Beaches, parties and nose jobs: How Bali woos tourists with thriving cosmetic surgery scene
summary: Bali, Indonesia, is attracting international tourists for cosmetic procedures, such as rhinoplasties and breast augmentation, due to relatively low prices and tropical getaway appeal. Many internationally accredited clinics and hospitals have set up shop on the island, aiming to capture a larger share of the region's booming medical tourism market. However, Indonesia as a whole faces challenges in growing this sector, despite Bali's strides in attracting foreign patients. The island's healthcare scene is still trailing that of Malaysia and Thailand in popularity.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
In 2023, Malaysia attracted 1.4 million medical tourists, generating total revenue of RM2.25 billion (S$680 million), surpassing its pre-pandemic peak.

site_title: Private lenders set to take over Alacrity in debt restructuring
summary: Private lenders Antares Capital, Blue Owl Capital, and KKR are set to take over insurance claims manager Alacrity Solutions through a debt restructuring deal. BlackRock, which purchased a 70% stake in the company less than two years ago, will have its existing equity investment completely wiped out. The lenders will own around 90% of the company, with Goldman Sachs Asset Management holding the remaining piece. The deal includes a $175 million revolving credit facility and a $450 million term loan. Operations will remain unaffected during the restructuring process, which is expected to close in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 08: The BlackRock NYC headquarters is seen on August 08, 2024 in New York City.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The company has more than 21,000 employees, meaning the cuts apply to about 200 staff.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's net profit for the first half ended Jun 30, 2024, rose 77.2 per cent on the year to 3.1 billion yuan.

site_title: India infrastructure lender plans up to 400 billion rupees fundraising
summary: India's state-owned National Bank for Financing Infrastructure & Development (NaBFID) plans to raise up to 400 billion rupees (S$6.4 billion) from the local debt market through bonds and loans in the January to March period. The funds will support the nation's ambitious growth push and infrastructure development, with a goal to increase the country's economy to $7 trillion by 2030. This is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government's efforts to improve India's infrastructure, which requires $2.2 trillion of investment.

site_title: Nvidia slams Biden for trying to ‘pre-empt’ Trump with chip rules
summary: Nvidia criticized the Biden administration for trying to limit US AI chip exports ahead of Donald Trump's presidency, calling it a "pre-emptive" move. The proposed regulations would cap chip sales on a country and company basis, affecting mainstream computers worldwide. Nvidia's vice-president Ned Finkle stated that the policy would harm the US economy and set the country back, while also playing into the hands of adversaries. The rules, expected to be announced soon, would create three tiers of chip curbs, with some countries still having full access to American chips.

images.alt_text: The US wants to curb the sale of AI chips used in data centres on both a country and company basis.

site_title: Suntec Reit unitholders should reject revised S$1.19-a-unit offer: Morningstar
summary: Morningstar recommends Suntec Reit unitholders reject the revised S$1.19-a-unit offer from Gordon Tang and his wife Celine, citing it falls below the research company's fair-value estimate of S$1.38 a unit. The offer, a 2.6% improvement from the initial S$1.16 apiece, was made to comply with the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers. Unitholders may get more value by selling shares on the open market, and Morningstar believes Aelios does not intend to take the Reit private with this offer.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
The offer was first made on Dec 5 last year, at S$1.16 per unit.

site_title: Japan’s economy minister vows to coordinate policy with Bank of Japan
summary: Japan's Economy Minister Ryosei Akazawa vowed to coordinate policy with the Bank of Japan, citing the need to dispel deflationary mindset and achieve growth driven by higher wages and investment. The government is cautious about declaring an end to deflation, which has been stuck in a vicious cycle for years, and will scrutinize factors behind underlying inflation. This decision may affect the timing of future interest rate hikes by the Bank of Japan, which is set to meet on Jan 23-24.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending has been on a downtrend for months as shoppers cope with inflation that’s been at or above the BOJ’s price target for more than 30 months.
Pedestrians walk past an electronic board displaying various companies' share prices, at a business district in Tokyo, Japan, October 31, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
Japan's final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers’ index grew to 50.9 in December from 50.5 in November, according to a survey compiled by S&P Global Market Intelligence.
Manufacturers stayed confident about their outlook as they expect business to expand thanks to the launch and mass production of new products.

site_title: Developer Sunac China receives liquidation petition in Hong Kong
summary: Sunac China Holdings, a Chinese private developer, has received a liquidation petition in Hong Kong, citing financial stress. The petition was filed by China Cinda HK Asset Management and a hearing is scheduled for March 19. This follows Sunac's initial default on a US dollar bond in 2022 and its failed attempt to restructure debt in mid-2023. The developer's stock and bond prices have dropped to their lowest levels in several months, highlighting the ongoing challenges in China's property market.

images.alt_text: Sunac has 15.4 billion yuan (S$2.9 billion) in outstanding onshore debt.
Sunac is one of the few large real estate companies to pull off a debt restructuring.
Sunac became the first major Chinese builder to reorganise its offshore debt late last year.

site_title: India, Indonesia set for travel ‘bonanza’ as middle classes grow
summary: India, Indonesia, and Vietnam are poised for a tourism boom as their growing middle classes increase spending power, according to Accor's deputy CEO. The region's sluggish post-pandemic recovery is attributed to China's slow economic growth. Accor plans to expand its portfolio by 3-4% this year, with Asia accounting for half of the new openings. As consumers increasingly seek experiences over products, hotels like Accor are well-positioned to capitalize on the trend.

images.alt_text: Vietnam is targeting a 31 per cent jump in foreign travellers this year from 2024.
People are posing for pictures with a snowman sculpture in Harbin, China’s northeastern Heilongjiang province.
The latest tourism data from UN Tourism indicateS that tourist arrival numbers in most regions have already surpassed those of 2019 – the year before the Covid pandemic when travel was shut down.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sats, Hotel Properties, Manulife US Reit
summary: Sats and Worldwide Flight Services have secured 14 new cargo and ground-handling contracts with Air India, along with renewing 11 existing contracts. Hotel Properties Limited's shares fell 0.3% after property tycoon Ong Beng Seng acquired 150,000 shares, increasing his stake to 60.22%. Manulife US Reit's portfolio value dropped 9.3% due to valuation decline and weak occupancy, with the company expected to report a loss for FY2024.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

site_title: US December jobs report expected to showcase healthy labour market
summary: US employers are expected to add 165,000 jobs in December, according to economists, which would show a labor market that continues to moderate only gradually. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain unchanged at 4.2%, defying expectations for a sharper slowdown. A robust job market would support the Federal Reserve's intent to shift focus back to inflation, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicating that the central bankers can be cautious about further rate cuts as long as the job market remains solid.

images.alt_text: Outstanding credit-card and other revolving debt decreased US$13.7 billion, the most since early in the pandemic, after surging a month earlier.
Resilient demand, illustrated by the pickup in business activity and stronger orders, adds to concerns that inflation will remain stubborn.

The jump in imports was broad, including increases in consumer goods, capital equipment and motor vehicles, likely reflecting a preference by US companies to secure shipments in advance of potential tariffs.
Americans have mostly exhausted their pandemic savings and have generally been putting aside a smaller share of their incomes each month.

site_title: Nvidia partnership puts MediaTek stock on course for record high
summary: MediaTek's shares are on track for a record high after the chip designer announced a tie-up with Nvidia on an AI personal computer chip. The partnership, combined with Nvidia's existing collaboration in automotive tech, has boosted investor optimism for MediaTek's artificial intelligence growth potential. The company's diversified business set and key role in handset supply chains position it well for the AI tech evolution, according to an investment manager. MediaTek's shares have more than doubled in the past two years and are now within a whisker of its June peak.

images.alt_text: The chip is based on Arm’s ready-made designs, which can significantly speed development because less design work is needed using ready-made, tested chip components.

site_title: BlackRock leaves major climate group amid Wall Street exodus
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is leaving the Net-Zero Asset Managers initiative amid attacks from Republican lawmakers for its climate policies. The move follows legal inquiries from public officials and criticism over its practices. BlackRock oversees over $11 trillion in assets and cited "confusion regarding our practices" and "legal inquiries" as reasons for its departure. This is the latest in a wave of Wall Street firms distancing themselves from climate-focused initiatives amid GOP backlash.

images.alt_text: The company has more than 21,000 employees, meaning the cuts apply to about 200 staff.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's net profit for the first half ended Jun 30, 2024, rose 77.2 per cent on the year to 3.1 billion yuan.
The tapering of flows to IBIT is another sign of Bitcoin’s record-breaking run in 2024 taking a breather.

site_title: Bangladesh garment industry rebounds, but workers say little change
summary: Bangladesh's garment industry has rebounded after a revolution that toppled the government last year, with production increasing by 13% from July to December 2024 compared to the same period the previous year. However, workers say little change has occurred in terms of their working conditions and wages, with many still struggling to maintain a minimum standard of living. Despite a 5% wage hike, workers report being forced to work long hours with unrealistic production targets, and many factory owners are accused of exploiting workers for the sake of profit.

images.alt_text: Leaders in Sheikh Hasina’s party are in jail or hiding in Bangladesh, or have left the country.

site_title: Mergers and acquisitions expected to rise in South-east Asia in 2025
summary: Mergers and acquisitions in South-east Asia are expected to rise in 2025, driven by the growing participation of sovereign wealth funds and raised private capital. Key buyer trends include the expanding number of sovereign wealth funds with a mandate to develop local businesses and critical industries. Additionally, confidence has returned to the market, with a 51% increase in transactions in 2024, and private capital raised for alternative investors remains high. Valuation gaps between buyers and sellers continue to narrow, and sectors to watch include sustainability, clean energy, logistics, and education platforms.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Nvidia has listed 11 job postings in Vietnam – all them for remote working, with half not specifying a particular city.

site_title: Japan’s household spending falls for fourth month
summary: Japan's household spending fell for the fourth consecutive month, with outlays adjusted for inflation decreasing 0.4% in November compared to the previous year. This decline, despite a 3% increase in nominal spending, indicates economic fragility and may prompt the Bank of Japan to pause further interest rate hikes. Real wages fell for a fourth month, despite a significant wage growth in workers' base salaries, and the BOJ remains cautious about additional rate hikes, citing fragile consumption.

images.alt_text: Japan's final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers’ index grew to 50.9 in December from 50.5 in November, according to a survey compiled by S&P Global Market Intelligence.
Manufacturers stayed confident about their outlook as they expect business to expand thanks to the launch and mass production of new products.

site_title: Adani Group to raise 71.48 billion rupees as it exits JV with Wilmar International
summary: The Adani Group is selling up to 20% stake in Mumbai-listed Adani Wilmar for 71.48 billion rupees (S$1.1 billion) as it exits non-core activities to focus on infrastructure businesses. The stake sale is the first phase of the conglomerate's exit from the joint venture, with the remaining stake to be acquired by Wilmar International at a price not exceeding 305 rupees. The sale is amid Adani facing legal challenges and rating agencies citing it as a potential risk to fund raising.

images.alt_text: Adani Enterprises will sell a 13 per cent stake in Adani Wilmar to comply with India’s minimum public shareholding requirements.

site_title: Apollo weighs 1.5 trillion yen stake in Seven & i management buyout
summary: Apollo Global Management is considering a $13 billion investment in a bid by Seven & i's founding Ito family to take the Japanese convenience store operator private. The US private equity giant would join the Ito family and Itochu, the operator of FamilyMarts, as key investors. Apollo's proposed commitment is subject to change, with the Ito family weighing a 500 billion yen stake and Itochu considering over one trillion yen. Other partners are still negotiating stakes, with the deal pending further discussions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Seven & i’s logo is seen at a 7-Eleven convenience store in Tokyo, Japan August 19,  2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Seven & i has been spurred into radical action to fend off Couche-Tard’s approach.

The owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores has rejected a US$47 billion buyout offer from Canada’s Alimentation Couche-Tard and the retailer’s founding family is in talks to take the company private to fend off the takeover.
Seven & i is looking to hive off non-core businesses, including its sprawling supermarket operations, into the York Holdings unit.

The scramble for Seven & i gives a taste of how deals are likely to develop in the years to come, industry experts say, as changes in Japan Inc’s corporate governance standards make delisting an increasingly compelling option.

site_title: Trump’s bid to halt hush money sentencing in US Supreme Court’s hands
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's sentencing for his conviction on criminal charges stemming from hush money paid to a porn star is set for January 19, but the case now hangs in the balance as the US Supreme Court considers his bid to halt the case. A New York state court rejected Trump's request to halt the sentencing, and Manhattan prosecutors have opposed Trump's bid for a stay at the Supreme Court, citing a lack of basis for such intervention. The Supreme Court's decision could place an administrative pause on Trump's sentencing or grant or deny his request.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk speaks with U.S. President-elect Donald Trump at a viewing of the launch of the sixth test flight of the SpaceX Starship rocket in Brownsville, Texas, U.S., November 19, 2024 Brandon Bell/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
The move will allow Trump to build a new tariff programme by using the International Economic Emergency Powers Act, which authorises a president to manage imports during a national emergency.

US President-elect Donald Trump has been a harsh critic of Meta and Zuckerberg for years, accusing the company of bias against him and threatening to retaliate once back in office.
Sajwani, who has described himself in press releases as “Trump’s Middle Eastern business partner”.

site_title: Firm dollar adds pressure to sterling and euro
summary: The US dollar surged on Thursday, January 9, driven by rising Treasury yields and concerns over US President-elect Donald Trump's agenda, including potential tariffs that could reignite inflation. The dollar strengthened against the sterling, euro, and yen, with sterling experiencing its biggest three-day drop in nearly two years and the euro nearing its two-year low. The sell-off in UK government bond markets and confidence in Britain's fiscal outlook also contributed to the decline in sterling.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this photo illustration taken February 12, 2018. REUTERS/Jose Luis Gonzalez/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: With consumer demand diverted overseas, Singapore retailers see another tough year ahead
summary: Singapore retailers expect a tough year ahead, with modest growth of 3.5% in retail sales value and 1% in volume, driven by geopolitical and economic uncertainties. High rents and manpower shortages remain challenges. Consumer sentiment may weaken, and overseas spending may divert demand. Analysts suggest retailers with robust omnichannel sales strategies and those that innovate and differentiate themselves will have more success. Lower inflation and real wage growth could help, but external shocks could exacerbate the challenges.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Amazon Black Friday advertisement next to the bus stop outside COURTS NOJIMA The Heeren at 260 Orchard Road on Nov 21, 2024.

While Singapore is already considered a competitive market, the crowd outside the Chagee store in Singapore shows that even in the ultra-competitive tea industry there is still room to create a unique experience.

site_title: Out with the old, in with the new
summary: To celebrate the Chinese New Year, designers have created a range of sophisticated and symbolic home decor pieces inspired by the snake, a mysterious and auspicious creature in Chinese culture. These designs include the Serpentine pendant, Mandarin storage unit, and Array sofa, which feature snake-inspired patterns and forms. Other pieces, such as the Ma-Rock lamp and Victoria-Maria Geyer snake fabric, pay homage to the snake's elegance and mystique. These designs aim to bring abundance and prosperity into the home during the Chinese New Year celebrations.

images.alt_text: luxedesignkrisyao9 - kris yao 01-01-New Taipei City Art Museum_┬⌐Iwan Baan

site_title: E-commerce in 2025: Sustainable growth and rationality to emerge as key themes
summary: E-commerce in 2025 is expected to focus on sustainable growth and rationality, shifting away from deep discounts and subsidized shipping. Market consolidation and new entrants, such as TikTok Shop, have driven change in the industry. As customers become more price-sensitive, platforms like Shopee are unlikely to employ deep discounts to grow their market share. Instead, they will prioritize unit economics and enhancing the customer experience to drive long-term growth. Regulatory challenges, such as Indonesia's regulatory setbacks, may also impact the industry's trajectory.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Shopee even faced allegations of monopolistic behaviour in the country, being accused of prioritising its logistics service SPX Express over 3PL players on its platform.

The Vietnamese government is heightening scrutiny over local operators of foreign e-commerce platforms as well as eyeing additional taxes on duty-free imported goods enabled by the de minimis threshold.
ByteDance set out to increase TikTok’s US e-commerce arm 10-fold this year, to as much as US$17.5 billion.

site_title: Fed officials signal interest rates likely on hold for a while
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to hold interest rates at current levels for an extended period, according to several Fed officials, due to lingering inflation risks and a healthy labour market. Boston Fed president Susan Collins and Kansas City Fed president Jeff Schmid expressed a cautious approach to adjusting policy, with Collins favouring fewer rate cuts this year. The Fed's inflation gauge rose 2.4% in the year to November, above the central bank's 2% target, and policymakers may consider holding rates steady when they meet on January 28-29.

images.alt_text: The Fed will also face an array of new policies from the incoming Trump administration – on tariffs, immigration and taxes – that could blow their forecasts off course.
Analysts expect the Japanese currency to be supported by further Fed easing and rate hikes by the Bank of Japan.
The adjusted RRP rate is meant to help keep funding markets running smoothly by driving short-term rates closer to the offering level on the Fed’s facility.

site_title: Dealers welcome extension of scheme for cleaner commercial vehicles, but bemoan lack of coverage for heavy vehicles
summary: Singapore's Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme (CVES) has been extended to March 31, 2027, promoting the use of cleaner light commercial vehicles with rebates for electric vehicles. However, the scheme still lacks coverage for heavier vehicle types, which are more pollutive and remain outside the remit of CVES. Dealers welcome the extension but note that the lack of penalties for heavy diesel vehicles blunts the measure's effectiveness, and the current system discourages companies from downsizing their fleets.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The surcharge for vehicles in Band C, that are mostly diesel vehicles, will be raised from the current S$15,000 to S$20,000.

A National Environment Agency (NEA) officer conducting checks on a Malaysian-registered vehicle using a probe which measures exhaust emissions. Drivers of vehicles found to be emitting excessive exhaust fumes will be fined. This vehicle was found with an extremely high index of 91 HSU (Hartridge Smoke Unit).
Penalties for pollutive light commercial vehicles push buyers to switch to heavier vehicles instead

site_title:
Country Garden proposes 
new restructuring 
terms with key banks
summary: Country Garden Holdings, China's largest developer by sales, proposed new restructuring terms with key banks to slash its debt by up to $11.6 billion. The proposal includes a debt maturity extension of up to 11.5 years, a reduction in funding costs, and a conversion of its existing loan into shares. The move aims to address the company's significant debt burden, which has risen to $1.36 trillion yuan. The proposal follows lengthy negotiations with offshore bondholders and creditors, with the company facing a winding-up petition in court on January 20.
