site_title: The urgency of global debt reform
summary: Global debt levels are rising, with many developing countries struggling to service their external obligations. Several countries, including Sri Lanka and Zambia, have defaulted on their debts, triggering debt restructuring and economic reforms. The World Bank warns that low-income countries face a "metastasizing solvency crisis." To address this, an international framework for sovereign debt restructuring is needed, involving targeted fiscal and monetary measures, as well as structural adjustments such as expenditure cuts and tax increases. The IMF and World Bank must play a critical role in helping countries restore creditworthiness and implement reforms to prevent recurring crises.

images.alt_text: American consumers have not been more bullish on US stocks since surveys began tracking this sentiment. Momentum investing looks poised to crash in a way that could hit many investors hard.

Sri Lankan protesters in 2022, calling for the president to resign over the economic crisis. Sri Lanka has faced long delays in receiving debt relief, because their Chinese creditors refuse to agree to the debt-restructuring terms agreed in the Paris Club.

A food stall in front of commercial buildings in downtown Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, April 18, 2022. Sri Lanka has been thrust into uncertainty as protesters angered by sky-high inflation and lengthy power cuts called for the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his brother, Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. Photographer: Buddhika Weerasinghe/Bloomberg

site_title: Uniqlo operator posts higher Q1 profit despite sluggish China results
summary: Fast Retailing, the operator of Uniqlo, reported a 7.4% increase in operating profit to 157.6 billion yen in Q1, despite a decline in China sales due to unseasonably warm temperatures. Domestic sales in Japan rose due to a surge in duty-free shopping, while international sales were strong in North America and Europe. The company maintained its full-year operating profit forecast of 530 billion yen.

images.alt_text: Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing's operating profit rose 31 per cent to 500.9 billion yen (S$4.4 billion) in the 12 months through August from 381.1 billion yen a year earlier.
Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing will likely post steady growth in operating profit, mainly fuelled by its international business.

GLENDALE, CALIFORNIA - DECEMBER 26: Shoppers walk at a Uniqlo store in the Glendale Galleria shopping mall on the day after Christmas on December 26, 2023 in Glendale, California. site_title: Helping SMEs take the next leap towards AI
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are lagging behind in adopting artificial intelligence (AI) due to high costs and a knowledge gap. Despite 44% of large enterprises adopting AI in 2023, only 4.2% of SMEs have done so. The government has introduced initiatives to support SMEs, including the SMEs Go Digital programme and the Chief Technology Officer-as-a-Service. To accelerate AI adoption, the government may consider establishing sector-focused AI innovation hubs and providing enhanced AI adoption incentives. Upskilling individuals is also crucial to leveraging AI's full potential.

images.alt_text: From left: IMDA assistant chief executive of the sectoral transformation group Leong Der Yao; Senior Minister of State for Digital Development and Information Tan Kiat How; DBS group head of corporate and SME banking Koh Kar Siong; and EnterpriseSG executive director Simon Lim, at the launch of Spark GenAI.

site_title: Pranai Phornprapha: Finding ‘soul’ in Thai cuisine
summary: Pranai Phornprapha, CEO of Kaleido Lifestyle, is set to shake up Bangkok's hospitality sector with his concept of Thai cuisine. His transformative experience in Vietnam's Son Doong Cave, where he spent 7 days without showers or electricity, shaped his understanding of hospitality. Phornprapha's journey emphasizes the importance of connecting with nature and simplicity in creating a unique dining experience.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Xenia Tan and Shawn Thia prove that opposites really do attract.
Glenn Yong wears a washed indigo sweatshirt by Coach.

site_title: Raspy-voiced hit machine Rod Stewart turns 80
summary: Rod Stewart turns 80, marking his 80th birthday on January 10, 2025. Despite his milestone birthday, the singer has no plans to retire, citing his love for music and fitness. Stewart's forthcoming European and North American tour dates will be his last large-scale project, with a focus on more intimate venues in the future. He will also headline a new residency in Las Vegas and tour in 2026 with his album Swing Fever.

images.alt_text: (FILES) British singer and songwriter Rod Stewart performs during the Platinum Party at Buckingham Palace on June 4, 2022 as part of Queen Elizabeth II's platinum jubilee celebrations. British rock singer Rod Stewart will celebrate his 80th birthday on January 10, 2025. (Photo by HENRY NICHOLLS / POOL / AFP)
Peter Yarrow, founding member of the legendary folk group Peter, Paul and Mary, had been battling bladder cancer for four years.

site_title: Malaysia sees GDP growth above 5% despite Trump tariff risks
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to sustain its growth momentum, exceeding 5% in 2025, driven by foreign investments and government initiatives that shield the economy from global risks. The country's diversified economy and strong foreign direct investments will support its currency, the ringgit, which is expected to trade around 4.10-4.15 against the dollar. The government plans to narrow its budget deficit to 3.8% of GDP in 2025, and investments through a joint economic zone with Singapore will fuel the next phase of growth.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim presenting the 2025 national budget document at Parliament.
Malaysia plans to cut subsidies for its cheapest and most popular petrol by mid-2025.

site_title: Bountiful feasts for the Year of the Snake
summary: Top hotels and restaurants in Singapore offer special Chinese New Year menus and reunion dinners, featuring premium ingredients and unique dishes. Peach Blossoms, Peppermint, and Portman's Bar are among the destinations offering festive options, including the Abundant Harvest set at Peach Blossoms, which costs S$688 per person. These celebrations mark the arrival of Spring and the Year of the Snake.

site_title: Rolex perfects the art of the dial
summary: Rolex has perfected the art of watch dial design, showcasing attention to detail and craftsmanship. The luxury brand unveiled various dial designs for its Oyster Perpetual models, including a floral-motif azzurro-blue dial, mint green dial, and diamond-set white mother-of-pearl dials. According to David Riboli, head of Rolex's watch prototype department, a beautiful dial is crafted to perfection to make a statement and attract attention. The brand's commitment to dial design is evident in its latest watch releases, highlighting the importance of aesthetics in the world of luxury watches.

images.alt_text: The Black Bay with a burgundy bezel.

site_title: Europe: Markets rise as mining, healthcare surge amid bond market jitters
summary: European markets rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by gains in the healthcare and mining sectors, despite concerns over monetary policy and US tariff plans. The Stoxx 600 index closed at 515.84 points, with copper prices and London-listed mining companies fueling the surge. Healthcare stocks also rose 1%, while bond markets remained volatile due to uncertainty over US president-elect Donald Trump's policies.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent lower on Wednesday, with most regional bourses in the red.

site_title: Oil settles up 1% as cold weather in US, Europe drives winter fuel demand
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday, driven by cold weather in the US and Europe, boosting winter fuel demand. Brent crude futures settled at $76.92 a barrel, up 76 US cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 60 US cents to $73.92. The cold weather is expected to lead to increased demand for heating oil and propane, with JP Morgan analysts estimating a 113,000 barrels per day increase in demand for every degree Fahrenheit below the 10-year average.

images.alt_text: The premium of the first-month Brent contract to the six-month contract widened to US$3.05 a barrel on Wednesday, the most since late August.

site_title: Vitol plans to cut costs by taking aluminium from London Metal Exchange warehouses in Malaysia: sources
summary: Vitol, a major energy and commodities trader, plans to cut costs by removing aluminium from London Metal Exchange (LME) warehouses in Malaysia. The move aims to reduce storage costs, with LME-approved warehouses charging 56 US cents per metric tonne, five times more than rent charged outside the LME system. Vitol's actions, which include cancelling warrants, have led to a surge in aluminium prices. The company's decision follows a previous foray into base metals that ended in 2014 and may be linked to its contractual obligations to sell aluminium to end-users.

images.alt_text: Unlike other metals such as nickel, cobalt and lithium – which have their fortunes mainly tied to electric vehicle batteries – copper has a wider role in the green transition, said Marex' Edward Meir.

site_title: Sats and WFS clinch 14 new cargo and ground handling contracts from Air India
summary: Sats and its subsidiary Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) have secured 14 new cargo and ground handling contracts from Air India in major airports worldwide, including North America, the UK, Europe, and Asia. The contracts include stations in Chicago, London, Frankfurt, and Kuala Lumpur. The partnerships will significantly expand Air India's services, with Sats and WFS highlighting their global network and capabilities. The agreements are part of a global tendering process and include renewals of 11 existing contracts.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The transaction is a strategic move to capitalise on market opportunities in the Middle Eastern country, said the in-flight caterer and ground handler.

site_title: Making time for the Year of the Snake
summary: Luxury watch brands continue to celebrate the Chinese New Year with new timepieces, despite economic challenges. Three models unveiled specifically for the Year of the Wood Snake include IWC's Portofino Automatic Moon Phase 37, Longines' Conquest Heritage Year of the Snake, and Blancpain's Villeret Calendrier Chinois Traditionnel 2025. These limited-edition watches showcase the brands' commitment to honoring traditional Chinese zodiac celebrations, highlighting their ability to adapt and thrive in tough times.

site_title: Liberating architecture
summary: Taiwanese architect Kris Yao emphasizes the importance of crafting unique buildings over cultural heritage. Yao credits his unencumbered childhood and experiences in "free" educational institutions with fostering his creative side. His architectural designs, such as the Wuzhen Theater and Hainan Energy Trading Building, showcase innovative materials and forms that tell stories of their respective locations. Yao's work has received international recognition, including the prestigious International Architecture Awards.

images.alt_text: Ming’s Heart Armchair.

site_title: Saved by the bell
summary: Sound healing, a wellness trend once considered "woo woo," has gained popularity due to rising mental health needs and greater openness to alternative solutions. The practice, which uses sound to calm the mind and body, has been valued at $1.12 billion in 2023 and is forecast to double by 2032. Science is catching up to the benefits of sound healing, with the US FDA approving a technology using high-intensity sound waves to treat liver tumors. Modern sound healers, like Ashley Tan, are adopting a science-based approach, combining sound with other practices like acupressure and binaural beats to promote relaxation and recovery.

images.alt_text: IWC's Portofino Automatic Moon Phase 37 Year of the Snake.

site_title: Singapore SMEs sustain expansionary momentum in Q4, led by trade-related sectors: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) sustained expansionary momentum in Q4 2024, with a quarterly index reading of 50.7, indicating sustained but moderated growth. This marks the third consecutive quarter of expansion, following a year-long contractionary period. Trade-related sectors, such as transport and logistics, and wholesale trade, drove growth, while domestically oriented sectors, including food and beverage, also registered healthy performances. However, labour-intensive sectors like healthcare and education faced mounting cost pressures, and concerns over cost pressures and geopolitical risks remain.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The quarterly index, which tracks the health and performance of SMEs, rose to 50.8 in Q3 from 50.2 in Q2.

site_title: Xenia Tan & Shawn Thia: A yin-yang romance
summary: Celebrity couple Xenia Tan and Shawn Thia prove that opposites attract and thrive in their relationship. Xenia, an extroverted people person, and Shawn, an introvert, have learned from each other's strengths and weaknesses. Since getting married, Xenia has become more introverted and prefers hosting friends at home, while Shawn has adjusted to her large family gatherings. Their contrasting personalities have influenced each other, creating a harmonious and supportive partnership.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Siam Motors Group's scion Pranai Phornprapha, CEO of Kaleido Lifestyle, is boldly innovating Thai food and beverages.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 9)
summary: Singapore and Malaysia establish a new Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone, aiming to attract investments and drive growth. The zone may help shift supply chains due to US-China trade tensions, with Maybank predicting it could be a "game changer" for SMEs. Malaysia proposes an RM5 billion infrastructure fund for the zone, while the US Federal Reserve minutes indicate slower rate cuts in 2025, contributing to a 0.6% decline in Singapore shares.

site_title: Washington’s Capitol Hill fight: Government is not the enemy
summary: US billionaires Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy announced an advisory team to cut federal government spending and regulations, dubbed "Doge". Most taxpayers support reducing government spending, but many Americans also want to keep social-economic programs like Social Security and Medicare. Americans have an ambivalent relationship with their government, resenting bureaucracy but appreciating its services. Conservative Republicans who criticize the government may demand increased military spending but oppose cuts to social programs. Expect opposition from Congress, with lawmakers likely to prioritize their constituents' interests over proposed cuts.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk (above) has become one of Donald Trump’s closest advisers as the latter prepares to return to the White House, and is set to lead up a new agency along with entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy.
As Musk (centre) and Ramaswamy (right) wield their axes, it may be hard to tell whether they are aimed at red tape or more like DIY home renovators taking a swing at a load-bearing wall.

site_title: Patek Philippe welcomes CNY with vibrant hues and precious metals
summary: Patek Philippe releases three vibrant watches to celebrate Chinese New Year, featuring precious metals and bright hues. The Cubitus, a square-case watch, comes in platinum, stainless steel, and rose gold, with a bold geometric design and in-house automatic movement. The Ref 5236P-010 In-Line Perpetual Calendar and Twenty-4 Ref 4910/1201R also make their debut, showcasing Patek Philippe's commitment to craftsmanship and style. Prices range from S$68,900 to S$204,800.

images.alt_text: The Oyster Perpetual Day-Date 36 in yellow gold with a mother-of-pearl, diamond-set dial.

site_title: Tottori: Crabs, sand and nature’s bounty
summary: Tottori, a Japanese prefecture, offers an authentic travel experience with its natural beauty and unique attractions. The prefecture is home to the itsukiboshi-gani, a prized snow crab found only in its coastal waters. Locals and wholesalers gather at the port to buy the crabs, highlighting the region's dedication to preserving its natural bounty. Visitors can explore the Tottori Sand Dunes, showcasing the prefecture's unspoiled nature, and experience the authentic Japanese culture that sets it apart from larger cities.

images.alt_text: Celebrate at home in style with exquisite takeaways by the team at yi by Jereme Leung.

site_title: Musk acknowledges US$2 trillion spending cut goal a long shot
summary: Elon Musk, tapped by US President-elect Donald Trump to oversee a government cost-cutting effort, has acknowledged that his goal of cutting $2 trillion in federal spending is a long shot. Musk described the target as a "best-case outcome" and believes he can achieve $1 trillion. However, most federal spending, including Social Security and Medicare programs, is unlikely to be cut, making the goal challenging.

site_title: North by Northwest: Journey to the Arctic
summary: A writer retraces a fabled remote sea route, the Northwest Passage, in pursuit of polar bear sightings. The journey, aboard the technologically advanced polar-class vessel Ultramarine, offers breathtaking views of icebergs, seabird colonies, and the Canadian Arctic. The passage, once a challenge for explorers, is now more accessible due to global warming, but this also poses threats to the polar bear population, which is declining. The writer encounters polar bears, musk ox, and other wildlife, as well as historic sites, including the final resting place of the ill-fated Franklin expedition. The journey highlights the beauty and fragility of the Arctic environment.

images.alt_text: Sound healing is quickly becoming one of the world’s biggest wellness trends – the market was valued at US$1.12b in 2023, and is forecast to more than double by 2032.
A distant view of Tottori Sand Dunes.

site_title:
China EV brands dominate debuts 
at Singapore Motorshow
summary: China dominates the electric vehicle (EV) debuts at the Singapore Motorshow 2025, with 12 out of 16 new EV models on display. Chinese brands such as Deepal, Jaecoo, IM Motors, Neta, and Yangwang made their first appearance in Singapore, while four other brands introduced in 2024 also debuted at the show. The rise of Chinese brands indicates shifting consumer preferences towards EVs, with many brands citing export markets as a key strategy. The Singapore Motorshow marks the growing presence of Chinese EV brands in the region, which is expected to increase due to government incentives and tariffs imposed on Chinese EVs in other markets.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

IM Motors LS6 sport-utility vehicle will go on sale in Singapore in the second half of 2025.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng acquires 150,000 more shares in Hotel Properties for S$537,000
summary: Singapore property tycoon Ong Beng Seng has acquired 150,000 shares in Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) for S$537,000, increasing his stake to 60.22%. He now holds a deemed interest in 206,479,232 shares, as the founder and managing director of the company. The transaction also led to a 0.17% stake for director Christopher Lim, who acquired 900,000 shares for S$3.24 each. Shares of HPL closed at S$3.55, down 0.3% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Embattled tycoon Ong Beng Seng's Hotel Properties can make a major contribution to Singapore by successfully redeveloping a trio of its Orchard Road assets.

site_title: New year traditions with Mosu chef Anh Sung-jae
summary: Korean chef Anh Sung-jae, owner of three Michelin-starred Mosu restaurant in Seoul, shares his personal memories and traditions of the Lunar New Year (Seollal). Born in California but raised in South Korea, Anh cherishes childhood memories of playing traditional games, such as go-stop and yutnori, and helping his grandparents prepare traditional dishes like jeon and tteok mandu guk. As a chef, Anh aims to infuse his food with emotions from his childhood, and Mosu will follow Korean holiday traditions based on the seasons. Anh looks forward to spending the Lunar New Year with his parents and reliving childhood memories.

images.alt_text: Xenia Tan and Shawn Thia prove that opposites really do attract.

site_title: Tudor sees red for Chinese New Year
summary: Tudor has released limited-edition watches for Chinese New Year, featuring auspicious colors such as salmon pink and burgundy. The Tudor Royal and Black Bay Chrono Blue Boutique Edition are available, with the latter showcasing Tudor's signature "Tudor Blue" hue. The watches are powered by automatic mechanical movements and come in various sizes, with prices ranging from S$3,460 to S$8,390.

site_title: Johor-Singapore SEZ could be ‘game changer’ for SMEs, but details on support needed: OCBC
summary: OCBC's global commercial banking chief, Linus Goh, suggests the Johor-Singapore SEZ could be a "game changer" for Singapore's SMEs, but notes they need government support in financing and capability building to create a viable cross-border operating model. Unlike Malaysia, which has announced tax incentives, Singapore has not provided specific details on how to support its businesses in setting up in the SEZ. Goh's comments come after OCBC released its quarterly SME Index, highlighting the need for targeted support to help SMEs thrive in the SEZ.

site_title: Beijing says EU imposed unfair trade barriers on Chinese firms
summary: China's commerce ministry claims the European Union imposed unfair "trade and investment barriers" on Chinese firms, including extra tariffs on Chinese-made electric cars and probes into Chinese government subsidies. Beijing denies its industrial policies are unfair and has threatened to take action to protect Chinese companies' rights. The EU seeks to expand renewable energy use and reduce reliance on Chinese technology amid concerns over Beijing's national security threat. The dispute reflects a wider trade standoff between the two economic powers.

The move will allow Trump to build a new tariff programme by using the International Economic Emergency Powers Act, which authorises a president to manage imports during a national emergency.

site_title: 🤯 Is ‘brain rot’ taking over your life?
summary: Brain rot, a term describing the feeling of mental exhaustion or numbness from excessive digital consumption, affects young adults, particularly Gen Z. Characterized by constant buzzing with trivial content, brain rot can lead to social isolation, anxiety, depression, and difficulties forming healthy relationships. Experts stress the importance of intentional screen time, suggesting strategies like setting boundaries, engaging in physical activities, and adopting personal habits to create balance. By reclaiming control over digital habits, individuals can overcome brain rot and reconnect with real-world relationships and activities.

site_title: Bountiful feasts for the Year of the Snake
summary: Celebrations for the Year of the Snake are underway in Singapore, with top hotels and restaurants offering opulent reunion dinners, takeaway treats, and auspicious menus. Orchard Hotel Singapore's Hua Ting restaurant and Carlton Hotel Singapore's Wah Lok Cantonese Restaurant are among the top spots, featuring dishes such as abalone, hamachi, and braised pork belly. Mandarin Oriental Singapore offers exclusive Hennessy menus, while Cherry Garden presents curated menus with premium ingredients like South African abalone and Miyazaki wagyu beef. The Capitol Kempinski Hotel Singapore offers Good Fortune and Prosperity Blooming set menus, and takeaway options from The Boutique.

site_title: Gold subdued; investors await US data for cues on Fed’s policy path
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $2,659.27 per ounce, weighed down by rising US yields and a stronger dollar, as investors await US data for clarity on the Federal Reserve's interest rate stance for 2025.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held its ground at US$2,650.62 per ounce.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars struggle near two-year lows, data on help
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are near two-year lows due to rising US Treasury yields. Australian retail sales rose 0.8% in November, but missed forecasts, and core inflation is slowing, leading to expectations of a February interest rate cut. Analysts predict a 0.4% quarterly rise in inflation, which would support rate cuts. Markets imply a 75% probability of a US quarter-point rate reduction and a 50-basis-point rate cut in New Zealand by February.

images.alt_text: Rents are a key input for quarterly inflation data which is due later this month.
The Electronic Travel Authorisation (ETA) scheme – similar to the ESTA system in the United States – requires visitors who do not need a visa to enter Britain to acquire pre-travel authorisation.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as trades fret over US inflation, rates outlook
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday as investors worried about US inflation, interest rates, and the potential impact of Donald Trump's presidency. Chinese consumer inflation remained low despite stimulus measures, and the Federal Reserve's hawkish pivot has raised concerns about sticky inflation and a strong labor market. The Dow and S&P 500 ended slightly higher, while the Nasdaq dipped. Hong Kong edged up, while Shanghai fell, and Tokyo, Sydney, and other Asian markets also declined.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.3 per cent to 42,635.20, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index picked up by 0.2 per cent to 5,918.25 on Wednesday.

site_title: Wall Street expected to shed 200,000 jobs as AI erodes roles
summary: Global banks are expected to shed 200,000 jobs over the next three to five years due to the impact of artificial intelligence on tasks currently carried out by human workers. According to a report by Bloomberg Intelligence, chief information and technology officers expect a 3% net workforce cut, with back office, middle office, and operations being the most at risk. This shift towards AI-driven productivity aims to improve efficiency and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: The US wants to curb the sale of AI chips used in data centres on both a country and company basis.

site_title: Biden to further limit Nvidia AI chip exports in final push
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration plans to impose additional restrictions on the export of AI chips from companies like Nvidia, targeting both countries and companies, ahead of his departure. The goal is to curb the spread of AI technology to China and Russia, concentrating development in friendly nations and aligning businesses with American standards. The regulations, set to be issued as soon as Friday, would create three tiers of chip curbs and expand existing semiconductor trade restrictions to most of the world.

images.alt_text: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang expects automotive hardware and software revenue of US$5 billion in fiscal 2026, up from an expected US$4 billion this year.

Nvidia minted multiple billionaires as directors, not co-founders, after its stock surged 171% in 2024, driven by soaring demand for artificial intelligence chips, ranking second on the S&P 500 Index.
Nvidia dominates the market for AI graphics processors and commands about 80 per cent of its share.

site_title: Los Angeles wildfire economic loss estimates top US$50 billion
summary: Raging wildfires in Los Angeles have killed at least two people and destroyed hundreds of buildings, with estimated economic loss topping US$50 billion, according to US private forecaster AccuWeather. The fires, fueled by fierce winds, have stretched firefighting resources and water supplies, with potential for further damage if the fire spreads to densely populated neighborhoods. Insured losses are expected to be around US$10 billion, with property consultant CoreLogic estimating nearly US$300 billion in reconstruction value at risk in the affected areas.

site_title: Malaysia proposes RM5 billion infrastructure fund for Johor-Singapore SEZ: economy minister
summary: Malaysia proposes an RM5 billion infrastructure fund for the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone, aiming to attract investments in 11 key sectors. The fund is included in Malaysia's Budget 2025 and is currently under discussion regarding its adequacy and implementation mechanism. Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli emphasized that the challenge lies in the mechanism due to multiple layers between federal and state governments. The joint development of the zone aims to boost economic cooperation between Malaysia and Singapore.

site_title: Irish home asking prices rise at highest rate since 2022: report
summary: Ireland's average residential transaction prices rose 8.4% in the fourth quarter of 2024, the highest rate since June 2022, according to a report by MyHome. The average transaction now settles for 9% over the asking price, with one in seven homes selling for 20% or more over the asking price. This intensifies competition for homes, driven by a chronic shortage. The report forecasts a 4% rise in Irish house prices in 2025, attributed to European Central Bank rate cuts and household savings.

site_title: Malaysia at final stage of petrol subsidy revamp: Economy minister
summary: Malaysia is nearing completion of a proposal to cut subsidies for its cheapest petrol, targeting the wealthiest 15% of the population. The plan aims to free RM8 billion annually by mid-2025. The economy minister plans to implement a two-tier price system, with the richest 15% paying market rate for RON95 petrol while the rest enjoy subsidized prices. This move is part of the government's efforts to re-target subsidies more granularly using a net disposable income approach.

site_title: Epson puts Tuas building up for sale at S$55 million as it winds down Singapore plant
summary: Epson is selling its Tuas facility in Singapore for approximately S$55 million, marking the Japanese electronics firm's plan to wind down its Singapore plant operations over the next three years. The two-storey industrial building has a potential built-up area of about 768,550 sq ft and significant redevelopment potential, according to CBRE. The site is suitable for various industrial needs and caters to sectors with growing demand, such as the data centre sector, offering "ample facilities" for these sectors.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The collective sale of Concorde Hotel and Shopping Mall for S$821 million in November was the largest such transaction last year.

site_title: Auspicious celebrations at the Raffles
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore is celebrating the Chinese New Year with an exclusive dining experience at yi by Jereme Leung, featuring authentic Chinese delicacies and modern twists. Takeaways and gift hampers are also available, including yusheng platters and auspicious blooms. The hotel's Raffles Spa offers rejuvenating treatments, such as the Festive Glow and Raffles Sparkle. From January 20 to February 12, families can enjoy a range of festive experiences, including dine-in menus, a la carte options, and dim sum sets, with prices starting from S$198++ per person.

site_title: China car sales maintain growth pace in 2024, EV and hybrid sales hit record
summary: China's car sales maintained growth in 2024, with electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids reaching a record high amid a price war and subsidized trade-ins. Local winners like BYD, Geely, and Xiaomi benefited, while Tesla's China sales hit a record high despite a global decline. This growth accelerated industry shakeouts in the competitive market, with Tesla bucking the trend by expanding its robotaxi services in California and Arizona.

images.alt_text: Buyers who trade in an old car for a new EV or plug-in hybrid will receive a 20,000 yuan subsidy.

site_title: Extreme weather drives insured losses to highest since 2017
summary: Insured losses from natural catastrophes reached a record $140 billion in 2024, surpassing the 2017 peak and more than doubling the 30-year average. Hurricanes Milton and Helene caused $41 billion in losses in the US, while extreme flooding in Dubai and Spain's Valencia region resulted in billions of dollars in insurance losses. The increase in natural disasters coincides with a rapid rise in temperatures, with 2024 being the planet's hottest year on record. Climate change is believed to play a crucial role in making weather disasters more frequent and extreme.

images.alt_text: Indonesia suffered the highest death toll, with more than 160,000 people killed along its western coast.
In 2004, in the months leading up to the tsunami, there were 60 reported piracy raids in the Straits of Malacca. It fell sharply immediately after the tsunami, mostly because of the disruption.

Authorities have warned of a high-risk bush fire season this Australian summer after several quiet seasons compared with the 2019-2020 “Black Summer” fires.
More than 13,000 people had been forced to flee their homes, with temporary shelters set up in schools and temples.

site_title: Apollo to boost staffing for Japan and Asia wealth, top regional executive says
summary: Apollo Global Management plans to expand its Japan office, adding around 10 people to accelerate its growth in the country. The Tokyo office will increase to 30 staff in the next two years, making it the firm's fastest-growing office in Asia. This expansion comes as global investment firms, including rivals Warburg Pincus and Carlyle, also expand their presence in Japan. The move is driven by a surge in dealmaking in the country, with Japan accounting for 30% of private equity deals in the Asia-Pacific region in 2023.

images.alt_text: Apollo manages about US$275 billion of investment-grade credit and its high-grade capital solutions business.

site_title: Vietnam proposes ‘unprecedented’ policies for financial centres in Ho Chi Minh City, Da Nang
summary: Vietnam has proposed "unprecedented" policies for its financial centers in Ho Chi Minh City and Da Nang, aiming to attract global capital flows shifting away from traditional hubs like Hong Kong and Singapore. The government seeks to capitalize on its strategic location and unique time zone, which could attract idle capital during trading downtime. The proposed policies include simplified administrative procedures, exemptions or reductions in taxes, and regulatory sandboxes for fintech businesses. A steering committee, led by Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, will review the draft resolution and related reports before submitting it to parliament for final approval in May 2025.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s GDP grew 7.55 per cent in the fourth quarter, the General Statistics Office said in a report.
Vietnam expects its stock market to be upgraded in 2025 by FTSE to emerging market, from the current frontier status.
Programme on Connecting to Promote Vietnam – Singapore Trade and Investment was held on Oct 1 in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Australia retailers get Black Friday boost, but no bar posed to rate cut
summary: Australia's retail sales rose 0.8% seasonally adjusted in November, driven by Black Friday discounts, but missed forecasts. The increase, the biggest in 10 months, suggests the boost may not pose a challenge to rate cuts. Analysts expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to consider easing policy in February, with a 60-78% chance of a rate cut amid a tight labor market and slowing inflation.

images.alt_text: Rents are a key input for quarterly inflation data which is due later this month.
The Australian dollar slipped 0.34 per cent to US$0.6214, while three-year bond futures reversed earlier losses to be up 4 ticks to 96.11.

site_title: Malaysia aiming to become energy, chip making hub, PM says
summary: Malaysia aims to become a hub for energy and chip manufacturing in 2025, capitalizing on recent investments and a favorable domestic economy. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said the country's economy rebounded last year, driven by strategic investments in renewable energy and artificial intelligence. Malaysia is targeting over $100 billion in semiconductor investments and plans to produce its own graphics processing unit chips, with a goal of becoming a global market leader in oil and gas, semiconductors, and Islamic finance.

images.alt_text: Higher salaries for civil servants, as well as plans to increase the minimum wage in the private sector, are also poised to boost domestic demand.
The package is designed to attract high-value investments into Johor.

site_title: A stimulus is good, but China still faces a hard slog
summary: China's efforts to boost its economy have shifted global market sentiment, with the US Federal Reserve no longer the sole driver of market sentiment. To sustain its "stardom," China needs to deliver on its promised monetary easing, fiscal expansion, and other measures, while also setting concrete goals to justify the optimism. However, the article questions whether such a victory would be temporary or have lasting impact, highlighting the need for China to demonstrate sustained progress to maintain its global influence.

images.alt_text: China’s top policymakers have adopted a more pro-growth policy stance for next year, including pledges to use fiscal tools, as a new Trump presidency could lead to more US tariffs.
China has made boosting consumption a higher priority this year as it looks to fight deflation amid subdued household and business confidence.

site_title: China discovers cluster of new mpox strain
summary: China has discovered a cluster outbreak of the Ib subclade of the mpox virus, a mutated strain that spreads through close contact, after a foreigner with a history of travel to the Democratic Republic of the Congo was infected. Four further cases have been found in people who had close contact with the individual, with mild symptoms including skin rash and blisters. The World Health Organization declared a global public health emergency for mpox last year, and China is managing the outbreak as a Category B infectious disease, enabling emergency measures to be taken.

images.alt_text: A test tube labelled "Mpox virus positive" is held in this illustration taken August 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Sweden, Thailand, and India have confirmed cases of the clade Ib type of the virus, outside of the Democratic Republic of Congo and neighbouring countries.

site_title: Endowus raises US$17.5 million in funding; new investors include basketball star Jeremy Lin
summary: Wealth advisory platform Endowus has raised US$17.5 million in funding, with new investors including OSK Ventures, The Wells Investment, and basketball star Jeremy Lin's impact fund. This follows a US$35 million round last year, taking cumulative funding to US$52.5 million. The new funding will be used to expand in Singapore and Hong Kong, investing in talent and technology, including artificial intelligence. Endowus' assets under management have reached US$7 billion as of November 2024, with plans to continue growing its client base.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Gregory Van, co-founder and chief executive officer of Endowus says that the fintech will hone in on personalisation as its next stage or growth.
Robo-advisors leveraged on tech and easy passive investing to bring customers on board
Endowus' Gregory Van (left) and Samuel Rhee. The firm expands into ultra-wealthy client segment with purchase of HK-based multi-family office, Carret Private.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, China Everbright Water, Tan Chong International
summary: Property tycoon Gordon Tang and his wife Celine have raised their mandatory conditional cash offer to acquire all units of Suntec Reit to S$1.19 apiece. China Everbright Water issued its first tranche of medium-term notes for 2025 with a principal amount of 1.5 billion yuan and a 1.78% coupon rate. Tan Chong International expects an unrealised loss of HK$29 million due to share price changes in its listed investments. The developments may affect trading of these companies' securities.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

site_title: Chip designer Arm considers acquiring Ampere computing
summary: Arm Holdings is exploring a potential deal to acquire Ampere Computing, a semiconductor designer backed by Oracle. Ampere, valued at $8 billion in a 2021 investment, is considering strategic options amid a competitive AI spending boom. A deal could add expertise and impetus to Arm's push into the data centre market. Ampere's founder and CEO Renee James had eyed taking the company public, but a sale could be an alternative. Talks could still fall apart, with another suitor potentially acquiring Ampere.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm is one of Arm’s biggest customers and a long-time partner, but the companies have grown increasingly at odds.
Arm licenses the fundamental set of instructions that software uses to communicate with chips.
Arm says that the move is a breach of Qualcomm’s license and is demanding that the company destroy Nuvia designs that were created before the Nuvia acquisition.
Intel, once the world’s largest chipmaker, has become the target of takeover speculation since a rapid deterioration of its business this year.

site_title: Wide range of Japanese firms see need to hike wages, Bank of Japan says
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) stated that a wide range of Japanese firms need to hike wages due to structural labor shortages, aligning with the central bank's previous stance for tightening monetary policy. The BOJ raised its economic assessment for two Japanese regions and maintained its view for the remaining areas, with some firms discussing rate hikes. This development is seen as a factor that may lead to a near-term interest rate hike from the current 0.25% at the BOJ's next policy-setting meeting on Jan 23-24.

images.alt_text: japan worker job Photographer: Kentaro Takahashi/Bloomberg
Japan's final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers’ index grew to 50.9 in December from 50.5 in November, according to a survey compiled by S&P Global Market Intelligence.
Manufacturers stayed confident about their outlook as they expect business to expand thanks to the launch and mass production of new products.
Japan is one of the world’s oldest societies, and this year the proportion of its people aged 65 or over reached a record 29.3 per cent.

site_title: From banks to tech: Potential Singapore winners from the Johor-Singapore SEZ
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have established a Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) that aims to drive investments in 11 key sectors, including manufacturing, logistics, and the digital economy. The zone may attract supply chains shifting due to US-China trade tensions, benefiting sectors such as banks, gaming, and technology. Maybank analysts predict increased demand for banks and financial services companies to expand their presence in the zone, creating opportunities for OCBC and UOB. The zone also aims to create 20,000 skilled jobs and 100 projects over the next decade.

images.alt_text: The exchange of the SEZ document took place during the 11th Malaysia-Singapore Leaders’ Retreat on Jan 7 in Putrajaya, and was witnessed by Singapore’s Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.
The Johor-Singapore Causeway is one of the busiest land border crossings in the world.

site_title: LG Energy posts unexpected loss as EV demand slows; shares drop
summary: LG Energy Solution reported a 225.5 billion won (S$211.7 million) operating loss for the third quarter, surpassing analyst estimates for a 16.4 billion won profit, as EV demand cooled due to higher living costs and subsidy removal in Europe. The company's shares fell 4% in Seoul, and battery demand from General Motors is expected to be lower than anticipated. LG Energy faces a challenging business environment, with CEO Kim Dong-myung stating the EV industry will rebound after 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee walks past the logo of LG Energy Solution at its office building in Seoul, South Korea, Nov. 23, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: China’s consumer prices stall in 2024 on feeble demand
summary: China's consumer prices stagnated in 2024 due to weak domestic demand, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising only 0.2% year-over-year. Factory-gate prices have remained deflationary for 27 straight months. Authorities have responded with fiscal stimulus, including a record $411 billion special treasury bond insurance, but experts warn that underlying inflation will drop back later this year. The slowdown in China's economy is attributed to job insecurity, a housing downturn, debt, and tariff threats from the US.

images.alt_text: China has made boosting consumption a higher priority this year as it looks to fight deflation amid subdued household and business confidence.
China’s economy has struggled over the past few years, weighed down by weak consumption and investment, and a severe property crisis.
Chinese manufacturers maintained an optimistic view about output in 2025 though the degree of optimism eased to the lowest since September.

site_title: Singapore shares retreat after Fed December minutes; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.6% on Thursday, Jan 9, after US Federal Reserve minutes showed slower expected rate cuts in 2025. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,862.6. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the biggest gainer, rising 1%. The broader market saw 281 losers beat 222 gainers, with 982.3 million shares worth S$913.1 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

Suntec City Fountain of Wealth decked in blue on 4 February 2021 to mark World Cancer Day. World Cancer Day (WCD) is an initiative of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC). As Singapore’s leading charity in the fight against cancer, SCS has rallied support from 15 buildings/landmarks to join in the light up and signal their commitment to the global challenge of cancer. The act of lighting up major landmarks not only helps to bring attention to World Cancer Day, but is a symbolic act of hope in the ongoing fight against cancer, especially during this COVID-19 situation in Singapore.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, January 9, 2025
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday due to concerns over US inflation and interest rate outlook. The Pound reached a one-year low, while China announced a record issuance in Hong Kong to prop up its currency. Chinese consumer inflation fell for the fourth consecutive month. Meanwhile, Hyundai Motor Group announced a record investment of 24.3 trillion won in South Korea this year.

images.alt_text: In early trade, Hong Kong edged up while Shanghai fell as investors assessed data showing Chinese inflation eased in December.
Hyundai Motor Group, including Hyundai Motor and Kia, ranks third in global vehicle sales behind Toyota Motor and Volkswagen.

site_title: Bryan Lee: Putting faith in Eastern wellness principles
summary: Bryan Lee, a 43-year-old Malaysian businessman, is launching an Eastern-meets-West wellness hospitality concept in Labrador Park, Singapore. The luxury wellness hub will integrate traditional Chinese medicine with Western healing modalities, focusing on preventive care and health maintenance. Lee, who has sunk "eight figures" into the properties, aims to bring the concept to Malaysia and Indonesia. His vision is to provide bespoke services and treatments, including food, exercise, and wellness retreats, in an upscale environment. The refurbishment plans for the hotel are set to begin in the second half of 2025.

images.alt_text: Over the years, the iconic Serpenti has undergone multiple transformations and is Bvlgari's most successful collection.

site_title: UK shop prices dropped in December but prices likely to rise in 2025: BRC
summary: The British Retail Consortium reported that UK shop prices fell by 2.4% in December, the largest drop in over three years, driven by a 1% annual deflation. However, higher costs in 2025 may lead to retailers struggling to keep inflation on a downward path. Food prices remained unchanged at 1.8%, while non-food prices dropped. Retailers will face increased costs due to employment costs, business rates, and packaging levies, prompting potential price hikes.

images.alt_text: The five-year UK yield is up about 20 basis points since the budget, and the benchmark 10-year rate has risen around 30 basis points to trade at the highest since October 2023.
Business confidence has “declined significantly”, with only 49 per cent expecting turnover to increase in the coming year.
The caution of consumers – who make up about two-thirds of the economy – comes despite growing real incomes and easing borrowing costs.
CEBR expects Britain to narrow the gap with the poorer-performing German economy over the next 15 years.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to hire more Asia wealth relationship managers
summary: Morgan Stanley plans to expand its Asia wealth management team, aiming to increase the number of relationship managers from 140 to 200 over the next few years. The firm's focus on the super wealthy in Asia allows customers to diversify away from the region, investing in sectors like AI and healthcare in the US. Wealth management firms in Asia are targeting a 50% increase in assets under management to $260 trillion by 2026, driven by the sector's strong secular growth in the ultra-high net worth segment.

images.alt_text: Investors have been bullish on New York offices that are well-located, especially on Park Avenue.

site_title: Maybank initiates Parkway Life Reit coverage with ‘buy’ call,  S$4.10 price target, on strong growth prospects
summary: Maybank Securities has initiated coverage on Parkway Life Reit with a "buy" call and a target price of S$4.10, citing strong growth prospects driven by the Reit's acquisition in France and in-built rent escalation in Singapore. Analyst Krishna Guha expects a compound annual growth rate of 7.2% in distribution per unit for financial years 2024 to 2026, backed by the French acquisition and Singapore lease renewals. The Reit's yield spread is tight, but Guha views the premium valuation as justified by its defensive attributes.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as bond yields jump on rate, tariff jitters
summary: European shares declined 0.2% on Wednesday, with most regional bourses also falling, amid rising bond yields and concerns about new tariffs under Donald Trump's presidency. Bond yields surged, with German 10-year notes reaching their highest level in over five months, mirroring a rise in US Treasury yields. Investors priced in fewer interest rate cuts in Europe and the US this year, contributing to the dip in sentiment.

site_title: Australian rents are rising at the slowest pace in three years
summary: Australian median rents rose 6.9% in the three months to December from a year ago, the slowest pace in three years, according to REA Group Market Insight. Despite this, nationwide rents reached a new high of A$620 per week. The slowing pace of rent growth may lead to a Reserve Bank of Australia rate cut sooner than expected. Experts expect rents to increase "moderately" this year, amid an increase in available rentals and cost of living pressures.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar slipped 0.34 per cent to US$0.6214, while three-year bond futures reversed earlier losses to be up 4 ticks to 96.11.
Higher interest rates, a shortage of homes and booming population growth have triggered a housing crisis in parts of Australia.

site_title: Dyna-Mac delists from SGX on Jan 9
summary: Dyna-Mac, an offshore oil-and-gas contractor, has delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) effective January 9, 2025. The move follows the completion of a compulsory acquisition by Hanwha Ocean SG, which acquired all shares not acquired under a previous offer. Dyna-Mac's executive chairman and CEO, Lim Ah Cheng, was fired in December after a business review, as the company sought to improve its strategic direction and operations.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Dyna-Mac will lose its free float on the Singapore Exchange as Hanwha Ocean SG Holdings will make a compulsory acquisition of all its shares, the offeror said on Wednesday (Nov 20).

site_title: Japan’s November real wages fall for fourth straight month as inflation weighs
summary: Japan's real wages fell 0.3% in November, marking the fourth consecutive month, due to inflation. Despite a 2.7% increase in base salary, the inflation-adjusted real wages slipped due to higher prices. The Bank of Japan considers sustained wage hikes as a prerequisite for raising interest rates. Large Japanese firms are expected to raise wages by 5% in 2025, with the government prioritizing wage growth in this year's spring negotiations.

images.alt_text: The owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores has rejected a US$47 billion buyout offer from Canada’s Alimentation Couche-Tard and the retailer’s founding family is in talks to take the company private to fend off the takeover.

The initial residents of Woven City will be composed mostly of the carmaker’s own employees and their families.

site_title: Blackstone’s infrastructure fund for individuals raises more than US$1 billion
summary: Blackstone's new infrastructure fund for individuals has raised over $1 billion, one of the largest initial hauls for such a vehicle. The fund, led by Greg Blank, allows investors to withdraw up to 3% of the fund's net asset value each quarter. This move marks a shift for Blackstone, which now oversees about a fifth of its $1.1 trillion of assets for individuals and banks' wealth clients. The fund's annual management fee is 1.25%, and it takes 12.5% of total returns.

images.alt_text: The deal is the latest in a string of transactions that have seen planned office projects ditched in favour of alternative uses including hotels and student accommodation.
Blackstone will continue to be Resolution’s investment manager across private credit and other areas after Nippon completes the acquisition.

site_title: Gordon Tang and wife increase cash offer for Suntec Reit to S$1.19 a unit
summary: Gordon Tang and his wife have increased their cash offer for Suntec Reit to S$1.19 per unit, from S$1.16 per unit previously announced. The offer, made through investment holding company Aelios, represents about 33.3% of Suntec Reit's issued units. The closing date for the offer has been extended to February 3.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
The offeror intends to maintain the listing status of Suntec Reit on the Singapore Exchange following the completion of the offer.
The offeror intends to maintain the listing status of Suntec Reit on the Singapore Exchange, following the completion of the offer.

site_title: Bangladesh garment industry rebounds, but workers say little change
summary: Bangladesh's garment industry, the world's second-largest, has partially rebounded after a revolution that crippled production in 2023. While owners report business is back to normal, workers say little change has occurred, and life remains hard. Garment workers, who earned $140 a month, welcomed a 5% wage hike but report increased demands for production targets, leaving them with minimal benefits. The industry's apparent fiscal success hides underlying struggles, with workers facing exploitation and struggling to maintain a minimum standard of living.

site_title: Trump mulls national economic emergency declaration to allow for new tariff programme: CNN
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is considering declaring a national economic emergency to justify a series of universal tariffs on allies and adversaries. This move would allow Trump to build a new tariff programme using the International Economic Emergency Powers Act, which authorizes a president to manage imports during a national emergency. A source familiar with the matter stated that "nothing is off the table" in the discussion.

site_title: Hyundai Motor Group to invest record 24.3 trillion won in South Korea this year
summary: Hyundai Motor Group plans to invest a record 24.3 trillion won (S$22.8 billion) in South Korea this year, a 19% increase from last year. The investment will focus on research and development, electrification, and software-defined vehicles, with 11.5 trillion won allocated for next-generation products. The company aims to secure future growth despite economic and political uncertainties, citing external risks such as recession and global conflicts. The investment boost follows a dip in global sales in 2024 and comes ahead of a 2% growth target for combined global sales to 7.4 million vehicles in 2025.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s Hyundai and BAIC subsidiary BAIC Investment will each inject about US$548 million into their equally owned venture Beijing Hyundai Motor.
Hyundai aims to have a full lineup of 23 EV models by 2030.

site_title: US consumer borrowing drops on plunge in credit-card balances
summary: US consumer borrowing unexpectedly dropped in November by $7.5 billion, the largest decline in over a year, as credit-card balances plummeted $13.7 billion. Non-revolving credit, such as loans for vehicle purchases, increased $6.2 billion. The decline suggests consumers are paying down credit-card balances amid high borrowing rates near 20%. The data contradicts expectations and may indicate a slowdown in consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Resilient demand, illustrated by the pickup in business activity and stronger orders, adds to concerns that inflation will remain stubborn.

The jump in imports was broad, including increases in consumer goods, capital equipment and motor vehicles, likely reflecting a preference by US companies to secure shipments in advance of potential tariffs.
Americans have mostly exhausted their pandemic savings and have generally been putting aside a smaller share of their incomes each month.

site_title: Thai central bank rebuffs demand for steps to boost inflation
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, has rebuffed demands to boost inflation, citing a focus on financial stability and economic growth. Assistant Governor Sakkapop Panyanukul stated that inflation is not a problem, and maintaining a target band of 1-3% will provide flexibility and credibility. The bank has kept the benchmark rate steady at 2.25% and expects consumer prices to stay around 1% in 2025, with a possible dip below the target range in the third quarter. The decision comes as the government and bank clash over strategies to jump-start the country's economy after a decade of lackluster growth.

images.alt_text: Monetary policy becomes less effective under high uncertainty, but holding the rate steady does not rule out future policy adjustments, the central bank says.
The government and BOT have sparred for months over how best to jumpstart South-east Asia’s second-largest economy after about a decade of lacklustre growth.
The government has been exploring ways to exert greater influence on the BOT, including by appointing its nominee as chair.

site_title: Malaysia’s growth set to surpass 5% this year, minister says
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to surpass 5% growth this year, driven by strong foreign direct investments and support from state-owned funds. The government plans to narrow its deficit to 3.8% of GDP and boost domestic demand with higher civil servant salaries and increased minimum wage. Malaysian government-linked investment companies have also boosted investments in the economy, fueling growth. The country's diversified economy is expected to withstand global risks, including trade wars and tariffs, and the ringgit is expected to remain strong.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Deputy Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Liew Chin Tong said: “We will have to stand together and tell the MNCs that we need to collect these taxes for the greater good of our people.”
The Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry said the decision to impose the anti-dumping duty is to protect domestic industry from alleged unfair trade practices.

site_title: Tesla poised for 1 billion euros windfall from EU’s emissions curbs
summary: Tesla is set to collect over 1 billion euros in compensation from rival automakers in the European Union for helping them meet tougher pollution standards. The US company will pool its electric vehicle fleet with manufacturers like Toyota, Stellantis, and Ford to balance emissions. This arrangement allows carmakers to average out their emissions, with those selling fewer EVs compensating those that over-comply. The move eases pressure on manufacturers like Stellantis to ramp up production of EVs.

images.alt_text: Panasonic Energy, which supplies batteries to Tesla as well as other automakers, is a unit of Japanese electronics giant Panasonic.

site_title: Car dealer Tan Chong expects unrealised loss of HK$29 million for FY2024
summary: Tan Chong International expects to report an unaudited unrealised loss of HK$29 million for FY2024, primarily due to share price changes in its listed investments. The loss is lower than the audited unrealised gain of HK$270 million in the previous year. The group's financial performance is expected to be published before the end of March 2025, and the loss will be reported in its other comprehensive income statement.

site_title: US: Wall St opens muted as investors assess data, Trump economic emergency report
summary: US stocks opened muted on Wednesday as investors assessed softer-than-expected jobs data and a report that President-elect Donald Trump was considering a national economic emergency declaration. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 13.7 points, or 0.03%, to 42,542.1, while the S&P 500 rose 1.6 points, or 0.03%, to 5,910.66. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 20.3 points, or 0.10%, to 19,469.365.

site_title: Be wary of Sam Altman’s AI doublespeak
summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has made contradictory statements about the future of artificial intelligence (AI), admitting to past guesswork while making new, speculative predictions. He claims AI will surpass human intelligence during the current president's term and that "agents" will join the workforce this year, but has also downplayed AI safety concerns. Altman's comments have been criticized for deflecting attention from current issues and promoting a mirage of safety and abundance. His actions are seen as a sophisticated version of the Silicon Valley hype machine, which could shape how businesses and policymakers view AI and potentially lead to a loosening of regulation.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Donald Trump has been a harsh critic of Meta and Zuckerberg for years, accusing the company of bias against him and threatening to retaliate once back in office.

OpenAI’s existing for-profit arm is currently controlled by its non-profit organisation.

site_title: Oil market structure changes as prompt supplies tighten
summary: Oil prices surged to a near five-month high due to tightening supply and expectations of a Chinese demand revival. The premium of the first-month Brent contract to the six-month contract widened to $3.05 a barrel, the most since late August. Oil output from OPEC fell in December, partly due to losses in Iran, and concerns about sanctions on Russia and China also boosted prices. Analysts attribute the widening premium to a perception of tighter prompt supply, a structure known as backwardation.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$77.05 a barrel, up 75 cents, or 0.98 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: Second US port strike averted as union, employers reach deal
summary: The United States Maritime Alliance and the International Longshoremen's Association reached a tentative six-year contract deal, averting a potential strike that could have impacted US supply chains. The agreement includes a resolution on automation and protects current ILA jobs, with terms not disclosed. This deal comes after a three-day ILA strike in October, which led to a 62% wage increase over six years. The parties will continue operating under the current contract until a ratification vote can be scheduled.

images.alt_text: In early October, a three-day ILA strike won generous pay concessions while barely denting the US economy. The union agreed to suspend its walkout until mid-January.

The US built, owned and operated Panama Canal until US president Jimmy Carter struck a deal in the 1970s to gradually hand over control of the vital waterway to the Panamanian authorities.
US President-elect Trump has taken to speaking out against the deal, refusing on Tuesday to rule out using military action to take it.
Shandong Port oversees major ports on China’s east coast including Qingdao, Rizhao and Yantai, which are major terminals for importing sanctioned oil.

site_title: BlackRock to cut about 1% of its employees; asset managing giant has over 20,000 staff
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, plans to cut approximately 1% of its workforce, affecting around 200 of its 21,000 employees. The cuts are part of the company's efforts to realign resources with its strategy, following significant acquisitions last year. BlackRock added 3,750 employees in 2024 and expects 2,000 more in 2025. The company believes these investments will enable it to accelerate its momentum in 2025 and serve clients over the long term.

site_title: Google must face mobile phone privacy class action, possible trial
summary: A US federal judge rejected Google's attempt to dismiss a class action lawsuit, paving the way for a possible trial in August. The lawsuit claims Google collected users' personal data from cellphones after they switched off a button to stop tracking, violating a California law against unauthorized fraudulent computer access. The judge found Google's conduct to be "highly offensive" due to ambiguous disclosures and internal communications suggesting intentional vagueness. Google will continue to argue that the allegations are "patently false."

site_title: ABSD tweak, housing affordability, urban rejuvenation lead property players’ Budget wish list
summary: Singapore's property players are urging the government to relax market cooling measures, particularly the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) regime, to boost housing affordability and promote urban renewal. They also want more efforts to tackle housing affordability, collectives sales, and the review of the executive condominium (EC) model. Experts suggest tweaking ABSD rules, raising the mortgage servicing ratio, and extending the Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) Scheme to encourage greater urban regeneration and sustainability.

site_title: Fed minutes show officials were eager to slow interest-rate cuts
summary: US Federal Reserve officials expressed eagerness to slow interest-rate cuts amid elevated inflation risks, citing higher inflation readings and reduced downside risks to the labour market. The Fed cut its benchmark lending rate by a quarter-point to 4.25-4.5% in December, and officials indicated they would adopt a more cautious approach to monetary policy decisions in the coming quarters. The incoming Trump administration's new policies on tariffs, immigration, and taxes could potentially blow the Fed's forecasts off course.

site_title: Deft at blending AI with design practices? This Singapore-based venture capitalist firm wants you, Design AI and Tech Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Singapore and the Netherlands identified key growth opportunities in green and digital transitions, as well as circular economy sectors. According to Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Grace Fu, the two nations can leverage their strengths in technology, innovation, and sustainability to drive growth. The focus will be on sectors such as renewable energy, sustainable infrastructure, and eco-friendly products. The partnership aims to enhance trade and investment between the two countries, promoting economic cooperation and sustainable development. The collaboration is expected to create new business opportunities and drive growth in both Singapore and the Netherlands.

site_title: Kia to debut made-in-Singapore EV5 as part of Apac EV strategy
summary: Kia is set to debut its first made-in-Singapore electric vehicle, the EV5, at the Singapore Motorshow on January 9. The EV5, built at the Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Center Singapore, will have a Singapore-only version with less than 110 kilowatts of power, eligible for a less expensive Category A COE. Pricing starts at under S$200,000, targeting a more affordable and mainstream EV offering for the region, taking on Chinese EV brands.

site_title: Lucky, Forever 21 operator merges with JCPenney
summary: SPARC Group, operator of fashion brands including Lucky and Forever 21, has merged with JCPenney to form Catalyst Brands. The joint venture was formed in an all-equity transaction, with Catalyst having approximately $9 billion in revenue, 1,800 store locations, and 60,000 employees. The combined company will be headed by Marc Rosen, former JCPenney CEO, and has sold its US operations of Reebok, with Forever 21 operations being explored for strategic options.

site_title: Panama Canal CEO says Trump’s plans would ‘lead to chaos’
summary: US President-elect Trump has sparked concern over the Panama Canal, stating he won't rule out using military action to take control of the waterway. The Panama Canal Authority's leader, Ricuarte Vasquez Morales, warned that granting Trump's demand for preferential treatment would "lead to chaos" and violate international law. Morales denied China's involvement in the canal's operations, stating it is run solely by the Panama Canal Authority. Vasquez Morales emphasized that rules are rules and exceptions are not allowed, highlighting the need to maintain neutrality and respect international law.

images.alt_text: The village of Kangaamiut in Greenland. Trump claims that US ownership of the Danish territory is "an absolute necessity".

Greenland is known both for its strategic location at a time when the melting of Arctic ice is opening new commercial and naval competition and for its reserves of rare earth minerals needed for advanced technology.

site_title: MAS equities market review group to complete report by August
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore's review group for the country's equities market is set to complete its report by August this year. Updates and recommendations will be provided in phases as the report is finalized, according to Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong. The review group was established in August last year to recommend ways to develop the Singapore equities market.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng

Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong says: “While there have been suggestions to channel sovereign monies into our equities market, it is not practical to rely on sovereign monies alone to sustain these funds and to support the equity market.”

site_title: Jefferies profit triples in sign dealmaking slump is ending
summary: Jefferies Financial Group's profit tripled in the fourth quarter, driven by a rebound in mergers and acquisitions and a surge in equity-trading revenue. Investment-banking fees jumped 73% and advisory revenue nearly doubled, with the company's full-year revenue reaching a record $3.44 billion. The results signal the end of a two-year dealmaking slump, with Jefferies attributing the turnaround to a normalization of interest rates and increased global M&A activity. The company's president, Brian Friedman, expects growth in the new issue and M&A markets in 2025.

site_title: Trump is China’s chance to be world’s climate leader
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's presidency may create a power vacuum allowing other major negotiating blocs to assume leadership in climate talks. With the US expected to turn conservative on climate change, China may emerge as the world's leading climate leader, leveraging its significant renewable energy financing and dominating EV sales in South-east Asia. Despite Trump's climate denialism, decarbonisation momentum is likely to continue globally, with South-east Asian countries setting their own climate targets and enacting policies to support them. China's increased importance in international climate talks could further deepen its role in the region's decarbonisation efforts.

site_title: Europe seeks to shift sentiment about its economic and political prospects
summary: Europe faces uncertain economic and political prospects in 2025, with a potential shift in sentiment. Despite recent crises, including the eurozone crisis, the region has shown resilience, particularly in Eastern Europe and the Mediterranean. Key initiatives from the new European Commission and potential trade deals with the US and other nations could rejuvenate growth. However, right-wing populism is growing in appeal, and the geopolitical context remains challenging, driven by Russia's actions and China's growing interest in Europe. The region's future is at a historical hinge point, where unexpected changes could either worsen or improve its prospects.

Scholz (top), a Social Democrat who will head a caretaker government until a new one can be formed, lost a confidence vote in parliament earlier this month after the departure of Finance Minister Christian Lindner’s Free Democrats left his unwieldy governing coalition without a legislative majority.
On Feb 23, Germany faces a ballot likely to sweep Chancellor Olaf Scholz from the nation’s top job.

site_title: Independent directors: A safeguard on dual roles of CEO-cum-executive chairman
summary: A letter to the editor responds to a commentary on the benefits of separating CEO and executive chairman roles. While the commentary suggests that having one person in both positions can lead to reduced effectiveness and conflicts of interest, it notes that the Code of Corporate Governance provides a safeguard in the form of a lead independent director to provide leadership in situations where the chairman is conflicted. This director can offer a neutral perspective and help mitigate potential conflicts of interest.

images.alt_text: Listed groups with an executive chairman may not have businesses that are way more complex than groups which have a non-executive chairman.

site_title: TikTok shop rival raises funds at US$5 billion valuation
summary: Whatnot, a US-based livestream shopping platform, has raised $265 million at a valuation of $4.97 billion, rivaling TikTok's shopping features. Founded in 2019, Whatnot has sold over $3 billion worth of goods last year, including sneakers and collectibles. The funding round, led by Greycroft Partners and DST Global, aims to expand the platform into new countries, launch new categories, and improve customer service. The move may attract sellers who could be impacted by a potential US ban on TikTok.

images.alt_text: The Whatnot app. Source: Whatnot

site_title: Japan’s Seven & i Holdings reports 24% drop in third-quarter profit
summary: Seven & i Holdings, operator of 7-Eleven, reported a 24% drop in third-quarter profit to 128 billion yen (S$1.1 billion), missing analyst estimates. This poor showing adds pressure on the company to demonstrate its ability to improve corporate value as it faces a proposed US$47-billion buyout offer from Canada's Alimentation Couche-Tard. The retailer has accelerated plans to focus on its core convenience store business by offloading non-core assets amid inflation weighing on consumer spending in Japan and North America.

site_title: Dollar strengthens as solid US data pushes up bond yields
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Wednesday, rising 0.15% to 108.86, driven by solid economic data, including a rise in job openings and a surge in services sector activity. This pushed 10-year bond yields to an eight-month high of 4.699%. The dollar's gain was accompanied by a decline in other major currencies, including the yen, euro, and sterling, which languished near multi-month lows. Markets now expect the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged, with a first cut in July.

images.alt_text: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's resignation is a market development that has driven spikes in currency options trading.

site_title: Celebrities flee Los Angeles fires as Hollywood events scrapped
summary: Wildfires in Los Angeles, California, killed at least two people and destroyed hundreds of homes, including those of celebrities. A-list actors and musicians, such as Mandy Moore and Mark Hamill, evacuated their homes due to the raging blazes. Hollywood events, including the Critics Choice Awards and a Pamela Anderson film premiere, were cancelled. Firefighters battled nearby flames whipped up by hurricane-force winds, and the Universal Studios theme park was closed. The Pacific Palisades area and Altadena were among the hardest hit, with multimillion-dollar homes destroyed in minutes.

images.alt_text: A firefighter works to extinguish wildfires in  Pacific Palisades on the west side of Los Angeles, California, Jan 7, 2025. site_title: Current scope of workplace fairness law is just a beginning: Tan See Leng
summary: Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng says Singapore's new workplace fairness law, which prohibits adverse employment decisions based on age, nationality, disability, and mental health, is just the beginning. He suggests that the law will be constantly reviewed, and suggestions to expand its protections to groups like platform workers and LGBT employees may not be adopted "at this particular point in time", but can be considered in future reviews.

site_title: US: Stocks rise modestly as traders assess Fed minutes
summary: US stocks rose modestly on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.3% to 42,635.20 and the S&P 500 Index adding 0.2% to 5,918.25. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.1% to 19,478.88. Investors await the government employment report due this week while assessing the prospect of further interest rate cuts. Minutes from the Federal Reserve's recent policy meeting showed officials raised concerns the fight against inflation may have stalled, potentially delaying rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent lower on Wednesday, with most regional bourses in the red.

site_title: Why Brics will not become the new fulcrum of world politics
summary: The BRICS alliance, comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, is unlikely to become the new center of power in world politics due to its lack of representation and unity. The addition of new members, such as Egypt and Ethiopia, has introduced rivalries, rather than strengthening the alliance. Key differences between its largest members, China, India, and Russia, hinder its ability to organize the Global South. The BRICS has limited success in achieving its goals, including replacing the US dollar as a global reserve currency. While it serves as a diplomatic device for some nations, its potential to challenge Western power is overstated.
