site_title: New law lets more Singapore companies undergo simpler, more cost-effective insolvency process
summary: Singapore has introduced a new law, dubbed "SIP 2.0", making its corporate debt restructuring and insolvency process simpler and more cost-effective for companies with total liabilities not exceeding S$2 million. The permanent programme, which was previously a temporary Covid-era scheme, will be a permanent feature of the country's corporate debt restructuring and insolvency regime, aiming to support companies in debt restructuring and insolvency.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The amendments in the Bill seeks to provide a simpler and more cost-effective insolvency process for companies.

site_title: Singapore does not cap number of ride-hailing operators; no conclusive link to COE prices
summary: Singapore will not limit the number of ride-hailing operators, Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor said in Parliament. The existing regulations aim to keep the sector "open and contestable," driving competition and service improvements, and matching demand and supply. The entry of two new ride-hailing operators has no conclusive evidence on affecting Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices, as COE prices are determined by macroeconomic conditions and quota supply. The point-to-point sector is demand-driven, with supply based on demand rather than the number of platform operators.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Generic photo of people browsing cars on display at car show The Car Expo, October 2024 in Singapore. PHOTO: DERRYN WONG ,BT
The  Certificate of Entitlement premium for Category C was the only one to drop this round, by 0.6 per cent to S$69,890.
Private hire cars  currently use the same Certificates of Entitlement as passenger cars and have been blamed for driving premiums up.
Major updates to improve taxi, private-hire car sector in Singapore effective from January
According to driver feedback, earnings may have dropped by 30 per cent in the past six months.

site_title: Tencent SDRs fall nearly 7% after US designates tech giant as ‘Chinese military company’
summary: Tencent's Singapore-listed shares fell nearly 7% after being designated as a "Chinese military company" by the US Department of Defense. The US ban, under the National Defense Authorization Act of 2004, prohibits US defense agencies from procuring goods and services from companies on the list. Tencent's US gaming revenue is estimated to be in the "high single digit" percentage range, but Morningstar believes the impact will be minimal. The company's Hong Kong-listed shares also declined, with Morningstar maintaining its fair value estimate and considering Tencent shares undervalued.

images.alt_text: Tencent is one of the top players in China’s expansive technology sector, operating the WeChat “super-app” with other offerings across gaming, content streaming and cloud services.
EVs at the BYD showroom in Singapore on Alexandra Road.

site_title: South Korean transport minister plans to resign over country’s worst air crash
summary: South Korea's Transport Minister Park Sang-woo plans to resign over the country's worst air crash, which killed 179 people on board a Boeing jet operated by Jeju Air on December 29. The crash occurred when the plane belly-landed and overshot the runway after hitting an embankment, which experts say was too rigid and too close to the end of the runway. The ministry will swiftly improve airport safety measures, including the landing systems, and investigators are investigating how the embankment was constructed. The US National Transportation Safety Board will analyze a flight data recorder recovered from the crash scene.

images.alt_text: A crane lifts the tail section during the salvage operation of the Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 aircraft which crashed and burst into flames at Muan International Airport, Muan, South Korea, Jan 3, 2025. The closure of Muan International Airport has been extended until Jan 14, the ministry of land said in a statement on Monday.
Tributes placed along a fence near the site where a Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 aircraft crashed and burst into flames at Muan International Airport in Muan, South Korea, Jan 2, 2025.
An official takes part in an investigation at the site where a Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 aircraft crashed and burst into flames at Muan International Airport.

Police forensics personnel and National Bureau of Investigation officials work at the scene where a Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 aircraft crashed and burst into flames at Muan International Airport in Muan.

Experts say many questions remain, including why the Jeju Air plane, powered by two CFM 56-7B26 engines, appeared to be travelling so fast and why its landing gear did not appear to be down when it skidded down the runway and into a concrete embankment.
Many victims of the plane crash, the worst in the country’s history, appeared to be returning from vacation for the holiday season, officials say.

site_title: Malaysia imposes provisional anti-dumping duties on PET imports from China, Indonesia
summary: Malaysia has imposed provisional anti-dumping duties on PET imports from China and Indonesia, ranging from 6.33% to 37.44%, to protect its domestic PET industry from unfair trade practices. The move follows an investigation initiated by domestic producer Recron Malaysia in August 2024. The duties will be in force for up to 120 days. The Malaysian Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry stated that the duties are necessary to prevent further injury to the domestic industry.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
The tariff is expected to take effect 15 days from the date of signing and will be in place for five years, the ministry says.
The new duties announced on Nov 29 by the Commerce Department extend the US’ anti-dumping regime in South-east Asia to solar cells, from just finished modules previously.
Beijing’s commerce ministry said that authorities have “decided to implement temporary anti-dumping measures in the form of a cash deposit or letter of guarantee” against European brandy products.

Indonesia finance ministry said that the duties will be introduced after an investigation showed “there was dumping on ceramic tile products that came from China, causing losses to domestic industries".

site_title: Currency options trading skyrockets as politics upend bets
summary: Currency options trading surged to $108 billion on Monday, the highest in nearly two months, amid political risks and a surging US dollar. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's resignation and potential US tariffs drove the spike, with investors cutting back on positions that would have profited from a stronger US currency. The yuan was also in focus, with some traders taking advantage of a weaker greenback to buy US dollar-yuan calls. This heightened volatility is expected to continue in 2025, with the US$7.5 trillion foreign exchange market being significantly impacted by politics and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Canada’s Prime Minister Justin Trudeau now trails his main rival, Conservative Pierre Poilievre, by 20 points in public opinion polls.

site_title: DBS upgrades PropNex to a ‘buy’ rating, lifts target price on expected ‘rebound’ in property market
summary: DBS upgraded its rating for real estate agency PropNex to "buy" and raised its target price to S$1.15 due to a forecast property market rebound. The bank believes PropNex's earnings are at an "inflexion point" with a strong pipeline of new launches and stable property prices. DBS predicts transaction volumes for 2025 to 2026 to stand at around 8,000 to 8,500 units, with private resale volumes remaining stable at 13,500 to 14,000 units.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
2024 has been an unprecedented one for Singapore's private residential market, with contrasting performance in new home sales and non-awards for state land tenders.

site_title: China’s residential foreclosures increase in 2024 amid property slump
summary: China's residential foreclosures increased to 370,000 in 2024, up from 364,000 in 2023, amid a property slump. A total of 117,000 homes were successfully sold for 163.6 billion yuan, a 1.9% year-on-year decrease. Foreclosures, including commercial properties, totaled 768,000 units, with most found in tier-three and tier-four cities. This marks a gradual rise since 2020, amid a severe property crisis triggered by a government-led initiative to curb indebted developers.

images.alt_text: China’s December home sales stay flat in sign of stabilisation

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise after tech-fuelled Wall Street rally
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Tuesday, following a tech-fuelled rally on Wall Street, despite Hong Kong stocks retreating due to Tencent's 7.8% drop after being named by the US as a "Chinese military company". The US jobs data release at the end of the week and potential changes in Donald Trump's tariff plans also influenced investors. Strong results from Foxconn sparked a fresh rush for semiconductors, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq hit fresh records.

images.alt_text: XXX
The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index faired the best out of the three major Wall Street indices, jumping 1.2 per cent to finish the day at 19,864.98.
Europe’s premier index, Stoxx 600, closed up 0.9 per cent, at its highest level in more than two weeks.

site_title: Johor-Singapore special economic zone agreement signed at leaders’ retreat
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have signed an agreement to establish a Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), covering over 3,500 square kilometers. The zone aims to attract new investment projects globally, enhance vendor propositions, and create jobs for both countries. The agreement was signed by Prime Ministers Lawrence Wong and Anwar Ibrahim, with the goal of building on the complementary strengths of both nations to increase competitiveness and extract more investments. The JS-SEZ will also promote economic resilience bilaterally and within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.
The panel also discusses the potential of generative AI for SMEs, and the implications of Donald Trump's second term.
The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.
The SEZ is located just across the Causeway, the world's busiest land crossing.

site_title: China’s biggest shipping line added to US military blacklist
summary: China's largest shipping line, Cosco Shipping Holdings, has been added to the US military blacklist for alleged links with the People's Liberation Army. The move follows previous sanctions in 2019 and 2021, and may impact US companies' dealings with the company. Cosco shares fell 4.4% in Hong Kong, while Chinese oil major China National Offshore Oil Corporation (Cnooc) saw its stock drop 1.6%. The blacklist highlights increased scrutiny of marine transport and shipbuilding amid rising tensions between the US and China.

images.alt_text: The second phase of Cosco Shipping's logistics hub aims to address the growing demand for specialised logistics services serving the petrochemical and chemical sectors in Jurong Island, which houses Singapore’s major petrochemical hub.

site_title: Eight telemed providers, including MaNaDr, investigated for regulatory breaches: Janil
summary: Eight telemedicine providers, including MaNaDr, have been investigated for regulatory breaches, with three cases completed and resulting in enforcement actions. Investigations into five providers are ongoing, with breaches categorized into lapses in clinical care and inappropriate advertising. Medical practitioners involved have been referred to the Singapore Medical Council for review. The Ministry of Health emphasizes that telemedicine can bring benefits, but acknowledges the need for vigilance to prevent abuse and misuse, particularly in the initial implementation period.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
A brief look at the MaNaDr app or website reveals little change.
The ministry had issued a notice of intent to revoke MaNaDr’s licence on 24 October.
Friday’s circular was issued by the Ministry of Health, Health Sciences Authority and  the Singapore Medical Council.
Telemedicine regulations remain valid, no review needed despite MaNaDr case: Ong Ye Kung

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jan 7)
summary: Singapore Prime Ministers Lawrence Wong and Anwar Ibrahim signed a Johor-Singapore special economic zone agreement, aiming to foster long-term business growth. Anwar Ibrahim stated that the KL-Singapore high-speed rail project can proceed only with 'full participation' from the private sector. The Singapore government issued a warning to SingPost regarding governance issues, while the services sector saw a slight decline in credit payments for the first time in six quarters. A new insolvency law allows simpler, more cost-effective procedures for Singapore companies.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the new Downtown Line/North-South Line interchange DE2/NS6 located at Sungei Kadut Avenue.

site_title: US trade deficit widens on largest jump in imports since 2022
summary: The US trade deficit widened in November, with the gap in goods and services trade growing 6.2% to $78.2 billion. Imports surged 3.4% to $351.6 billion, driven by a preference to secure shipments ahead of potential tariffs, while exports rose 2.7%. The increase in imports was the largest since March 2022, likely reflecting companies' efforts to avoid potential disruptions. The data is in line with economists' median projection.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has said that Congress will use revenue from tariffs to help pay for extending his 2017 tax cuts in a “powerful” bill that would eliminate taxes on tips.

site_title: Play your Trump card – 2025 is likely positive for investors but brace for bumpy ride
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's Republican clean sweep of the presidency, House of Representatives, and Senate promises to extend US exceptionalism, but with risks due to the valuation gap between US assets and the rest of the world. Trump's agenda may face constraints due to contradictions in his policy objectives, including jobs onshore, inflation control, and strong financial markets. As a result, investors can expect a positive 2025, but with a bumpy ride, and a preference for US equities with a globally diversified portfolio to mitigate risks.

site_title: Nvidia CEO unveils robot training tech, Toyota deal and new gaming chips
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang unveiled AI-powered robot training technology, known as Cosmos, which generates photo-realistic video to train robots and self-driving cars at a lower cost. The technology also enables the creation of synthetic training data, similar to Meta's Llama3 language models. Additionally, Nvidia introduced its new RTX 50 gaming chips, which use AI technology to improve graphics and realism. The company also announced a partnership with Toyota to use its Orin chips and automotive operating system in advanced driver assistance systems. Nvidia expects $5 billion in automotive hardware and software revenue in 2026.

images.alt_text: Nvidia minted multiple billionaires as directors, not co-founders, after its stock surged 171% in 2024, driven by soaring demand for artificial intelligence chips, ranking second on the S&P 500 Index.
Nvidia dominates the market for AI graphics processors and commands about 80 per cent of its share.
All of Nvidia’s AI semiconductors now use Ibiden’s substrates, although Taiwanese rivals such as Unimicron Technology are eyeing the field.
Nvidia has listed 11 job postings in Vietnam – all them for remote working, with half not specifying a particular city.

site_title: China’s WuXi Biologics to sell vaccine facility to Merck for US$500 million
summary: China's WuXi Biologics is selling its vaccine facility in Ireland to Merck for approximately US$500 million. The site, designed to meet Merck's commercial manufacturing needs, will be integrated into Merck's manufacturing network to supply global markets. The sale comes as WuXi Biologics seeks to enhance margins amidst US curbs on Chinese biotechnology companies, including the proposed Biosecure Act. The transaction is expected to be completed in the first half of 2025.

images.alt_text: Drugmakers have been racing to come up with pills that could duplicate the effects of Ozempic but would be more convenient to take.

Merck headquarters in Rahway, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, April 18, 2023. Merck & Co. will buy Prometheus Biosciences Inc. for about $10.8 billion to bolster its research pipeline and strengthen its portfolio of autoimmune drugs. Photographer: Christopher Occhicone/Bloomberg

site_title: Terminated KL-Singapore high-speed rail project can happen only with ‘full participation’ from private sector: Anwar
summary: Malaysia is reviving its high-speed rail project linking Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, with Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stating that "full participation" from the private sector is required for the project to proceed. This marks a significant shift from the original plan, which was terminated due to funding issues. Singapore is open to new proposals and is willing to start from a "clean slate." The project's revival is seen as a positive development for regional economic cooperation, with Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim expressing optimism about the project's potential.

site_title: India plans about US$3 billion aid, tariff cuts for electronics
summary: India's government is considering a $3.7 billion subsidy for electronic component-makers and cutting tariffs on imports to boost local manufacturing, particularly for smartphones. The proposal includes subsidies for components like batteries, camera parts, and microprocessors. If approved, the details will be announced in the upcoming budget in February. This move aims to create a broader supply chain for smartphone makers, who currently import most of their components from China.

images.alt_text: People on the rocks along the Bandstand Promenade in the suburb of Bandra in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Jan. 3, 2025. India’s new central bank governor said the economy will probably rebound next year on the back of strong consumer and business confidence, his first public comments about the growth outlook since he took office earlier this month. Photographer: Abeer Khan/Bloomberg
Around 85 companies aim to list on the Indian stock exchanges in 2025, collectively targeting 1.53 trillion rupees.
India's manufacturing output has shown sustained expansion with the index remaining above 50, which separates growth from expansion, for the past three-and-a-half years.

Villagers fill water from a well in Shahapur, Maharashtra, amid an ongoing heatwave, May 26, 2024. Far from India's financial capital Mumbai, impoverished villages in areas supplying the megacity's water are running dry - a crisis repeated across the country that experts say foreshadows terrifying problems. Demand is increasing in the world's most populous nation of 1.4 billion people, but supplies are shrinking - with climate change driving erratic rainfall and extreme heat.

site_title: Global firms set to leverage dual-region power play in Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone
summary: Multinational corporations (MNCs) are set to leverage the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone to combine Singapore's business expertise with Johor's cost advantages, driving cross-border expansion. The zone aims to facilitate smoother regulations, streamlined logistics, and enhanced investment incentives. Companies in the region are already reaping the benefits of Malaysia's abundant land, lower costs, and prime location for manufacturing, warehousing, and logistics. With the signing of the landmark pact, MNCs are expected to capitalize on these opportunities, fueling greater efficiency and scalability in the region.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, right, speaks during a press conference with Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the prime minister's office in Putrajaya, Malaysia, Tuesday, Jan. 7, 2025. Vincent Thian/Pool via REUTERS
The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (right) will host Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) for the 11th Singapore-Malaysia Leaders' Retreat in Putrajaya.

site_title: Indonesia’s move to join Brics signals  Prabowo’s global ambitions – but risks loom
summary: Indonesia has joined the Brics alliance, a grouping of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, as a full member. The move is seen as a strategic bid by President Prabowo Subianto to boost foreign investments and strengthen Indonesia's geopolitical flexibility. However, observers warn of increased geopolitical and trade risks, including potential tariff hikes imposed by the US under a new administration. The inclusion is expected to unlock new markets, particularly for Indonesia's natural resources, and provide access to China's economic stimulus policies and infrastructure development under the Belt and Road Initiative.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesia had previously expressed its desire to join the group as a means of strengthening emerging countries and furthering the interests of the so-called Global South.

site_title: Top 10 trends for 2025
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The global economy is expected to be shaped by various trends in 2025, including a potential return of contrarian investing, a crash in momentum investing, and a decrease in US exceptionalism. The US economy is expected to slow down due to high deficits and diminishing fiscal stimulus, leading to a decrease in interest rates and potential recession. Meanwhile, emerging markets such as China, India, and others are expected to rise, driven by disciplined government spending and resilient consumer spending. The article also highlights the potential for AI to undercut big tech companies and trade without the US.

images.alt_text: A container ship being loaded at the port in Lianyungang, China. The country's export price index may slump as far as 10% in some months in 2025, which would deliver a big competitive shock to companies that compete with Chinese rivals.

site_title: Tesla supplier Panasonic Energy: cutting China supply ‘No.1 objective’ for US
summary: Panasonic Energy, a unit of Japanese electronics giant Panasonic, plans to eliminate its China-based supply chain for US-made electric vehicle batteries due to rising US tariffs on Chinese goods. The shift, a "No.1 objective," is aimed at reducing dependence on China and diversifying its manufacturing processes. Panasonic Energy operates US plants in Nevada and plans to open a second factory in Kansas this year. The move is a response to President Donald Trump's pledge to raise tariffs on Chinese imports, forcing companies to reassess their global supply chains.

site_title: Samsung CEO touts AI fridges and washers after year to forget
summary: Samsung Electronics is ramping up its investment in artificial intelligence (AI) for consumer electronics, with a focus on home appliances such as fridges and washers, under CEO Han Jong-Hee's leadership. The company aims to utilize its unique market position to compete in the AI arena, having previously experienced setbacks in areas like top-end memory and generative AI.

images.alt_text: Samsung is getting substantially less than originally expected.
The appeal hearings, which wrap up on Monday, come as Lee Jae-yong faces growing questions about his ability to lead Samsung, as it grapples with slowing profits and falling stock prices.

site_title: Toyota invests in Japanese rocket startup as SpaceX races ahead
summary: Toyota is investing 7 billion yen (S$60 million) in Japanese rocket startup Interstellar Technologies, with the aim of mass-producing lightweight rockets and competing with major players like SpaceX. This investment is part of Toyota's broader effort to innovate in transportation and leverage automotive industry expertise to transition rocket manufacturing into a high-quality, cost-effective process. The deal is seen as a significant step for Japan's private space sector, which aims to launch 30 times annually by the mid-2030s, but faces a challenge of keeping up with the fast-paced and competitive field dominated by giants like SpaceX.

images.alt_text: The initial residents of Woven City will be composed mostly of the carmaker’s own employees and their families.
Toyota’s domestic sales have fallen more than 20 per cent between January and October, while production fell 13 per cent.
Toyota’s strategy is in contrast to that of other global automakers, including Japanese ones, that are either scaling back or pulling out of China.

site_title: Appetite for Bitcoin in Singapore and beyond surges after 2024’s launch of such ETFs, US election
summary: Bitcoin's popularity surged in Singapore and beyond in 2024, driven by the introduction of US Bitcoin ETFs and the US presidential election. Trading volumes increased, with brokerages and exchange platforms reporting spikes in Bitcoin ETFs and direct investments. By the end of 2024, Bitcoin's assets under custody in Singapore's ETFs grew to nearly 3% of overall assets, with interest evident across all age groups. Market watchers expect Bitcoin to continue gaining popularity among individual and institutional investors, with some predicting prices could reach US$200,000 under President Trump's presidency.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Chloe Lim
BT’s checks show at least some of these ETFs are available via the following brokerages: Citibank, FSMOne, Phillip Securities and Syfe.
The world’s largest and most well-known cryptocurrency hit US$100,000 earlier this month.

site_title: Gold steady as market awaits more US data
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,636.05 per ounce on Tuesday, awaiting US economic data for cues on the Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory. Investors are watching the US jobs report on Friday, job openings data, ADP employment numbers, and minutes from the Fed's December meeting. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield hit its highest since May 2024, while the US dollar fell amid uncertainty about President-elect Donald Trump's tariff plans. Economists suggest Trump's plans may not be as inflationary as initially thought, but a potential Fed rate cut could re-ignite price pressures.

images.alt_text: Gold flourishes in a low-interest-rate environment and serves as a hedge against geopolitical uncertainties and inflation.

site_title: Rolex, Patek used watch prices fall to three-year low in 2024
summary: Luxury watch prices for pre-owned models from Rolex, Patek Philippe, and Audemars Piguet fell 6% in 2024, marking a three-year low. The Bloomberg Subdial Watch Index, which tracks prices for the 50 most traded models, declined 5.5% for Rolex, 4% for Patek, and 7.5% for Audemars Piguet. The market for pre-owned luxury timepieces has experienced a sharp pullback since 2022, with prices down 13% over two years. Cartier is the only brand to post gains, with its index rising 4% over the same period.

images.alt_text: Rolex Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong eases investment thresholds to attract family offices
summary: Hong Kong has eased the investment thresholds for its capital investment entrant scheme, aiming to attract family offices and boost its status as a global wealth hub. The revised scheme allows investments made by eligible private companies and family-owned vehicles to count towards the program, starting March 1. The city expects over HK$24 billion in investments, which could help its economic rebound. This move follows previous adjustments, including the addition of single residential properties of HK$50 million and above, and aims to attract more super-rich individuals, with the goal of having 200 large family offices set up by this year.

images.alt_text: Singapore, by contrast, requires minimum investment amounts and greater disclosures as it steps up scrutiny of family offices following a huge money laundering scandal.
The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.
Details on the roll-out of MAS' new framework for Singapore’s SFOs are likely to be announced in due course.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Straits Trading
summary: The Straits Trading Company has launched a three-month commercial paper in digital securities on Singapore's Digital Assets Exchange, raising between S$5 million and S$10 million. The issuance is expected to determine the final amount after considering demand from investors. Shares of Straits Trading ended flat at S$1.44 on Monday.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

site_title: TikTok ban thrusts Apple, Google into US-China geopolitical fray
summary: US President Joe Biden signed a law addressing national security concerns related to TikTok, potentially leading to the app's shutdown in the US. To avoid the ban, many US users are seeking workarounds, such as changing their smartphone settings, using VPNs, or sideloading the app. The move has thrust Apple and Google into the US-China geopolitical fray, with billions in fines at risk if they fail to enforce the ban.

images.alt_text: tiktok Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg
The app has been accused of putting users in danger with the spread of hazardous challenge videos.
TikTok’s owners have sought to have the law struck down, and the US Supreme Court has agreed to hear the case.

site_title: Toyota aims to open its futuristic city in Japan this year
summary: Toyota plans to open its futuristic city, Woven City, in Japan by this fall with 100 initial residents, mostly its own employees and their families. The city aims to accelerate technology development and testing. Toyota chairman Akio Toyoda stated that the city will gradually expand to about 2,000 residents, with the goal of bringing Woven City to life. The city is located at the base of Mount Fuji.

images.alt_text: The new ComfortDelGro Toyota Alphard Hybrid models will feature LED taxi signs behind the windscreen instead of traditional rooftop-toppers.
Toyota’s domestic sales have fallen more than 20 per cent between January and October, while production fell 13 per cent.
Toyota’s strategy is in contrast to that of other global automakers, including Japanese ones, that are either scaling back or pulling out of China.

site_title: Trump keeps world guessing over how he intends to impose tariffs
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has denied plans to scale back sweeping tariffs, sparking uncertainty about his economic policy. Despite reports suggesting limited tariffs on critical imports, Trump claimed the story was "incorrect" and reaffirmed his commitment to tariffs as a way to raise revenue and boost American manufacturing. Trump's tariff plans could face legal challenges and criticism from free-trade advocates, who worry about potential inflation and economic growth consequences.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Kamala Harris hits the gavel after reading the vote totals as Speaker of the House Mike Johnson looks on during of a joint session of Congress to certify the results of the 2024 Presidential election, Washington, DC, Jan 6, 2025.

Musk’s potential to have extraordinary clout with the Trump administration raises questions about the fate of federal investigations and regulatory actions affecting his business empire, of which at least 20 are ongoing.

The Dow was up almost 200 points in morning trading before the Federal Reserve holds its meeting today on interest rates.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Former PSA chairman and veteran banker Fock Siew Wah dies, aged 84
summary: Former PSA International chairman Fock Siew Wah, a veteran banker, died on January 6 at the age of 84. He led PSA for over 13 years, growing its global footprint, and played a key role in transport boards. Fock started his career at 19 as a junior clerk at OCBC Bank and later led regional investment banking operations at JPMorgan. His passing was mourned by Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who described him as "deeply saddened" to hear of his death.

images.alt_text: Saudi Global Ports was formed in 2012 and operates container terminals in King Abdulaziz Port on the country’s east coast.
The PSA Supply Chain Hub @ Tuas will also be able to handle sensitive goods and improve Tuas Port's competitiveness.
PSA International said the acquisition will allow it to enhance existing hinterland connections from its container terminal in Poland.

site_title: SingPost issued government advisory to uphold governance after whistle-blowing report
summary: Singapore Post (SingPost) has received a government advisory to uphold proper corporate governance and processes after a whistle-blowing incident alleging falsification of international e-commerce shipment data. Senior Minister of State for Digital Development and Information Tan Kiat How assured that domestic postal services are not affected, with SingPost performing within the quality of service standard in the last four years. The government is monitoring the situation closely, particularly with the recent firings of senior executives and the new group CEO's appointment.

A postman delivering letters at Block 721 Tampines St 72 on Feb 16, 2023. Can be used for stories on post, postal, mail, SingPost, letter, manpower and communication.

David Gerald, founder, president and chief executive of Sias, says that shareholders deserve better and so does the market.

The senior management staff stressed that the full facts only became known after the external forensics team’s investigations established the causative correlation.
The competition among e-commerce platforms might have driven SingPost employees to bypass internal controls in order to avoid being penalised.
Two phases of the investigation are outlined in SingPost’s response to stakeholders.
Yu Li says he will enforce his legal rights and vindicate his reputation.

SingPost’s board of directors is helmed by chairman Simon Israel, whom SingPost has said will provide increased guidance to and exercise greater oversight of the senior management leadership team in the interim.

The Securities Investors Association (Singapore), or Sias, noted that the company’s 2024 annual report – published in the last week of June this year – did not specifically mention any whistleblowing report.

site_title: South Korea investigators seek new warrant to arrest President Yoon
summary: South Korean investigators are seeking a new warrant to arrest impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol, who has refused to answer questions about his failed martial law decree. The former star prosecutor has been holed up in his residence surrounded by hundreds of guards, and it's likely a new warrant will be granted by the same court that issued the first order. Yoon faces charges of "insurrection" and could face prison or the death penalty if arrested and convicted. A trial is set to begin on January 14, and investigators are confident the court will grant the new warrant, with the deputy director stating the likelihood of denial is "very low".

images.alt_text: An effigy of impeached South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol is seen behind bars during a rally against Yoon near his residence in Seoul on January 5, 2025. Thousands of South Korean protesters braved a snowstorm January 5 over suspended President Yoon Suk Yeol who was still resisting arrest over a failed martial law bid less than 48 hours before the warrant expires. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)
Global funds were net buyers of government bonds in December, and the cost to insure Korea’s debt against default hit only a four-month high.
An effigy of impeached South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol is seen during a rally against Yoon near his residence in Seoul, South Korea, Jan 5, 2025.

An effigy of suspended President Yoon Suk-yeol during a protest against him; Yoon plunged the country into political chaos on Dec 3 with the bungled martial law declaration and has since holed up in his residence, surrounded by hundreds of security officers resisting arrest efforts.
If the warrant is carried out, Yoon would become the first sitting South Korean president to be arrested.

site_title: Bridgewater cuts 7% of staff in effort to remain ‘nimble’
summary: Bridgewater Associates, the world's largest hedge fund, cut 7% of its workforce, affecting approximately 90 employees, as part of its effort to remain "nimble" and maintain flexibility to hire top talent. The firm, which posted double-digit returns for most of its strategies last year, aims to achieve its objectives through a more dynamic ecosystem of ideas and innovation. Bridgewater's leadership team ensures its strategy and resources are aligned, and the firm will continue to hire selectively. This move follows similar layoffs by Two Sigma Investments and Brevan Howard Asset Management.

site_title: McDonald’s rolls back some diversity practices in head office
summary: McDonald's has rolled back some diversity practices in its head office, citing a "shifting legal landscape" in the US. The company will no longer aim to reach 35% of its US leaders from underrepresented groups by 2025 and will end its requirement for suppliers to make a diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) commitment. McDonald's will also pause participation in external surveys measuring workplace inclusion. The move comes amid pressure from conservative activists, including Robby Starbuck, who has targeted several companies with similar DEI initiatives.

images.alt_text: The writer expects more companies to announce returns to the office, even as the majority quietly shrink their office footprints or continue to embrace hybrid arrangements.

site_title: Slow payments among Singapore firms rise for first time in 6 quarters: credit bureau
summary: Singapore firms saw a slight increase in slow payments for the first time in six quarters, rising to 44.05% in Q4 2024, from 44% in Q3. The services sector led the increase, while prompt payments slid 0.05 percentage point to 41.15%. Despite this, local companies are still in a relatively better state compared to the previous year. The manufacturing sector saw a decline in slow payments, while the construction and retail sectors experienced increases. Overall, the annual average proportion of slow payments decreased to 44.06%, while prompt payments rose to 41.13%.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Slow payments inch down 0.07 percentage point to 41.2 per cent in Q3, from 41.4 per cent in Q2.

site_title: ‘Comeback’ queen Demi Moore ‘has always been here’, says director
summary: Demi Moore, 62, has seen her Oscar chances rise after winning the Golden Globe for her role in "The Substance", a blood-drenched body horror film. Director Coralie Fargeat says Moore has "always been here" and was unfairly dismissed as a "popcorn actress" in her early career. Moore's Golden Globe win has transformed her into a seemingly unlikely Oscar favourite, with some now betting against her to win the award. Moore, known for her hit films and high-profile love life, has said she has never won anything as an actor, highlighting her late-career reappraisal.

images.alt_text: (From left) Mexican actress Adriana Paz, Venezuelan actor Edgar Ramirez, US singer and actress Selena Gomez, French director Jacques Audiard, Spanish actress Karla Sofia Gascon and US actress Zoe Saldana pose with the Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy award for "Emilia Perez" in Beverly Hills, California, Jan 5, 2025.
Season 2 is set to compete for best TV series at the upcoming Golden Globes.

site_title: Google to bring Gemini AI to TV sets running its software
summary: Google is bringing its Gemini AI to third-party TV sets running its Google TV operating system, marking the first time the company has expanded Gemini to non-Google devices. The update, set to roll out later this year, will enable users to hold natural voice commands and access content more easily, without needing to use the "Hey Google" trigger phrase. The upgrade will also improve content search and deepen YouTube integration, allowing users to call up specific content, such as videos saved to Google Photos.

site_title: The unravelling of Hin Leong and OK Lim’s fall from grace
summary: Singapore's oil trading giant Hin Leong Trading collapsed due to a web of fraud, forgery, and financial mismanagement. Founder Lim Oon Kuin, also known as OK Lim, was declared bankrupt and jailed for 17 years and 6 months after being found guilty of various crimes. The company's downfall exposed a culture of corruption and poor management, leading to significant losses and damage to the industry's reputation. The incident serves as a cautionary tale for the importance of corporate governance and ethics in Singapore's business sector.

site_title: Singapore shares in the black on Tuesday; STI rises 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,828.17 points, driven by a lean into the Nikkei's 2% gain. Other regional markets were mixed, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 1.2% and South Korea's Kospi index up 0.1%. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose, with analysts predicting earnings growth in 2025. The STI's top gainer was Seatrium, while CapitaLand Investment fell 2.3%.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Therese Soh
Straits Trading Company launches three-month commercial paper in digital securities on Singapore's Digital Assets Exchange.

site_title: AMD adds Dell as commercial PC customer for the first time
summary: AMD has secured a deal with Dell to use its chips in business PCs for the first time, marking a significant blow to Intel's dominance in the market. AMD's new processors are designed to provide the best performance for artificial intelligence (AI) software, and Dell plans to use them in some of its computers aimed at business customers. This partnership is seen as a major win for AMD and a challenge to Intel's eroding market share, with the chipmakers and manufacturers believing the revival of the PC market is driven by the ability of machines to run more tasks with AI.

images.alt_text: PC sales have been anaemic for years following a buying frenzy towards the beginning of the pandemic.

site_title: Qualcomm’s new chips will bring AI to US$600 personal computers
summary: Qualcomm has introduced new chips designed to power personal computers (PCs) capable of running AI software at a cost of $600. The Snapdragon X Platform consists of an 8-core processor, graphics component, and dedicated AI chip, which will run Microsoft's Copilot+ software. PC makers like Dell and Lenovo will offer laptops based on the new product in early 2025. Qualcomm aims to expand its presence in the PC market, reducing its reliance on smartphone chips, and touting its chips as more energy-efficient and offering extended battery life.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm is one of Arm’s biggest customers and a long-time partner, but the companies have grown increasingly at odds.
Apple has spent years trying to replace the Qualcomm modem chip in its iPhones.
Qualcomm has been looking ahead to new markets to generate an additional US$22 billion in annual revenue by fiscal 2029.

site_title: Oil prices ease as weak economic data offsets higher US winter storm heating demand
summary: Oil prices eased on Monday, January 6, as weak economic data offset higher US winter storm heating demand. Brent futures fell 21 US cents, or 0.3%, to settle at US$76.30 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 40 US cents, or 0.5%, to settle at US$73.56. Despite declines, both benchmarks remained in overbought territory. The easing in prices was attributed to bearish economic news from the US and Germany, offsetting bullish support from a weaker US dollar.

images.alt_text: The outlook for 2025 remains uncertain, however, with expectations for oversupply, the possible revival of idled Opec+ production and lacklustre demand from top importer China. The return of Donald Trump to the White House later this month also adds unpredictability for global markets.

site_title: Ex-New York mayor Giuliani held in contempt of court in defamation case
summary: US District Judge Lewis Liman held former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani in contempt of court for failing to reveal assets to two Georgia election workers he defamed. Giuliani was ordered to pay nearly $148 million to Ruby Freeman and Wandrea Moss for making false claims of election fraud. The judge criticized Giuliani for attempting to "run out the clock" and did not specify potential sanctions. Giuliani has been disbarred over his false election claims and has been ordered to surrender assets, including a $6 million apartment and a 1980 Mercedes Benz convertible.

images.alt_text: Rudy Giuliani was photographed on Tuesday in the luxury car outside of a Palm Beach, Florida polling station.
Donald Trump's unique role as president makes it unlikely that he will face legal consequences in criminal cases brought against him, at least while he is in office.

US Vice-President Kamala Harris hits the gavel after reading the vote totals as Speaker of the House Mike Johnson looks on during of a joint session of Congress to certify the results of the 2024 Presidential election, Washington, DC, Jan 6, 2025.

site_title: Are the days of Singapore’s en bloc fever over?
summary: Singapore's en bloc fever appears to be over, with a dismal success rate of 25% in 2024, compared to 33% in 2023 and 36% in 2022. The market saw only four completed collective sales out of 16 properties put on the market, with the largest transaction being the sale of Concorde Hotel and Shopping Mall for S$821 million. Market watchers attribute the decline to high price expectations, increased development costs, and cooling measures. However, commercial and mixed-use developments may offer opportunities for investors and developers, and the government's GLS programme may divert attention away from the en bloc market.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

The method of distributing sales proceeds is often a contentious issue, particularly for mixed-use developments where expectations on the acceptable range of en-bloc premiums and what constitutes a ‘fair and equitable’ method of apportionment may differ.

Total investment sales in Q3 amounted to S$8.3 billion, up 24.8% from the previous quarter, says Knight Frank Singapore.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after report of selective Trump tariffs; chip stocks gain
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by optimism over AI and a report suggesting a less aggressive stance on tariffs from the incoming Trump administration. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 103.4 points, or 0.24%, to 42,835.52, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, reaching fresh records. Chip stocks surged, benefiting from the AI boost. The news lifted investor sentiment and helped to push stocks higher despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US adds Tencent, CATL to list of ‘Chinese military companies’
summary: The US Department of Defence has added tech giant Tencent and battery manufacturer CATL to a list of Chinese military companies operating in the US, citing affiliations with Beijing's military. The move comes as the US seeks to curb China's growing influence in the tech sector. Tencent operates the popular WeChat "super-app" and other gaming, content streaming, and cloud services, while CATL is a leading battery manufacturer. The list, to be published on the US Federal Register, is part of the US government's efforts to regulate Chinese companies with ties to the military.

site_title: Dell unveils Apple-like rebrand in bid to make PCs cool again
summary: Dell is rebranding its PCs with a simplified naming convention, similar to Apple, in an effort to boost sales. The company will discontinue product names like "XPS" and "Inspiron" and replace them with three tiers: Dell, Dell Pro, and Dell Pro Max. The move aims to make Dell's products easier to remember and easier to upgrade. PC sales have been sluggish due to a buying frenzy during the pandemic, and Dell hopes the new branding will encourage customers to upgrade to AI-optimized systems.

images.alt_text: Dell fell 13 per cent in trading before the bell, with the company set to shed nearly US$13 billion from its US$99.50 billion market value, after it forecast quarterly revenue below estimates.
Dell is best known for its computer business but the company has enjoyed a renaissance of investor interest due to its high-powered servers for AI workloads.

site_title: Indonesia joins Brics bloc as full member, Brazil says
summary: Indonesia has been accepted as a full member of the Brics bloc, a group of major emerging economies, following a consensus decision by member states. Brazil, which holds the bloc's presidency in 2025, said Indonesia's entry was approved as part of an expansion push initiated in 2023. The move is seen as a strategic way for Indonesia to strengthen its ties with other developing nations and further the interests of the Global South. Indonesia's membership will bring the group to 11 members, including Russia, India, China, South Africa, and several other countries.

images.alt_text: Malaysia has applied to be part of the bloc, which aims to challenge a world order dominated by Western economies, but has not yet been officially accepted as a member.
The infrastructure that backs the US dollar, such as the cross-border payment system, will likely give the US currency a decisive edge for decades to come.
Russia's President Vladimir Putin speaks during the BRICS summit in Kazan on October 24, 2024. (Photo by Alexander NEMENOV / AFP)

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Economic growth and market projections for 2025
summary: The US economy is expected to continue its robust performance in 2025, with strong private domestic final purchases, low unemployment rates, and manageable inflation. This could lead to potential upside for the S&P 500, with investors advised to differentiate between fears and realities. Meanwhile, the Singapore market, driven by the three major banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB, is expected to benefit from shifts in global production and investment flows amid US-China tensions and the Fed's rate policies.

site_title: The postman’s impossible position
summary: State-backed postal services are struggling, with Japan Post Co and the UK's Royal Mail experiencing financial losses. The US Postal Service, which has lost over $100 billion since 2007, may be privatized by President-elect Donald Trump. Singapore Post, like many commercial mail services, faces challenges from rival firms and shareholder demands for better returns. The article suggests that the need for a national postal service is dwindling, as digital communication methods have reduced the demand for physical mail.

site_title: Philippines vows to stay vigilant on prices even as target hit
summary: The Philippines' inflation rate returned to its target of 2-4% in 2024, with a 2.9% increase in December, following two years of missing the target. Despite this, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) vows to remain vigilant due to upside risks, including geopolitical tensions and adverse weather. The BSP has cut interest rates by 75 basis points in 2024, and will continue to monitor prices closely, with the possibility of further rate cuts at its next policy meeting.

images.alt_text: Philippines Photographer: Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg

site_title: Manhattan drivers face US$9 fee in first such US effort to fight gridlock
summary: New York City has implemented the first US congestion fee, charging US$9 for passenger vehicles in Manhattan south of 60th Street, with trucks and buses paying up to US$21.60. The fee, which went into effect on Sunday, aims to raise US$500 million for mass transit improvements. The charge, which will be paid via electronic license plate readers, is expected to reduce traffic by 11% and 80,000 cars per day. The fee is expected to be unpopular initially, but similar schemes in London and other cities have seen traffic and transit benefits over time.

images.alt_text: Cars drive under E-ZPass readers and license plate-scanning cameras on Columbus Circle as congestion pricing takes effect in New York City on January 5, 2024. site_title: US records its first human death from bird flu
summary: The US has reported its first human death from bird flu, a 65-year-old patient with underlying medical conditions who was hospitalized for a respiratory ailment. The patient contracted H5N1 after exposure to backyard and wild birds. Despite the death, the public health risk remains low, with no human-to-human transmission detected. Genetic sequencing revealed the virus was different from those in dairy herds and poultry farms. Experts warn that a high circulation of the virus in mammals could lead to mutations making it more easily spread among humans.

images.alt_text: The USDA currently only requires testing of lactating dairy cattle moving across state lines, a requirement laid out in its only other federal bird flu order issued in April.
As bad as the Biden administration has been on pandemic prevention, of course, it's about to be replaced by something far worse.
H5N1 first emerged in 1996 but since 2020, the number of outbreaks in birds has grown exponentially, alongside an increase in the number of infected mammals.

site_title: Opec output dips in December as UAE improves delivery of cuts
summary: OPEC's crude production dipped 120,000 barrels a day to 27.05 million barrels a day in December, primarily due to the UAE's increased implementation of supply cuts. The UAE's output remains above its agreed limit, with the country slashing oil exports to an 18-month low. Despite the reduction, oil prices have reached a three-month high above $77 a barrel, but analysts predict a surplus due to slowing consumption growth in China and abundant US output.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell 21 US cents, or 0.3 per cent, to settle at US$76.30 a barrel.

site_title: China’s Xi cites corruption as ‘biggest threat’ to ruling Communist Party
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has declared corruption the biggest threat to the ruling Communist Party, citing a rise in corruption cases despite previous efforts to tackle the issue. A record 58 "tigers" - senior officials - were probed last year, including high-profile cases involving top officials and former high-ranking officials. Xi has vowed to continue the crackdown, but concerns remain about the effectiveness of the anti-corruption efforts, with some suggesting that corrupt officials are being promoted to replace those who have been purged.

images.alt_text: China said on Nov 28, 2024 that top military official Miao Hua (front) had been removed from office and was suspected of "serious violations of discipline".
China’s President Xi Jinping reiterated a call to adopt more proactive macroeconomic policies to aid the economy’s continued recovery.
China’s top policymakers have adopted a more pro-growth policy stance for next year, including pledges to use fiscal tools, as a new Trump presidency could lead to more US tariffs.

site_title: GE Vernova to invest US$20 million in expanding gas turbine repair centre in Singapore
summary: GE Vernova plans to invest US$20 million in its Singapore gas turbine repair centre, expanding its capabilities to include robotics and artificial intelligence. The investment is part of a larger US$60 million commitment made in 2019. Amid global pressure to decarbonize the power sector, GE Vernova sees gas playing a key role over the next decade, particularly in Asia, where its high-efficiency gas turbines are in high demand. The company aims to hit US$35 billion in global revenue this year and US$45 billion by 2028.

Dr Tan See Leng, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry, speaks at the ceremony.
Siemens Energy's third-quarter sales rose 18.5 per cent to 8.8 billion euros, beating the analyst consensus of 8.6 billion euros
Analysts see light at the end of the tunnel as the company leaves the spectre of large write-downs and lawsuits behind.

site_title: Europe: Shares rev up as auto sector jumps on report of softer US tariffs
summary: European markets closed higher on Monday, driven by optimism over potential softer US tariffs on the auto sector. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.9%, its highest level in over two weeks, with the auto sector surging nearly 3%. Luxury brands also benefited, with LVMH, Hermes, and Kering rising between 2.4% and 4.5%. However, US President-elect Donald Trump later denied the report, and the market's reaction may be short-lived.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.5 per cent lower in light trade after the New Year holidays.

site_title: The Maga’s crack-up over immigration
summary: The Make America Great Again (Maga) movement is experiencing internal divisions, contradicting its initial perception as a united front. The base of Donald Trump's electoral victory, which was partly driven by opposition to immigration, appears to be comprised mainly of white and Christian Americans, with little concern for the cultural erosion caused by non-white immigrants. This disparity suggests that the movement's core values may not be as cohesive as initially thought.

site_title: LG CNS begins taking orders for Korea’s biggest IPO since 2022
summary: LG CNS, South Korea's largest tech services provider, is set to raise up to $816 million in its initial public offering (IPO), the country's largest since 2022. The company, which offers cloud and warehouse management services, is accepting bids until January 15. LG CNS plans to use the proceeds for facility upgrades, mergers and acquisitions, and bond repayments. The IPO, led by Macquarie Korea Asset Management, will test appetite for Korean stocks after a sudden political maneuver last year. The deal is expected to price on January 17 and list on February 4.

images.alt_text: Global funds were net buyers of government bonds in December, and the cost to insure Korea’s debt against default hit only a four-month high.

site_title: Investment lessons to get a sound footing in 2025
summary: Investors can prepare their portfolios for future downturns by adopting five key strategies. Firstly, diversification is crucial to avoid concentration risk, and holding onto investments until they recover can be costly. Second, beware of "sure things" that have already baked in exuberance, and instead focus on value. Third, fees can significantly impact wealth, with a 1% difference adding up over time. Fourth, timing the market does not work in the long run, and investors should focus on long-term strategies. Lastly, developing an investment strategy tailored to individual life goals and circumstances is essential for achieving success.

site_title: US lawmakers certify Trump win, four years after Capitol riot
summary: US lawmakers certified President-elect Donald Trump's election victory on January 6, 2025, four years after a violent Capitol riot. The ceremony was a stark contrast to the 2021 event, where Trump's supporters stormed the Capitol. Trump, 78, spent his campaign facing prosecution over the insurrection, but was voted back into office in November. The certification process was marked by a major winter storm, but no objections were raised. The event marked the final blow to efforts to have Trump face justice over the riot, with prosecutors dropping all charges upon his election.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - (L-R) US Vice President Kamala Harris hits the gavel after reading the vote totals as Speaker of the House Mike Johnson looks on during of a joint session of Congress to certify the results of the 2024 Presidential election, inside the House Chamber at the US Capitol on January 6, 2025, in Washington, DC. Exactly four years after Donald Trump's supporters stormed the US Capitol, seeking to overturn his election loss, lawmakers meet today to certify his 2024 Presidential win, cementing the Republican's comeback from political ignominy. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)

Keir Starmer has insisted that the UK-US special relationship will "prosper" under Donald Trump but the British prime minister's Labour government has multiple reasons to fear the Republican's presidential comeback. Possible trade wars, Labour ministers' unflattering comments about Trump, and any role for Starmer critic Elon Musk in Trump's administration, would make for a bumpy ride between the allies. Starmer made a first move late on November 6, 2024, phoning Trump to offer his congratulations to the US president-elect as senior government figures played down earlier outspoken comments by Labour politicians. (Photo by Elijah Nouvelage and Nicolas TUCAT / AFP)

site_title: US Steel, Nippon Steel sue Biden administration over decision to block merger
summary: US Steel and Nippon Steel have filed a lawsuit against the Biden administration, alleging that President Biden's decision to block their $14.9 billion merger was unconstitutional and unfairly influenced by politics. The companies claim that Biden prejudiced the review process of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US, violating their right to a fair review. They seek a federal court to scrap the decision and allow for a fresh national security review.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said the decision to block the US steel deal had sparked worries over future Japanese investments in the US.

site_title: Indonesia posts 2.3% budget deficit in 2024, lower than expected
summary: Indonesia recorded a 2.3% fiscal deficit in 2024, lower than expected, but analysts warn that the country's debt burdens, spending plans, and global uncertainties pose long-term fiscal health risks. The government had initially projected a 2.7% deficit, but tax revenue grew modestly, and the government will keep the deficit below 3%. Despite this, analysts predict slower economic growth and a potential tax revenue shortfall, which could widen the fiscal deficit. The government plans to continue optimizing spending and reallocate funds to priority areas, but its ambitious spending plans have raised concerns about long-term fiscal sustainability.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesia's central bank, led by Governor Perry Warjiyo, has targeted inflation in 2024 and 2025 to be within a range of 1.5 per cent to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: After year of big corruption crackdown, China promises more probes, retribution
summary: China has vowed to continue its anti-corruption crackdown, promising more probes and retribution after a year of high-profile cases. The country aired a program on fighting corruption, focusing on petty cases, amid a surge of probes last year that ensnared high-ranking officials. The move aims to reassure the public and bolster Xi Jinping's leadership, as China grapples with economic struggles and a fading sense of wealth.

images.alt_text: China’s economy has struggled over the past few years, weighed down by weak consumption and investment, and a severe property crisis.

A safety driver monitors a Lexus vehicle equipped with Pony.ai's autonomous driving system as the car drives on a road during a test event, Beijing, China, May 13, 2021. Pony.ai plans to provide robotaxi commuting services for airport staff within Hong Kong International Airport before expanding into other urban areas in the city, the company said on Friday.
China is the world’s biggest crude importer and the teapots are a cornerstone of a market that has driven gains in global oil demand for over a decade.
While the yuan has weakened against the US dollar, it climbed to the highest since 2022 versus trading partners’ exchange rates as a result of Beijing’s control.

The statement by the central bank reiterates plans to cut interest rates and the reserve requirement ratio, which dictates how much banks must hold in their coffers, rather than lending or investing.

site_title: ‘Timepass’ is India’s way of lying flat
summary: India's young, educated population is adopting a "timepass" lifestyle, characterized by filling up one's day with unimportant activities to pass the hours. This phenomenon is similar to China's "lying flat" movement, where young people opt out of the economic race and settle for mediocre success. The unemployment rate among young college graduates in India is 29%, with 34% for female graduates. As technology advances, Indians are spending more time on mobile devices, with a fifth devoted to watching short-form videos. This has led to a surge in online gratuity and the commercialization of timepass, with the state actively encouraging the creator economy.

images.alt_text: People on the rocks along the Bandstand Promenade in the suburb of Bandra in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Jan. 3, 2025. India’s new central bank governor said the economy will probably rebound next year on the back of strong consumer and business confidence, his first public comments about the growth outlook since he took office earlier this month. China is under instruction to unleash “new productive forces”, with government policies targeting narrow areas of science and technology including AI and robotics.

China’s youth are seen as key to growth in the country’s huge consumer market.
Pacifying this generation amid some of the slowest economic growth in nearly half a century presents a key policymaking challenge for Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Straits Trading Company expects to raise up to S$10 million through digital commercial paper
summary: Straits Trading Company launched a digital commercial paper issuance on Singapore's Digital Assets Exchange (SDAX), aiming to raise up to S$10 million. The three-month commercial paper will mature in approximately three months and be offered at an interest rate of 3.7% per annum. This is part of the company's S$55 million multicurrency debt issuance programme, following a successful first issuance in October 2024.

Eric Teng, chief executive officer at Straits Developments, envisioned the Straits City development to transform Butterworth from an industrial area into a vibrant, sustainable urban community.

site_title: At Las Vegas show, tech world turns to mental health tools
summary: The tech industry is presenting new mental health tools at CES in Las Vegas, with startups showcasing solutions to detect and manage anxiety and panic attacks. Swiss firm Nutrix is introducing cortiSense, a device that measures cortisol levels in saliva, allowing users to analyze their stress hormone levels in minutes via a mobile app. Other startups are also pitching their solutions, offering a range of tools to support mental health.

images.alt_text: Buyers at Canton Fair in Guangzhou on Oct 19.

site_title:
Eurozone economy ended 2024 
in precarious state, PMI shows
summary: The eurozone economy ended 2024 in a fragile state, with its economy contracting for a second straight month in December. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 49.6, above the breakeven point of 50, driven by a modest recovery in the services sector but weighed down by a steep fall in factory activity. Despite this, economists expect the European Central Bank to cut interest rates further in 2025 due to ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: Chinese exchanges ask big fund managers to restrict stock selling: sources
summary: Chinese stock exchanges have asked large mutual funds to restrict stock selling at the start of 2025 amid concerns over US President Donald Trump's potential tariffs on Chinese goods, which are putting pressure on China's already sluggish economy. The guidance was issued as Chinese stocks began the year with deep losses. At least four large mutual funds received calls from the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges to buy more stocks than they sold each day.

site_title: Indonesia launches ambitious free-meal programme to combat stunting
summary: Indonesia has launched a US$4.3 billion free-meal programme aimed at combating stunted growth due to malnutrition. The programme, a key election promise of President Prabowo Subianto, will provide nutritious meals free to tens of millions of schoolchildren and pregnant women, improving their quality of life and boosting economic growth. This is Indonesia's first nationwide nutrition programme for toddlers, students, pregnant, and breastfeeding mothers.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank, led by Governor Perry Warjiyo, has targeted inflation in 2024 and 2025 to be within a range of 1.5 per cent to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: Pace of SGX delistings may not slow down in 2025: analysts
summary: SGX saw 20 delistings in 2024, with only four new entrants, attributed to low market liquidity, increasing regulatory scrutiny, and growing private funding appeal. Industry analysts expect the trend to continue in 2025, despite potential catalysts such as strong global market performance and a local equities market revamp. This is the second consecutive year of high delistings, with 25 privatisations in 2023 and six new IPOs.

site_title: Japan PM says blocked US Steel deal could hit investments
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba expressed concerns over future Japanese investments in the US after the US blocked Nippon Steel's $14.9 billion takeover of US Steel, citing national security concerns. Ishiba urged the US government to clarify its reasons for the decision, which sparked worries among Japan's industrial world. The move has also drawn criticism from both companies and Tokyo, with the US Chamber of Commerce warning of a chilling effect on international investment in America.

images.alt_text: Nippon Steel may file a lawsuit against the US government challenging the procedures behind the decision, Japan’s Nikkei business daily reported on Saturday.

summary: Singapore is set to connect the Downtown Line and North-South Lines with a new interchange in 2035, featuring three new MRT stations. OCBC Investment Research suggests healthcare S-Reits for portfolio diversification amid slower rate cuts. River Valley Apartments are up for sale at S$56 million. Indonesia maintained a 2.3% budget deficit in 2024, while Singapore shares closed 0.5% higher on Monday despite regional declines.

site_title: Nippon Steel could face growth challenges after US Steel purchase blocked: analysts
summary: Nippon Steel may face growth challenges after US President Joe Biden blocked its proposed $14.9 billion acquisition of US Steel, citing national security concerns. Despite the setback, analysts expect Nippon Steel's share price to bounce back in the near-term, citing the removal of financing uncertainty. site_title: River Valley Apartments up for sale at S$56 million
summary: River Valley Apartments, a four-storey development with 24 units, is up for collective sale at S$56 million. The site, with a land area of 1,152.7 sq m, is zoned for residential use and has a gross plot ratio of 2.8. The tender closes on Feb 18, with Knight Frank Singapore expecting strong interest from developers and investors due to the lack of collective sale activity in prime districts. The site's proximity to Great World MRT station and nearby schools makes it attractive for families and professionals.

site_title: Asia: Most markets cautiously higher as traders eye Trump 2.0
summary: Asian markets opened cautiously higher on the first full week of 2025, driven by a positive run on Wall Street and traders' anticipation of Donald Trump's second presidency. Concerns about China's stuttering economy, US interest rates, and ongoing conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East continue to cast uncertainty. Despite this, investors are hopeful that Trump's tax cuts and regulatory removals could boost profits and potentially reignite inflation. The Federal Reserve's decision on rate cuts this year is also being closely watched, with Richmond Fed boss Tom Barkin indicating a slower pace of reductions.

images.alt_text: All three local banks close in positive territory. UOB rises 0.6 per cent or S$0.22 to S$36.80, OCBC climbs 1.3 per cent or S$0.22 to S$16.79 and DBS is up 0.8 per cent or S$0.33 at S$43.95.

site_title: Samsung adds generative AI to world’s best-selling TV lineup
summary: Samsung is expanding its Vision AI suite with enhancements for its premium TV lineup, featuring a built-in AI processor that can analyze content, boost colors and contrast, and optimize audio. The AI-powered screens can also search online, identify objects, translate in real-time, and generate personalized background images. The company will collaborate with Microsoft and Alphabet's Google to expand the suite with additional capabilities. Samsung aims to position its TVs as interactive, intelligent partners that adapt to user needs, rather than passive devices for consumption.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s Ray Farris named Prudential’s first chief economist
summary: Ray Farris, a 22-year veteran of Credit Suisse, has been named Prudential's first chief economist for Eastspring Investments. Based in Singapore, Farris will provide macroeconomic data and insights to guide investment decisions. He will report to Eastspring's chief investment officer, Vis Nayar, and drive economic analysis for Eastspring and its parent company. This appointment highlights Farris' expertise in economics, markets, and policy across three continents.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Prudential is working with a financial adviser on a review of Eastspring, which could be valued at about US$3 billion in a potential stake sale.
Based in Singapore, Vis Nayar will report to Eastspring chief executive Bill Maldonado.

site_title: The UK can find its way in Trump’s America
summary: The UK must adopt a strategic approach to its economic relations with the US under the incoming Trump administration to avoid mismanaging its vital trade and investment ties. The UK's economy faces challenges, including a wobbly economy, a large budget deficit, and limited fiscal policy flexibility. To position itself for opportunities, the UK should pursue informal trade and investment concessions before Trump assumes office, and consider joining a US-led economic "coalition of the willing" to offset potential challenges from China.

images.alt_text: Business confidence has “declined significantly”, with only 49 per cent expecting turnover to increase in the coming year.
CEBR expects Britain to narrow the gap with the poorer-performing German economy over the next 15 years.
British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has outlined six milestones that he wants voters to use in order to hold his government to account during this first term.
British PM Keir Starmer said: “(This) is my plan for change. The driving purpose of this government and we will stay the course. We will fix the foundations, repair the damage, reform government.”

site_title: Intel says new laptop chips will extend computer battery life
summary: Intel has introduced new laptop chips that aim to extend computer battery life and improve AI performance. The new Core Ultra processors will be available starting this month, enabling laptops to run for up to 10.5 hours on a single charge and 20.3 hours for cloud-based applications. This is compared to rival Dell devices, which can last around 9.2 hours and 18.5 hours. The new chips are designed for corporate and high-end consumer devices, and will initially be aimed at business machines before expanding to thin and light laptops and desktop PCs.
