Intel’s struggles to keep pace with rivals — along with its deteriorating financial condition — have spurred speculation that the next CEO will make dramatic changes.

site_title: China’s Pony.ai eyes robotaxi services in Hong Kong, joining Baidu
summary: China's Pony.ai plans to launch robotaxi services in Hong Kong, targeting airport staff, before expanding into other urban areas. The move follows Baidu's approval to conduct trials in the city. Pony.ai has obtained robotaxi licenses in several Chinese cities and is exploring deployments in South Korea, Luxembourg, and other countries. The company aims to capitalize on the growing demand for autonomous driving services globally.

site_title: Japan stocks look set for new highs in 2025 on earnings, reform
summary: Japan's stocks are expected to reach new record highs in 2025, driven by corporate governance reforms and robust earnings, with a median 7.8% advance for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average and 8.6% for the Topix index. The yen may remain under pressure due to the Bank of Japan's possible launch of quantitative tightening and a wide interest-rate gap with other economies. Corporate governance reforms and shareholder activism are seen as tailwinds, while interest-rate hikes and the US trade presidency pose headwinds.

images.alt_text: Japan's final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers’ index grew to 50.9 in December from 50.5 in November, according to a survey compiled by S&P Global Market Intelligence.
Manufacturers stayed confident about their outlook as they expect business to expand thanks to the launch and mass production of new products.

site_title: OCBC says healthcare S-Reits offer defence amid slower rate cuts, names top picks
summary: OCBC Investment Research recommends investing in healthcare S-Reits to bolster portfolios, citing long-term growth potential driven by an ageing population and chronic diseases. Analysts name Parkway Life Reit as top pick due to growth potential, while First Reit receives a "buy" rating. The recommendation comes amid uncertainty from a potential second Trump presidency, which may slow rate cuts and impact S-Reits.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
2024 saw S-Reits become more active in their equity fundraising, raising over S$2.8 billion, and with two S-Reits launching EFR exercises that raised more than S$1 billion.

site_title: Thai central bank says interest rate hold was robust policy amid uncertainty
summary: The Bank of Thailand has stated that holding the interest rate steady at 2.25% last month was a robust policy amidst heightened economic uncertainty. The central bank cited a growth rate of over 3% in the last quarter of 2024, driven by exports, tourism, and domestic demand. Despite this, the bank noted that monetary policy becomes less effective under high uncertainty and does not rule out future policy adjustments. The next interest rate review is scheduled for February 26.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016.   REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia Airports takeover offer extended to Jan 17; consortium secures 70% stake
summary: A consortium led by Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund and the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority has secured a 70.08% stake in Malaysia Airports, surpassing the 40.85% stake held as of December 6, 2024. The takeover offer has been extended to January 17, and shares of the company have surged 38.8% over the past year. The move is part of a larger effort to increase the consortium's stake in the airport company.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei slips more than 1% on 1st trading day of 2025 after year-end rally
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 1.47% to 39,307.05 on its first trading day of 2025, after a year-end rally, despite gains in chip-related stocks. The broader Topix index also declined 1.02% to 2,756.38, led by Toyota Motor's 4.29% drop. Investors sold stocks after the index's strong December gain, with the Nikkei rising 4.4% in December, its largest monthly gain since February last year.

site_title: Singapore faces risk of new property curbs, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley warns of a potential 5% drop in Singapore residential property prices this year due to a housing rally driven by speculative buying. The city-state's private residential prices jumped 2.3% in the latest quarter, with buyers flipping units making an average 21% profit. To combat this, the government may introduce new cooling measures, likely raising seller stamp duties, to curb speculation and affordability concerns ahead of the election year. Analysts predict the government will act, following a growing chorus of banks and experts.

images.alt_text: More moves on the housing front can be considered to address Singapore's baby woes.

site_title: South Korean investigators seek extension of arrest warrant for impeached president
summary: South Korean investigators sought an extension of an arrest warrant for impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol, who faces charges over his martial law proclamation. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken expressed confidence in South Korea's handling of the political turmoil, saying the response was "peaceful and fully consistent with the constitution and the rule of law." The warrant, which was blocked by presidential security service guards, will expire at midnight on Monday if not extended.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, CSE Global
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is divesting a Malaysian property for RM31.5 million (S$9.6 million), with the transaction expected to be completed in the first half of FY2025/2026. This move has no significant impact on MLT's net asset value and net property income for the current financial year. Meanwhile, CSE Global is divesting a US-based industrial property for US$29.3 million to free up capital for business expansion.

site_title: South Korea extends closure of Muan airport where plane crashed
summary: South Korea has extended the closure of Muan International Airport until January 14, following a fatal plane crash on December 29 that killed 179 people. The cause of the crash remains unknown, but investigators are probing possible factors including a bird strike, faulty landing gear, and the runway barrier. The bodies of the victims will be returned to families on Monday, allowing them to hold funerals after a week-long wait. South Korean and US investigators are continuing to examine the crash site.

site_title: Rare win for Najib as court grants appeal in house detention bid
summary: Malaysia's Court of Appeal granted ex-PM Najib Razak's appeal, overturning a lower court's dismissal of his request for house detention. The court's two-to-one decision allows Najib to proceed with his case, which will now return to the High Court for a new hearing. A letter from the palace confirmed a royal order granting Najib home detention was "valid and authentic", marking a surprise twist in the case. Najib, jailed over the 1MDB scandal, remains on trial for corruption in several other cases.

site_title: Former HDB chief Cheong Koon Hean joins Surbana Jurong’s board
summary: Former HDB chief Cheong Koon Hean has joined Surbana Jurong's board, bringing decades of experience in urban development and sustainability. Alongside Prof Yaacob Ibrahim and MP Desmond Choo, she will contribute to the firm's strategic direction, tackling complex challenges and driving innovative solutions for communities and ecosystems. Her expertise will strengthen Surbana Jurong's ability to deliver sustainable solutions for the built environment.

site_title: Asia-Pacific loans set to recover in 2025 from three-year drop
summary: Asia-Pacific loan volumes are expected to rebound in 2025 after a three-year decline, driven by merger and acquisition activity and favorable interest rates. In the final quarter of 2024, loan volumes reached $164 billion, the strongest fourth-quarter performance in three years. The region's loan volumes fell 4.6% to $590 billion in 2024, with a strong deal pipeline already building for 2025. Key markets, including China and India, are expected to remain significant, with refinancing, capital expenditure, and growth funding driving loan activity.

images.alt_text: The loan will be used to refinance an existing S$4 billion seven-year borrowing from August 2019, sources said.

site_title: Thai inflation returns to target for first time in seven months
summary: Thailand's inflation has returned to the Bank of Thailand's (BOT) 1-3% target range for the first time in seven months, with a 1.23% increase in December from the previous year. This move gives the central bank more flexibility to address government calls for deeper rate cuts amid global uncertainties. Despite exceeding the target, the BOT maintains its "broadly neutral stance" to preserve policy space. The government seeks further rate cuts to boost economic growth, while the central bank is under pressure to maintain a robust monetary policy stance.

Thailand's household debt, which currently stands at about 90 per cent of GDP, is too high, says Bank of Thailand governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput.

site_title: China services activity hits seven-month high but US trade fears dent optimism: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at the fastest pace in seven months in December, driven by domestic demand, but orders from abroad declined, reflecting growing trade risks. The Caixin/S&P Global services PMI rose to 52.2, surpassing the 50-mark that separates expansion from contraction. Exports could face more US tariffs under a second Trump administration, posing a major risk to China's economy. Despite a positive business confidence reading, policymakers face pressure to address tepid domestic demand and mounting external factors.

images.alt_text: Chinese manufacturers maintained an optimistic view about output in 2025 though the degree of optimism eased to the lowest since September.
China’s President Xi Jinping reiterated a call to adopt more proactive macroeconomic policies to aid the economy’s continued recovery.

site_title: Canada PM Trudeau says he will resign
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced his intention to resign, citing the ruling Liberal Party's need to choose a replacement. He will remain in office until the party selects a new leader, potentially prolonging his tenure. Trudeau faces heavy pressure due to polls showing the party's expected poor performance in the next election. The timing of his departure is uncertain, with parliament set to resume on Jan 27, but Trudeau has proposed suspending parliament until March 24 to allow for a leadership contest.

images.alt_text: On Feb 23, Germany faces a ballot likely to sweep Chancellor Olaf Scholz from the nation’s top job.

Canada's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance Chrystia Freeland speaks during Question Period in the House of Commons on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada September 16, 2024.  REUTERS/Blair Gable

site_title: ‘Emilia Perez’, ‘The Brutalist’ win big at diverse Golden Globes
summary: The 82nd Golden Globes honored a diverse range of films, with "Emilia Perez" and "The Brutalist" emerging as the big winners. "Emilia Perez," a Brazilian narco-musical, took four prizes, including best comedy or musical film, while "The Brutalist," a Hungarian Holocaust drama, won best drama and best actor for Adrien Brody. Fernanda Torres of Brazil won best actress in a drama film for "I'm Still Here," an epic immigrant drama. The ceremony marked a significant shift in the awards, with the Hollywood Foreign Press Association disbanded and the show's voting body revamped.

images.alt_text: "Mufasa: The Lion King" has earned US$168.6 million domestically over three weekends, propelling it into the top 15 of 2024 releases, Variety reported.
Beast Games will look familiar to anyone who watches Donaldson's YouTube channel. The stunts, which have a tinge of Depression-era dance marathons to them, have just moved to a larger stage.
Season 2 is set to compete for best TV series at the upcoming Golden Globes.

site_title: SingPost cautions sale of Aussie assets not done deal; no definitive agreement yet for Famous Holdings
summary: SingPost has cautioned that the sale of its Australian assets, including Freight Management Holdings and Famous Holdings, is not a done deal. The company's board will review and restate its strategy in due course, with no definitive agreement in place. A potential special dividend from divestments is also not confirmed, despite a report suggesting it could raise S$80-100 million. The company's decision to sell assets is subject to shareholders' approval, and the board will consider all major divestments for approval if required.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Maybank maintains its buy rating on SingPost, with a price target of S$0.77.
David Gerald, founder, president and chief executive of Sias, says that shareholders deserve better and so does the market.
Neo Su Yin, 44, will work with SingPost's board in a review of the group's international business unit.
SingPost says customers are aware of the clauses and conditions covering delivery failure.

site_title: China oil refineries face reckoning as Beijing tackles overcapacity
summary: China's independent oil refineries, known as "teapots," face a reckoning as Beijing tackles overcapacity and shrinking demand for their products. The country's economy slowdown and shift towards greener energy are driving down demand for petrol and diesel, while stricter tax policies and reduced access to sanctioned crude are further squeezing their margins. As a result, three firms in Shandong province went bankrupt last year, and more are predicted to follow, with analysts forecasting 6-15 million tonnes of capacity to close nationwide in 2025.

images.alt_text: Sinochem inherited the troubled Shandong refineries in a Beijing-orchestrated merger in 2021 with their previous operator, state-owned ChemChina.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Monday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,821.84 on Monday, driven by gains from local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS. The top gainer was Keppel, up 1.7%, while CapitaLand Investment fell 1.5%. The broader market saw 263 gainers beat 258 losers, with 945.4 million securities worth S$854.5 million changing hands. The regional market was mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 1.5% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index declining 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
Therese Soh
ST20190726_201954166463  Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic scenes as seen from level 17 of the Mapletree Business City located on Pasir Panjang Road.

site_title: Microsoft expects to spend US$80 billion on AI this fiscal year
summary: Microsoft is expected to spend approximately $80 billion on artificial intelligence this fiscal year, according to the company's president Brad Smith. He emphasized the importance of the US being a global leader in AI, stating it could build a foundation for America's economic success for the next quarter century. Smith described AI as the "electricity of our age," highlighting its transformative potential across all aspects of life.

images.alt_text: Microsoft 365 Copilot is an AI assistant built into Microsoft’s suite of enterprise software including Word and PowerPoint.
Hui Li Lee, Managing Director, Microsoft Singapore.
Microsoft acquired a minority stake in Cruise in January 2021 in a combined new equity investment of more than US$2 billion.

site_title: Xpeng, Volkswagen to build ultra-fast charging network in China
summary: Xpeng Motors and Volkswagen have signed a memorandum of understanding to expand their partnership to create an ultra-fast electric vehicle charging network in China. The network, which spans over 420 cities and 20,000 charging piles, will allow customers of both companies to use each other's charging stations. The companies also plan to explore joint construction of co-branded ultra-fast charging stations. This partnership builds on their previous agreement in 2023, in which Volkswagen acquired a 4.99% stake in Xpeng for $700 million, with plans to launch two Volkswagen-branded EV models by 2026.

site_title: Johor-Singapore SEZ on radar of China firms eyeing lower costs, improved connectivity
summary: Chinese companies are eyeing Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (SEZ) for its proximity to Singapore's market and infrastructure, lower costs, and improved connectivity across the Causeway. The SEZ's expected signing on January 7 is drawing interest from companies in the semiconductor materials, specialty chemicals, and electrical and electronics sectors. Chinese firms hope for streamlined customs procedures and simplified cross-border trade processes to reduce business costs. The US-China trade war is also a factor, with companies seeking alternative manufacturing hubs in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Sharon See
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (right) will host Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) for the 11th Singapore-Malaysia Leaders' Retreat in Putrajaya.
The SEZ is located just across the Causeway, the world's busiest land crossing.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.

site_title: South Korean markets ride out crisis as global debt funds keep buying
summary: South Korea's markets weathered a crisis in December, with global debt funds buying government bonds and the cost to insure the country's debt against default at a four-month high. Despite President Yoon Suk-yeol's bid to impose martial law, which threatened the country's democratic foundations, investors maintained confidence in the nation. Authorities' swift response and efforts to modernize the market infrastructure, including securing a spot in the FTSE Russell's bond index, bolstered investor faith. The country's economy is showing signs of strain, but the financial system remains stable.

images.alt_text: Entertainment has been a major factor fuelling interest in Asian beauty standards, with industry players pointing to the “Netflix effect”.

site_title: What if TikTok loses its fight and gets banned in the US?
summary: US President Joe Biden signed a bipartisan bill in April 2024 aimed at banning TikTok unless its Chinese owner, ByteDance, gives up control. The US Supreme Court will hear TikTok's challenge on January 10, with the company's last-ditch effort to thwart the ban. If the law goes into effect, companies like Oracle, Apple, and Alphabet's Google face liabilities if they continue to provide support to TikTok. President-elect Donald Trump has asked the justices to pause the law, and if the ban is upheld, ByteDance may be more open to selling TikTok. The company has an estimated valuation of $268 billion, making it difficult to find a buyer.

images.alt_text: US president-elect Donald Trump once supported a TikTok ban, but he has spoken more favourably about the platform in recent days.
TikTok’s owners have sought to have the law struck down, and the US Supreme Court has agreed to hear the case.

site_title: Hong Kong-based Logan Group proposes restructuring its US$8 billion offshore debt
summary: Hong Kong-based property developer Logan Group is proposing a restructuring plan to alleviate its US$8 billion offshore debt. The plan involves converting a significant portion of the debt to mandatory convertible bonds, offering creditors options to exchange debt for cash, bonds, or notes. The move aims to relieve the company's debt burden and restore its capital structure, following a failed repayment since August 2022. Logan Group had previously secured an HK$8.2 billion loan to refinance part of the debt. The proposal is part of efforts to recover from the 2021 property sector collapse.

site_title: Vietnam posts 2024 GDP growth of 7.09%, faces challenges to meet faster 2025 growth target
summary: Vietnam's 2024 GDP growth reached 7.09%, exceeding forecasts and the government's target of 6-6.5%. The country's economy expanded in the fourth quarter by 7.55% year-on-year, driven by strong exports and industrial output. However, analysts warn that slower exports to the US and falling foreign direct investment could impact growth in 2025, with a target of 6.5-7% set by the government. The country's growth trajectory is also influenced by domestic factors, including firmer consumption and increased infrastructure spending.

images.alt_text: Motorists pass by high-rise residential buildings in Hanoi on January 2, 2025. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP)
Levels of hazardous small particles, known as PM2.5, were measured at 266 micrograms per cubic metre in Hanoi early on Friday (Jan 3), the highest reading among a list of most-polluted cities.
Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has urged officials to focus on disbursing public investment from the start of 2025 to create growth momentum.
The tariff is expected to take effect 15 days from the date of signing and will be in place for five years, the ministry says.

site_title: New interchange to connect Downtown and North-South Lines in 2035
summary: A new interchange connecting the Downtown Line and North-South Line in Singapore is set to be completed in 2035. The DE2/NS6 interchange, located in Sungei Kadut Avenue, will improve transport links to the Sungei Kadut Eco-District and Yew Tee Village. Two new stations will form the interchange, with the underground DE2 becoming the new terminus for the Downtown Line and the above-ground NS6 connecting existing North-South Line stations. The project aims to enhance regional connectivity and improve travel options for commuters.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
ST Engineering has commenced works under the contracts which are due for completion by July 2030..
Properties near the new Thomson-East Coast Line stations have seen substantial price and rental hikes.
Passengers heading westwards on the East-West Line have been advised to factor an extra five minutes into their travel time.

The upcoming Jurong Region Line will span 24 MRT stations and connect key activity nodes in the western part of Singapore, such as the Jurong Industrial Estate, Jurong Innovation District, Nanyang Technological University and the Tengah new town.
Construction work at a site in Clementi Close on Dec 13, for a 753-unit Build-To-Order project that has yet to be announced.

site_title: Singapore bank earnings to continue riding higher-for-longer rates, wealth sector growth in 2025
summary: Singapore banks' earnings are expected to grow in 2025, driven by higher non-interest income from wealth management and treasury services. Strong dividends and clear dividend policies will remain attractive to investors. Higher-for-longer interest rates and structural changes in geopolitics and taxation are expected to spur increasing wealth flows to Singapore, driving faster wealth management fee income growth. Net interest margins are also expected to benefit from higher rates, but may soften potential credit demand. Capital management will be a key area to watch in 2025, with analysts expecting consistent increases in capital return.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The local benchmark Straits Times Index could get a boost from market reforms that the Monetary Authority of Singapore's review group may put up.
The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.
The US Federal Reserve, chaired by Jerome Powell (above), signals a slower pace of interest rate cuts for 2025.
Dubai – and the rest of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) – has become a strong magnet for private wealth and talent in recent years.

site_title: Singapore should still see real wage growth in 2025, but probably less than in 2024
summary: Singapore is expected to see sustained real wage growth in 2025, albeit at a slower pace than in 2024, due to moderating economic growth and inflation. Economists predict 2.8% to 2.5% real income growth in 2025, with some forecasting slightly stronger gains. Nominal wage growth is expected to slow, but will remain above pre-pandemic norms. Sectoral-dependent wage pressures are expected, with lower-wage workers in retail and healthcare sectors potentially seeing bigger gains, while higher-skilled employees in growth sectors like finance may also experience good real wage gains.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Some 89 per cent of 525 employers surveyed plan to award bonuses averaging more than one month in 2024 and 2025.
The 2025 job market will present both opportunities and challenges.
Pay increments may be preferred, but alternatives such as flexible work arrangements aren't bad options either.
Hiring sentiment in Singapore remains relatively stable, according to the latest ManpowerGroup Employment Outlook Survey.

site_title: Local property giants should aspire to pan-Asean leadership
summary: Local Singapore property giants may shift their focus to pan-Asean leadership as China's real estate sector faces challenges. Despite Singapore's stable property market, limitations exist due to its small population and reliance on public housing. To diversify and scale up their business, property groups have invested in Asean countries like Vietnam, Thailand, and Malaysia. Emulating banking group UOB's transformational acquisition, local property groups can grow Asean as a core market, targeting young populations and rapidly climbing the economic value chain, potentially making the bloc the world's fourth-largest economy by 2030.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
For the nine months ended September, CLI's total revenue amounted to S$2.1 billion, up from S$2.09 billion in the year prior.
CapitaLand wants to reduce its exposure in the world’s second-largest economy to 10-20 per cent of its expected S$200 billion in funds under management by 2028.

site_title: Asian currency index falls to two-decade low on Fed, tariff bets
summary: Asian currencies fell to a two-decade low due to the US dollar's broad gains, driven by Federal Reserve officials' cautious tone on interest rates and investors' bets on US tariffs. The Bloomberg Asia Dollar Index dropped to 89.0409, its lowest since 2006. Asian currencies, such as the won and rupee, have declined against the US dollar, with some nearing all-time lows seen during the 1998 Asian Financial Crisis. Central banks may respond to potential US trade protectionism by allowing their exchange rates to depreciate in a controlled manner.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this photo illustration taken February 12, 2018. REUTERS/Jose Luis Gonzalez/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Should we fire CEOs more often?
summary: More CEOs than ever are jumping ship or being walked off a short plank, according to a BT columnist. This trend is not limited to SingPost, an outlier in the local landscape, but is seen elsewhere globally. The article highlights the high turnover rate of CEOs, with no specific numbers or explanations provided, but notes that SingPost's CEO may be an exception.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi

There are two mega listings in the pipeline that could not only inject some life into the Singapore stock market, but more importantly, be emblematic of larger investor preoccupations next year, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

As the US and China endlessly slap-fight each other, analysts have looked for opportunities in other markets and settled on India for its favourable demographics and lower tariff risks, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
If you haven’t gotten in on any of the Magnificent Seven US megacap stocks, don’t despair even if the basket of stocks has advanced 60 per cent this year, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
Haidilao’s Sichuan Spicy soup base is red as all heck, but the restaurant operator’s bottom line no longer is, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

Share buybacks have been around for as long as our oldest and grumpiest millennials, but just as with millennials, no one can agree on whether they are good for business, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

site_title: PBOC maintains support for yuan with fix stronger than key level
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) reaffirmed its support for the yuan, setting its daily reference rate stronger than 7.2 per US dollar to blunt the impact of a stronger US dollar following Donald Trump's US election victory. The move eased concerns that Beijing would allow a sharper depreciation, following the onshore yuan's slide past 7.3 per US dollar due to mounting economic pressures. The PBOC also plans to sell more bills in Hong Kong to mop up yuan liquidity and boost the currency.

images.alt_text: The onshore yuan has been relatively steady, testing the 7.3 level multiple times last month but failing to break it.

site_title: French budget deficit for 2025 will not be ‘much’ above 5%: minister
summary: France's budget minister Amelie de Montchalin stated that the country's 2025 budget deficit is expected to be "slightly above 5%". This comes after French Finance Minister Eric Lombard previously mentioned the same target. The goal of reducing the deficit, which has consistently exceeded the EU's limits, is a priority for Prime Minister Francois Bayrou. However, finding ways to cut public spending is challenging due to opposition from both far-right and far-left parties, following in the footsteps of his predecessor Michel Barnier.

site_title: Japan’s service activity expands on solid demand, PMI shows
summary: Japan's service sector expanded for a second consecutive month in December, driven by solid demand and business expansion. The final au Jibun Bank Service Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 50.9, above the 50.0 threshold, led by a sixth straight month of rising new business and 15th consecutive month of employment growth. Business sentiment remained positive, but optimism softened slightly, with firms expecting demand and activity to grow in the coming year. The composite PMI also rose to 50.5, driven by service sector inflation picking up in November.

images.alt_text: Michelin-starred sushi restauranteurs the Onodera Group says that they paid 207 million yen for the 276 kg bluefin tuna, roughly the size and weight of a motorbike.
Nippon Steel faces a US$565 million penalty payment to US Steel following the deal's collapse.
The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Blackstone Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on October 17. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: iPhone supplier TDK rolls out new batteries to keep pace with AI
summary: TDK, a main iPhone battery supplier, will start mass-producing its third-generation silicon-anode cells in late summer to meet the growing power demands of built-in AI. Silicon batteries, more complex to manufacture but carrying more energy, have already been adopted by major Chinese phone makers. CEO Noboru Saito plans to accelerate investment in R&D, citing it as a business strength, as the technology is expected to see further growth.

images.alt_text: The headquarters building of General Motors Co. stands in Detroit, Michigan, U.S., on Tuesday, June 1, 2010. General Motors Corp. filed for bankruptcy protection one year ago today, becoming the largest failure of an industrial company in U.S. history. The company, now known as General Motors Co. (GM), is currently seeking to sell shares in an initial public offering. Photographer: Jeff Kowalsky/Bloomberg

site_title: UBS targets Japan’s regional banks with senior sales hires
summary: UBS has hired three senior salesmen in Japan to boost its business selling high-yielding structured investments to local financial firms. Former HSBC Holdings banker Shuhei Sanada joined UBS's Tokyo brokerage arm on January 1, along with Eiichiro Yoshida from Nissay Asset Management and Hiroaki Sato from Barclays. This move aims to expand UBS's reach in the Japanese market and bring its ideas and capabilities to a wider client base, according to UBS's co-head of global markets in Japan.

images.alt_text: An analyst says the report itself is unlikely to have any direct impact on UBS, but its findings could set the mood in Switzerland.
UBS is seeking a broader banking license in the US.
UBS said in a statement that it “welcomes the court’s decision to acquit the bank in connection with a legacy matter related to Credit Suisse.”

site_title: China’s Geely Holding targets over five million units of annual sales by 2027
summary: China's Geely Holding Group aims to sell over 5 million vehicles annually by 2027, representing a 79% growth from 2023. The goal is driven by consolidation of its brands and improved efficiency. Geely sold 3 million vehicles in the first 11 months of 2024, a 20% growth compared to the same period in 2023. The company plans to consolidate its brands into two units: Geely Auto for mass market and premium segments, and Zeekr Technology. This move could position Geely among the top 10 automaking groups globally.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Gen XYZ - who really knows jack about cash?
summary: In the 200th episode of the Money Hacks podcast, correspondent Howie Lim explores generational differences in financial habits and strategies. Financial experts Dawn Cher and Ge Jiabao, representing Gen X, Y, and Z, respectively, discuss distinct financial motivations and strategies. Cher emphasizes saving and increasing earning potential to combat inflation, while Ge highlights Gen Z's transition into financial consciousness and adventurous approach to investments like cryptocurrency and NFTs. The episode also touches on common financial mistakes, such as underestimating retirement needs and lack of understanding about credit card debt.

images.alt_text: How do we navigate rates, risks and growth in 2025?
Who is the SRS really for and can it supercharge our retirement savings?

site_title: Manchester United rally to slow Liverpool charge towards Premier League title with 2-2 draw
summary: Manchester United secured a 2-2 draw against Liverpool, halting the Reds' four-game winning streak and narrowing the gap in the Premier League title race. The draw came after Liverpool took a 2-1 lead through goals from Cody Gakpo and Mohamed Salah's penalty. Manchester United equalized twice, with Amad Diallo scoring the second goal, to secure a crucial point. The result keeps Liverpool six points clear at the top of the table, but Manchester United's draw keeps their title hopes alive.

images.alt_text: Flags are displayed at a makeshift stand outside Old Trafford. Manchester United are in 14th place in the EPL, 23 points behind their next opponents, Liverpool.
Manchester City midfielder Rodri took the prestigious prize in October with favourite Vinicius (above) in second place.

site_title: China seeks to bolster ports and aviation hubs in western regions
summary: China plans to launch 15 measures to bolster its western provinces by developing logistical infrastructure such as ports and aviation hubs. The measures include enhancing international aviation hubs, developing comprehensive bonded zones, and integrating these with ports and other transport links. China aims to boost the economic development of its western regions, which have lagged behind coastal provinces, and increase linkages to Europe and South Asia through trade corridors. The efforts are part of China's "new urbanisation" plan to revitalise rural areas and expand poverty alleviation efforts.

images.alt_text: The statement by the central bank reiterates plans to cut interest rates and the reserve requirement ratio, which dictates how much banks must hold in their coffers, rather than lending or investing.

site_title: From the West for the best: How the South Korean wave is redefining aesthetics
summary: South Korea's medical tourism industry experienced a significant surge in 2023, with 606,000 international patients, a 150% increase from the previous year. Dermatological treatments and plastic surgery were the top attractions, with procedures such as rhinoplasty and facial contouring drawing patients from around the world. The industry's growth can be attributed to South Korea's cutting-edge medical technology, well-regulated industry, and affordable pricing, which is significantly lower than in the US. The "Netflix effect" and the rise of K-pop and K-drama have also fueled interest in Asian beauty standards. The government has announced plans to make South Korea a medical tourism hub in Asia, aiming to attract 700,000 international patients by 2027.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Stem-cell treatments, a particularly contentious and highly regulated field, are becoming increasingly popular in Thailand as patients seek treatment for diseases like Alzheimer's and anti-ageing remedies.
In 2023, Malaysia attracted 1.4 million medical tourists, generating total revenue of RM2.25 billion (S$680 million), surpassing its pre-pandemic peak.
Industry observers believe Singapore still has what it takes to remain at the top – largely by taking on complicated treatment and surgeries.

site_title: Hong Kong budget deficit to be just under HK$100 billion, financial chief says
summary: Hong Kong's estimated budget deficit for the year ending in March is expected to be just under HK$100 billion, roughly double the previous forecast of HK$48.1 billion. The deficit is attributed to a sharp decline in land sales revenue. Finance Chief Paul Chan emphasized the need for cost-saving measures to tackle the deficit, prioritizing urgent public works projects while boosting the economy amid a fiscal deficit. The economy is expected to grow 2.5% in 2024, following a 1.8% third-quarter growth rate that fell below expectations.

site_title: Gold extends drop after Fed officials express inflation concern
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.5% to near $2,630 an ounce after Federal Reserve officials expressed concerns over inflation, pushing forecasts for a $3,000 an ounce price to mid-2026. The comments reinforced a cautious approach to cutting rates in 2025, a headwind for gold, which benefits from lower rates. Goldman Sachs revised its forecast, citing fewer expected Fed cuts. The Fed's easing trajectory will be closely watched, with data on non-farm payrolls and job openings due this week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars from the vault of a bank are seen in this illustration picture taken in Zurich November 20, 2014. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: ‘Mufasa’ roars to top of North American box office
summary: "Mufasa: The Lion King" has taken the top spot at the North American box office, earning US$168.6 million over three weekends, surpassing "Sonic the Hedgehog 3" with an estimated US$23.8 million. The film is on track to reach the half-billion-dollar mark, with an additional US$307 million earned internationally.

images.alt_text: Season 2 is set to compete for best TV series at the upcoming Golden Globes.
Disney’s animated drama 'Mufasa: The Lion King' prevailed in the five days from Christmas Day to Sunday with an estimated take of US$63.8 million.
The third and final season of Squid Game is due in 2025.
Christmas Eve sales are closely watched because this is the last sprint at the end of the year.

site_title: 10,000-seater stadium, indoor pools and sheltered courts among new sports facilities in Toa Payoh
summary: Singapore's Toa Payoh town is set to undergo a major rejuvenation with the completion of the Toa Payoh Integrated Development (TPID) by 2030. The 12ha development will feature a 10,000-seater stadium, indoor pools, sheltered courts, and community amenities, including a polyclinic, library, and town park. The project aims to create a vibrant hub for sports and community activities, with a focus on sustainability and community engagement. The development is part of Singapore's Sports Facilities Master Plan and will complement existing facilities in other parts of the city-state.

images.alt_text: Construction work at a site in Clementi Close on Dec 13, for a 753-unit Build-To-Order project that has yet to be announced.

site_title: New York City congestion pricing takes effect after years of delays
summary: New York City's congestion pricing program took effect on January 5, 2025, charging $9 per vehicle entering Manhattan during peak hours. The program aims to reduce traffic and air pollution, generating $15 billion for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) to upgrade the city's subway and commuter-rail lines. Despite years of delays and legal challenges, the program is expected to boost public-transportation ridership and reduce traffic congestion. However, some officials warn the fee will hurt small businesses and residents, and its long-term future remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A passenger train glides on the tracks in downtown Jakarta on November 5, 2024. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP)

site_title: Trump’s presidency expected to boost S&P 500
summary: The S&P 500 is expected to continue its growth in 2025, driven by President-elect Donald Trump's pro-growth policies and a resilient US economy. Despite inflation and the Federal Reserve's response, the market is likely to see a more inclusive rally, with growth above trend but short of the 20% gains seen in 2024. The "no landing" scenario, where growth continues at a steady pace but inflation remains slightly above target, is expected to materialize, supporting the S&P 500.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 2, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Perennial’s hospitals target wealthy boomers in China as population ages
summary: Perennial Holdings, a Singaporean hospital operator, is targeting wealthy Chinese boomers with premium care services, capitalizing on the country's aging population. With over 400 million Chinese set to enter their 60s, Perennial is betting on a substantial market, estimating it's "so big that I don't think at this stage you are talking about competing." The company operates two developments in China, offering integrated hospitals, rehabilitation facilities, and amenities, with prices ranging from $1,310 to $2,000 per month.

images.alt_text: The 500-bed Perennial General Hospital Tianjin.

site_title: Revolutionising Engagement: Envoku Launches to Transform Communication Across Industries
summary: Live Group has launched Envoku, a platform revolutionizing communication and engagement in events, workplaces, and customer interactions. Envoku uses AI-driven personalization, AudienceDNA profiling, and real-time adaptability to tailor interactions to each participant's unique preferences. The platform offers features such as personalized content, matchmaking suggestions, and dynamic real-time adaptation, aiming to meet today's demand for personalization and inclusivity. Envoku is set to expand into sectors like employee engagement and customer interaction, positioning itself as a global leader in personalized communication and inclusive engagement.

site_title: Oil heads for weekly gains on colder weather, Chinese policy support
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, closing the week higher due to cold weather in Europe and the US, as well as China's economic stimulus measures. Brent crude futures gained 2.4% and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose nearly 5% to their highest levels since October. China's announcement of wage increases and increased funding for business investment and consumer initiatives heightened expectations of policy measures to boost growth, supporting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$75.93 a barrel, up US$1.29, or 1.7 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Australia’s Insignia Financial gets A$2.9 billion takeover bid from CC Capital Partners
summary: Australia's Insignia Financial received a takeover bid from US-based investment manager CC Capital Partners for A$2.87 billion. The offer, worth A$4.30 cash per share, represents a 7.5% premium to Bain Capital's earlier offer of A$2.67 billion, which Insignia Financial rejected in December. The company's board is considering CC Capital's proposal to assess its best interests.

site_title: Top US Republican eyes swift passage of Trump priority mega-bill
summary: US House Speaker Mike Johnson is pushing for a multi-trillion-dollar mega-bill to be passed within his first 100 days in office, combining priorities such as border security, tax cuts, and energy production. Johnson has strategized with President-elect Donald Trump to combine these priorities into one bill, utilizing the reconciliation process to potentially clear the Senate with a simple majority. The bill aims to address immigration, tax cuts, and energy production, and Johnson aims to have an initial House vote by April 3, with a potential signing into law by the end of the month.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 2, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid
US President Joe Biden on Jan 3, 2025 announced the veto of the sale of US Steel on national security grounds.

US President Joe Biden’s call to block the deal was taken despite contrary efforts by some of his senior advisers over concerns that it could damage US-Japan relations, the Washington Post report said.

site_title: Here’s why I’m optimistic about climate financing
summary: A UN-backed carbon market agreement was reached at COP29, potentially boosting the quality of and demand for carbon credits. Despite this, the climate crisis remains a pressing issue, with global temperatures likely to exceed 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. The "funding gap" between climate change mitigation and adaptation efforts and fossil fuel subsidies remains significant. While technological advances and economic realities offer reasons for optimism, headwinds from geopolitical volatility and inequality may hinder progress. A shift in messaging is needed to emphasize realism and action in addressing the climate crisis.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as markets await data, policy changes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, January 3, as investors await economic data and potential policy shifts under the incoming Trump administration. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 103.5 points, or 0.24%, to 42,495.76, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains. The market is closely watching upcoming economic releases and the impact of the Trump administration's policy changes on the economy.

site_title: Global trends in sustainable finance bonds
summary: Global sustainable finance bond issuances reached a record US$990 billion by the end of November 2024, driven by a growing market and favorable investor sentiment. Green bonds remain the most popular format, but their issuance is expected to increase following the introduction of the European Green Bond Standard (EGBS). Sustainability bonds and social bonds also had a strong year, with notable issuances from companies like Citigroup and Deutsche Bank. However, sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs) experienced a decline, with concerns over greenwashing and the lack of clear targets and performance indicators. The EU's EGBS is expected to enhance market efficiency and promote further growth in the green bond market.

site_title: Miles reward cards are a lot of trouble, but they may be worth it if you don’t mind the math
summary: Miles reward cards offer higher rewards and richer benefits, but come with caps on earnings and complex terms. Despite not having minimum-spend requirements, cardholders must navigate conversion ratios, expiry dates, and category spending to maximize rewards. For those willing to dive into the math, miles cards can be a lucrative option.

site_title: A year after Boeing’s blowout, quality remains work in progress
summary: A year after a near-catastrophic fuselage blowout, Boeing's efforts to improve manufacturing quality are still in the early stages, according to outgoing FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker. A production cap instituted by the FAA remains in place, and it will take time before Boeing can hope to be relieved from it. Whitaker emphasizes the need for a fundamental cultural shift at Boeing, prioritizing safety and quality above profits, to ensure long-term success.

site_title: UK business confidence sinks to lowest since Liz Truss mini-budget: survey
summary: UK business confidence has reached its lowest level since former Prime Minister Liz Truss's mini-budget in 2022, according to a survey by the British Chambers of Commerce. Only 49% of firms expect turnover to increase in the coming year, down from 56% before the budget. The survey found that 63% of firms are worried about tax, with many planning to pass on higher taxes and a jump in the minimum wage to consumers. Business conditions are described as "weak" with investment slowing down more than accelerating.

images.alt_text: The caution of consumers – who make up about two-thirds of the economy – comes despite growing real incomes and easing borrowing costs.
CEBR expects Britain to narrow the gap with the poorer-performing German economy over the next 15 years.
Britain’s economy contracted in September and October as employers worried about the new government’s first budget which was announced on Oct 30.

site_title: 17Live aims to be the ‘izakaya’ of live-streaming services
summary: 17Live, a live-streaming service, aims to replicate the experience of an izakaya, a Japanese restaurant where chefs host dinner for small groups. The company, which has no significant presence in Singapore, has seen a decline in viewership and revenue due to streamers leaving for larger platforms. To retain streamers, 17Live is changing its policies to allow them to stream on multiple platforms. The company is also introducing events and contests to encourage fan support and is expanding its virtual-influencer business, which has seen significant growth. Despite a net loss in 2023, 17Live has turned a profit in the past six months.

It would be the first merger by a Singapore’s special purpose acquisition company.

site_title: Thailand moves to seize tycoon’s assets in 12 billion baht scam
summary: Thailand's authorities have begun seizing assets of 86-year-old tycoon Boon Vanasin, founder of Thonburi Healthcare Group, who is wanted for allegedly scamming investors out of 12 billion baht (S$478 million) through fake medical projects. Boon fled Thailand in September and his associates are at large, with 13 suspects already taken into custody. The Department of Special Investigation is probing charges of fraud and money laundering, and investigators have leads on Boon's whereabouts, with plans to file charges by the end of the month.

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission said HSBC Australia’s failings were widespread and systemic.

Property developer Truong My Lan was found guilty in April of swindling cash from the Saigon Commercial Bank - which prosecutors said she controlled - in one of the biggest corruption cases in history, and sentenced to death.

site_title: S Korea’s Yoon ignored Cabinet opposition to martial law: prosecutors
summary: South Korea's suspended President Yoon Suk-yeol ignored Cabinet opposition to declare martial law, according to a prosecutors' report. Key Cabinet ministers expressed concerns about the economic and diplomatic fallout, but Yoon pushed forward with the plan, citing the opposition's threat to the country's stability. Despite objections, Yoon has holed up in his residence, surrounded by hundreds of security officers, and faces arrest, prison, or the death penalty. The Constitutional Court will start Yoon's impeachment trial on January 14.

images.alt_text: If the warrant is carried out, Yoon would become the first sitting South Korean president to be arrested.

site_title: Italy plans US$1.6 billion SpaceX telecom security services deal
summary: Italy is in advanced talks with SpaceX to secure a $1.6 billion deal for a five-year contract to provide secure telecommunications services for the Italian government and military. The project, which has been approved by Italy's Intelligence Services and Defense Ministry, aims to supply top-level encryption for telephone and internet services and provide direct-to-cell satellite services in emergencies. The deal, valued at 1.5 billion euros, is the largest of its kind in Europe and will provide broadband services to over 100 countries and territories.

site_title: Oil extends rally as bullish momentum overpowers China woes
summary: Oil prices extended their rally, reaching the highest in over two months, driven by shrinking US crude stockpiles and a risk-on tone in broader markets. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) climbed to nearly $74 a barrel, surpassing mid-October's closing price. However, the outlook for 2025 remains uncertain due to expectations of oversupply, possible Opec+ production revival, and China's lacklustre demand. The return of Donald Trump to the White House adds unpredictability to global markets.

images.alt_text: Oil heads for weekly gains on colder weather, Chinese policy support

site_title:
US dollar on track for 
best week in a month
summary: The US dollar is on track for its best weekly performance in a month due to a solid labor market and high inflation, which have lifted Treasury yields and boosted demand for the currency. The solid labor market and stubbornly high inflation are expected to continue to outperform peers globally this year, with the US economy potentially staying ahead. New policies under the incoming Donald Trump administration, including business deregulation and tariffs, are also expected to boost growth and add to price pressures.

images.alt_text: The euro fell to as low as US$1.0314, its lowest since November 2022, down around 0.3 per cent on the day.

site_title: Breeding success: London Zoo counts its animals one by one
summary: London Zoo has begun its annual animal count, coaxing over 10,000 animals from their enclosures for a week-long tally. The zoo has seen successful breeding successes, including 11 penguin chicks, three Asiatic lion cubs, and two baby gorillas born in 2024. The count also includes the rescue of 53 Darwin's frogs and the breeding of Socorro doves now extinct in the wild. The results will be shared with other zoos worldwide to help manage global conservation breeding programs for endangered animals.

site_title: Arrest deadline for impeached South Korean president enters final day
summary: South Korean investigators are racing against time to arrest impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol, whose 7-day arrest warrant expires on Monday. Yoon, who has refused to emerge for questioning over his martial law decree, is being held in his residence surrounded by loyal security forces. If the warrant expires, investigators will have to apply for another one, which could lead to a court-ordered detention. The US Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in Seoul on Monday for talks with government officials, amid a tense standoff between Yoon's supporters and investigators.

images.alt_text: An effigy of impeached South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol is seen behind bars during a rally against Yoon near his residence in Seoul on January 5, 2025. Thousands of South Korean protesters braved a snowstorm January 5 over suspended President Yoon Suk Yeol who was still resisting arrest over a failed martial law bid less than 48 hours before the warrant expires. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: China's central bank vows 'moderately loose' monetary policy
summary: China's central bank has vowed to implement a "moderately loose" monetary policy to boost domestic demand and spur economic growth. The plan includes cutting interest rates and easing homebuying restrictions, but economists warn that more direct stimulus may still be needed. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) aims to create a good monetary environment for sustained economic recovery, while also addressing financial risks and corruption in the finance industry. The move comes after President Xi Jinping called for more proactive macroeconomic policies, amid a slowdown in China's economy last year.

images.alt_text: A RRR cut – which is typically used only sparingly – could add more pressure to the Chinese currency because it sends a strong signal of monetary easing.

site_title: US plans US$8 billion arms sale to Israel, Axios reports
summary: The US has informed Congress of a proposed $8 billion arms sale to Israel, including munitions for fighter jets and attack helicopters. The package includes artillery shells, air-to-air missiles, small-diameter bombs, and warheads to defend against threats such as drones. The sale needs approval from House and Senate committees. The US official stated that President Biden has made clear Israel's right to defend its citizens, consistent with international law. The sale comes as diplomatic efforts to end the 15-month-old Israeli war in Gaza have failed.

site_title: iPhone maker Hon Hai Q4 sales beat expectations on strong AI demand
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, also known as Foxconn, reported strong Q4 sales growth, beating analyst expectations with a 15% revenue increase to NT$2.13 trillion, exceeding a 13% rise forecast. December sales rose 42% to NT$654.83 billion. The company attributes the growth to AI infrastructure demand, particularly from US tech firms. Hon Hai expects significant Q1 sales growth and aims to match AI server sales with iPhone sales in 2025, diversifying its business away from Apple.

images.alt_text: Nvidia minted multiple billionaires as directors, not co-founders, after its stock surged 171% in 2024, driven by soaring demand for artificial intelligence chips, ranking second on the S&P 500 Index.

site_title: South Korea in political crisis after president resists arrest
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol resisted arrest on Friday after a warrant was issued for his arrest over a failed martial law decree. The arrest attempt was thwarted by Yoon's presidential guards and military troops, who shielded him from investigators. If the warrant is carried out, Yoon would become the first sitting South Korean president to be arrested. He faces criminal charges of insurrection and could be sentenced to prison or the death penalty. The Constitutional Court has scheduled an impeachment trial for January 14, and experts say investigators may wait for greater legal justification before attempting to arrest him again.

images.alt_text: Economists see weak private spending, a cooling export rally and deteriorating consumer confidence as factors driving the BOK to accelerate its easing next year.

site_title: Crypto’s unholy choir
summary: Crypto enthusiasts claim it will revolutionize finance and replace fiat currencies, but the reality is that crypto remains a solution in search of a problem. Despite its 16-year existence, Bitcoin cannot be used for everyday transactions, and the industry lacks regulation. Boosters tout predictions that crypto will be like digital gold or make payments cheaper, but these claims are largely unfounded. Instead, crypto has become closely tied to governments, with many of its largest users being tax dodgers, money launderers, and dictators. The industry's lack of transparency and dubious associations have led to accusations of deception and demagoguery.

images.alt_text: The crypto universe does not provide a desirable alternative monetary system. But technology can and should do so.
If crypto is the future, why has Bitcoin (introduced back in 2009!) yet to find any significant world-world uses?
Crypto is but a get-rich-quick lie, wrapped in hype, bobbing on an ocean of libertarian technobabble -- that's the grim reality.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends sharply higher with assist from tech; investors eye Trump policies
summary: US stocks rebounded on Friday, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq closing higher, driven by gains in tech companies like Tesla and Nvidia. Despite modest weekly declines, the S&P 500 logged its third weekly loss in four, while the Nasdaq led the way with a 1.77% gain. The market is awaiting the incoming Trump administration's policies, which could impact inflation and corporate profits, but also bring potential rate cuts and looser regulations.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.4 per cent lower at 42,392.27 on the first day on trading of the year.

site_title: Mortgage brokers made rate hikes more painful: Bank of England
summary: The Bank of England research found that mortgage brokers encouraged households to take out short-term fixed mortgages, leading to higher repayments when interest rates rose. Between 2013 and 2020, mortgages sold by intermediaries, such as brokers, increased from 57% to 81% for first-time buyers, and the use of short-term fixed mortgages rose in tandem. This practice may have increased the impact of rising interest rates on households, particularly in the UK, where mortgage rates typically remain fixed for only two or five years.

images.alt_text: The drop in asking prices - which followed a 1.4 per cent fall in November - was in line with the historic average decline for the end of the year, the company said.

site_title: Europe: stocks see off holiday-shortened week lower
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.5% lower on Friday, January 3, amid concerns over China's economy and a looming trade war with the US. Luxury firms and spirits makers led losses, while miners, luxury stocks, and automakers were also under pressure. The French bourse fell 1.5%, its biggest single-day decline in over seven weeks. Economists at Goldman Sachs recommended caution on companies exposed to tariffs, citing a valuation gap with US markets.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.4 per cent lower at 42,392.27 on the first day on trading of the year.

site_title: Nine cars to watch for in 2025
summary: The 2025 car lineup promises to be bold and innovative, with a focus on electrification and efficiency. Key models to watch include the Bentley GT Mulliner, available on special order with a six-month wait, and the BMW i4, which boasts all-seam well design. Other notable cars include the Kia Carnival and Sorento, the MG ZS Hybrid+, and the Lamborghini Revuelto. site_title: Volatile commodity prices portend a challenging 2025
summary: Volatile commodity prices are expected to pose a challenge in 2025 due to slowing growth and geopolitical risks. Oil and copper prices are likely to be weighed down by China's economic slowdown and higher trade tariffs, with Brent crude oil potentially falling below $70 per barrel and copper prices sliding to $7,500 per tonne. However, gold is expected to continue its strong rally in 2025, driven by safe haven demand and uncertainty surrounding the US economy. The European Central Bank's rate cuts and the US's large oil production capacity are also contributing to the volatility in commodity prices.

site_title: Pioneer of sustainability: Carter’s dream and Singapore’s green leadership

site_title: Issue 130: Waiting on transition credits; US banks leave net-zero alliance
summary: Transition credits, a form of carbon credit for reduced emissions from hard-to-abate activities, are still in development due to complex challenges. Methodologies for transition credits have not been finalized, with issues such as additionality and leakage hindering progress. As a result, investors may need to wait several years for transition credits to appear. Meanwhile, US banks have retreated from the Net Zero Banking Alliance, but remain committed to decarbonizing their portfolios. Sustainable finance remains a growth segment in banking, with Asia and Europe poised to take on a larger role in greening the global financial sector.

site_title: S-Reits navigate a challenging 2024 with mixed returns
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) ended 2024 in the red, with a total return of minus 6.1% and a price-to-book ratio of 0.84 times, a 16% discount from its longer-term average. The sector's performance was influenced by the US Federal Reserve's rate cuts, which reduced the Fed funds rate to 4.25-4.5% by the end of 2024. Despite this, specialized S-Reits, such as healthcare and retail S-Reits, achieved the highest total returns, while industrial, diversified, and hospitality S-Reits underperformed.

The company is hiring for Asia-Pacific (Apac) operations, with job listings on recruitment portal JobsDB. A director of financial operations at SpaceX stated she is "building accounting and tax teams from the ground up." The move is seen as a significant expansion for SpaceX, which is valued at about $350 billion.

summary: CSE Global, a technology solutions provider, has entered a purchase and sale agreement with Gladstone Commercial to dispose of an industrial property in North Houston, Texas, for US$29.3 million. The property, currently leased to CSE W-Industries, a subsidiary of CSE Global, will continue to be used as a manufacturing plant after disposal.

Thailand's home advantage is expected to decide the tie, with the Golden Star Warriors seeking a record-extending eighth title.

site_title: Biden’s decision on US Steel deal followed divide in his orbit
summary: US President Joe Biden vetoed the sale of US Steel to Japan's Nippon Steel on national security grounds, following a divided decision within his administration. The deal, valued at $14.1 billion, faced opposition from the US Steelworkers Union and was seen as a potential threat to US critical supply chains. Despite offers of sweeteners, including $1.4 billion in capital expenditures, Biden ultimately blocked the deal, citing "credible evidence" of national security risks. The decision was influenced by factions within the White House, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan, who pitched alternative options that ultimately failed to sway the president.

site_title: Stock bears are going extinct. Time to worry?
summary: Strategists are predicting a 12% upside for the S&P 500 index in 2025, with a median target of 6,600. This marks a significant shift from last year's expectations, with only two strategists predicting a decline below 6,000. The optimism is driven by the continued success of "Magnificent Seven" growth companies and the US economy's productivity-driven growth, but also raises concerns about investor saturation and concentrated portfolios. Analysts caution that a sell-off could still occur due to various risks, emphasizing the need for a balanced investment approach.

site_title: Hanoi declared world's most polluted city, authorities seek action
summary: Hanoi, Vietnam's capital, has been declared the world's most polluted city, with hazardous small particles (PM2.5) reaching 266 micrograms per cubic meter. The smog is mainly caused by heavy traffic, trash burning, and industrial activities. Authorities have called for an accelerated transition to electric vehicles (EVs) to alleviate the problem, with a target of 50% of buses and 100% of taxis to be EVs by 2030. The government aims to reduce pollution and improve air quality, with the elderly and young people particularly affected by the poor air quality.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk across a street on a cold smoggy morning in New Delhi, India, Nov 18, 2024. New Delhi and the surrounding metropolitan area, home to more than 30 million people, consistently tops world rankings for air pollution in winter.

site_title: China AI firm SenseTime cuts back on Singapore office space: sources
summary: China AI firm SenseTime is scaling back its office footprint in Singapore, giving up a 11,000 square foot space in Frasers Tower for a less central building. The move comes as the company struggles to compete in the post-ChatGPT era. SenseTime is reducing its office space in an effort to cut costs, signaling a shift in its business strategy.

images.alt_text: SenseTime, led by CEO Xu Li, was one of China’s hottest AI firms but has fallen behind rivals amid the generative AI boom. Its shares have dropped 61 per cent from their issue price three years ago.

site_title: Thai PM Paetongtarn declares millions in watches and bags among US$400 million assets
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra has declared over US$400 million in assets, including 75 luxury watches valued at almost US$5 million and 200 designer handbags worth over US$2 million. Her total investments are worth 11 billion baht (S$437.2 million), with another billion baht in deposits and cash. This declaration is required by the National Anti-Corruption Commission.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a press conference after a special cabinet meeting at the Government house in Bangkok, Thailand, September 7, 2024. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: One hundred million fans cannot make you famous
summary: Hollywood is struggling with a "star problem" as young actors like Zendaya, Paul Mescal, and Sydney Sweeney are unable to open movies solely based on their name. Even popular YouTubers like MrBeast, with over 338 million followers, are not widely recognized by average people. The inability to identify new pop culture heroes is a sign of middle age, and the atomization of fame has made it harder for stars to break through to a broader audience, even with massive online followings.

site_title: Seven billionaire founders rode India’s IPO boom in 2024
summary: Seven Indian billionaires, including solar energy and electric vehicle entrepreneurs, rode India's booming IPO market in 2024, catapulting them into the US dollar billionaires league. The market saw a record 1.66 trillion rupees raised through IPOs, with around 85 companies aiming to list on Indian stock exchanges in 2025, targeting 1.53 trillion rupees. However, experts warn of potential headwinds from a slowing economy, weak corporate profits, and volatile rupee, which could trigger a deep correction in the market.

images.alt_text: The case underlines the dark side of India’s stock market boom that has seen its equity benchmarks treble since the pandemic amid a rush of small investors dazzled by impressive returns.
A wholesale market in Bengaluru. India is one of the world's fastest-growing economies, supported by a resilient macro backdrop.

site_title: Singapore firms key to powering Indonesia’s green energy goals: envoy
summary: Singapore is set to play a key role in Indonesia's green energy goals, with seven consortiums exploring renewable-energy projects and aiming to export clean energy to Singapore. The move aligns with Indonesia's stringent local content regulations and comes as the government considers prioritizing domestic energy needs over exports. Singapore's ambassador to Indonesia, Kwok Fook Seng, emphasized the importance of energy in driving Indonesia's industrial expansion and deepening ties between the two nations.
