site_title: Surprise Q4 growth of 4.3% lifts Singapore’s full-year GDP to 4%
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 4% in 2024, surpassing the official forecast of 3.5%, with Q4 growth at 4.3%. The full-year growth is attributed to manufacturing and construction sectors, which grew 3.5% and 4.8% respectively. The services sector also contributed to the growth, with a 4.1% expansion. The government expects a 1-3% growth rate in 2025.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

"2024 too had its share of difficulties. The government did not get everything right in the first instance. But as always, we were upfront with Singaporeans when we fell short and could have done better", said PM Wong.
Higher-than-expected tax collection in FY2024 so far has put government finances in a “good position”, said Maybank economist Brian Lee.

site_title: Digital Core Reit to lose sole tenant at North Virginia property
summary: Digital Core Reit announced that the option to renew the lease for its 8217 Linton Hall data centre facility in Northern Virginia expired and was not exercised on December 31, 2024. The building, which is wholly occupied by a customer, contributed around 11% of annualized rent as of September 30, 2024. The lease expiration marks a significant loss for the company, as it loses its sole tenant at the property.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Singapore stocks start the year higher; STI up 0.2% on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks started the year with a 0.2% increase, driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 63 to 40. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 5.73 points to 3,793.33 at the opening bell on Thursday, January 2. The most actively traded counter was Hiap Seng Industries, with 10.5 million shares changing hands.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Nio's numbers for December 2024 stand at a monthly high with 31,138 vehicles delivered.

site_title: HDB resale prices continue climbing; up 2.5% in Q4 and 9.6% for 2024
summary: HDB resale prices rose 2.5% in Q4 2024, with a 9.6% increase for the full year, driven by strong demand and supply tightness. This marks the slowest growth rate since Q2 2024. Resale flat prices for 2024 also slowed down for some flat types, with median prices for four-room flats increasing 2.5% in Q4. Despite a decrease in resale transactions, market watchers expect prices to continue rising at a slower pace amid robust demand and limited supply.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
A heating up of the private housing market could see more property cooling measures being rolled out.
Construction work at a site in Clementi Close on Dec 13, for a 753-unit Build-To-Order project that has yet to be announced.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s Mubadala eclipses Saudi PIF with US$29 billion deals
summary: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment surpassed Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) with $29.2 billion in investments in 2024, more than 67% higher than the previous year and outpacing the 7% global growth in sovereign funds. This marked Mubadala's second consecutive year as the world's most active sovereign wealth fund. Middle East sovereign funds dominated the top 10 most active global dealmakers, with Abu Dhabi's sovereign funds investing over $57.6 billion last year.

images.alt_text: The ranking places Abu Dhabi ahead of Oslo, Beijing, and Singapore.
Global cumulative data-centre demand is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 11 per cent by 2032, Mubadala said.

site_title: SingPost says all contracts have clauses that cover delivery failure in dangerous situations
summary: SingPost has confirmed that all its contracts with customers include clauses to cover situations where delivery is too dangerous or expensive, and that customers are aware of these conditions. The company's former executives, Vincent Phang and Vincent Yik, were fired after allegations surfaced that they had manually changed delivery status codes to avoid penalties, a practice they denied. The company maintains that this was not a case of seeking deliveries in challenging conditions, but rather a one-off incident in non-conflict countries.

images.alt_text: The senior management staff stressed that the full facts only became known after the external forensics team’s investigations established the causative correlation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, SingPost, Digital Core Reit, Trendlines
summary: Nio delivered a record 72,689 vehicles in the fourth quarter of 2024, a 45.2% increase from the previous year. Shares closed 1.3% lower at US$4.51. Meanwhile, SingPost appointed Neo Su Yin as its group chief operating officer. Digital Core Reit's units ended flat at US$0.58 after a customer's lease renewal option expired. Trendlines Group reported a potential issue of misappropriation of funds from its Singapore subsidiary, with a police report lodged.

site_title: Bitcoin more than doubles in 2024 on spot ETF approval, Trump euphoria
summary: Bitcoin more than doubled in 2024, reaching $100,000, driven by US regulator approval for spot ETFs and optimism over easing regulatory hurdles under a potential Trump administration. The cryptocurrency's market value surged to $3.5 trillion, with Ether jumping nearly 50%. Analysts predict further gains, with some forecasting a $200,000 cycle-high in late 2025. MicroStrategy's shares nearly quintupled, and several companies are allocating cash to Bitcoin, positioning it as a potential "store of value" asset.

images.alt_text: Tokenisationisr the process of creating digital representations of real-world assets on a blockchain.
Singapore has been taking the lead in regulating fintech, aiming to take advantage of new technologies while minimising risks.

site_title: China faces first FX test of 2025 with yuan’s red line in focus
summary: China's offshore yuan fell 0.7% to 7.3695 per US dollar in December, its weakest since October 2022, amid concerns about the country's growth and escalating trade tensions with the US. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is expected to set a strong fixing to defend the currency, which has been relatively steady at the 7.3 level. The yuan's decline may pressure the PBOC to intervene, and Wall Street banks forecast a potential decline to 7.5 in the new year.

site_title: ECB hopes to hit 2% inflation target in 2025, Lagarde says
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) expects to hit its 2% inflation target in 2025, according to President Christine Lagarde. Euro-area consumer-price growth slowed in 2024, going below the ECB's target in September, but has ticked up in recent months. The ECB plans to cut interest rates four more times to June, and Lagarde highlighted the review of monetary policy strategy, digital euro, and euro-area banknote redesign. Despite fluctuations, the ECB is optimistic about meeting its target and sustaining low inflation.

site_title: Johor-Singapore SEZ poised to absorb Singapore’s  lower-skilled jobs – but that may be the point
summary: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (SEZ) is poised to shift lower-skilled jobs from Singapore to Johor, Malaysia, offering cost savings of 30-50% for industries such as manufacturing, logistics, and offshore companies. This shift aligns with the economic objectives of both nations, allowing Singapore firms to retain access to the market while reducing costs. The SEZ aims to mitigate Johor's "brain drain" and drive revenue through industrial land sales and construction activities. However, its success depends on seamless integration with Singapore's economy and efficient cross-border logistics, which may take months or years to complete.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

Mak Joon Nien, chief executive officer of Standard Chartered Bank Malaysia, said the special economic zone will drive the seamless connectivity between two countries, which will create a robust and interconnected economic corridor.
The bank has deployed a team of 25 bankers, comprising 15 in Singapore and 10 in Malaysia, to advise SMEs on entering the JS-SEZ.
PM Lawrence Wong said on Dec 3 that he was self-isolating at home after testing positive for Covid-19 for the first time.
The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.

site_title: Billionaire Li Ka-shing’s Hutchmed in US$608 million health unit stake sales
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's Hutchmed is selling a 45% stake in its health subsidiary Shanghai Hutchison Pharmaceuticals for around $608 million. The sale aims to optimize capital and debt structure, following a dip in earnings for Li's flagship firms due to trade and geopolitical tensions. Hutchmed anticipates a profit of $477 million from the transaction, which will be reinvested in core operations. The move is part of Li's strategy to pivot towards core operations and ramp up capital.

site_title: Asia has huge potential for investors and private markets: Blackstone
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, sees huge potential for growth in Asia's private market, which accounts for about one-third of the global private wealth market. Ed Huang, Asia-Pacific head of private wealth solutions, believes that private markets can add diversification to individual investor portfolios, outperforming public benchmarks over 600 basis points in the past 15 years. He recommends increasing allocation to private markets for individuals, with a target of 5-10%, and notes that institutions have a longer time frame to invest in private markets.

images.alt_text: Lee Su Shyan
Blackstone is one of the world’s largest investors in real estate, with US$336.1 billion in assets in the sector as at the end of June.

site_title: Alibaba to sell China’s Sun Art to buyout firm at big discount
summary: Alibaba agreed to sell its 70% stake in Sun Art Retail Group, a hypermarket chain in China, to private equity firm DCP Capital for up to HK$12.3 billion (S$2.2 billion), significantly less than its 2020 purchase price. The sale accelerates Alibaba's retreat from physical retail, a major investment initiative under former CEO Daniel Zhang, as the company focuses on its core online business. This is the latest move in Alibaba's efforts to sell off non-core assets and raise capital to invest in areas like artificial intelligence and the cloud.

images.alt_text: IM Motors LS6 sport-utility vehicle will go on sale in Singapore in the second half of 2025.

Alibaba, which owns a 99 per cent stake in Intime, expects to record a loss of about 9.3 billion yuan on its initial investment in Intime, it said.

site_title: Why US port workers are threatening to strike again
summary: The International Longshoremen's Association (ILA), a US union representing 47,000 cargo handlers at major Eastern US and Gulf Coast ports, is threatening to strike on January 15 over automation concerns. The union seeks stronger protections against semi-autonomous equipment, while the US Maritime Alliance (USMX) wants to maintain current automation language. A strike could lead to cargo delays and higher freight rates, potentially affecting US consumers. Economists expect minimal economic impact if the strike lasts less than a week, but prolonged disruptions could compound, affecting industrial production and consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: A container ship being loaded at the port in Lianyungang, China. The country's export price index may slump as far as 10% in some months in 2025, which would deliver a big competitive shock to companies that compete with Chinese rivals.
On Canada’s west coast, a separate labour dispute is already disrupting an estimated C$800 million of activity per day.
The government has resisted calls to interfere in collective bargaining in other disputes, other than offering mediation.

site_title: ‘Bleisure’ accommodation and more – 4 travel trends to watch in 2025
summary: The global tourism sector is approaching a full recovery to pre-pandemic levels, with tourist arrival numbers in most regions surpassing those of 2019. However, air travel demand is expected to come down from post-Covid highs. Key trends to watch in 2025 include diversified accommodation options, eco-centric experiences, and medical tourism. Travelers are prioritizing holistic travel experiences, with a focus on wellness, authenticity, and sustainability. Retail travel is expected to grow, but will face challenges in adapting to changing consumer behavior and data protection regulations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
For the year to date, visitor arrivals total 15.1 million, exceeding the lower band of the tourism agency's full-year expectation.
The biggest problem or barrier aviation faces is its supply chain.

site_title: Don’t believe the hype on these three workplace trends
summary: As the new year begins, many companies are expected to announce returns to the office despite the majority already adopting hybrid arrangements. Contrary to media hype, most companies have quietly shrunk their office footprints or continue with flexible work models. Predictions of AI adoption and DEI programs are also overstated, with many companies not implementing these changes. The reality is that companies have accepted hybrid work and are adapting to changing employee needs.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing expected to stay strong in 2025, though Trump’s trade policies cloud outlook
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector is expected to maintain robust growth in 2025, driven by the electronics sector, which accounts for nearly half of the country's total manufacturing output. Despite uncertainty surrounding US President Donald Trump's trade policies, which could impact global electronics players, Singapore's manufacturers are expected to continue growing, with some analysts predicting a 4% growth rate. However, others, such as OCBC's Selena Ling, are less optimistic, anticipating a moderation in growth to around 2.7% in 2025 due to expected tariffs under Trump's administration.

site_title: ‘Squid Game’ season 2 tops global charts despite mixed reviews
summary: Squid Game season 2 has topped global Netflix streaming charts with over 68 million views since its release on December 26, making it the most-watched TV show in 92 countries where Netflix operates. The show, produced in South Korea, also holds the record for the biggest debut ever for a Netflix original show. It is set to compete for the best TV series award at the upcoming Golden Globes.

images.alt_text: The third and final season of Squid Game is due in 2025.

site_title: Let’s go for a generous SG60 baby gift and Baby Bonus
summary: Elon Musk has sparked concern with a statement that Singapore and other countries are "going extinct" due to low birth rates. The UN estimates Singapore will reach a super-aged status in 2026, with a resident total fertility rate of 0.97 children per female, below the 2.1 threshold for a stable population. This has led Musk to express concern about the impact of low birth rates on civilization.

images.alt_text: Lee Su Shyan
Musk's comment highlights the pressing demographic and fertility problems that have plagued Singapore’s policymakers for years.

site_title: Singapore-flagged ship collides with Japan-flagged vessel in Chinese waters
summary: A Singapore-flagged ship, Yangze 22, collided with a Japan-flagged vessel, Vega Dream, in Chinese waters on December 30. No injuries were reported, and both ships are in stable condition. The Yangze 22 sustained damage to its hull, resulting in the spill of 9 tonnes of fuel oil. The incident occurred in the Changjiang River around 10 pm on December 30.

site_title: China is catching up with America in quantum technology
summary: China is rapidly advancing in quantum technology, with a focus on state-led innovation, producing only 20 quantum computers globally each year. This industry is highly sensitive due to its potential for ultra-secure communications and military applications. The Chinese government restricts exports of related technologies and little is known about its supply chain. In contrast, the US has imposed stringent restrictions on American investment in China's quantum industry, highlighting the competition between the two nations in this emerging field.

images.alt_text: Google's quantum computer chip called "Willow". The chip needs less than five minutes to perform a mathematical calculation that one of the world’s most powerful supercomputers could not complete in 10 septillion years, a length of time that exceeds the age of the known universe.

site_title: Indonesia waters down planned VAT hike in last-minute move
summary: Indonesia has lowered its planned value-added tax (VAT) hike to 12% for luxury goods and services, while maintaining the current 11% rate for other goods and services. The move comes amid public outcry and criticism that the initial plan would have dampened consumption and manufacturing activity. The government still plans to increase social aid and offer tax incentives, which could reduce revenue by 3.2 trillion rupiah. Indonesia aims to keep its fiscal deficit below 3% of GDP despite ambitious spending plans.

images.alt_text: Airlangga Hartarto, Indonesia’s coordinating minister for economic affairs, says: “The VAT rate will increase to 12 per cent as scheduled, while maintaining the principle of fairness."

site_title: Singlife launches product-agnostic shared services hub for financial advisers
summary: Singlife has launched Propel with Singlife, a product-agnostic shared services hub for financial advisers, allowing them to sell products from any provider without obligation. The platform provides integrated digital and administrative support, addressing common challenges faced by tied agents. Since its launch in September 2023, Propel with Singlife has onboarded over 230 advisers and aims to surpass 3,000 advisers and 20 financial advisory firms by 2029. Singlife expects to capture a share of business generated by Propel with Singlife and contribute to growing its overall sales, with annual growth in insurance premiums forecast at 13% over the next few years.

site_title: Chong Siew Ling is new CEO of Kingsmen Creatives
summary: Chong Siew Ling, 64, has taken over as CEO of Kingsmen Creatives, succeeding Cheng Oon Teck, who retired last December. As CEO, Chong will oversee strategic leadership, corporate governance, and operational management of the group's diverse portfolio, including retail, theme parks, museums, exhibitions, and events. Marianne Soh, daughter of co-founder Benedict Soh, has been named a director of Kingsmen Exhibits.

site_title: Malaysia yet to license most social media platforms as new rules to curb online harm kick in
summary: Malaysia has yet to license most social media platforms, despite new rules aimed at curbing online harm such as scams, bullying, and sexual crimes. Only two of eight main platforms have obtained licenses, excluding major tech giants like Meta and Google. The new rules allow for warrantless arrests and data sharing, sparking resistance from operators, civil society, and lawmakers. The regulations are intended to tackle online harm but have raised concerns about freedom of speech and data protection.

site_title: Where we’ll go in 2025
summary: For the Singaporean traveler, 2025 promises exciting adventures, from stargazing and vintage shopping to male-bonding and multi-generational travel. Design enthusiasts can look forward to the Singapore Art Week 2025, featuring over 100 events. Meanwhile, foodies can explore the new restaurant Asu, showcasing progressive Asian cuisine. The article highlights various trends and events to look out for in the coming year, including Father's Day guides, destination wellness, and tips for maximizing travel budgets.

site_title: India’s 2024 was hottest year since 1901: meteorological office
summary: India's 2024 was the hottest year on record since 1901, with temperatures 0.65 degrees Celsius above the long-term average, according to the India Meteorological Department. The year followed a global pattern of extreme weather sparked by climate change, fueling natural disasters that caused billions of dollars in damage. India's heatwave, which lasted for several months, reached temperatures of over 45 degrees Celsius, and the country is reliant on coal for power generation, with plans to achieve a net-zero emissions economy by 2070.

Current pledges and policies are insufficient to limit warming to 1.5 or even two deg C above the pre-industrial average, according to the UN.

site_title: Driver in fatal New Orleans truck ramming may not have acted alone, had ISIS flag
summary: A US Army veteran, Shamsud-Din Jabbar, 42, from Texas, plowed his truck into a crowded French Quarter in New Orleans on New Year's Day, killing at least 10 people and injuring 30. An ISIS flag was found on Jabbar's rented vehicle, prompting an investigation into possible links to terrorist organizations. Police believe Jabbar may not have acted alone and are searching for others who may have placed explosive devices in the area. Investigators found weapons and a potential explosive device in the vehicle, and two other potential explosive devices were found and rendered safe.

site_title: Vietnam prepares ground for stronger capital markets to foster higher economic growth
summary: Vietnam's stock market is expected to be upgraded to emerging-market status in 2025 by FTSE, marking a significant step in the country's development of more diverse and healthy capital markets. The upgrade aims to foster higher economic growth, with the government aiming for a 8% GDP growth in 2025 and a double-digit range during the 2026-2030 period. The upgrade follows significant progress made in 2024, including the need for more efficient capital mobilization via financial markets.

site_title: Russian gas era in Europe ends as Ukraine stops transit
summary: Russian gas exports via Ukraine's Soviet-era pipelines have halted on January 1, marking the end of Moscow's dominance over Europe's energy markets. Ukraine refused to renew a transit agreement, and alternative supplies have been arranged for EU countries such as Slovakia and Austria. Russia's gas firm Gazprom will lose around $5 billion in gas sales, while Ukraine will lose up to $1 billion a year in transit fees. The EU has prepared for the cut-off, with significant new LNG import capacities since 2022.

site_title: World’s 500 richest people surpass US$10 trillion in wealth in 2024
summary: The world's 500 richest people surpassed $10 trillion in combined wealth in 2024, driven by a strong rally in US technology stocks. Billionaires such as Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, and Jensen Huang led the gains, with Musk's fortune increasing to $442.1 billion. The tech sector's performance was fueled by the election of US President Donald Trump, which sparked a historic rally in digital assets and pushed Bitcoin above $100,000. The combined wealth of the 500 richest people is similar in size to last year's combined GDP of Germany, Japan, and Australia.

site_title: Nio delivers 221,970 vehicles in 2024 and hits record high in December
summary: Nio delivered a record 221,970 vehicles in 2024, a 38.7% increase from the previous year, with a monthly high of 31,138 vehicles in December, 72.9% higher than the year-ago period. The company's fourth-quarter deliveries were 72,689 vehicles, 45.2% higher than the previous year. Deliveries of the Nio ET9, a smart electric executive flagship model, are expected to commence in March 2025.

Nio passing its 10-year anniversary and yet to turn a profit, heading down into the mass market to ramp up sales volumes may be the most sensible way forward.

summary:

In 2024, several significant science breakthroughs were made, including China's Chang'e-6 lunar probe drilling beneath the moon's surface and sending back rock samples, a drug that prevents HIV infection, and a new AI study that showed chatbots can persuade conspiracy theorists to consider alternative views. The James Webb Telescope recalculated the universe's expansion rate, and a study on ageing found sudden molecular-scale shifts at 44 and 60 years old. Additionally, a new reconstruction of Earth's climate showed it fluctuated wildly over 485 million years, and research found plastic particles are building up in human brains.

site_title: Semiconductor companies poised for more broad-based recovery in 2025
summary: The semiconductor industry is expected to experience a more broad-based recovery in 2025, following a bumpy recovery in 2024. Singapore-listed companies such as Frencken Group and Grand Venture Technology may outperform, according to market watchers. The sector has been recovering from a chip oversupply caused by weak macroeconomic conditions and falling electronics production in 2023. Analysts expect a more stable outlook in 2025, with some players poised to outperform as the industry enters its next upcycle.

site_title:
Shaping a globally adept workforce 
is a challenge for SMEs
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) face a significant challenge in international expansion due to a shortage of managerial talent with the skills and experience to navigate unfamiliar markets. A recent survey found that 59% of respondents plan to expand overseas, but nearly three in 10 businesses cited the lack of managers to run overseas businesses as a key barrier. To overcome this, the Singapore government has launched initiatives such as the Workforce Singapore's Overseas Markets Immersion Programme, which provides salary support and living allowances for employees posted to overseas operations. This program aims to equip employees with global perspectives and skills, enabling SMEs to succeed in international markets.

images.alt_text: To qualify, companies must pay employees on overseas postings a fixed monthly salary of at least S$4,000.

site_title: China 2024 box office revenue plunges as industry downturn deepens
summary: China's 2024 box office revenue plummeted 22.6% to 42.5 billion yuan (S$7.9 billion), the lowest in at least 13 years. Domestic film revenue declined 27.3% to 33.4 billion yuan, with only 612 feature films produced last year, down from 792 in 2023. The slump is attributed to a decline in film production, increased competition from online offerings, and a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. The industry continues to struggle with the aftermath of strict Covid-19 restrictions, hindering its recovery.

images.alt_text: China’s President Xi Jinping reiterated a call to adopt more proactive macroeconomic policies to aid the economy’s continued recovery.

site_title: BYD chalks up new record as it narrows EV sales gap with Tesla
summary: BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer, achieved a new record in 2024 with 4.25 million passenger car sales, narrowing the gap with Tesla as the top-selling EV maker. BYD's December sales reached 509,440 plug-in hybrid and pure-electric vehicles, including 1.76 million battery-powered car sales. Despite trailing Tesla in annual sales, BYD's surge is seen as a contrast to the turmoil facing legacy auto giants. The company's annual revenue is expected to surpass $100 billion for the first time, driven by domestic Chinese sales and increased subsidies.

images.alt_text: The factory has become a symbol of China’s growing influence in the South American nation and an example of a closer relationship between both countries.

site_title: China’s December home sales stay flat in sign of stabilisation
summary: China's residential property sales in December remained flat on-year, marking a stabilisation in the market after a government stimulus package. The value of new-home sales from the top 100 builders stayed unchanged at 451.4 billion yuan (S$83.9 billion) compared to a 6.9% on-year drop in November. For the year, sales from the top 100 builders slumped 28.1% compared to a 16.5% drop in 2023, indicating a possible end to the country's longest housing slump.

images.alt_text: Since September, China policymakers have been encouraging homebuying by cutting mortgage rates, among other means.

site_title: Bitcoin slips in December as investors cash in on record rally
summary: Bitcoin experienced its first monthly drop since August, falling 3.2% in December as US investors cashed in on its record rally. The digital asset reached an all-time high of $108,315 in mid-December, but speculation cooled as interest-rate cut expectations from the Federal Reserve waned. Despite this, Bitcoin still gained 120% in 2024, outperforming gold and global equities. The US saw a net outflow of $1.8 billion from Bitcoin exchange-traded funds since December 19.

site_title: Dyna-Mac shareholders may have dodged a bullet as company delists
summary: Dyna-Mac, a Singapore-listed offshore oil-and-gas contractor, has delisted from the Singapore Exchange after a South Korean conglomerate Hanwha Ocean SG acquired the company for S$0.67 a share. Hanwha's offer came after it raised its stake in Dyna-Mac to 95.15% in September 2024. The company's former CEO, Lim Ah Cheng, was fired just weeks after the close of the offer, leaving Dyna-Mac's future uncertain. Hanwha had initially stated it would not take Dyna-Mac private, but the offeror reserves the right to reassess its intentions if trading in shares is suspended.

CCCS has approved Hanwha's proposed acquisition of Dyna-Mac.

site_title: More corporate gifts bought from social service agencies, charities
summary: Corporate gifts are shifting towards social responsibility, with companies purchasing items from social service agencies and non-profit organizations that support persons with intellectual disabilities. These collaborations not only support meaningful causes but also align with companies' values and enhance their brand image. The artisans behind the items receive a monthly allowance, and the agencies generate additional revenue from these partnerships. Long-term collaborations, such as those between NCS, Minds, and LHN, create opportunities for open employment and promote greater inclusivity in the community, contributing to the sustainability of social enterprise programs.

site_title: Big Lots wins approval of rescue deal after creditor backlash
summary: Big Lots, a US retailer, has secured court approval for a rescue deal worth $250 million, which will transfer 200-400 stores to Variety Wholesalers. The deal was agreed upon after a creditor backlash and an earlier sale fell through. The sale, supported by Big Lots' unsecured creditors and lenders, aims to maximize asset value and repay creditors. A liquidation would result in thousands of job losses and worse losses for creditors.

images.alt_text: Big Lots operated more than 1,300 locations and employed more than 27,000 workers.

site_title: Miami waterfront site sells for US$520 million in record land deal
summary: A waterfront site in Miami's financial district has been sold for a record-breaking $520 million, marking the largest land transaction in the Florida city. The 1.7-hectare properties, currently home to an office tower and apartment property, will be developed into ultra-luxury condos by Oak Row Equities. The sale surpasses the previous record of $363 million set in 2022 and comes as the Brickell neighborhood continues to boom with financial companies and new residents, boasting an office vacancy rate of 11.9%.

site_title: Sunnystep looks to gain foothold in South-east Asian market
summary: Sunnystep, a Singapore shoemaker, plans to expand into South-east Asia, opening its first physical store in Indonesia this month and aiming for 50 stores in the country over the next five years. The company also plans to open more stores in Malaysia, where it has already seen healthy online sales and tourist demand. Founder Mao Ting believes the business still has room to grow in Singapore, with plans for 17-18 stores, and has bigger ambitions to take the company further to markets like Japan, South Korea, and the US.

site_title: China’s December new home prices rise a touch faster: survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.37% in December, a slight increase from November, according to a private survey. The average price rose 2.7% year-on-year, as policymakers continue to support the property sector with measures such as cutting mortgage rates and minimum down-payments. This is the latest attempt to revive the sector, which crashed in 2021 due to government-led efforts to curb indebted developers. Official data on home prices will be released on January 17.

site_title: Taiwan president wants exchanges with China, sees lack of goodwill
summary: Taiwan President Lai Ching-te expressed hope for "healthy and orderly exchanges" with China, but expressed concern over the lack of goodwill from Beijing. Despite regularly offering talks, China has rebuffed Taiwan, viewing it as its own territory. Lai pointed out China's restrictions on Chinese tourists visiting or studying on Taiwan, while allowing Taiwanese to visit China. China detests Lai as a "separatist" and only Taiwan's people can decide their future, according to Lai.

Taiwan’s defence ministry expects the sales to “take effect” within a month and that the equipment will help maintain the F-16 fleet’s readiness and “build up a credible defense force”.

site_title: South Korea says will send Jeju Air crash black box to US
summary: South Korea has agreed to send the black box from the Jeju Air crash, which killed 179 people, to the US for analysis. The damaged flight data recorder is deemed unrecoverable domestically, and US National Transportation Safety Board investigators will help extract data. The investigation is also examining a bird strike and a concrete barrier at the end of the runway as possible causes. A special inspection of Boeing 737-800 models is also underway to check for mechanical failures in the landing gear. The probe aims to determine the cause of the worst aviation disaster on South Korean soil.

site_title: US Treasury is latest victim of most ‘persistent’ hacking threat
summary: The US Treasury Department has been hacked by Chinese state-sponsored hackers via a third-party provider, accessing some unclassified documents. This incident is the latest in a growing list of US government agencies and companies targeted by China, including AT&T, Verizon Communications, and the email accounts of key government officials. US officials have vowed further punitive actions against China, citing its as the "most active and persistent cyber threat to US government, private-sector, and critical infrastructure networks." China has denied the allegations, but cybersecurity experts say China's cyber capabilities have vastly improved and its focus has shifted towards more sophisticated attacks.

site_title: Two Park Nova units sold in January at near-record prices, one penthouse at S$6,593 psf
summary: Two Park Nova units sold in January 2025 at near-record prices, with one unit selling at S$6,593 psf, the second-highest psf price ever recorded in the market. The sales were made by a foreigner and a permanent resident, marking a rare uptick in luxury condominium sales in Singapore, which has been subdued since the government doubled ABSD rates for foreigners in 2023. The median price of Park Nova units remains at S$4,979 psf, and experts predict the prime non-landed market to remain soft in 2025, with prices potentially falling by 1% or inching up 2%.

site_title: Korea’s presidential aides seek to resign as turmoil continues
summary: South Korea's presidential aides are seeking to resign en masse amid turmoil surrounding President Yoon Suk-yeol's impeachment trial. Acting President Choi Sang-mok's appointment of two new judges on December 31 has raised the likelihood of a ruling to finalize Yoon's removal from power. The aides, including the chief secretary, director of national policy, and national security adviser, have expressed their intent to step down, following previous offers that were rejected by the president and prime minister. A South Korean court has also issued an arrest warrant for Yoon, who is under investigation for insurrection allegations.

images.alt_text: Anyone trying to block authorities from arresting Yoon Suk-yeol could face prosecution, say South Korean investigators.

site_title: UPS breaks with Amazon to take ‘control of own destiny’
summary: UPS is scaling back business with Amazon.com by 50% to focus on more profitable shipments. The move, led by CEO Carol Tomé, aims to take control of the company's destiny. By reducing its reliance on Amazon, UPS can concentrate on higher-paying customers and increase revenue. Tomé defended the shift, stating that Amazon is not the company's most profitable customer. The decision comes after UPS suffered its biggest one-day share drop.

site_title: Hamas to free three Israeli hostages in next ceasefire swap
summary: Hamas and Israel will conduct their next ceasefire swap on February 1, releasing three Israeli hostages, including the father of the youngest hostages, in exchange for 183 Palestinian prisoners held in Israeli jails. The hostages, Yarden Bibas, Keith Siegel, and Ofer Kalderon, were abducted during an October 2023 attack on Israel. The release is part of the fragile 42-day ceasefire's first phase, which aims to exchange 33 hostages for 1,900 Palestinians in Israeli jails.

site_title: Manmohan Singh and the making of the Indian miracle
summary: Former Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, 92, has passed away. He led India from 2004 to 2014, transforming the country from one of the world's poorest to an emerging power. Singh was known for his economic reforms and gentle leadership style, earning him recognition as a true global citizen. Before becoming PM, he held prominent roles, including governor of the Reserve Bank of India and secretary-general of the South Commission. His legacy as architect of India's transformation will be remembered.

images.alt_text: Manmohan Singh became a vocal critic of Modi’s economic policies, and more recently warned about the risks that rising communal tensions posed to India’s democracy.

site_title: High-profile designer moves show how much luxury is hurting
summary: Luxury brands are experiencing a creative downturn, with high-profile designers leaving their posts when results disappoint. This trend is reflected in the recent departures of Hedi Slimane from Celine and Kim Jones from Fendi. The luxury sector is expected to see a decline in demand this year, with prices having risen by 54% since 2019. To turn things around, brands are looking to bring in fresh talent to create revolutionary products and re-energize their brand identities. Investors should be watching Chanel under Matthieu Blazy, Gucci under Louise Trotter, and Celine under Michael Rider as they navigate this challenging period.

Demand for Christmas workers was barely higher in October than when Britain was in recession a year earlier, in a fresh sign of trouble for Europe’s second-largest economy. site_title: South Korea export growth rebounds in December, but risks loom
summary: South Korea's exports grew 6.6% in December, beating expectations, and reached a record high for the year with $683.8 billion in sales. Shipments to China, the country's largest export market, rose 6.6% to $133 billion, while exports to the US increased 5.5% to a record $11.9 billion. However, risks loom due to US trade policy changes, which may affect South Korean firms and global trade. The government plans to team up with the private sector to minimize negative impacts and maximize new opportunities.

images.alt_text: Economists see weak private spending, a cooling export rally and deteriorating consumer confidence as factors driving the BOK to accelerate its easing next year.

site_title: World greets 2025 after sweltering year of Olympics, turmoil and Trump
summary: The world welcomed 2025 after a sweltering year marked by Olympic glory, a dramatic Donald Trump return, and turmoil in the Middle East and Ukraine. 2024 is expected to be the hottest year on record, with climate-fuelled disasters causing widespread devastation. Global elections saw Vladimir Putin prevail in Russia, while a student uprising toppled Bangladesh's prime minister. Turmoil in the Middle East continued, with civilians weary of the grinding war in Gaza. In contrast, 2025 holds promise with reunions of Britpop band Oasis and K-pop group BTS, a revamped Club World Cup, and the largest gathering of humanity at the Kumbh Mela festival.

images.alt_text: 2024: A year of market volatility

site_title: South Korea investigators vow to execute Yoon arrest warrant
summary: South Korean investigators have vowed to execute an arrest warrant for impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol by January 6, despite his supporters blocking authorities. The Corruption Investigation Office issued the warrant after Yoon failed to report for questioning for the third time. Investigators warned that anyone trying to obstruct the arrest could face prosecution. Yoon's legal team has described the arrest order as "illegal and invalid" and pledged to apply for an injunction to nullify it. The situation remains volatile, with protesters and police clashing outside Yoon's residence.

images.alt_text: The current arrest warrant is viable until Jan 6, and once it is exercised, President Yoon Suk-yeol is expected to be held at the Seoul Detention Center.

site_title: Japan’s Ishiba faces crunch over Budget, meeting with Trump
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba faces a critical period as his minority government seeks to pass a record 115.5 trillion yen annual budget, amid sliding public approval ratings and a looming upper house election. Ishiba aims to secure support from smaller opposition parties to pass the budget and navigate ties with the new US administration, including a trip to meet with President Donald Trump in early February. The budget includes measures to address Japan's economic challenges, including wage hikes to keep up with inflation, and Ishiba's government is under pressure to balance competing demands from various factions within his party.

images.alt_text: Nippon Steel and US Steel said on Saturday the Biden administration delayed until June an order for the Japanese company to abandon its US$14.9 billion bid for US Steel.

site_title: Nissan plans job, output cuts at Mississippi, Tennessee plants
summary: Nissan plans to cut 9,000 jobs globally and reduce production capacity by 20% as part of a restructuring effort. The cuts impact the company's two best-selling US models. Nissan will move to a single shift at two US vehicle assembly plants starting in mid-April, and seek voluntary buyouts or early retirements. The company is also exploring a possible sale to Honda Motor, citing lower sales volumes and market needs. Nissan did not disclose the estimated cost-savings from the reductions or the number of cars expected to be produced after the cuts.

images.alt_text: The report came after Nissan and Honda last year said they would begin formal talks on the merger that could potentially create the world’s third-largest auto group.
Honda is concerned that Nissan could fall under an undesirable foreign influence should Renault’s stake be snapped up by a third party while negotiations to absorb Nissan are underway.
Before Honda’s move on Nissan, the two inked a partnership to carry out joint research in the area of platforms for next-generation software-defined vehicles.

site_title: Tofu: never judge a food by its political reputation
summary: Tofu, often maligned due to its association with leftist ideologies, is a versatile and nutritious food source. Rich in calcium, protein, and minerals, tofu has been a staple in Asian cuisine for millennia. Unlike its reputation, tofu comes in various forms, from delicate silken tofu to firm and meaty textures, offering endless culinary possibilities. A new book, "Tofu: A Culinary History," argues that tofu deserves better than its negative reputation, highlighting its adaptability and deliciousness as a protein source, particularly for carnivores looking to reduce their meat consumption.

images.alt_text: The dining room of Astrid y Gaston in Peru.
Consume a variety of protein-rich foods for muscle health.
The new 'protein' diet

site_title: Don’t let AI ‘rip off’ artists, Beatles star McCartney warns UK government
summary: Paul McCartney warned the UK government that artificial intelligence (AI) could "rip off" artists unless proper copyright protections are put in place. The Beatles musician expressed concerns that tech giants would benefit from AI models trained on popular works without compensating creators. McCartney called for a balance between allowing AI use and protecting artists' rights, stating that "the money should be the person who created it, not just some tech giant somewhere." The UK government is currently consulting on copyright law reforms to address these concerns.

site_title: Trump pushes India’s Modi on ‘fair’ trade
summary: US President Donald Trump discussed "fair" trade ties with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in a call, pressing for increased procurement of American-made security equipment and a more balanced bilateral relationship. The two leaders also discussed strengthening the "Quad" grouping with Australia and Japan. Trump's aggressive stance on trade follows his first week in office, where he has promised tariffs on Mexico, Canada, and China. Modi welcomed the call, calling Trump a "dear friend," and the White House described the conversation as "productive."

site_title: Forecasting the world in 2025
summary:
FT writers predict various global events in 2025, including:

- A 10% slump in China's export price index, which could deliver a big competitive shock to companies competing with Chinese rivals.
- US interest rates unlikely to end the year lower than now due to inflationary pressure from Trump's tax cuts and tariffs.
- Emmanuel Macron likely to survive as French president despite a weakened position.
- The Magnificent Seven tech companies (Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla) to hold strong but face caveats in capital expenditure and investor hype around AI.
- China's carbon emissions unlikely to fall, with energy demand rebounding and President Xi Jinping's economic stimulus efforts offsetting efforts to reduce emissions.
- Britain's Labour government likely to stick to its promise not to raise taxes further, but with a wobbly commitment.
- Israel unlikely to strike Iran's nuclear plants, but tempted by the opportunity.
- Bitcoin price expected to hit US$200,000 under the Trump administration's wholehearted embrace of crypto.
- India's GDP unlikely to overtake Japan's in 2025, but expected to happen in 2026.
- EVs to make up less than a quarter of global auto sales, but carmakers launching dozens of new electric cars to meet emissions and sales targets.

site_title: MAS eases monetary policy settings, lowers 2025 core inflation forecast to between 1% and 2%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased monetary policy settings, lowering its core inflation forecast for 2025 to 1-2% and reducing the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band. This move follows Singapore's core inflation moderating more quickly than expected and averaging 2.7% in 2024, within the official forecast range. MAS expects the economy's growth momentum to slow this year, with a 1-3% GDP growth forecast.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore's core inflation averaged 2.7 per cent in 2024 and is within the central bank's 2.5 to 3 per cent forecast range.

Core inflation, which excludes private transport and accommodation, eased marginally to 1.8 per cent in December, from 1.9 per cent in the previous month, data from the Department of Statistics Singapore showed on Thursday (Jan 23).

site_title: Aramco chief expects additional oil demand of 1.3 million bpd this year
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser expects oil demand to reach 106 million barrels per day this year, driven by an additional 1.3 million barrels per day, despite US sanctions on Russian crude tankers potentially impacting over 2 million barrels. Nasser considers the oil market healthy and notes that Saudi Arabia is pumping at about three quarters of its capacity to support the market. The market's health is still being assessed, but Nasser expects growth in the market.

site_title: Sri Lanka revokes power purchase deal with Adani Group
summary: Sri Lanka has revoked a power purchase agreement with the Adani Group, a move that comes amid allegations of corruption and energy ministry probes into the company's local projects. The agreement, signed by the administration of the previous president, would have purchased electricity at US$0.0826 per kilowatt from an Adani wind power complex yet to be built. The decision not to proceed with the deal was made by President Anura Kumara Dissanayake's cabinet, citing concerns over the project's environmental impact and smaller renewable projects selling electricity at lower prices.

site_title: Three sustainable staycations to consider in Singapore
summary: Singapore is witnessing a growing demand for eco-friendly alternatives in the tourism industry, with 96.4% of Singaporeans valuing sustainable travel. Three sustainable staycation options in Singapore include Tiny Away Escape @ Lazarus Island, offering secluded cabins with solar energy and organic toiletries; House of Melissa, a boutique farm stay with a permaculture farm and zero-waste ethos; and Garden Pod @ Gardens by the Bay, an eco-friendly hotel with energy-efficient systems and immersive nature walks. These retreats showcase how mindful design and operations can enhance local tourism while promoting environmental stewardship, appealing to travelers seeking a unique and sustainable experience.

site_title: TikTok owner ByteDance plans to spend US$12 billion on AI chips in 2025, FT reports
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, plans to spend $12 billion on AI chips in 2025, with $6.8 billion invested overseas for foundation model training capabilities. The company will acquire AI chips in China, with 60% of domestic orders going to Chinese suppliers, and the rest to Nvidia chips that have been watered down for US export controls. This move comes amid pressure from Washington to sell TikTok in the US, and as China's tech companies are advised to buy at least 30% of their chips from domestic suppliers.

site_title: ESR Reit posts 15.9% fall in H2 DPU to S$0.00997
summary: ESR Reit reported a 15.9% decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.00997, bringing total FY2024 DPU to S$0.02119, down 17.4% year-over-year. Distributable income fell 14.7% to S$77.8 million for the half-year period, while revenue and net property income (NPI) remained unchanged. The Reit expects improved portfolio fundamentals to translate into NPI and DPU contributions in FY2025, driven by positive rental reversions and lower interest costs.

site_title: LHN hosts 140 seniors at Chinese New Year event in the heartlands
summary: LHN, a property player, co-hosted a Chinese New Year event for 140 seniors from Touch Community Services in Yishun, promoting active ageing and socialisation. The event included singing performances, dance activities, and games, fostering connections among seniors and volunteers. This is part of LHN's ongoing partnership with Touch, which aims to address social isolation among vulnerable residents. The event aims to improve social cohesion and better support seniors' mental and physical well-being.

images.alt_text: The inductees for its 10th edition come from all sorts of fields and industries.

site_title: Microsoft relaxes data centre grip on OpenAI amid US$500 billion joint venture
summary: Microsoft has relaxed its exclusive control over OpenAI's data centers, allowing the AI company to build new capacity, primarily for research and training of models. This change comes as OpenAI announced a joint venture with Oracle and Japan's SoftBank Group to build up to $500 billion of new AI data centers in the US. Microsoft retains the exclusive right to offer OpenAI's API, which is the main way software developers and business customers buy OpenAI's services.

site_title: EU steps up probe into Musk’s X with new demands
summary: The European Commission has stepped up its investigation into X, Elon Musk's social media network, alleging potential breaches of EU rules on content moderation. The EU executive is requesting X to provide internal documentation about its recommender system by February 15, as well as any recent changes made to it. This follows a December 2023 investigation and a retention order requiring X to preserve internal documents and information regarding future changes to its recommender algorithms for the period from January 17 to the end of 2025.

site_title: ‘Dialogue will prevail’: Mexico’s president on Trump’s return
summary: Mexico's President Claudia Sheinbaum expressed confidence that relations with US President-elect Donald Trump will be "good, respectful, and marked by dialogue" upon his return to the White House. Sheinbaum, who has been at odds with Trump over issues such as immigration and trade, emphasized Mexico's sovereignty and independence, vowing not to be "subordinated" by its northern neighbor. Her popularity has surged, with 80% of Mexicans approving of her performance, according to a recent poll.

site_title: 20 months’ pay in year-end bonus for staff at Taiwan shipping giant Evergreen
summary: Taiwanese shipping giant Evergreen announced its employees will receive a year-end bonus averaging 20 months of their salary, with an additional three-month bonus. Based on an average salary of NT$60,000 (S$2,500), this translates to approximately S$50,000. Evergreen has a history of generous bonuses, with previous years offering up to 40-52 months of pay. The company's profits are expected to continue rising in 2025 due to the Red Sea crisis, which has led to supply chain disruptions and increased freight rates.

site_title: Three faces of Trump and their implications for markets
summary: Investors are grappling with the implications of Donald Trump's presidency, with three possible versions of the US leader potentially impacting markets. The "textbook" Trump, with his proposed policies, has been largely priced into the market. The "volatile" Trump could lead to higher implied volatility, while the "curveball" Trump, who is more likely to cut deals, represents potential value for investors. Trump's policies could lead to inflationary effects, higher fiscal spending, and lower taxes, which could influence the yield curve and the US dollar.

site_title: Asia: Stocks begin year on cautious note
summary: Asian stocks began 2025 on a cautious note, with Hong Kong and China shares falling amid worries about US interest rates, tariffs, and China's economy. The Dow ended 2024 up 13%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq climbed 23% and 29%, respectively. Despite this, investors remain optimistic, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. The uncertainty surrounding US-China trade relations and the Federal Reserve's split views on interest rates continue to affect markets.

images.alt_text: The local banks are trading mixed at Tuesday's open.

site_title: Your next big adventure: experts answer questions and share tips on what’s hot in 2025
summary: Experts from luxury travel operator Scott Dunn share their top recommendations for 2025, covering nature-centric adventures, unique safaris, and tropical escapes. Must-visit destinations include Iguazu Falls in South America, Northern Kenya for a diverse and intimate safari experience, and Raja Ampat in Indonesia for a marine biodiversity-rich aqua safari. Other notable recommendations include exploring Mongolia's untouched wilderness and nomadic culture, experiencing the Naadam Festival, and visiting the Maldives for an ecological twist on luxury. European destinations include Iceland for its unique landscapes and activities, and Morocco for its vibrant cities, stunning architecture, and cultural experiences.

images.alt_text: Travelling can deeply personalise and transform your perspective of the world.

site_title: At courtside, Laver has prime view of history in the making
summary: Rolex Testimonee Rod Laver, 86, is celebrating a milestone this year as it marks 65 years since he won his first Grand Slam title at the Australian Open in 1960. Laver, who frequently attends tennis tournaments, has a special connection to Melbourne Park, where the Rod Laver Arena is named in his honor, celebrating 25 years of greatness. This year's Australian Open will be significant for Laver, who has been attending the tournament for years, watching history unfold at his home Grand Slam.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

The first Grand Slam of the year, the Australian Open is under way until the championship finals take place on the weekend of Jan 25-26, at the majestic Rod Laver Arena which is celebrating a quarter-century of greatness and success.

site_title: Grab-backed Super Bank said to consider Jakarta IPO this year
summary: Jakarta-based digital banking company Super Bank Indonesia is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in Jakarta this year, potentially raising US$200 million to US$300 million. The company, backed by Grab Holdings, Singtel, and KakaoBank, may seek a valuation of US$1.5 billion to US$2 billion. This move comes as Elang Mahkota Teknologi, the conglomerate that owns Super Bank, has seen its shares lose about 8% in the past 12 months. The IPO is still in preliminary discussions and may not result in a deal.

site_title: Major housing policy moves unlikely so soon after rollout of new BTO classification, enhanced grants
summary: The Singapore government is unlikely to introduce major housing policy changes in Budget 2025, as new policies are still taking effect. The government has already implemented changes to boost affordability and reduce wait times for first-time Build-to-Order flat applicants. Observers suggest that more time is needed to evaluate the impact of these policies before considering further adjustments. However, the government may tweak existing schemes, such as raising the income ceiling for executive condominiums or providing more targeted help in the form of vouchers or subsidies for needy families.

site_title: Crypto fears ease in Asia as officials aim to keep up with Trump
summary: Asian officials ease fears about crypto adoption after US President Donald Trump's pro-crypto agenda, which has encouraged countries to catch up with the US in regulating the industry. Thailand, Malaysia, and Japan are among those signaling shifts in their treatment of cryptocurrencies, with Thailand considering permitting Bitcoin exchange-traded funds and Malaysia prioritizing blockchain and crypto for digital transformation. The Asia-Pacific region already boasts aspiring crypto hubs in Singapore and Hong Kong, which have been working to foster the industry.

site_title: Olympic push for kho kho, India’s ancient tag sport
summary: The ancient Indian tag sport of kho kho is experiencing a resurgence, with the inaugural Kho Kho World Cup featuring 23 nations in New Delhi. Organisers aim to secure the sport's inclusion in the Olympics, which has been played since 1936 but was dropped after the 1936 Olympics. The sport's popularity has grown, with the Ultimate Kho Kho League becoming the third most-watched non-cricket sports tournament in India. The World Cup's success has given the sport a strong claim to be featured in the Olympics, potentially coinciding with India's bid to host the 2036 Games.

site_title: Australian Open serves up the opening chapter in a season of captivating action
summary: The Australian Open, the first Grand Slam of the year, has begun in Melbourne, Australia, with the top players from the men's and women's tours competing for the championship. The tournament, which runs until January 25-26, marks a new beginning for the players, with ranking points reset. Rolex Testimonee Coco Gauff, a rising star in tennis, is looking to continue her red-hot form on the blue hard courts of Melbourne, where she boasts a perfect record of eight wins from eight WTA Tour finals. The tournament is expected to be a thrilling battle, with many top players vying for the top prize.

summary: US President Donald Trump's second inauguration marked a pro-business agenda with investors optimistic about trade reform, tax cuts, and loosening cryptocurrency regulation. Despite initial concerns about aggressive action on tariffs, Trump's speech fell short of immediate imposition of tariffs on key trading partners. Markets reacted positively, with stock futures up 0.3% and the dollar falling, while Bitcoin prices remained below its overnight low. The incoming administration's plans to ease regulation and tighten immigration controls may have mixed effects on markets, while efforts to boost the US oil, gas, and power industries are expected to support economic growth.

summary: US President-elect Donald Trump vowed to end "American decline" at a rally on January 19, 2025, promising to crack down on woke ideology and immigration. site_title: A new electricity supercycle is under way
summary: A new electricity supercycle is underway, driven by the decarbonization of electricity generation, rising demand for electricity, and the growth of data centers. Global investment in grid infrastructure reached nearly $400 billion in 2024, reversing a decline that began in 2017. Companies such as Schneider Electric, Hitachi, and Siemens Energy are booming, with market values tripling or quadrupling, as they cater to the increasing demand for power equipment and infrastructure. The International Energy Agency forecasts that spending will rise to $600 billion annually by 2030, driven by the need to manage renewable energy sources and enhance grid resilience.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: High voltage power lines are seen near Strasbourg February 3, 2012. Bitterly cold weather is expected to push gas and electricity consumption to new record highs in France, France's gas and electricity grids said, as subfreezing temperatures continue to hit Europe. REUTERS/Vincent Kessler (FRANCE - Tags: ENERGY ENVIRONMENT)/File Photo

site_title: Trendlines launches investigations into potential misappropriation of funds
summary: A police report has been made against an employee of Trendlines Group, suspected of misappropriating funds from the company's Singapore subsidiary. Trendlines has launched preliminary investigations and provided documents to authorities. The company expects the amount involved not to have a financial impact on its current fiscal year, but warns that this assessment may be revised. Trendlines will cooperate with authorities and take necessary actions, including appointing advisers and considering legal recourse. The investigation is ongoing, and the company will provide updates once completed.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
A staff counts Singapore dollar currency notes at a money changer booth at Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on October 6, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Pity the middle-sized nations of the world
summary: The article argues that countries with medium-sized populations, like Britain, Germany, and France, are at a disadvantage in today's global landscape. These nations are too big to be ignored, yet too small to be influential. In contrast, small countries like Finland and Singapore tend to be more efficient and effective. The author suggests that the advantages of smallness, such as being able to adapt quickly and think about foreign markets, are no longer unique to small nations. Instead, brute scale is becoming an advantage in a world where might is right. The article concludes that European integration could be a way for mid-sized nations to make their numbers count in the outside world.

images.alt_text: Shoppers walk along Oxford Street during traditional Boxing Day holiday sales, in London, UK, on Thursday, Dec. 26, 2024. UK retail sales grew more slowly than expected in November suggesting Christmas shoppers might not boost the economy in the crucial final months of the year. Photographer: Carlos Jasso/Bloomberg

site_title: PM Wong in Malaysia for retreat with Anwar, Johor-Singapore SEZ deal signing
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will host Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong for a two-day retreat in Putrajaya, where they are expected to sign an agreement to formalize the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ). The trip, postponed in December due to PM Wong's Covid-19 infection, aims to enhance bilateral cooperation and deliver tangible benefits to Singaporeans and Malaysians. The JS-SEZ deal seeks to bring mutual benefits to businesses and people from both sides, including enhanced trade and investment.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim at Seri Perdana in Putrajaya, Malaysia, on June 12, 2024. PM Wong, who was on his first overseas trip since he was sworn in as prime minister in May, said his priority during the visit to Kuala Lumpur was to forge a good relationship with Datuk Seri Anwar.

site_title: South Korean presidential guards prevent arrest of impeached Yoon after tense stand-off
summary: South Korean presidential guards and military troops prevented authorities from arresting impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol on Friday, a six-hour stand-off at his official residence in Seoul. The Corruption Investigation Office for High-ranking Officials (CIO) had issued an arrest warrant for Yoon over his martial law bid, but the PSS and troops blocked the CIO officers and police. The CIO called off the effort due to concerns over personnel safety, and the police have designated the PSS chief and deputy as suspects in a criminal case. Yoon's arrest warrant remains viable until January 6.

images.alt_text: Vehicles believed to be of investigators from the Corruption Investigation Office for High-ranking Officials arrive at the impeached South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol's official residence as Yoon faces potential arrest after a court-approved warrant, in Seoul, South Korea, January 3, 2025. site_title: US: Stocks mixed as Nvidia soars to new heights
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.2% to a new high, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.1%. Chip designer Nvidia soared 3.4% to a record close, valuing the company at over $3.6 trillion, following strong results from Taiwan-based Foxconn. The S&P 500 Index rose 0.6% to a fresh record. Other stocks, including Fubo and Disney, also saw significant gains.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. US stocks powered higher on the back of optimism over the technology giants, signaling that Wall Street is set to rebound from the four-day slump that marked the end of 2024. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as Trump revives tariff fears on taking office
summary: Asian markets experienced significant fluctuations on Tuesday following US President Donald Trump's comments on imposing tariffs on Canada and Mexico, with potential delays on China. Stocks in Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington, and Taipei fell, while Tokyo rose slightly. The Mexican peso and Canadian dollar declined, with the latter hitting its weakest point since 2020. Trump's comments, along with executive orders, indicated a hardline approach to global diplomacy and trade, including potential withdrawal from the Paris climate accord and the World Health Organization.

images.alt_text: An employee of the foreign exchange trading company Gaitame.com works near a screen broadcasting U.S. President Donald Trump's inauguration speech while another screen displays Japan's Nikkei share average and the current Japanese Yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar, at their dealing room in Tokyo, Japan January 21, 2025.  REUTERS/Issei Kato
